en: Chapter 1
vi: Chapter 1
tr: First Chapter
es: I

en: mr Jones, of the Manor Farm, had locked the hen-houses for the night, but was too drunk to remember to shut the pop-holes.
vi: Phạm Minh Ngọc translated from the original English version, with reference to the Russian version by Лара Беспалова -2001г. Mr. Jones, the owner of the Manor Farm, closed the chicken coop, but because he was too drunk, he forgot to close the pigsty.
tr: Mr. Jones, the owner of Manor Farm, had closed the henhouse door as he did every night, but because he was very drunk, he had forgotten to close the holes through which the chickens went in and out.
es: Mr. Jones, owner of Manor Farm, closed the henhouses for the night, but he was too drunk to remember that he had left the windows open.

en: With the ring of light from his lantern dancing from side to side, he lurched across the yard, kicked off his boots at the back door, drew himself a last glass of beer from the barrel in the scullery, and made his way up to bed, where ms Jones was already snoring.
vi: With a hurricane lamp in hand, swaying, sometimes to the right, sometimes to the left, he staggered across the yard, kicked off his boots at the back door, and stepped into the kitchen to finish the last mug of beer of the day before climbing into bed, where his wife, Mrs. Jones, was already snoring.
tr: As he stumbled and staggered across the yard, the light from the lantern in his hand was swaying this way and that. At the back door, he took off his boots and threw them aside, filled one last glass of beer from the barrel in the pantry and drank it in one gulp, then went upstairs to his bedroom. Mrs. Jones was snoring loudly.
es: With the light of the lantern dancing from side to side, he crossed the yard, took off his boots at the back door, poured himself a final glass of beer from the barrel in the kitchen, and went straight to bed, where Mrs. Jones was already snoring.

en: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out there was a stirring and a fluttering all through the farm buildings.
vi: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out, rustling and whispering sounds suddenly arose here and there.
tr: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out, a commotion and a rush began in all the buildings of the farm.
es: As soon as the light went out in the bedroom, the commotion began throughout the farm.

en: Word had gone round during the day that old Major, the prize Middle White boar, had had a strange dream on the previous night and wished to communicate it to the other animals.
vi: That day, there was a rumor that the Leader, a white boar who had once won a medal at an exhibition, had a strange dream the night before and wanted to share it with all the animals.
tr: It had been announced during the day: Old Major, the boar who had once won a prize, wanted to tell all the animals about a strange dream he had the night before.
es: During the day, word had spread that Old Major, the prize boar, had had a strange dream the previous night and wanted to share it with the other animals.

en: It had been agreed that they should all meet in the big barn as soon as mr Jones was safely out of the way.
vi: They agreed that as soon as Mr. Jones went to sleep, they would gather in the big barn.
tr: As soon as Mr. Jones was out of the way, it was decided that everyone would gather in the big barn.
es: They had agreed to all meet in the main barn once Mr. Jones retired.

en: Old Major (so he was always called, though the name under which he had been exhibited was Willingdon Beauty) was so highly regarded on the farm that everyone was quite ready to lose an hour’s sleep in order to hear what he had to say.
vi: All the animals on the farm respected the Leader (they called him that, although at the exhibition he was known as Willingdon Handsome) and were willing to sacrifice their sleep to hear him speak.
tr: Old Major (he had entered the competition under the name Willingdon Beauty, but everyone called him Old Major) was so highly respected on the farm that everyone was willing to lose sleep to hear what he had to say.
es: Old Major (that was always his name, although he had been exhibited under the name Willingdon Beauty) was so highly regarded on the farm that everyone was willing to lose an hour of sleep to hear what he had to say.

en: At one end of the big barn, on a sort of raised platform, Major was already ensconced on his bed of straw, under a lantern which hung from a beam.
vi: The Leader sat on a straw-cushioned platform at the far end of the barn, under the light of a hurricane lamp hanging from the rafters.
tr: The leader had already settled on a straw mattress laid on a platform illuminated by a lantern hanging from one of the beams in the ceiling, in a corner of the large barn.
es: At one end of the main barn, on a sort of raised platform, Major was already settled comfortably in his straw bed, under a lantern hanging from a beam.

en: He was twelve years old and had lately grown rather stout, but he was still a majestic-looking pig, with a wise and benevolent appearance in spite of the fact that his tushes had never been cut.
vi: It was twelve years old, and although it had recently gained some weight, with its protruding canine teeth, it still looked dignified and benevolent.
tr: He was twelve years old, had recently put on a bit of weight; despite his long, sharp canine teeth never having been cut, he was an imposing pig who looked wise and fatherly.
es: He was twelve years old and had recently become quite fat, but he was still a majestic pig with a wise and good-natured appearance, despite his tusks never having been cut.

en: Before long the other animals began to arrive and make themselves comfortable after their different fashions.
vi: The other animals began to arrive one by one, each finding a favorable spot to sit.
tr: Soon, the other animals also began to arrive one after another and started to take their places in an orderly manner.
es: After a short while, the other animals began to arrive and settle down comfortably, each in their own way.

en: First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, and then the pigs, who settled down in the straw immediately in front of the platform.
vi: First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, followed by the pigs; they sat on the straw pile in front of the platform.
tr: First appeared three dogs named Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher; then the pigs came and settled on the straw right in front of the platform.
es: First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, and then the pigs, who settled down in the straw in front of the platform.

en: The hens perched themselves on the window-sills, the pigeons fluttered up to the rafters, the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew the cud.
vi: The hens perched on the window sills, the pigeons settled on the rafters, and the cows and sheep lay behind the pigs and began their cud-chewing.
tr: The hens perched on the window sills, the pigeons settled on the roof beams, and the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew cud.
es: The hens perched on the windowsills, the pigeons fluttered up to the rafters, the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew the cud.

en: The two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover, came in together, walking very slowly and setting down their vast hairy hoofs with great care lest there should be some small animal concealed in the straw.
vi: Two cart horses named Boxer and Clover also came in, slowly approaching the platform, carefully watching each step to avoid crushing any small animals beneath the straw.
tr: Two cart horses named Boxer and Clover entered together; they walked slowly, carefully placing their large, hairy feet on the ground, worried that there might be a small animal among the straw that they couldn't see.
es: The two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover, entered together, walking slowly and placing their large hairy hooves with great care, fearing that some small animal might be hidden in the straw.

en: Clover was a stout motherly mare approaching middle life, who had never quite got her figure back after her fourth foal.
vi: Clover, a gentle middle-aged mare, had become somewhat stout after giving birth four times.
tr: Clover was a large, motherly mare who could be considered middle-aged; she had never quite regained her former shape after giving birth to her fourth foal.
es: Clover was a sturdy mare, getting on in years and with a maternal appearance, who had not managed to regain her figure after her fourth foal.

en: Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high, and as strong as any two ordinary horses put together.
vi: Boxer, a majestic horse nearly two meters tall and as strong as two ordinary horses.
tr: Boxer, on the other hand, was a very large animal, nearly two meters tall, with the strength of two horses.
es: Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high and as strong as two ordinary horses put together.

en: A white stripe down his nose gave him a somewhat stupid appearance, and in fact he was not of first-rate intelligence, but he was universally respected for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work.
vi: Because of a white stripe down his nose, he looked somewhat stupid, and indeed he was not very intelligent, but he was respected by the other animals for his steadiness and hard work.
tr: A white stripe down his forehead to his nose made him look somewhat stupid; indeed, he was not considered the smartest animal on the farm, but he had earned everyone's respect with his solid character and astonishing work ethic.
es: A white stripe down his nose gave him a somewhat stupid appearance, and indeed he was not very intelligent, but he was respected by all for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work.

en: After the horses came Muriel, the white goat, and Benjamin, the donkey.
vi: Next came a white goat named Muriel and a donkey named Benjamin.
tr: After the horses, a white goat named Muriel and a donkey named Benjamin appeared.
es: After the horses came Muriel, the white goat, and Benjamin, the donkey.

en: Benjamin was the oldest animal on the farm, and the worst tempered.
vi: Benjamin was the oldest animal among them, but also the most ill-tempered.
tr: Benjamin was the oldest and most cantankerous animal on the farm.
es: Benjamin was the oldest and the worst-tempered animal on the farm.

en: He seldom talked, and when he did, it was usually to make some cynical remark — for instance, he would say that God had given him a tail to keep the flies off, but that he would sooner have had no tail and no flies.
vi: Benjamin spoke little, but whenever he did, it was always to make a sarcastic remark, such as once declaring that God had given him a tail to swat flies, but he would have preferred to have neither tail nor flies.
tr: It couldn't be said that honey dripped from his mouth, but he spoke little and to the point: "God gave me a tail to shoo away flies; but I wish there were no flies and no tail either."
es: He rarely spoke, and when he did, it was usually to make some cynical remark; for example, he would say that "God had given him a tail to keep the flies off, but that he would rather have had no tail and no flies."

en: Alone among the animals on the farm he never laughed.
vi: He was the only animal that never laughed.
tr: He was the only animal on the farm who never laughed.
es: He was the only animal on the farm that never laughed.

en: If asked why, he would say that he saw nothing to laugh at.
vi: If asked why, he would say: there was nothing to laugh about.
tr: To those who asked why he didn't laugh, he would reply, "What's there to laugh at?"
es: If asked why, he would say that he saw nothing to laugh at.

en: Nevertheless, without openly admitting it, he was devoted to Boxer; the two of them usually spent their Sundays together in the small paddock beyond the orchard, grazing side by side and never speaking.
vi: Despite this, and although he never spoke of it, he was very loyal to Boxer; every Sunday, the two of them would quietly graze together in the paddock behind the orchard.
tr: But despite not showing it openly, he admired Boxer; the two of them would spend their Sundays together, usually grazing side by side in silence in the meadow behind the orchard.
es: However, without openly admitting it, he was devoted to Boxer; the two of them usually spent their Sundays together in the small paddock beyond the orchard, grazing side by side without speaking.

en: The two horses had just lain down when a brood of ducklings, which had lost their mother, filed into the barn, cheeping feebly and wandering from side to side to find some place where they would not be trodden on.
vi: As soon as the two horses lay down, the orphaned ducklings rushed into the barn, chirping softly as they scurried around, hoping to find a safe spot.
tr: Just as the two horses had lain down, the orphaned ducklings, chirping loudly, entered the barn in a single file; waddling around, they were looking for a place where they wouldn't get trampled.
es: As soon as the two horses lay down, a group of ducklings that had lost their mother entered the barn, chirping weakly and wandering from side to side in search of a place where they wouldn't be in danger of being stepped on.

en: Clover made a sort of wall round them with her great foreleg, and the ducklings nestled down inside it and promptly fell asleep.
vi: Mrs. Fat used her front legs to create an enclosure for them, and the ducklings quickly nestled inside and fell asleep without realizing it.
tr: Clover built a wall around the ducklings with her large foreleg; they huddled there and immediately fell asleep.
es: Clover formed a sort of wall with her enormous front hoof, and the ducklings nestled there, falling asleep immediately.

en: At the last moment Mollie, the foolish, pretty white mare who drew mr Jones’s trap, came mincing daintily in, chewing at a lump of sugar.
vi: Just before the meeting began, Mollie, a foolish white mare who usually pulled Mr. Jones's small cart, sashayed in while chewing on a lump of sugar.
tr: At the last moment, Mollie, the white mare with long hair but short on brains, who pulled Mr. Jones's two-wheeled cart, arrived; with a lump of sugar in her mouth, she gracefully entered.
es: At the last moment, Mollie, the pretty and silly white mare that pulled Mr. Jones's cart, entered affectedly, chewing on a sugar lump.

en: She took a place near the front and began flirting her white mane, hoping to draw attention to the red ribbons it was plaited with.
vi: She immediately took a spot in front of the platform and shook her mane, hoping the others would notice the red ribbon adorning it.
tr: She chose a spot at the front; hoping to draw attention, she began to sway her white mane, braided with red ribbons, from side to side.
es: She positioned herself in front, flirting with her white mane to draw attention to the red ribbons with which it had been braided.

en: Last of all came the cat, who looked round, as usual, for the warmest place, and finally squeezed herself in between Boxer and Clover; there she purred contentedly throughout Major’s speech without listening to a word of what he was saying.
vi: Finally, there was a cat, which looked around and, as usual, sought out a warm place for itself. It squeezed in between Boxer and Mrs. Fat, purring contentedly, indifferent to whatever the Leader had to say.
tr: Finally, the cat appeared; true to its nature, it immediately began to look for the warmest spot and eventually nestled between Boxer and Clover; it purred contentedly throughout Old Major's speech –without listening to a single word he said.
es: The last to appear was the cat, who, as usual, sought the warmest place, finally settling between Boxer and Clover; there she purred contentedly during Major's speech, without hearing a single word of what he was saying.

en: All the animals were now present except Moses, the tame raven, who slept on a perch behind the back door.
vi: So all the animals in the Manor Farm were present, except for the raven Moses, who was sleeping on the fence just outside the back door.
tr: Except for the pet raven Moses, who was sleeping on the perch near the back door, all the animals had arrived.
es: All the animals were already present —except for Moses, the tame raven, who was sleeping on a perch behind the back door—.

en: When Major saw that they had all made themselves comfortable and were waiting attentively, he cleared his throat and began:
vi: When the Leader saw that everyone was settled and ready to listen, he cleared his throat and began:
tr: The leader, seeing that everyone had taken their place and was waiting in silence, cleared his throat and began to speak:
es: When Major saw that they were all settled and waiting attentively, he cleared his throat and began:

en: “Comrades, you have heard already about the strange dream that I had last night.
vi: "Comrades! As you all know, last night I had a strange dream.
tr: "Comrades, you all know that I had a strange dream last night.
es: —Comrades: you have already heard about the strange dream I had last night.

en: But I will come to the dream later.
vi: But I will talk about that later.
tr: I will come to the dream later.
es: But I will talk about that later.

en: I have something else to say first.
vi: First, I want to discuss with you some entirely different matters.
tr: I want to tell you something else first.
es: First, I have to say something else.

en: I do not think, comrades, that I shall be with you for many months longer, and before I die, I feel it my duty to pass on to you such wisdom as I have acquired.
vi: Comrades, I think that I won't be able to stay with you much longer, so I believe that before I die, I have a responsibility to share with you the experiences I have accumulated throughout my life.
tr: Comrades, I don't think I have much time left. Therefore, I consider it my duty to pass on to you the knowledge and experiences I have gained so far.
es: I do not believe, comrades, that I will be with you for many more months, and before I die, I feel it is my duty to pass on to you the wisdom I have acquired.

en: I have had a long life, I have had much time for thought as I lay alone in my stall, and I think I may say that I understand the nature of life on this earth as well as any animal now living.
vi: I have had what can be called a long life, and I have thought a lot while lying alone in the barn. I think I can say that I understand life as well as any animal in this world.
tr: I have lived a long life, and while lying alone in my stall, I had much time to think; I can say that I have understood the order of this world as much as any living animal.
es: I have lived many years, had plenty of time to meditate while I have been alone in my sty, and I believe I can say that I understand the meaning of life in this world as well as any other living animal.

en: It is about this that I wish to speak to you.
vi: That is what I want to tell you, comrades.
tr: What I want to talk to you about today is precisely this.
es: It is about this that I wish to speak to you.

en: “Now, comrades, what is the nature of this life of ours?
vi: Now, comrades, what is the true nature of our lives?
tr: "Yes comrades, what kind of life are we living?
es: "Let's see, comrades: What is the reality of this life of ours?

en: Let us face it: our lives are miserable, laborious, and short.
vi: We must look straight at the truth. Our lives are toil, misery, and short-lived.
tr: Let's not be afraid to say it openly: Our short lives pass by in poverty, struggling and toiling from morning till night.
es: Let's face it: our lives are sad, laborious, and short.

en: We are born, we are given just so much food as will keep the breath in our bodies, and those of us who are capable of it are forced to work to the last atom of our strength; and the very instant that our usefulness has come to an end we are slaughtered with hideous cruelty.
vi: We are born, we are given just enough food to keep us from starving, those who can work must work until they are exhausted, and when we can no longer work, we are slaughtered in a most brutal and savage manner.
tr: After coming into the world, they give us just enough food to survive; they make those of us who remain standing work until we drop; and when we become useless to them, they slaughter us with terrible cruelty.
es: We are born, we are given the necessary food to sustain ourselves, and those of us who are able to work are forced to do so until the last ounce of our strength; and the very moment we are no longer useful, we are killed with appalling cruelty.

en: No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness or leisure after he is a year old.
vi: No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness and joy from the moment they are one year old.
tr: In England, after reaching one year of age, no animal knows what happiness is, no animal can rest or have fun.
es: No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness or leisure after reaching one year of age.

en: No animal in England is free.
vi: No animal in England is free.
tr: In England, no animal is free.
es: There is no free animal in England.

en: The life of an animal is misery and slavery: that is the plain truth.
vi: The life of an animal is one of misery and slavery: that is the plain truth.
tr: What is our life but misery and slavery! This, in all its starkness, is the truth.
es: The life of an animal is only misery and slavery; this is the plain truth.

en: “But is this simply part of the order of nature?
vi: But is that the law of nature?
tr: "So, is this situation a law of Nature?
es: "But, does this really form part of the order of nature?"

en: Is it because this land of ours is so poor that it cannot afford a decent life to those who dwell upon it?
vi: Could it be that our country is so poor that it cannot support the animals living here?
tr: Is our country so poor that it cannot offer a decent life to those living on its land?
es: "Is it perhaps because this land of ours is so poor that it cannot provide a decent life for all its inhabitants?"

en: No, comrades, a thousand times no!
vi: No, a thousand times no, comrades.
tr: No, comrades, never!
es: "No, comrades; a thousand times no."

en: The soil of England is fertile, its climate is good, it is capable of affording food in abundance to an enormously greater number of animals than now inhabit it.
vi: Our land is fertile, the weather is favorable, and it can easily provide food for a much larger number of animals than it currently does.
tr: The lands of England are fertile; the air and water of our homeland are good; today, it can provide plenty of food for many more animals than those living in this country.
es: "The soil of England is fertile, its climate is good, it is capable of providing abundant food for a much larger number of animals than currently inhabit it."

en: This single farm of ours would support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep — and all of them living in a comfort and a dignity that are now almost beyond our imagining.
vi: Just our farm alone could support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep, and all of them could live in comfort and dignity that we cannot even imagine now.
tr: Even just our farm alone can feed a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep; not just feed, but can give them a life of comfort and dignity that we cannot even dream of today.
es: "Our farm alone can support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep; and all of them living with a comfort and dignity that at this moment is almost beyond our imagination."

en: Why then do we continue in this miserable condition?
vi: So why do we continue to live in such miserable conditions?
tr: So, why should we submit to this misery?
es: "Why, then, do we continue in this miserable condition?"

en: Because nearly the whole of the produce of our labour is stolen from us by human beings.
vi: Because almost everything we produce is taken by humans.
tr: Humans are stealing almost all of what we produce with our labor.
es: "Because human beings take away almost all the fruit of our labor."

en: There, comrades, is the answer to all our problems.
vi: That is the cause of all our problems.
tr: Here, comrades, the answer to all our problems lies here.
es: "There it is, comrades, the answer to all our problems."

en: It is summed up in a single word — Man.
vi: In short, in one word: Man.
tr: It can be summarized in a single word: Man.
es: "Everything is explained in a single word: Man."

en: Man is the only real enemy we have.
vi: Man is our enemy.
tr: Our only real enemy is Man.
es: "Man is the only real enemy we have."

en: Remove Man from the scene, and the root cause of hunger and overwork is abolished for ever.
vi: If there were no humans, we would never be hungry again, and we would no longer have to do hard labor.
tr: Remove Man, and the root cause of hunger and overwork will be abolished forever from the earth.
es: "Remove man from the scene and the root cause of our hunger and overwork will be abolished forever."

en: “Man is the only creature that consumes without producing.
vi: Humans are the only creatures that eat without working.
tr: "Man is the only creature that consumes without producing.
es: »Man is the only creature that consumes without producing.

en: He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is too weak to pull the plough, he cannot run fast enough to catch rabbits.
vi: Humans do not produce milk, do not lay eggs, cannot pull a plow, and do not run as fast as a rabbit.
tr: He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is not strong enough to pull the plow, he cannot run fast enough to catch a rabbit.
es: He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is too weak to pull the plow, and his speed does not even allow him to catch rabbits.

en: Yet he is lord of all the animals.
vi: Yet they are the masters of all of us.
tr: Yet, he is the lord of all the animals.
es: Yet he is lord and master of all the animals.

en: He sets them to work, he gives back to them the bare minimum that will prevent them from starving, and the rest he keeps for himself.
vi: They make us work, take away all the fruits of our labor, and only feed us enough to keep us from starving.
tr: He sets them to work, he gives them just enough food to keep them from starving, and the rest he keeps for himself.
es: He makes them work, gives them the bare minimum to keep them alive, and keeps the rest for himself.

en: Our labour tills the soil, our dung fertilises it, and yet there is not one of us that owns more than his bare skin.
vi: We plow the fields, fertilize them with our dung, but what do we get? Nothing but skin and bones.
tr: We plow the fields with our labor, we enrich the soil with our manure; yet none of us has anything except our bare skin.
es: Our labor tills the soil, our manure fertilizes it, and yet there is not one of us that owns more than his skin.

en: You cows that I see before me, how many thousands of gallons of milk have you given during this last year?
vi: Comrades cows sitting in front of me, how many liters of milk did you produce last year?
tr: You, cows sitting before me; how many thousands of liters of milk did you give this year?
es: You, cows, who are here, how many thousands of liters of milk have you given this last year?

en: And what has happened to that milk which should have been breeding up sturdy calves?
vi: And where did the milk that was supposed to nourish your calves go?
tr: Where did the milk that was necessary to raise sturdy calves go?
es: And what has become of that milk which should have been used to raise sturdy calves?

en: Every drop of it has gone down the throats of our enemies.
vi: Our enemy drank every last drop.
tr: Every drop of it has gone down the throats of our enemies.
es: Every last drop has gone down the throats of our enemies.

en: And you hens, how many eggs have you laid in this last year, and how many of those eggs ever hatched into chickens?
vi: And you, hens, how many eggs did you lay last year, and how many of those hatched into chicks?
tr: You, hens; how many eggs did you lay this year, how many of those eggs hatched into chicks?
es: And you, hens, how many eggs have you laid this year and how many chicks have hatched from those eggs?

en: The rest have all gone to market to bring in money for Jones and his men.
vi: Old Jones and his men took them all to the market to sell for money.
tr: Almost all of them were sold at the market, bringing money to Jones and his men.
es: All the rest has gone to the market to produce money for Jones and his people.

en: And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore, who should have been the support and pleasure of your old age?
vi: Mrs. Fat, where are your four children, your joy and support in your old age?
tr: And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore; where are those foals you would lean on and enjoy when you grow old?
es: And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore, that should have been the support and joy of your old age?

en: Each was sold at a year old — you will never see one of them again.
vi: They were sold when they were just a year old, and you will never see them again.
tr: All four were sold when they reached a year old; you will never see them again.
es: All were sold at a year old; you will never see them again.

en: In return for your four confinements and all your labour in the fields, what have you ever had except your bare rations and a stall?
vi: A starvation diet and a shed, that's all your four labors and your farm work have earned you!
tr: What did you get in return for those four foals you gave to the humans and your labor in the fields, other than a handful of feed and a cold barn?
es: As a reward for your four offspring and all your work in the fields, what have you had except for your meager rations and a stall?

en: “And even the miserable lives we lead are not allowed to reach their natural span.
vi: But even though we are in such a miserable state, we don't get to live our full lifespan.
tr: "Moreover, they don't even allow this wretched life we live to reach its natural end.
es: "They don't even allow us to reach the natural end of our miserable lives."

en: For myself I do not grumble, for I am one of the lucky ones.
vi: As for me, I have nothing to complain about, because in reality, I have been lucky.
tr: I'm considered lucky, so I'm not complaining too much.
es: "I don't complain for myself, because I have been one of the fortunate ones."

en: I am twelve years old and have had over four hundred children.
vi: This year, I am twelve years old, and I have more than four hundred children.
tr: I'm twelve years old, and I've had more than four hundred children.
es: "I am twelve years old and I have had more than four hundred offspring."

en: Such is the natural life of a pig.
vi: That's how the heavens created the pig species.
tr: Quite natural for a pig.
es: "Such is the natural fate of a pig."

en: But no animal escapes the cruel knife in the end.
vi: But in the end, no animal can escape the cruel blade.
tr: But no animal can escape that cruel knife in the end.
es: "But in the end, no animal escapes the cruel knife."

en: You young porkers who are sitting in front of me, every one of you will scream your lives out at the block within a year.
vi: All of you meat pigs sitting in front of me here, within a year, all of you will have to bid farewell to life on the slaughter table.
tr: You, young pigs sitting in front of me; within a year, you'll die squealing under the knife.
es: "You, young pigs sitting in front of me, each one of you will be squealing for your life within a year."

en: To that horror we all must come — cows, pigs, hens, sheep, everyone.
vi: All of us, cows, pigs, chickens, sheep, none of us can escape that terrible fate.
tr: Cows, pigs, chickens, sheep; this horrible end awaits all of us, all of us.
es: "We will all come to that horror: cows, pigs, chickens, sheep; all of us."

en: Even the horses and the dogs have no better fate.
vi: The fate of horses and dogs is no better.
tr: The fate of horses and dogs is not much different from ours.
es: "Not even the horses and dogs have a better fate."

en: You, Boxer, the very day that those great muscles of yours lose their power, Jones will sell you to the knacker, who will cut your throat and boil you down for the foxhounds.
vi: Comrade Warrior too, as soon as your muscles weaken, old Jones will sell you to the horse butcher, who will slit your throat and boil you down for the hunting dogs to eat.
tr: You, Boxer, as soon as those big muscles of yours lose their strength, Jones will sell you to the butcher who buys crippled and old horses. The butcher will slit your throat, boil you in a pot, and make dog food out of you.
es: "You, Boxer, the very day your great muscles lose their strength, Jones will sell you to the knacker, who will cut your throat and boil you down for the hunting dogs."

en: As for the dogs, when they grow old and toothless, Jones ties a brick round their necks and drowns them in the nearest pond.
vi: The old, toothless dogs will have a brick tied to their necks by old Jones and be thrown into the lake.
tr: As for the dogs; once they grow old and lose their teeth, Jones ties a stone around their necks and throws them into the nearest lake.
es: "As for the dogs, when they are old and toothless, Jones ties a brick around their neck and drowns them in the nearest pond."

en: “Is it not crystal clear, then, comrades, that all the evils of this life of ours spring from the tyranny of human beings?
vi: Comrades, don't you see that all the suffering in our lives is caused by humans?
tr: "So then, comrades, isn't it as clear as day that all the evils that befall us in this life stem from human tyranny?
es: Isn't it then of the utmost clarity, comrades, that all the evils of our lives stem from the tyranny of human beings?

en: Only get rid of Man, and the produce of our labour would be our own.
vi: If we eliminate humans, all the fruits of our labor will belong to us.
tr: Let's get rid of Mankind, and the fruits of our labor will be ours.
es: Eliminate Man, and the product of our labor will belong to us.

en: Almost overnight we could become rich and free.
vi: If we achieve this, in just one night we will become rich and free.
tr: Only then will we be rich and free.
es: Almost overnight, we would become rich and free.

en: What then must we do?
vi: So what must we do?
tr: So, what should we do?
es: So, what must we do?

en: Why, work night and day, body and soul, for the overthrow of the human race!
vi: Work tirelessly, day and night, using both strength and talent to overthrow the human oppressors!
tr: Day and night, with all our might, we must strive to overthrow the human race!
es: Work night and day, with body and soul, to overthrow the human race!

en: That is my message to you, comrades: Rebellion!
vi: Revolt! Comrades - that is my message.
tr: So, I tell you comrades: Rise up!
es: That is my message, comrades: Rebellion!

en: I do not know when that Rebellion will come, it might be in a week or in a hundred years, but I know, as surely as I see this straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be done.
vi: I don't know when the Revolt will happen, it could be next week, or it could be a hundred years from now, but I know for sure, as clearly as I see the straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be established.
tr: I don't know when this Uprising will happen, it could be in a week, it could be in a hundred years; but as surely as I see the straw beneath my feet, I see that justice will eventually prevail.
es: I do not know when that rebellion will come; perhaps in a week or in a hundred years; but I do know, as surely as I see this straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be done.

en: Fix your eyes on that, comrades, throughout the short remainder of your lives!
vi: Comrades, think about this for the rest of your short lives!
tr: Comrades, in this short life of yours, do not forget this!
es: Keep your eyes fixed on that, comrades, during the few years you have left to live!

en: And above all, pass on this message of mine to those who come after you, so that future generations shall carry on the struggle until it is victorious.
vi: Moreover, pass my message to future generations, so that they may continue the struggle until the final victory.
tr: And most importantly, pass on this advice to those who come after you, so that future generations may fight until victory.
es: And, above all, pass on my message to those who come after, so that future generations may continue the struggle until victory is achieved.

en: “And remember, comrades, your resolution must never falter.
vi: Comrades, be steadfast.
tr: "And comrades, your determination must never, but never waver.
es: "And remember, comrades: your will must never waver.

en: No argument must lead you astray.
vi: Do not waver.
tr: No argument should divert you from your path.
es: No argument should sway you.

en: Never listen when they tell you that Man and the animals have a common interest, that the prosperity of the one is the prosperity of the others.
vi: Do not listen to the propaganda that Man and animals have common interests, that the prosperity of one is the prosperity of the other.
tr: There may be those who say that humans and animals have a common interest, that the well-being of one is the well-being of the others. Do not listen to them.
es: Never pay attention when they tell you that Man and animals have common interests, that the prosperity of one is also that of the others.

en: It is all lies.
vi: It's all deceit.
tr: It is all lies.
es: They are lies.

en: Man serves the interests of no creature except himself.
vi: Man does not care about anyone's interests; he only cares about himself.
tr: Mankind does not consider the interests of any creature other than itself.
es: Man serves the interests of no being except his own.

en: And among us animals let there be perfect unity, perfect comradeship in the struggle.
vi: We animals must unite and have a spirit of comradeship in this struggle.
tr: In this struggle, establish complete unity among animals, ensure perfect comradeship.
es: And among us animals, let there be perfect unity, perfect comradeship in the struggle.

en: All men are enemies.
vi: All humans are enemies.
tr: All humans are enemies!
es: All men are enemies.

en: All animals are comrades.”
vi: All animals are comrades.
tr: All animals are comrades!"
es: All animals are comrades.

en: At this moment there was a tremendous uproar.
vi: At that moment, a commotion arose.
tr: At that moment, a tremendous noise erupted.
es: At that moment, a tremendous commotion occurred.

en: While Major was speaking four large rats had crept out of their holes and were sitting on their hindquarters, listening to him.
vi: It turned out that while the Leader was speaking, four sewer rats had crawled out of their hole and also came to listen.
tr: While Koca Reis was speaking, four large rats that had slipped out of their holes sat on their hind legs and began listening to him.
es: While Major was speaking, four large rats had come out of their hiding places and had sat on their haunches, listening to him.

en: The dogs had suddenly caught sight of them, and it was only by a swift dash for their holes that the rats saved their lives.
vi: The dogs saw them, and luckily the rats managed to run back into their hole, otherwise they would have lost their lives.
tr: The dogs, as soon as they saw them, launched an attack; the rats quickly escaped into their holes, barely saving their lives.
es: The dogs suddenly spotted them and only by a swift dash to their refuges did the rats manage to save their lives.

en: Major raised his trotter for silence.
vi: The Leader had to raise his paw to request silence.
tr: Reis raised his front paw and silenced everyone:
es: Major raised his paw to impose silence.

en: “Comrades,” he said, “here is a point that must be settled.
vi: "Comrades," it said, "there is a problem that needs to be addressed.
tr: "Comrades. We have a problem to solve.
es: —Comrades —he said—, there is a point here that must be clarified.

en: The wild creatures, such as rats and rabbits — are they our friends or our enemies?
vi: Wild animals like rats and rabbits, are they our friends or our enemies?
tr: Are wild animals like rats and rabbits our friends or our enemies?
es: Wild animals, like mice and rabbits, are they our friends or our enemies?

en: Let us put it to the vote.
vi: Let's put it to a vote.
tr: Let's put it to a vote.
es: Let's put it to a vote.

en: I propose this question to the meeting: Are rats comrades?”
vi: I would like to pose the question to the assembly as follows: Are rats comrades?"
tr: I ask this question: Are rats our comrades?"
es: "I pose this question to the assembly: Are the rats comrades?"

en: The vote was taken at once, and it was agreed by an overwhelming majority that rats were comrades.
vi: The vote was conducted immediately, with the majority agreeing to consider the rats as comrades.
tr: The vote was taken immediately; it was decided by a very large majority that the rats were comrades.
es: It was put to a vote immediately, and it was decided by an overwhelming majority that the rats were comrades.

en: There were only four dissentients, the three dogs and the cat, who was afterwards discovered to have voted on both sides.
vi: There were only four votes against, which came from three dogs and one cat, but it was later discovered that the cat had cast both a for and against vote.
tr: Only four votes were against, and they came from three dogs and a cat. Later, it was understood that the cat had voted both yes and no.
es: There were only four dissenters: the three dogs and the cat, who, as was later discovered, had voted on both sides.

en: Major continued:
vi: The Leader continued:
tr: The Big Chief continued his speech:
es: Major continued:

en: “I have little more to say.
vi: "I would like to add a little more.
tr: "I am not going to say anything more.
es: —I have little left to tell you.

en: I merely repeat, remember always your duty of enmity towards Man and all his ways.
vi: I just want to reiterate that your duty is to always fight against Man and everything created by him.
tr: There is only one point I want to repeat: Never forget that it is your duty to act hostile towards Man and all the misfortunes that come from him.
es: I simply insist: always remember your duty of enmity towards Man and his ways.

en: Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy.
vi: All two-legged creatures are enemies.
tr: Two-legged creatures are our enemies.
es: Anything that walks on two legs is an enemy.

en: Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend.
vi: All four-legged creatures or those with wings are friends.
tr: Four-legged creatures and winged creatures are our friends.
es: Anything that walks on four legs, or has wings, is a friend.

en: And remember also that in fighting against Man, we must not come to resemble him.
vi: Comrades, you must always remember that we must not imitate humans in our struggle against them.
tr: Also, remember that while fighting against Man, we must not end up resembling him.
es: And also remember that in the struggle against Man, we must not come to resemble him.

en: Even when you have conquered him, do not adopt his vices.
vi: Even when victorious, we must not adopt their vices.
tr: Even when you have defeated him, do not try to adopt his bad habits.
es: Even when you have defeated him, do not adopt his vices.

en: No animal must ever live in a house, or sleep in a bed, or wear clothes, or drink alcohol, or smoke tobacco, or touch money, or engage in trade.
vi: No animal must live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke, use money, or engage in trade.
tr: No animal should ever live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke, touch money, or engage in trade.
es: No animal must live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke tobacco, handle money, or engage in trade.

en: All the habits of Man are evil.
vi: All human customs are harmful.
tr: All of Man's habits are evil.
es: All the habits of Man are evil.

en: And, above all, no animal must ever tyrannise over his own kind.
vi: Most importantly, no animal must oppress another.
tr: And most importantly, no animal should ever tyrannize over its own kind.
es: And, above all things, no animal must tyrannize over his own kind.

en: Weak or strong, clever or simple, we are all brothers.
vi: Strong or weak, intelligent or ordinary, we are all brothers.
tr: The strong, the weak, the intelligent, the foolish, we are all brothers.
es: Weak or strong, clever or simple, we are all brothers.

en: No animal must ever kill any other animal.
vi: We must not kill one another.
tr: No animal should kill another animal.
es: No animal must kill another animal.

en: All animals are equal.
vi: All animals are born equal.
tr: All animals are equal.
es: All animals are equal.

en: “And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream of last night.
vi: And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream from last night.
tr: "Comrades, I can now speak about the dream I had last night.
es: "And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream from last night."

en: I cannot describe that dream to you.
vi: I cannot describe it.
tr: I cannot describe it exactly, but I can say that I saw what the world would be like after Man has vanished.
es: "I am not in a position to describe it to you."

en: It was a dream of the earth as it will be when Man has vanished.
vi: I dreamed of the Earth when humans had already disappeared.
tr: I cannot describe it exactly, but I can say that I saw what the world would be like after Man has vanished.
es: "It was a vision of how the earth will be when Man has been outlawed."

en: But it reminded me of something that I had long forgotten.
vi: This dream revived in my mind the following event:
tr: I remembered something I had long forgotten.
es: "But it brought to my memory something that I had long forgotten."

en: Many years ago, when I was a little pig, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they knew only the tune and the first three words.
vi: "A long time ago, when I was still a little pig, my mother along with other pigs used to sing a song from the old days: they only remembered the melody and the first three words.
tr: Years ago, when I was a little pig, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they only knew the tune and the first three words.
es: "Many years ago, when I was a little piglet, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they only knew the tune and the first three words."

en: I had known that tune in my infancy, but it had long since passed out of my mind.
vi: When I was young, I also knew the melody, but I had forgotten it long ago.
tr: I had learned the tune as a child, but it had long since slipped my mind.
es: "I learned that song in my childhood, but I had long since forgotten it."

en: Last night, however, it came back to me in my dream.
vi: However, last night, in a dream, I remembered everything, and more than that, I also recalled the lyrics of the song.
tr: Last night, in my dream, the tune of the song came back to me.
es: "Last night, however, it came back to me in the dream."

en: And what is more, the words of the song also came back-words, I am certain, which were sung by the animals of long ago and have been lost to memory for generations.
vi: I am certain that in the past, animals used to sing it, but later they forgot, and in recent generations, they completely lost the ability to sing.
tr: Moreover, I remembered the words of the song. I have no doubt that these were the words of a song that animals sang in ancient times, forgotten for generations.
es: "And more than that, the words of the song as well; words that, I am certain, were sung by animals of long ago and then forgotten for many generations."

en: I will sing you that song now, comrades.
vi: Now I will sing it for you comrades.
tr: Now, comrades, I will sing this song to you.
es: "I will sing that song to you now, comrades."

en: I am old and my voice is hoarse, but when I have taught you the tune, you can sing it better for yourselves.
vi: I am old, my voice is no longer clear, but when I teach you the melody, you will sing it better.
tr: I am old, my voice is hoarse, but once I teach you the tune, you can sing it much better.
es: "I am old and my voice is hoarse, but when I have taught you the tune you will be able to sing it better than I can."

en: It is called ‘Beasts of England’.”
vi: The song is called: Beasts of England."
tr: The name of the song is, 'Beasts of England.'"
es: "It is called 'Beasts of England.'"

en: Old Major cleared his throat and began to sing.
vi: The old leader cleared his throat and began to sing.
tr: Koca Reis cleared his throat and started singing.
es: The old Major cleared his throat and began to sing.

en: As he had said, his voice was hoarse, but he sang well enough, and it was a stirring tune, something between ‘Clementine’ and ‘La Cucaracha’.
vi: His voice was indeed hoarse, but he didn't sing too badly, with a melody that was a mix between "Clementine" and "La Cucuracha".
tr: His voice was indeed hoarse, but he wasn't singing badly at all. The song had a lively melody, something between Clementine and La Cucuracha.
es: Just as he had said, his voice was hoarse, but despite everything, he did quite well; it was a rhythmic tune, something halfway between "Clementine" and "La Cucaracha."

en: The words ran:
vi: The lyrics went like this:
tr: The lyrics were as follows:
es: The lyrics went like this:

en: Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland,
vi: "Animal of the United Kingdom"
tr: The animals of England and Ireland,
es: Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland!

en: Beasts of every land and clime,
vi: Animals everywhere
tr: Animals of all countries, of all climates,
es: Beasts of every land and clime!

en: Hearken to my joyful tidings
vi: Listening to new joys
tr: Listen to the most beautiful of the good news,
es: Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!

en: Of the golden future time.
vi: Of a bright tomorrow
tr: The Golden Age we dreamed of is ahead of us.
es: Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!

en: Soon or late the day is coming,
vi: Mountainous grasslands
tr: Eventually, a day will come,
es: Sooner or later the time will come

en: Tyrant Man shall be o’erthrown,
vi: Forever bright green
tr: The Tyrant Human will be overthrown,
es: in which the tyranny of Man is overthrown and the fertile pastures of England

en: And the fruitful fields of England
vi: When the people
tr: In the fertile lands of England
es: in which the tyranny of Man is overthrown and the fertile pastures of England

en: Shall be trod by beasts alone.
vi: No longer a burden on the shoulders
tr: Only animals will roam.
es: only by animals are they trampled.

en: Rings shall vanish from our noses,
vi: Branches, branches are no more
tr: The rings passed through our noses,
es: From our snouts, the rings will be banished, from our backs, the harnesses will disappear.

en: And the harness from our back,
vi: Firmness, not even firm
tr: The saddle strapped to our backs will be removed and thrown away,
es: From our snouts, the rings will be banished, from our backs, the harnesses will disappear.

en: Bit and spur shall rust forever,
vi: Beating, scolding
tr: The spur stuck in our belly will rot and rust,
es: Bits and spurs will fall prey to rust and never again will cruel whips crack.

en: Cruel whips no more shall crack.
vi: It's just a dark past
tr: The merciless whip will crack no more.
es: Bits and spurs will fall prey to rust and never again will cruel whips crack.

en: Riches more than mind can picture,
vi: I am rich, I have
tr: Riches will not fit into dreams,
es: Richer than the mind could imagine, wheat, barley, oats, hay, clover, alfalfa, and beetroot will be ours alone on the appointed day.

en: Wheat and barley, oats and hay,
vi: Orchards, rice fields
tr: Its wheat, its barley, its oats, its straw,
es: Richer than the mind could imagine, wheat, barley, oats, hay, clover, alfalfa, and beetroot will be ours alone on the appointed day.

en: Clover, beans, and mangel-wurzels
vi: Beans, cassava, corn, sweet potatoes
tr: Clover, broad beans, beetroot,
es: Richer than the mind could imagine, wheat, barley, oats, hay, clover, alfalfa, and beetroot will be ours alone on the appointed day.

en: Shall be ours upon that day.
vi: It's ours from here
tr: That day, everything will be ours.
es: The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.

en: Bright will shine the fields of England,
vi: The sun shines brightly
tr: The meadows of England are greener,
es: The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.

en: Purer shall its waters be,
vi: The water is increasingly fresh and sweet
tr: The rivers will be brighter,
es: The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.

en: Sweeter yet shall blow its breezes
vi: The cool breeze of eternity
tr: The winds will blow more sweetly,
es: The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.

en: On the day that sets us free.
vi: It is the day of future freedom
tr: When we attain our freedom.
es: The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.

en: For that day we all must labour,
vi: It is the day of future freedom
tr: Even if we die and pass away without seeing that day,
es: For that day we must all work even if we must die without seeing it.

en: Though we die before it break;
vi: It is the day of future freedom
tr: Everyone must fight for this cause,
es: For that day we must all work even if we must die without seeing it.

en: Cows and horses, geese and turkeys,
vi: Animal Farm
tr: Cows and horses, geese and turkeys hand in hand,
es: Horses and cows, geese and turkeys, all must unite and fight for freedom!

en: All must toil for freedom’s sake.
vi: Animals everywhere
tr: One must sweat for freedom.
es: Horses and cows, geese and turkeys, all must unite and fight for freedom!

en: Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland,
vi: Animals everywhere
tr: The animals of England and Ireland,
es: Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland!

en: Beasts of every land and clime,
vi: Animals everywhere
tr: Animals of all countries, all climates,
es: Beasts of every land and climate!

en: Hearken well and spread my tidings
vi: Listen to the new joy
tr: Listen to my good news, spread the word everywhere,
es: Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!

en: Of the golden future time.
vi: Of a bright tomorrow
tr: The Golden Age we dreamed of is ahead of us.
es: Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!

en: The singing of this song threw the animals into the wildest excitement.
vi: The song had made the animals extremely excited.
tr: The song had stirred a wild excitement in the hearts of the animals.
es: The rehearsal of this song put all the animals in the wildest excitement.

en: Almost before Major had reached the end, they had begun singing it for themselves.
vi: Some of them managed to join in even before the Leader finished singing.
tr: Before the Leader even reached the end, they had all begun to sing together.
es: Shortly before Major had finished, they had all started singing it.

en: Even the stupidest of them had already picked up the tune and a few of the words, and as for the clever ones, such as the pigs and dogs, they had the entire song by heart within a few minutes.
vi: Even the most ignorant ones grasped the melody and learned a few words, while the smarter ones, like the dogs and pigs, memorized the entire song within the first few minutes.
tr: Even the most foolish had picked up the tune and a few words of the song; those as intelligent as the pigs and dogs had memorized the entire song in a few minutes.
es: Even the most stupid had retained the melody and part of the lyrics, while the more intelligent ones, like the pigs and the dogs, learned the song in a few minutes.

en: And then, after a few preliminary tries, the whole farm burst out into ‘Beasts of England’ in tremendous unison.
vi: After a few practice sessions, the whole farm could sing the "Beasts of England" in unison.
tr: After a few attempts, the farm echoed with the sound of "Animals of England" sung in unison.
es: Shortly afterwards, with the help of several previous rehearsals, the entire farm broke into singing "Beasts of England" in unison.

en: The cows lowed it, the dogs whined it, the sheep bleated it, the horses whinnied it, the ducks quacked it.
vi: Each species sang in its own voice: cows bellowed, dogs barked, sheep bleated, horses neighed, and ducks quacked.
tr: The cows were mooing, the dogs were barking, the sheep were bleating, the horses were neighing, and the ducks were quacking.
es: The cows mooed it, the dogs howled it, the sheep bleated it, the horses neighed it, the ducks quacked it.

en: They were so delighted with the song that they sang it right through five times in succession, and might have continued singing it all night if they had not been interrupted.
vi: They enjoyed the song so much that they sang it five times in a row and could have kept singing it all night if they hadn't been interrupted.
tr: They enjoyed it so much that they sang the song from beginning to end five times; if Mr. Jones hadn't woken up, they might have sung it until morning.
es: They were so pleased with the song that they repeated it five times in a row and would have continued all night if they hadn't been interrupted.

en: Unfortunately, the uproar awoke mr Jones, who sprang out of bed, making sure that there was a fox in the yard.
vi: Unfortunately, the loud noise woke Mr. Jones, who got out of bed convinced that a fox had entered the yard.
tr: But unfortunately, Mr. Jones woke up from the noise; thinking a fox had entered the yard, he jumped out of bed.
es: Unfortunately, the armed commotion woke up Mr. Jones, who jumped out of bed believing there was a fox prowling around the pens.

en: He seized the gun which always stood in a corner of his bedroom, and let fly a charge of number 6 shot into the darkness.
vi: He grabbed the gun that was always kept in the corner of the room and fired a series of shots into the air.
tr: As he grabbed the rifle that always stood in the corner of his bedroom, he fired into the darkness.
es: He took the shotgun, which was permanently in a corner of the bedroom, and fired a shot into the darkness.

en: The pellets buried themselves in the wall of the barn and the meeting broke up hurriedly.
vi: Some pellets embedded themselves in the wall of the barn, and the meeting quickly came to an end.
tr: As soon as the large pellets embedded themselves in the wall of the barn, the animals at the meeting scattered like chicks.
es: The pellets embedded themselves in the barn wall and the meeting broke up hastily.

en: Everyone fled to his own sleeping-place.
vi: Each animal returned to its sleeping place.
tr: Everyone ran to where they slept.
es: Everyone fled to their sleeping places.

en: The birds jumped on to their perches, the animals settled down in the straw, and the whole farm was asleep in a moment.
vi: The poultry jumped onto their perches, while the livestock lay down on the straw, and soon the entire farm was asleep.
tr: The birds jumped to their perches, and the animals lay down on their straw beds. Soon, the entire farm fell asleep.
es: The birds jumped onto their perches, the animals lay down in the straw, and in an instant, the whole farm was asleep.

en: Chapter 2
vi: Chapter 2
tr: Second Chapter
es: II

en: Three nights later old Major died peacefully in his sleep.
vi: Three nights later, the old Leader peacefully passed away.
tr: Koca Reis died peacefully in his sleep three nights later.
es: THREE nights later, Old Major died peacefully in his sleep.

en: His body was buried at the foot of the orchard.
vi: His body was buried at the end of the garden.
tr: They buried him in a spot at the edge of the orchard.
es: His body was buried at the foot of the orchard.

en: This was early in March.
vi: That incident happened at the beginning of March.
tr: It was the early days of March when the Leader died.
es: That happened in early March.

en: During the next three months there was much secret activity.
vi: The animals intensified their underground activities continuously for the next three months.
tr: During the following three months, a lot of secret activities were carried out.
es: During the following three months, there was a great deal of secret activity.

en: Major’s speech had given to the more intelligent animals on the farm a completely new outlook on life.
vi: The Leader's speech had created an entirely new way of life for the intelligent ones.
tr: The Leader's speech had made the smarter animals on the farm look at life with a completely new perspective.
es: To the most intelligent animals on the farm, Major's speech had made them see life from a completely new perspective.

en: They did not know when the Rebellion predicted by Major would take place, they had no reason for thinking that it would be within their own lifetime, but they saw clearly that it was their duty to prepare for it.
vi: They didn't know when the Rebellion that the Leader predicted would happen, nor did they think they would witness it, but they knew one thing clearly: they had the responsibility to carry out the preparations.
tr: No one knew when the Rebellion he had predicted would occur; they also didn't know if they would live long enough to see such an uprising; but they could clearly see that their duty was to prepare for that day.
es: They did not know when the Rebellion that Major had predicted would occur; they had no reason to believe it would happen during their own lifetimes, but they clearly saw that their duty was to prepare for it.

en: The work of teaching and organising the others fell naturally upon the pigs, who were generally recognised as being the cleverest of the animals.
vi: Of course, the task of education and organization was assigned to the pigs because they were considered the most intelligent species.
tr: The task of educating and organizing the others was naturally given to the pigs, who were generally considered the smartest of the animals.
es: The work of teaching and organizing the others naturally fell upon the pigs, who were generally recognized as the most intelligent of the animals.

en: Pre-eminent among the pigs were two young boars named Snowball and Napoleon, whom mr Jones was breeding up for sale.
vi: Two young male pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, who were being fattened by Mr. Jones for sale, were the most famous.
tr: The most talented of the pigs were two young male pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones had raised for sale.
es: Prominent among them were two young pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones was raising to sell.

en: Napoleon was a large, rather fierce-looking Berkshire boar, the only Berkshire on the farm, not much of a talker, but with a reputation for getting his own way.
vi: Napoleon was a fierce-looking boar, the only Berkshire on the Manor Farm; he was known for being taciturn but reputedly patient.
tr: Napoleon was a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar; in fact, he was the only Berkshire on the farm. He wasn't much of a talker, but he was known for getting his way by force.
es: Napoleon was a large, fierce-looking boar, the only Berkshire pig on the farm; he was known for being taciturn and always getting his way.

en: Snowball was a more vivacious pig than Napoleon, quicker in speech and more inventive, but was not considered to have the same depth of character.
vi: Snowball was more lively, more articulate, and had more ideas, but most believed his character was not as deep as Napoleon's.
tr: Snowball was a more lively, more spirited pig than Napoleon; he was also more eloquent and more inventive; but it was said that his character was not as strong as Napoleon's.
es: Snowball was more lively than Napoleon, had greater ease of speech, and was more inventive, but he was considered to have a weaker character.

en: All the other male pigs on the farm were porkers.
vi: The rest were all meat pigs.
tr: All the male pigs on the farm were fattening pigs.
es: The other male pigs on the farm were very young.

en: The best known among them was a small fat pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, twinkling eyes, nimble movements, and a shrill voice.
vi: The most prominent among them was named Squealer, a small, rather fat but nimble pig with chubby cheeks, darting eyes, and a shrill voice.
tr: The most famous among them was a plump pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, constantly blinking eyes, a shrill voice, and a restless nature.
es: The best known among them was a small, fat pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, bright eyes, nimble movements, and a shrill voice.

en: He was a brilliant talker, and when he was arguing some difficult point he had a way of skipping from side to side and whisking his tail which was somehow very persuasive.
vi: He was an excellent speaker; when he needed to prove a difficult point, he would skip around and wag his tail, looking very persuasive.
tr: He was a brilliant speaker; when discussing a difficult topic, he would jump from side to side and wag his tail rapidly; for some reason, these actions made him very persuasive.
es: He was a brilliant orator, and when discussing a difficult matter, he had a way of skipping from side to side and wagging his tail that made him very persuasive.

en: The others said of Squealer that he could turn black into white.
vi: It was rumored that he could turn black into white with ease.
tr: They used to say about Squealer, "He could turn black into white."
es: It was said of Squealer that he could turn black into white.

en: These three had elaborated old Major’s teachings into a complete system of thought, to which they gave the name of Animalism.
vi: These three had developed the old Leader's doctrine into a complete philosophical system which they called Animalism.
tr: These three had developed Old Major's thoughts into a complete doctrine, which they named "Animalism."
es: These three had developed, based on the teachings of Old Major, a complete system of ideas which they named Animalism.

en: Several nights a week, after mr Jones was asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn and expounded the principles of Animalism to the others.
vi: Every night, after Mr. Jones went to bed, they would secretly gather in the barn to explain the main principles of Animalism to the other animals.
tr: Several nights a week, after Mr. Jones had gone to sleep, they held secret meetings in the barn, explaining the principles of Animalism to the other animals.
es: Several nights a week, when Mr. Jones was already asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn, during which they explained the principles of Animalism to the others.

en: At the beginning they met with much stupidity and apathy.
vi: At first, it was quite difficult because the animals were indifferent and very ignorant.
tr: At first, they encountered great stupidity and indifference.
es: At the beginning, they encountered much stupidity and apathy.

en: Some of the animals talked of the duty of loyalty to mr Jones, whom they referred to as “Master,” or made elementary remarks such as “mr Jones feeds us.
vi: Some said they had a duty of loyalty to Mr. Jones, whom they called their master, and some even naively remarked, "Mr. Jones feeds us.
tr: Some animals talked about their duty of loyalty to Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master"; others said, "Mr. Jones feeds us.
es: Some animals spoke of the duty of loyalty towards Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master," or made elementary remarks such as: "Mr. Jones feeds us"; "If he were not here, we would starve to death."

en: If he were gone, we should starve to death.”
vi: Without him, we would starve to death."
tr: If it weren't for him, we would starve to death," uttering such foolish remarks.
es: Some animals spoke of the duty of loyalty towards Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master," or made elementary remarks such as: "Mr. Jones feeds us"; "If he were not here, we would starve to death."

en: Others asked such questions as “Why should we care what happens after we are dead?” or “If this Rebellion is to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?”, and the pigs had great difficulty in making them see that this was contrary to the spirit of Animalism.
vi: Some even asked questions like, "Why should we care about what happens after we die?" or "The rebellion is going to happen anyway, whether we do anything or not." The pigs had a hard time convincing them that such arguments were completely contrary to the spirit of Animalism.
tr: Some asked questions like, "What good will it do us after we are dead?" or "If this Rebellion is going to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?" The pigs had a hard time making them understand that such talk was contrary to the spirit of Animalism.
es: Others asked questions like: "What do we care about what will happen when we are dead?" or "If the rebellion is going to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?" and the pigs had great difficulty making them see that this was contrary to the spirit of Animalism.

en: The stupidest questions of all were asked by Mollie, the white mare.
vi: But the most foolish questions came from a white mare named Mollie.
tr: The most foolish question came from the white mare Mollie; her first question to Snowball was, "Will there still be sugar after the Rebellion?"
es: The most foolish questions were asked by Mollie, the white mare.

en: The very first question she asked Snowball was: “Will there still be sugar after the Rebellion?”
vi: First, she asked Snowball:
tr: The most foolish question came from the white mare Mollie; her first question to Snowball was, "Will there still be sugar after the Rebellion?"
es: The first one she directed at Snowball was the following: —Will there be sugar after the rebellion?

en: “No,” said Snowball firmly.
vi: "So, after the uprising, is there a way?"
tr: Snowball cut in, "No," he said.
es: —No —replied Snowball firmly—.

en: “We have no means of making sugar on this farm.
vi: "No," Tuyết Tròn interrupted, "We do not produce sugar."
tr: "We cannot produce sugar on this farm.
es: We have no means to produce sugar on this farm.

en: Besides, you do not need sugar.
vi: In fact, comrade, you will not need sugar.
tr: Besides, sugar will not be necessary.
es: Besides, you don't need sugar.

en: You will have all the oats and hay you want.”
vi: You will have enough oats and straw that you need."
tr: You will be able to eat as much oats and hay as you want."
es: You will have all the oats and hay you need.

en: “And shall I still be allowed to wear ribbons in my mane?” asked Mollie.
vi: "So, can I still wear the ribbon?"
tr: This time, Mollie had asked, "Well, will I still be able to put ribbons in my mane?"
es: —And will I be allowed to keep using ribbons in my mane? —insisted Mollie.

en: “Comrade,” said Snowball, “those ribbons that you are so devoted to are the badge of slavery.
vi: "Comrade," Tuyết Tròn said, "The ribbon that you love so much is actually a symbol of the spirit of slavery."
tr: Snowball said, "Come on, comrade." "The ribbon you can't do without is a symbol of slavery.
es: —Comrade —said Snowball—, those ribbons you like so much are the symbol of slavery.

en: Can you not understand that liberty is worth more than ribbons?”
vi: "Don't you see that freedom is more precious than the ribbon?"
tr: Don't you get that freedom is worth more than ribbons?"
es: Don't you understand that freedom is worth more than those ribbons?

en: Mollie agreed, but she did not sound very convinced.
vi: Mollie agreed, but she didn't seem very trusting.
tr: Mollie didn't seem very convinced when she said "Kabul."
es: Mollie nodded, but it seemed that she was not very convinced.

en: The pigs had an even harder struggle to counteract the lies put about by Moses, the tame raven.
vi: The pigs had an even harder time refuting the arguments put forth by the raven Moses.
tr: The pigs had to fight an even tougher battle to curb the lies spread by the pet raven Moses.
es: The pigs had an even greater struggle to counteract the lies spread by Moses, the tamed raven.

en: Moses, who was mr Jones’s especial pet, was a spy and a tale-bearer, but he was also a clever talker.
vi: Moses was Mr. Jones's pet, he specialized in sneaking around but remembered many fairy tales and was also a skilled orator.
tr: Moses, who was Mr. Jones's favorite, was a tattler and a gossip, but he was a smooth talker.
es: Moses, who was Mr. Jones's favorite, was a spy and a gossip, but also a very skilled orator.

en: He claimed to know of the existence of a mysterious country called Sugarcandy Mountain, to which all animals went when they died.
vi: He claimed to know of a mythical kingdom called Sugarcandy Mountain, where the souls of animals would go after they died.
tr: He had made up another tale: supposedly, there was a mysterious country called the Land of Sugarcandy, where all animals went when they died.
es: He claimed to know of the existence of a mysterious country called Sugarcandy Mountain, to which all animals went when they died.

en: It was situated somewhere up in the sky, a little distance beyond the clouds, Moses said.
vi: Moses said that this place was not far away, just beyond the clouds.
tr: According to Moses, this country was somewhere in the sky, just beyond the clouds.
es: It was located somewhere in the sky, "just a little beyond the clouds," Moses said.

en: In Sugarcandy Mountain it was Sunday seven days a week, clover was in season all the year round, and lump sugar and linseed cake grew on the hedges.
vi: There, all seven days of the week were Sundays, the clover was green all year round, and rock candy and dry bread grew right on the hedges.
tr: In the Land of Sugarcandy, every day was Sunday; clover grew in all seasons, and trees and bushes were laden with sugar lumps and linseed cakes.
es: There it was Sunday seven times a week, clover was in season all year round, and lumps of sugar and linseed cakes grew in the hedges.

en: The animals hated Moses because he told tales and did no work, but some of them believed in Sugarcandy Mountain, and the pigs had to argue very hard to persuade them that there was no such place.
vi: The animals hated Moses because he only talked and did no work, but some of them believed in his Sugarcandy Mountain, so the pigs had to work very hard to convince them that no such place existed.
tr: Although the animals hated Moses because he spent his days telling tales and never worked, there were still some who believed in the tale of the Land of Sugarcandy. The pigs talked at length to convince them that such a place did not exist.
es: The animals hated Moses because he was a gossip and did no work, but some believed in Sugarcandy Mountain, and the pigs had to argue a lot to persuade them of the nonexistence of such a place.

en: Their most faithful disciples were the two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover.
vi: The most trusted apostles of theirs were the two cart horses, Boxer and Clover.
tr: The most loyal disciples were the two cart horses, Boxer and Clover.
es: The most loyal disciples were the draft horses Boxer and Clover.

en: These two had great difficulty in thinking anything out for themselves, but having once accepted the pigs as their teachers, they absorbed everything that they were told, and passed it on to the other animals by simple arguments.
vi: These two were originally slow to understand, but once they regarded the pigs as their masters, they absorbed every teaching and then explained it to the others in a more comprehensible language.
tr: These two horses, who had considerable difficulty thinking for themselves, had unquestioningly adopted everything the pigs said after deeming them as teachers and conveyed it exactly to the other animals.
es: Both had great difficulty in forming their own judgment, but since they accepted the pigs as teachers, they absorbed everything they were told and conveyed it to the other animals through simple arguments.

en: They were unfailing in their attendance at the secret meetings in the barn, and led the singing of ‘Beasts of England’, with which the meetings always ended.
vi: These two never missed a single meeting and were often the ones leading the singing of "Beasts of England" at the end of each meeting.
tr: They never missed the secret meetings in the barn; they led the singing of the "Beasts of England" song at the end of each meeting.
es: They never missed the secret meetings in the barn and led the singing of "Beasts of England" with which the meetings always ended.

en: Now, as it turned out, the Rebellion was achieved much earlier and more easily than anyone had expected.
vi: The Uprising happened much earlier and more easily than they had anticipated.
tr: Then, the Rebellion happened much earlier and much more easily than anyone had expected.
es: The fact was that the rebellion took place much earlier and more easily than they expected.

en: In past years mr Jones, although a hard master, had been a capable farmer, but of late he had fallen on evil days.
vi: In recent years, Mr. Jones, who had been a good and strict landlord, encountered many troubles.
tr: Although Mr. Jones was a skilled farmer, he had been treating the animals very harshly, and recently his affairs had taken a turn for the worse.
es: In previous years Mr. Jones, despite being a harsh master, had been a capable farmer, but lately he had acquired some vices.

en: He had become much disheartened after losing money in a lawsuit, and had taken to drinking more than was good for him.
vi: After losing a lot of money in lawsuits, he became gloomy and drank more than usual.
tr: Especially after losing money in a lawsuit, he had lost hope completely and had taken to drinking excessively, to the point of ruining his health.
es: He had become very discouraged after losing quite a bit of money in a lawsuit, and began to drink more than he should.

en: For whole days at a time he would lounge in his Windsor chair in the kitchen, reading the newspapers, drinking, and occasionally feeding Moses on crusts of bread soaked in beer.
vi: He often sat all day in the kitchen armchair, reading the newspaper and drinking beer, occasionally giving Moses some beer-soaked bread crumbs.
tr: Sometimes he would sit idly for days in his kitchen armchair, reading the newspaper and drinking, occasionally feeding Moses with pieces of bread soaked in beer.
es: For entire days he would remain in his kitchen chair, reading newspapers, drinking, and occasionally giving Moses crusts of bread soaked in beer.
