es: The birds did not fully understand Snowball's lengthy harangue, but they accepted his explanations, and even the most insignificant animals began to learn the new maxim by heart.

en: FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD, was inscribed on the end wall of the barn, above the Seven Commandments and in bigger letters.
vi: FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD was written larger, above the Seven Commandments.
tr: On the wall of the barn, above the Seven Commandments, it was written in even larger letters: FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD.
es: "Four legs good, two legs bad!" was inscribed on the back wall of the barn, above the seven commandments and in larger letters.

en: When they had once got it by heart, the sheep developed a great liking for this maxim, and often as they lay in the field they would all start bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad!
vi: Once they had memorized it, the sheep showed great enthusiasm for this maxim, and whenever they were resting, they would chant in unison, "Four legs good, two legs bad!
tr: After memorizing these words, the sheep loved the maxim so much that while lounging in the meadow, they would habitually bleat together, "Four legs good, two legs bad!
es: The sheep loved it, and once they had memorized it, they bleated it over and over again, even while resting on the field, and their "Four legs good, two legs bad!" could be heard for hours on end, repeated tirelessly.

en: Four legs good, two legs bad!” and keep it up for hours on end, never growing tired of it.
vi: Four legs good, two legs bad!" tirelessly for hours on end.
tr: Four legs good, two legs bad!" tirelessly for hours.
es: The sheep loved it, and once they had memorized it, they bleated it over and over again, even while resting on the field, and their "Four legs good, two legs bad!" could be heard for hours on end, repeated tirelessly.

en: Napoleon took no interest in Snowball’s committees.
vi: Napoleon did not care about Snowball's committees.
tr: Napoleon had never been interested in Snowball's committees.
es: Napoleon did not take an interest in the committees created by Snowball.

en: He said that the education of the young was more important than anything that could be done for those who were already grown up.
vi: He said that educating the younger generation was more important than mobilizing the already grown animals.
tr: He believed that educating the young was far more important than anything that could be done for those who were already grown up.
es: He said that the education of the young was more important than anything that could be done for the adults.

en: It happened that Jessie and Bluebell had both whelped soon after the hay harvest, giving birth between them to nine sturdy puppies.
vi: The two female dogs, Jessie and Bluebell, gave birth to nine healthy puppies right after the harvest.
tr: Jessie and Bluebell had given birth to nine sturdy puppies immediately after the harvest.
es: Meanwhile, it happened that Jessie and Bluebell had given birth shortly after the hay was harvested. Between the two of them, they had given the farm nine sturdy puppies.

en: As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon took them away from their mothers, saying that he would make himself responsible for their education.
vi: Napoleon took the puppies as soon as they were weaned, saying he would take responsibility for their education.
tr: As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon took them away from their mothers, saying that he would be responsible for their education.
es: As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon separated them from their mothers, saying that he would take charge of their education.

en: He took them up into a loft which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness-room, and there kept them in such seclusion that the rest of the farm soon forgot their existence.
vi: He hid the puppies in the attic, above the tool shed, which could only be reached by ladder, and kept them there so secretly that gradually no one remembered the puppies anymore.
tr: He then secluded them in a loft which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness-room, keeping them so out of sight that the rest of the farm soon forgot their existence.
es: He took them to an attic, which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness room, and there he kept them in such a degree of seclusion that the rest of the farm soon forgot about their existence.

en: The mystery of where the milk went to was soon cleared up.
vi: The issue of milk loss is no longer a secret.
tr: It was soon understood where the milk had gone.
es: The mystery of the fate of the milk was soon clarified: it was mixed every day into the pigs' food.

en: It was mixed every day into the pigs’ mash.
vi: The pigs mixed it into the daily feed.
tr: The milk was being mixed into the pigs' mash every day.
es: The mystery of the fate of the milk was soon clarified: it was mixed every day into the pigs' food.

en: The early apples were now ripening, and the grass of the orchard was littered with windfalls.
vi: The early-season apples have ripened, and every day some fall onto the grass in the garden.
tr: The apples were now starting to ripen; the grass of the orchard was covered with apples fallen by the wind.
es: The first apples were already ripening, and the grass in the orchard was covered with fruit fallen from the trees.

en: The animals had assumed as a matter of course that these would be shared out equally; one day, however, the order went forth that all the windfalls were to be collected and brought to the harness-room for the use of the pigs.
vi: All the animals thought they would be shared equally, but one day there was an order to collect the fallen apples and store them in the tool shed exclusively for the pigs.
tr: The animals naturally hoped that the apples would be shared equally; however, one day it was ordered that all the apples fallen from the trees be collected and delivered to the pigs in the room where the harnesses were kept.
es: The animals naturally believed that this fruit would be distributed equitably; one day, however, the order was given that all fallen apples should be collected and taken to the harness-room for the pigs' consumption.

en: At this some of the other animals murmured, but it was no use.
vi: Some animals complained about this, but it led nowhere.
tr: Some animals grumbled, but it was of no use.
es: Shortly after this happened, some animals began to murmur, but in vain.

en: All the pigs were in full agreement on this point, even Snowball and Napoleon.
vi: On this matter, the pigs, including Snowball and Napoleon, were in complete agreement.
tr: All the pigs, even Snowball and Napoleon, were of the same mind on this matter.
es: All the pigs agreed on this point, even Snowball and Napoleon.

en: Squealer was sent to make the necessary explanations to the others.
vi: Squealer was assigned to carry out the propaganda work.
tr: Squealer, who was tasked with making the necessary explanations to the other animals, shouted, "Comrades!" "I hope you do not think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness or a love for privilege.
es: Squealer was sent to give the necessary explanations.

en: “Comrades!” he cried.
vi: "Comrades," it said, "I hope you don't think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness and privilege, do you?
tr: Squealer, who was tasked with making the necessary explanations to the other animals, shouted, "Comrades!" "I hope you do not think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness or a love for privilege.
es: —Comrades —he shouted—, I imagine you don't suppose that we pigs are doing this with a spirit of selfishness and privilege.

en: “You do not imagine, I hope, that we pigs are doing this in a spirit of selfishness and privilege?
vi: "Comrades," it said, "I hope you don't think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness and privilege, do you?
tr: Squealer, who was tasked with making the necessary explanations to the other animals, shouted, "Comrades!" "I hope you do not think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness or a love for privilege.
es: —Comrades —he shouted—, I imagine you don't suppose that we pigs are doing this with a spirit of selfishness and privilege.

en: Many of us actually dislike milk and apples.
vi: Many pig comrades are also sick of milk and apples.
tr: In fact, most of us do not like milk and apples.
es: Many of us, in fact, have an aversion to milk and apples.

en: I dislike them myself.
vi: I don't like those two things either.
tr: I do not like them either.
es: Personally, I don't like them.

en: Our sole object in taking these things is to preserve our health.
vi: Our purpose in eating those things is solely to protect our health.
tr: The only reason we are taking these apples is to preserve our health.
es: Our only purpose in eating these foods is to preserve our health.

en: Milk and apples (this has been proved by Science, comrades) contain substances absolutely necessary to the well-being of a pig.
vi: Milk and apples (Comrades, science has proven) contain many substances that are extremely necessary for the health of pigs.
tr: There are certain substances in milk and apples that are absolutely necessary for the health of pigs. Science has proven this, comrades.
es: Milk and apples (this has been proven by Science, comrades) contain substances absolutely necessary for the health of a pig.

en: We pigs are brainworkers.
vi: We pigs do intellectual work.
tr: We pigs are the brainworkers.
es: We pigs work with our brains.

en: The whole management and organisation of this farm depend on us.
vi: We handle all the organization and management of this farm.
tr: We are responsible for the management and organization of this farm.
es: The entire administration and organization of this farm depend on us.

en: Day and night we are watching over your welfare.
vi: For your prosperity, we have to work day and night.
tr: We work day and night to safeguard your well-being.
es: Day and night we are watching over your happiness.

en: It is for YOUR sake that we drink that milk and eat those apples.
vi: We drink milk and eat apples for your own benefit.
tr: We drink this milk and eat these apples for your sake.
es: For your sake, we take that milk and eat those apples.

en: Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed in our duty?
vi: Can you imagine what would happen if we pigs couldn't handle our duties?
tr: Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed to perform our duty properly?
es: Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed in our duty?

en: Jones would come back!
vi: Mr. Jones would come back!
tr: Jones would come back!
es: Jones would come back!

en: Yes, Jones would come back!
vi: Yes, Mr. Jones would come back!
tr: Yes, Jones would come back!
es: Yes, Jones would come back!

en: Surely, comrades,” cried Squealer almost pleadingly, skipping from side to side and whisking his tail, “surely there is no one among you who wants to see Jones come back?”
vi: Surely none of us want Mr. Jones to come back, do we?" it pleaded loudly, shouting and jumping from right to left, its tail wagging furiously, "Surely none of us want Mr. Jones to come back, right?"
tr: Have no doubt about that, comrades." Then, jumping from side to side and wagging his tail, he shouted: "I believe there is not a single animal among you who wants Jones to come back!"
es: Surely, comrades —exclaimed Squealer almost pleadingly, dancing from side to side and wagging his tail—, surely there is no one among you who wants Jones to return.

en: Now if there was one thing that the animals were completely certain of, it was that they did not want Jones back.
vi: Surely no animal wanted Mr. Jones to come back.
tr: If there was one thing the animals had no doubt about, it was that they did not want Jones to return.
es: Certainly, if there was one thing the animals were completely sure of, it was that they did not want Jones back.

en: When it was put to them in this light, they had no more to say.
vi: When put that way, no animal dared to speak up anymore.
tr: If there was one thing the animals had no doubt about, it was that they did not want Jones to return.
es: When it was presented to them in this way, they didn't know what to say.

en: The importance of keeping the pigs in good health was all too obvious.
vi: The health of the pigs was of utmost importance, that was unquestionable.
tr: The importance of keeping the pigs healthy was very clear.
es: The importance of preserving the health of the pigs was too obvious.

en: So it was agreed without further argument that the milk and the windfall apples (and also the main crop of apples when they ripened) should be reserved for the pigs alone.
vi: So they unanimously agreed without further discussion that the milk and fallen apples (when in season, all of them) were to be reserved exclusively for the pigs. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: Thus, before the argument grew, it was agreed by everyone that all the milk and the apples that fell from the trees due to the wind (naturally, also the apples picked from the trees when they ripened) would be allocated to the pigs.
es: So it was decided without any discussion that the milk and the apples that had fallen from the trees (and also the main harvest of apples when they ripened) should be reserved exclusively for the pigs.

en: Chapter 4
vi: Chapter 4
tr: Chapter Four
es: IV

en: By the late summer the news of what had happened on Animal Farm had spread across half the county.
vi: By the end of summer, news about Animal Farm had spread across half the country.
tr: By the end of summer, almost the entire country had heard about what was happening at Animal Farm.
es: BY the end of summer, the news of what had happened at "Animal Farm" had spread almost throughout the entire county.

en: Every day Snowball and Napoleon sent out flights of pigeons whose instructions were to mingle with the animals on neighbouring farms, tell them the story of the Rebellion, and teach them the tune of ‘Beasts of England’.
vi: Every day, Snowball and Napoleon sent flocks of pigeons to infiltrate other farms to propagate the Rebellion and teach the song "Beasts of England."
tr: The carrier pigeons that Snowball and Napoleon sent out every day were making friends with the animals on neighboring farms, telling them the story of the Rebellion, and teaching them the song "Beasts of England."
es: Every day, Snowball and Napoleon sent flocks of pigeons with instructions to mingle with the animals of the neighboring farms, tell them the story of the Rebellion, and teach them the tune of "Beasts of England."

en: Most of this time mr Jones had spent sitting in the taproom of the Red Lion at Willingdon, complaining to anyone who would listen of the monstrous injustice he had suffered in being turned out of his property by a pack of good-for-nothing animals.
vi: Meanwhile, Mr. Jones almost every day sat in the Red Lion restaurant in Willingdon, lamenting to anyone who would listen about being robbed of his property by the useless animals.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Jones spent most of his time lounging at the Red Lion tavern in Willingdon; whenever he found someone to listen to him, he would immediately start complaining, saying he had been terribly wronged and driven out of his farm by a bunch of lowly animals.
es: For most of that time, Jones stayed at the "Red Lion" tavern in Willingdon, complaining to anyone who would listen about the monstrous injustice he had suffered by being thrown off his property by a band of useless animals.

en: The other farmers sympathised in principle, but they did not at first give him much help.
vi: The other farm owners were sympathetic, but they didn't offer any help.
tr: The other farmers had met him with understanding, but initially, they were not very inclined to help.
es: The other farmers sympathized with him, although they did not give him much help.

en: At heart, each of them was secretly wondering whether he could not somehow turn Jones’s misfortune to his own advantage.
vi: Moreover, deep down, they were looking for ways to take advantage of his misfortune.
tr: Each of them was secretly thinking about how they could benefit from Jones's misfortune.
es: Inwardly, each one secretly wondered if they could somehow turn Jones's misfortune to their own advantage.

en: It was lucky that the owners of the two farms which adjoined Animal Farm were on permanently bad terms.
vi: Fortunately, the owners of the two farms adjacent to Animal Farm were always at odds with each other.
tr: Fortunately, the owners of the two farms neighboring Animal Farm could never get along with each other.
es: It was fortunate that the owners of the two farms adjoining "Animal Farm" were always at odds.

en: One of them, which was named Foxwood, was a large, neglected, old-fashioned farm, much overgrown by woodland, with all its pastures worn out and its hedges in a disgraceful condition.
vi: One farm was called Foxwood, a large but neglected farm, cultivated in the old-fashioned way, with overgrown areas, trampled grazing grounds, and dilapidated fences.
tr: Foxwood was a large, neglected, and run-down farm; it was overgrown with bushes, its pastures had withered, and its fences were in tatters.
es: One of them, called Foxwood, was a large, old-fashioned, and neglected farm, covered with woodland, with its grazing fields exhausted and its fences in a lamentable state.

en: Its owner, mr Pilkington, was an easy-going gentleman farmer who spent most of his time in fishing or hunting according to the season.
vi: The owner of this farm, Mr. Pilkington, was an easygoing man who spent most of his time hunting and fishing.
tr: The owner of Foxwood, Mr. Pilkington, spent most of his time fishing during the fishing season and hunting during the hunting season; he was a laid-back, gentlemanly man.
es: Its owner, Mr. Pilkington, was a gentlemanly and lazy farmer who spent most of his time fishing or hunting, depending on the season.

en: The other farm, which was called Pinchfield, was smaller and better kept.
vi: The second farm was called Pinchfield, smaller but better maintained.
tr: Pinchfield Farm, on the other hand, was smaller but better maintained.
es: The other farm, called Pinchfield, was smaller and better kept.

en: Its owner was a mr Frederick, a tough, shrewd man, perpetually involved in lawsuits and with a name for driving hard bargains.
vi: The owner of this farm, Mr. Frederick, was a tough, shrewd man, constantly involved in lawsuits and notorious as a cunning swindler.
tr: The owner of Pinchfield, Mr. Frederick, was a bully and a cunning man; he was constantly involved in lawsuits; money was his religion, and once he got his hands on something, he wouldn't let go.
es: Its owner, one Frederick, was a tough, shrewd man who was always involved in lawsuits and had a reputation as a skilled negotiator.

en: These two disliked each other so much that it was difficult for them to come to any agreement, even in defence of their own interests.
vi: These two men hated each other so much that they couldn't find common ground even in protecting their own interests.
tr: These two hated each other so much that they couldn't agree even on matters that were in their mutual interest.
es: The two hated each other so much that it was difficult for them to agree, even in defense of their own interests.

en: Nevertheless, they were both thoroughly frightened by the rebellion on Animal Farm, and very anxious to prevent their own animals from learning too much about it.
vi: But the Rebellion at Animal Farm had frightened both of them, and they tried everything to prevent the news from reaching their own farms.
tr: However, both of them were very afraid of the Rebellion at Animal Farm; they were doing everything they could to prevent the animals on their own farms from getting detailed information about the rebellion.
es: Nevertheless, both were completely frightened by the rebellion at "Animal Farm" and very anxious to prevent their animals from learning too much about the event.

en: At first they pretended to laugh to scorn the idea of animals managing a farm for themselves.
vi: At first, they pretended to ridicule the idea of animals running a farm by themselves.
tr: In fact, at first, they had laughed a lot at the idea that animals could run a farm on their own; they thought that this would collapse in ten or fifteen days at most.
es: At first, they pretended to laugh and scorn the idea of animals managing their own farm.

en: The whole thing would be over in a fortnight, they said.
vi: "It won't last more than a fortnight," they said.
tr: In fact, at first, they had laughed a lot at the idea that animals could run a farm on their own; they thought that this would collapse in ten or fifteen days at most.
es: "This whole thing will be over by tomorrow," they said to each other.

en: They put it about that the animals on the Manor Farm (they insisted on calling it the Manor Farm; they would not tolerate the name “Animal Farm”) were perpetually fighting among themselves and were also rapidly starving to death.
vi: They spread rumors that the animals at Manor Farm (they insisted on calling it Manor Farm and refused to acknowledge the name Animal Farm) were constantly fighting among themselves and would soon starve to death.
tr: They had spread rumors that the animals at Manor Farm (they insisted on referring to the farm as Manor Farm, they couldn't tolerate the name "Animal Farm") were constantly quarreling with each other and would soon die of starvation.
es: They claimed that the animals at "Manor Farm" (they insisted on calling it "Manor Farm" because they could not tolerate the name "Animal Farm") were constantly fighting among themselves and would end up starving to death.

en: When time passed and the animals had evidently not starved to death, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began to talk of the terrible wickedness that now flourished on Animal Farm.
vi: After some time, seeing that the animals were not starving, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began talking about unimaginable immoral scenes taking place at Animal Farm.
tr: But when it turned out after a while that the animals were not dying of starvation, they changed their tune and started talking about the mind-boggling devilry at Animal Farm.
es: After some time, and when the animals evidently did not starve, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began to talk about the terrible wickedness flourishing at "Animal Farm."

en: It was given out that the animals there practised cannibalism, tortured one another with red-hot horseshoes, and had their females in common.
vi: They claimed that the animals were eating each other, torturing each other with red-hot horseshoes, and that the females had become communal property.
tr: According to these two farmers, cannibalism had taken hold at Animal Farm; the animals were torturing each other with hot horseshoes and sharing their females communally.
es: They spread the rumor that the animals practiced cannibalism, tortured each other with red-hot horseshoes, and practiced free love.

en: This was what came of rebelling against the laws of Nature, Frederick and Pilkington said.
vi: "That's what happens when you go against the laws of Nature," Frederick and Pilkington said.
tr: Frederick and Pilkington said that all of this was the natural consequence of rebelling against the laws of nature.
es: "That is the result of rebelling against the laws of Nature," Frederick and Pilkington maintained.

en: However, these stories were never fully believed.
vi: But not many people believed that story.
tr: But these stories did not seem credible to anyone.
es: However, these tales were never given much credit.

en: Rumours of a wonderful farm, where the human beings had been turned out and the animals managed their own affairs, continued to circulate in vague and distorted forms, and throughout that year a wave of rebelliousness ran through the countryside.
vi: The rumor about a strange farm, where humans were driven away and the animals managed the work themselves, continued to be passed around in a vague and distorted manner, and throughout that year, waves of unrest spread across the countryside.
tr: It was said that there was an extraordinary farm where animals drove out humans and managed everything themselves, and rumors about this continued with all their uncertainty and distortion. A wave of rebellion rose throughout the year on the surrounding farms.
es: Rumors about a wonderful farm from which humans had been expelled and where the animals managed their own affairs continued to circulate vaguely and falsely, and throughout that year a wave of rebellion spread across the region.

en: Bulls which had always been tractable suddenly turned savage, sheep broke down hedges and devoured the clover, cows kicked the pail over, hunters refused their fences and shot their riders on to the other side.
vi: Oxen that were usually docile suddenly became aggressive, sheep broke down fences and trampled the pastures, cows knocked over milk pails, and racehorses refused to jump over fences, throwing their riders high into the air.
tr: Bulls known to be docile suddenly went wild, sheep broke through fences and devoured clover, cows kicked over buckets, horses disobeyed orders, and suddenly stopped, throwing their riders over the fences to the other side.
es: Bulls that had always been docile suddenly turned wild; there were sheep that broke through fences and devoured the clover; cows that knocked over the buckets when being milked; hunting horses that refused to jump the hedges and threw their riders over their ears.

en: Above all, the tune and even the words of ‘Beasts of England’ were known everywhere.
vi: The melody and lyrics of the song "Beasts of England" spread to every nook and cranny.
tr: Most importantly, the tune and lyrics of the song "Animals of England" were now known everywhere.
es: Despite everything, the tune and even the lyrics of "Beasts of England" were known everywhere.

en: It had spread with astonishing speed.
vi: It was disseminated at an unprecedented speed.
tr: It had spread with unexpected speed.
es: They had spread with astonishing speed.

en: The human beings could not contain their rage when they heard this song, though they pretended to think it merely ridiculous.
vi: The song drove people mad, but they pretended it was just a ridiculous joke.
tr: Although people claimed to find it very ridiculous, they couldn't help but feel great anger when they heard this song.
es: Humans could not contain their fury when they heard this song, although they pretended to consider it simply ridiculous.

en: They could not understand, they said, how even animals could bring themselves to sing such contemptible rubbish.
vi: Even animals couldn't possibly sing such vile rubbish, they said.
tr: They argued that they couldn't even comprehend how such a disgraceful and absurd song could be sung by animals.
es: They could not understand, they said, how even the animals themselves dared to sing something so despicable.

en: Any animal caught singing it was given a flogging on the spot.
vi: Any animal caught singing that song was immediately beaten on the spot.
tr: Animals caught singing the song were whipped on the spot, yet the spread of the song could not be prevented.
es: Any animal caught singing it was whipped on the spot.

en: And yet the song was irrepressible.
vi: Yet it still couldn't be completely banned.
tr: Animals caught singing the song were whipped on the spot, yet the spread of the song could not be prevented.
es: However, the song proved irrepressible: blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, pigeons cooed it in the poplars, and it could even be recognized in the noise of the forges and the ringing of church bells.

en: The blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, the pigeons cooed it in the elms, it got into the din of the smithies and the tune of the church bells.
vi: Birds sang it on the fences, pigeons cooed it in the trees, the song entered the chirping of crickets, and even the church bells.
tr: While blackbirds whistled among the bushes and pigeons cooed in the trees, they were always singing this song; the melodies of the song mingled with the hammer blows of blacksmiths and the chimes of church bells.
es: However, the song proved irrepressible: blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, pigeons cooed it in the poplars, and it could even be recognized in the noise of the forges and the ringing of church bells.

en: And when the human beings listened to it, they secretly trembled, hearing in it a prophecy of their future doom.
vi: Humans shivered every time they heard it, as if they were hearing a forewarning of their own doom.
tr: While blackbirds whistled among the bushes and pigeons cooed in the trees, they were always singing this song; the melodies of the song mingled with the hammer blows of blacksmiths and the chimes of church bells.
es: And when humans heard it, they secretly trembled, for they sensed in it a forewarning of their future doom.

en: Early in October, when the corn was cut and stacked and some of it was already threshed, a flight of pigeons came whirling through the air and alighted in the yard of Animal Farm in the wildest excitement.
vi: At the beginning of October, after harvesting and storing all the grain, with some already threshed, a flock of pigeons suddenly tore through the air and landed in the farmyard, looking extremely agitated.
tr: It was early October; the crops had been harvested and stacked, and the threshing was largely completed. One day, suddenly, carrier pigeons came circling swiftly and landed in the courtyard of Animal Farm, flapping anxiously.
es: In early October, when the corn had been cut and stacked and some of it had already been threshed, a flock of pigeons sped across and landed, very excited, in the yard of "Animal Farm."

en: Jones and all his men, with half a dozen others from Foxwood and Pinchfield, had entered the five-barred gate and were coming up the cart-track that led to the farm.
vi: Mr. Jones, along with his servants and about half a dozen young men from Foxwood and Pinchfield farms, had passed through the main gate and were advancing into the farm.
tr: According to the news they brought, Jones and his men, along with half a dozen men from the Foxwood and Pinchfield farms, had entered through the barred gate and were coming up the driveway to the farm.
es: Jones and all his men, with half a dozen more men from Foxwood and Pinchfield, had crossed the gate and were approaching the house along the path.

en: They were all carrying sticks, except Jones, who was marching ahead with a gun in his hands.
vi: Mr. Jones was brandishing a loaded gun, while the others were armed with sticks.
tr: Jones, with a rifle in hand, was walking at the front; the men with sticks were following him.
es: They were all wielding sticks, except for Jones, who marched ahead with a shotgun in his hand.

en: Obviously they were going to attempt the recapture of the farm.
vi: There was no doubt about it, they intended to recapture the farm.
tr: Obviously, they had made up their minds to take back the farm.
es: Evidently, they were going to try to recapture the farm.

en: This had long been expected, and all preparations had been made.
vi: But the animals were not caught off guard; on the contrary, they had been preparing for this event for a long time.
tr: In fact, since such an attempt had been expected for a long time, all precautions had been taken, and all necessary preparations had been made.
es: This eventuality had long been anticipated and, consequently, the necessary precautions had been taken.

en: Snowball, who had studied an old book of Julius Caesar’s campaigns which he had found in the farmhouse, was in charge of the defensive operations.
vi: Snowball, who had previously studied the book on Julius Caesar's campaigns [2] thoroughly, which it found in the main house, was assigned to organize the defense.
tr: Snowball, who had gained extensive knowledge about Julius Caesar's campaigns by reading an old book he found in the farmhouse, was appointed to the command of the defense operation.
es: Snowball, who had studied Julius Caesar's campaigns in an old book found in the house, was in charge of the defensive operations.

en: He gave his orders quickly, and in a couple of minutes every animal was at his post.
vi: It immediately issued orders, and the animals quickly took up their assigned positions.
tr: He immediately gave his orders; all the animals took their positions within a few minutes.
es: He gave the orders quickly and within a few minutes, each animal was in its combat position.

en: As the human beings approached the farm buildings, Snowball launched his first attack.
vi: Tuyet Tron ordered an attack as soon as the group of people approached the row of houses in the farm.
tr: As the people approached the farm buildings, Snowball initiated the first attack.
es: When the human beings approached the farm buildings, Snowball launched his first attack.

en: All the pigeons, to the number of thirty-five, flew to and fro over the men’s heads and muted upon them from mid-air; and while the men were dealing with this, the geese, who had been hiding behind the hedge, rushed out and pecked viciously at the calves of their legs.
vi: Thirty-five pigeons were dispatched, flying back and forth and defecating on the heads of the people below. While they were busy dodging and brushing off, the geese, ambushed behind the fence, rushed out and bit their legs.
tr: Exactly thirty-five pigeons flew over the men's heads, defecating on them. While the men tried to chase away the pigeons, the geese, hidden behind the fence, suddenly rushed forward and began savagely pecking at their calves.
es: All the pigeons—there were about thirty-five of them—flew over the men's heads and soiled them from above; and while the men were busy dodging what was falling on them, the geese, hidden behind the hedge, attacked them by furiously pecking at their calves.

en: However, this was only a light skirmishing manoeuvre, intended to create a little disorder, and the men easily drove the geese off with their sticks.
vi: But that was just a tactical move to disrupt the enemy's ranks because it was easy for people to use sticks to drive the geese away.
tr: However, this was merely a feint to cause some confusion; indeed, the men easily drove the geese back with their sticks.
es: But that was a mere skirmish intended to create a bit of disorder, and the men easily drove the geese away with their sticks.

en: Snowball now launched his second line of attack.
vi: The second wave of attack was launched.
tr: This time, Snowball initiated the second attack.
es: Snowball launched the second line of attack: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head, advanced, charging and shoving the men from all sides, while Benjamin turned around and began kicking with his hind legs.

en: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head of them, rushed forward and prodded and butted the men from every side, while Benjamin turned around and lashed at them with his small hoofs.
vi: Muriel, Benjamin, and the entire flock of sheep, led by Tuyet Tron himself, charged forward, surrounding the people and butting them while Benjamin turned his back on them and kicked wildly.
tr: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, led by Snowball, charged forward, butting and horn-thrusting the men from all sides; meanwhile, Benjamin kept kicking back.
es: Snowball launched the second line of attack: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head, advanced, charging and shoving the men from all sides, while Benjamin turned around and began kicking with his hind legs.

en: But once again the men, with their sticks and their hobnailed boots, were too strong for them; and suddenly, at a squeal from Snowball, which was the signal for retreat, all the animals turned and fled through the gateway into the yard.
vi: But this time, the animals did not win either; the sticks and spiked shoes used by the humans were too strong for them. Seeing the unfavorable situation, Tuyet Tron neighed loudly, which was the signal to temporarily retreat, and the animals quickly fled into the yard.
tr: But with their sticks in hand and hobnailed boots on their feet, the men were still stronger than the animals. When Snowball suddenly squealed, signaling a retreat, all the animals turned back, dashed through the passage, and plunged into the yard.
es: But again, the men, with their sticks and hobnailed boots, were too strong for them, and suddenly, upon hearing Snowball's squeal, which was the signal to retreat, all the animals turned around and went through the gate into the yard.

en: The men gave a shout of triumph.
vi: The victorious cheers echoed.
tr: The men shouting victory cries, thinking their enemies were fleeing, ran chaotically after them.
es: The men let out a cry of triumph.

en: They saw, as they imagined, their enemies in flight, and they rushed after them in disorder.
vi: The attackers saw that the enemy had fled as expected, so without needing to reorganize their ranks, they hurriedly rushed forward to pursue.
tr: The men shouting victory cries, thinking their enemies were fleeing, ran chaotically after them.
es: They saw —or so they imagined— their enemies in flight and ran after them in disarray.

en: This was just what Snowball had intended.
vi: Just as Snowball had anticipated.
tr: This was exactly what Snowball wanted.
es: That was precisely what Snowball had been expecting.

en: As soon as they were well inside the yard, the three horses, the three cows, and the rest of the pigs, who had been lying in ambush in the cowshed, suddenly emerged in their rear, cutting them off.
vi: When everyone had entered the yard, three horses, three cows, and all the remaining pigs that had been lying in ambush in the cow shed rushed out to cut off the retreat.
tr: Once they all entered the yard, the three horses, three cows, and the other pigs who were lying in ambush in the barn suddenly appeared and cut off the men's retreat.
es: As soon as they were inside the yard, the three horses, the three cows, and the other pigs, who had been lying in wait in the cowshed, suddenly appeared behind them, cutting off their retreat.

en: Snowball now gave the signal for the charge.
vi: Snowball ordered a full assault.
tr: It was at that moment that Snowball gave the signal to attack and charged straight at Jones.
es: Snowball gave the signal to charge.

en: He himself dashed straight for Jones.
vi: He charged straight at Mr. Jones.
tr: It was at that moment that Snowball gave the signal to attack and charged straight at Jones.
es: He himself attacked Jones.

en: Jones saw him coming, raised his gun and fired.
vi: Mr. Jones saw him coming and pulled the trigger.
tr: Seeing Snowball coming at him, Jones aimed his rifle and fired.
es: Jones saw him coming, aimed his shotgun, and fired.

en: The pellets scored bloody streaks along Snowball’s back, and a sheep dropped dead.
vi: The shotgun blast wounded Snowball along his back, blood streaming out, and killed a sheep.
tr: The pellets opened bloody furrows on Snowball's back; one of the sheep died on the spot.
es: The pellets left their bloody mark on Snowball's back, and a sheep fell dead.

en: Without halting for an instant, Snowball flung his fifteen stone against Jones’s legs.
vi: Without hesitating for a second, Snowball continued to thrust his hefty body into Mr. Jones's legs.
tr: Without a moment's hesitation, Snowball, with his hundred-kilo body, lunged at Jones's legs.
es: Without hesitating for an instant, Snowball hurled his fifteen stone against Jones's legs, who fell onto a pile of manure as the shotgun slipped from his hands.

en: Jones was hurled into a pile of dung and his gun flew out of his hands.
vi: He fell sprawling into a pile of dung, his gun flying far away.
tr: As Jones tumbled onto a manure pile, his rifle flew out of his hand.
es: Without hesitating for an instant, Snowball hurled his fifteen stone against Jones's legs, who fell onto a pile of manure as the shotgun slipped from his hands.

en: But the most terrifying spectacle of all was Boxer, rearing up on his hind legs and striking out with his great iron-shod hoofs like a stallion.
vi: But the most terrifying was Boxer, who stood on his hind legs and brought down his iron-shod hooves on the man's head.
tr: But the most terrifying was Boxer; rearing up on his hind legs, he fought like a stallion, swinging his massive iron-shod hooves.
es: But the most terrifying sight was Boxer, rearing up on his hind legs and kicking like a stallion with his enormous iron-shod hooves.

en: His very first blow took a stable-lad from Foxwood on the skull and stretched him lifeless in the mud.
vi: His first blow knocked the Foxwood farmhand to the ground, unconscious.
tr: The first blow landed on the head of a stable boy from Foxwood Farm, who collapsed into the mud and died on the spot.
es: His first blow struck a stable boy from Foxwood on the head, leaving him lying lifeless in the mud.

en: At the sight, several men dropped their sticks and tried to run.
vi: Several people threw down their sticks and fled.
tr: Seeing this, many of the men dropped their sticks and tried to flee.
es: Seeing this scene, several men dropped their sticks and tried to escape.

en: Panic overtook them, and the next moment all the animals together were chasing them round and round the yard.
vi: Not missing the opportunity, the animals chased them around the yard.
tr: They were seized with panic. At that moment, all the animals chased after the men, pursuing them around the yard.
es: But panic seized them, and in an instant, the animals were running after them all over the yard.

en: They were gored, kicked, bitten, trampled on.
vi: They butted them up, then bit, kicked, and trampled.
tr: They gored, kicked, bit, and trampled anyone who lagged behind.
es: They were gored, kicked, bitten, trampled.

en: There was not an animal on the farm that did not take vengeance on them after his own fashion.
vi: There wasn't a single animal on the farm that didn't take part in the revenge in its own way.
tr: Not a single animal on the farm failed to take its revenge on the men.
es: There was not a single animal on the farm that did not take revenge in its own way.

en: Even the cat suddenly leapt off a roof onto a cowman’s shoulders and sank her claws in his neck, at which he yelled horribly.
vi: Even the cat leapt from the roof of the cow shed onto a cowherd's shoulders, biting his neck and screeching as if in a fit.
tr: Even the cat suddenly leaped from the roof onto a cowherd's back, digging its claws into his neck and making him scream in pain.
es: Even the cat suddenly leaped from a rooftop onto a cowboy's back and sank its claws into his neck, making him scream horribly.

en: At a moment when the opening was clear, the men were glad enough to rush out of the yard and make a bolt for the main road.
vi: As soon as they saw an opening to retreat, everyone hurriedly ran out of the yard to the main road.
tr: The men, finding an opportunity, bolted out of the yard and started running full speed towards the main road.
es: When the exit was clear, the men were glad to escape the yard and flee like lightning to the main road.

en: And so within five minutes of their invasion they were in ignominious retreat by the same way as they had come, with a flock of geese hissing after them and pecking at their calves all the way.
vi: Thus, having penetrated for less than five minutes, they had to flee, with the geese biting their legs and honking as they chased them.
tr: It had been less than five minutes since they had raided the farm, yet they were retreating in disgrace, just as they had come. A flock of geese, hissing as they followed, pecked at their legs all the way down the road.
es: And so, five minutes after their invasion, they were in shameful retreat along the same access route, with a flock of geese pecking at their calves all the way.

en: All the men were gone except one.
vi: There was one person who did not escape.
tr: They had all escaped, except for one.
es: All the men had left, except one.

en: Back in the yard Boxer was pawing with his hoof at the stable-lad who lay face down in the mud, trying to turn him over.
vi: In the yard, the Soldier was trying to turn over the stable cleaner who was still lying face down in the mud.
tr: Boxer was nudging the stable boy who was lying face down in the mud in the yard with his front hoof, trying to turn him over, but the boy wasn't moving.
es: Out in the yard, Boxer was pushing with his hoof at the stable boy who lay face down in the mud, trying to turn him over.

en: The boy did not stir.
vi: The man did not move at all.
tr: Boxer was nudging the stable boy who was lying face down in the mud in the yard with his front hoof, trying to turn him over, but the boy wasn't moving.
es: The boy did not move.

en: “He is dead,” said Boxer sorrowfully.
vi: "He's dead!", the Warrior exclaimed sadly, "I didn't mean to do that.
tr: Boxer said sadly, "He's dead."
es: —He is dead —said Boxer sadly—.

en: “I had no intention of doing that.
vi: "He's dead!", the Warrior exclaimed sadly, "I didn't mean to do that.
tr: "I had no intention of killing him.
es: I didn't mean to do it.

en: I forgot that I was wearing iron shoes.
vi: I forgot that I was wearing iron claws.
tr: I forgot that I had iron shoes on my feet.
es: I forgot that I had horseshoes.

en: Who will believe that I did not do this on purpose?”
vi: Who would believe now that I didn't do it on purpose?"
tr: Who will believe now that I didn't do it on purpose?"
es: Who is going to believe that I didn't do this on purpose?

en: “No sentimentality, comrade!” cried Snowball from whose wounds the blood was still dripping.
vi: "Stop being sentimental, comrade!"
tr: With his wounds still bleeding, Snowball shouted, "No need for sentimentality, comrade!"
es: —No sentimentality, comrade —shouted Snowball, from whose wounds blood was still flowing—.

en: “War is war.
vi: Tuyết Tròn said, blood still oozing from his back at times, "War is war.
tr: "War is war.
es: War is war.

en: The only good human being is a dead one.”
vi: Good people are those who have died."
tr: The best human is a dead human."
es: The only good human is a dead one.

en: “I have no wish to take life, not even human life,” repeated Boxer, and his eyes were full of tears.
vi: "I did not mean to kill, not even to kill a person," the Warrior kept repeating, eyes filled with tears.
tr: "I don't want to take anyone's life," said Boxer. His eyes were filled with tears.
es: —I do not wish to take a life, not even a human one —repeated Boxer with his eyes full of tears.

en: “Where is Mollie?” exclaimed somebody.
vi: "Where's Mollie?", someone asked.
tr: At that moment, someone shouted, "Where is Mollie?"
es: —Where is Mollie? —someone inquired.

en: Mollie in fact was missing.
vi: Indeed, Mollie was nowhere to be seen.
tr: Indeed, Mollie was missing.
es: Indeed, Mollie was missing.

en: For a moment there was great alarm; it was feared that the men might have harmed her in some way, or even carried her off with them.
vi: At first, they were very worried, fearing that Mollie might have been injured or captured by the humans.
tr: Suddenly, there was chaos. Had something happened to her? Could the men have kidnapped Mollie?
es: For a moment there was great alarm; it was feared that the men had harmed her in some way, or perhaps had taken her with them.

en: In the end, however, she was found hiding in her stall with her head buried among the hay in the manger.
vi: Eventually, she was found hiding in the horse stable, her head buried in a pile of straw.
tr: After a long search, they found Mollie in the barn; she had hidden in her stall, burying her head in the hay in the manger.
es: In the end, they found her hiding in her stall, in the stable, with her head buried in the hay of the manger.

en: She had taken to flight as soon as the gun went off.
vi: She had fled as soon as she heard the gunshots.
tr: She had bolted as soon as the guns went off.
es: She had run away as soon as the gunshot was fired.

en: And when the others came back from looking for her, it was to find that the stable-lad, who in fact was only stunned, had already recovered and made off.
vi: While the animals were searching for Mollie, the stable boy regained consciousness and escaped.
tr: When those who went to look for Mollie returned to the yard, they saw that the groom was nowhere to be found. Apparently, the young man they thought was dead had only fainted; he had come to later and made a run for it.
es: And, when the others returned from their search, they found that the stable boy, who was actually only stunned, had recovered and fled.

en: The animals had now reassembled in the wildest excitement, each recounting his own exploits in the battle at the top of his voice.
vi: The animals had gathered in full, they were extremely excited, and competed to speak.
tr: The animals had reunited with wild enthusiasm, shouting at the top of their lungs as they recounted to each other the heroics they had shown in the battle.
es: The animals gathered very excitedly, each one loudly recounting their exploits in the battle.

en: An impromptu celebration of the victory was held immediately.
vi: The victory celebration was organized immediately.
tr: They immediately organized a ceremony right then and there to celebrate the victory.
es: Immediately, an impromptu celebration of the victory took place.

en: The flag was run up and ‘Beasts of England’ was sung a number of times, then the sheep who had been killed was given a solemn funeral, a hawthorn bush being planted on her grave.
vi: The flag was raised and they sang "Beasts of England" several times, then they held a funeral for the fallen sheep and planted a hawthorn bush on its grave.
tr: They hoisted the flag and sang "Beasts of England" several times. Then, they held a solemn burial ceremony for the sheep they had lost in the battle, planting a hawthorn sapling over its grave.
es: The flag was raised and "Beasts of England" was sung several times, and then a solemn burial was given to the sheep that died in the action, with a hawthorn branch planted over its grave.

en: At the graveside Snowball made a little speech, emphasising the need for all animals to be ready to die for Animal Farm if need be.
vi: Snowball gave a speech right next to the fallen warrior's grave, emphasizing that every animal must be ready to sacrifice for Animal Farm when needed.
tr: Snowball, giving a short speech at the grave, emphasized that if necessary, all animals should be ready to die for Animal Farm.
es: At this event, Snowball gave a speech, emphasizing the need for all animals to be willing to die for "Animal Farm," if necessary.

en: The animals decided unanimously to create a military decoration, “Animal Hero, First Class,” which was conferred there and then on Snowball and Boxer.
vi: The animals unanimously decided to establish a reward for the recent feats, which was the title of First Class Animal Hero. This title was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer.
tr: The animals unanimously decided to establish a military decoration. The "First Class Hero Animal" medal was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer right there.
es: The animals unanimously decided to create a military decoration: "Animal Hero, First Class," which was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer.

en: It consisted of a brass medal (they were really some old horse-brasses which had been found in the harness-room), to be worn on Sundays and holidays.
vi: The reward was a bronze medal (which was actually a piece of brass found in the harness room) to be worn on holidays and Sundays.
tr: These brass medals (actually, old horse trappings they found in the room where the harnesses were kept) were to be worn on Sundays and holidays.
es: It consisted of a bronze medal (in reality, some bronze horse trappings found in the harness-room), which was to be worn on Sundays and holidays.

en: There was also “Animal Hero, Second Class,” which was conferred posthumously on the dead sheep.
vi: The title of Second Class Animal Hero was awarded to the sheep that had sacrificed itself.
tr: The sheep that had lost its life in the battle was deemed worthy of the "Second Class Hero Animal" medal.
es: They also created the "Animal Hero, Second Class," which was posthumously awarded to the dead sheep.

en: There was much discussion as to what the battle should be called.
vi: They argued for a long time about what to name the victory.
tr: The name of the war was discussed at length.
es: There was much discussion about the name that should be given to the battle.

en: In the end, it was named the Battle of the Cowshed, since that was where the ambush had been sprung.
vi: Finally, they decided to call it the Cow Shed Campaign because the ambush took place in a cow shed.
tr: In the end, it was decided to call it the "Battle of the Cowshed"; the ambushing animals had launched their attack from there.
es: In the end, it was called the "Battle of the Cow Shed," as it was there where the ambush took place.

en: mr Jones’s gun had been found lying in the mud, and it was known that there was a supply of cartridges in the farmhouse.
vi: They found Mr. Jones's gun in the mud, and there were still bullets available in the camp.
tr: Mr. Jones's gun was found in the mud. They knew there were a few boxes of cartridges in the farmhouse.
es: Mr. Jones's shotgun was found in the mud, and it was known that there were shells in the house.

en: It was decided to set the gun up at the foot of the Flagstaff, like a piece of artillery, and to fire it twice a year — once on October the twelfth, the anniversary of the Battle of the Cowshed, and once on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.
vi: The gun was placed at the foot of the flagpole, as if it were a cannon in other places, and they would fire it twice a year, once on the summer solstice to celebrate the Uprising, and again on the twentieth of October to celebrate the Victory. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: It was decided that the gun, like a cannon, would be placed at the base of the flagpole and that a ceremonial shot would be fired twice a year, once on October 12th, the anniversary of the Battle of the Cowshed, and the other on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.
es: It was decided to place the shotgun at the foot of the flagpole, as if it were a piece of artillery, and to fire it twice a year; once on October fourth, the anniversary of the "Battle of the Cow Shed," and the other on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.

en: Chapter 5
vi: Chapter 5
tr: Fifth Chapter
es: V

en: As winter drew on, Mollie became more and more troublesome.
vi: The closer it got to winter, the more irritable Mollie became.
tr: As winter approached, Mollie was acting even stranger.
es: As winter approached, Mollie became more and more troublesome.

en: She was late for work every morning and excused herself by saying that she had overslept, and she complained of mysterious pains, although her appetite was excellent.
vi: Every morning she was late for work, claiming she overslept; in addition, she complained of strange illnesses, although she ate like a horse.
tr: Every morning she came to work late, apologizing by saying she had overslept, and despite having a good appetite, she complained of some inexplicable pains.
es: She arrived late to work in the mornings with the excuse that she had overslept, complaining of mysterious ailments, even though her appetite was excellent.

en: On every kind of pretext she would run away from work and go to the drinking pool, where she would stand foolishly gazing at her own reflection in the water.
vi: She often found ways to shirk work and run to the pond, standing there gazing at her reflection.
tr: She would make up an excuse to avoid work, go to the trough, and watch her reflection in the water foolishly.
es: With any excuse, she would escape from work to go to the drinking pool, where she would stand staring at her reflection in the water like a fool.

en: But there were also rumours of something more serious.
vi: But according to rumors, she had much more serious flaws.
tr: But there were also more serious rumors circulating around.
es: But there were also rumors of something more serious.

en: One day, as Mollie strolled blithely into the yard, flirting her long tail and chewing at a stalk of hay, Clover took her aside.
vi: One day, as she was strolling in the yard, casually wagging her long tail and chewing a mouthful of grass, Mrs. Fat pulled her aside and said:
tr: One day, when Mollie entered the yard cheerfully with a straw in her mouth, wagging her tail, Clover pulled her aside.
es: One day, as Mollie was cheerfully entering the yard, swishing her long tail and chewing on a stalk of hay, Clover called her aside.

en: “Mollie,” she said, “I have something very serious to say to you.
vi: "Mollie, I have a few things to say to you.
tr: "Look, Mollie," he said, "I have something very serious to tell you.
es: —Mollie —he said to her—, I have something very serious to tell you.

en: This morning I saw you looking over the hedge that divides Animal Farm from Foxwood.
vi: This morning I saw you standing by the fence between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm.
tr: This morning, I saw you looking over the fence that separates Animal Farm from Foxwood Farm.
es: This morning I saw you looking over the hedge that separates "Animal Farm" from Foxwood.

en: One of mr Pilkington’s men was standing on the other side of the hedge.
vi: On the other side of the fence was someone from Pilkington's farm.
tr: On the other side of the fence, there was one of Mr. Pilkington's men.
es: One of Mr. Pilkington's men was on the other side of the hedge.

en: And — I was a long way away, but I am almost certain I saw this — he was talking to you and you were allowing him to stroke your nose.
vi: Even though I was very far away, I am certain that he was talking to you, I saw it clearly, and you let him stroke your cheeks.
tr: Although I was very far away, I am almost certain that I saw him talking to you and you didn't object to him stroking your nose.
es: And I was at a certain distance, but I am almost sure I saw you: he was talking to you and you were allowing him to pet you.

en: What does that mean, Mollie?”
vi: Mollie, what is the meaning of this?"
tr: What does this mean, Mollie?"
es: What does that mean, Mollie?

en: “He didn’t!
vi: "He didn't clap!" "You weren't standing there!
tr: "No! He didn't stroke my nose or anything!" shouted Mollie. "I didn't do such a thing!"
es: —He did nothing!

en: I wasn’t!
vi: That didn't happen!"
tr: "Lies!"
es: I wasn't there! It's not true!

en: It isn’t true!” cried Mollie, beginning to prance about and paw the ground.
vi: - Mollie screamed, her legs jumping up and pounding loudly on the ground.
tr: She was stamping her feet and scratching the ground with them.
es: —shouted Mollie, prancing and kicking the ground.

en: “Mollie!
vi: "Mollie, look straight into my eyes!
tr: "Mollie!
es: —Mollie!

en: Look me in the face.
vi: "Mollie, look straight into my eyes!
tr: Look at my face.
es: Look me in the face.

en: Do you give me your word of honour that that man was not stroking your nose?”
vi: Do you dare swear to me that guy has never patted your cheek?"
tr: Do you swear on your honor that man didn't stroke your nose?"
es: Can you give me your word of honor that that man was not petting your snout?

en: “It isn’t true!” repeated Mollie, but she could not look Clover in the face, and the next moment she took to her heels and galloped away into the field.
vi: "There's no such thing!", Mollie repeated, but she didn't dare to look at Fat Lady and immediately dashed out to the field.
tr: Mollie, "Lies! Nothing like that happened!" she repeated, but she avoided Clover's eyes and galloped away towards the field.
es: —It's not true! —repeated Mollie, but she couldn't look Clover in the face, and instantly she ran away, galloping towards the field.

en: A thought struck Clover.
vi: A thought suddenly flashed in Mrs. Fat's mind.
tr: Suddenly, Clover's mind got stuck on something.
es: A thought occurred to Clover.

en: Without saying anything to the others, she went to Mollie’s stall and turned over the straw with her hoof.
vi: Without telling any of the others, she slowly approached Mollie's stall and used her hoof to turn over the pile of straw in the stall.
tr: Without saying anything to anyone, she entered Mollie's stall in the barn, and when she dug a little with her foot, she saw that a handful of sugar cubes and various colored ribbons were hidden among the straw.
es: Without saying anything to anyone, she went to Mollie's stall and stirred the straw with her hoof.

en: Hidden under the straw was a little pile of lump sugar and several bunches of ribbon of different colours.
vi: Under the pile of straw was a lump of sugar and several colorful ribbons.
tr: Without saying anything to anyone, she entered Mollie's stall in the barn, and when she dug a little with her foot, she saw that a handful of sugar cubes and various colored ribbons were hidden among the straw.
es: Hidden under the straw, there was a small pile of sugar lumps and several strips of ribbons of different colors.

en: Three days later Mollie disappeared.
vi: Three days later, Mollie disappeared.
tr: Three days later, Mollie disappeared.
es: Three days later, Mollie disappeared.

en: For some weeks nothing was known of her whereabouts, then the pigeons reported that they had seen her on the other side of Willingdon.
vi: Weeks went by without any news, but then the pigeons reported that they had seen Mollie outside Willingdon.
tr: For a long time, no information could be obtained about where she was, until the pigeons reported that they had seen her in Willingdon.
es: For several weeks, nothing was known about her whereabouts; then the pigeons reported that they had seen her on the other side of Willingdon.

en: She was between the shafts of a smart dogcart painted red and black, which was standing outside a public-house.
vi: She was pulling a small cart, splendidly painted in black and red, resting near a tavern.
tr: She was harnessed to a small, stylish, red-and-black cart standing in front of a tavern.
es: She was harnessed between the shafts of a smart red and black painted carriage, which was standing outside a tavern.

en: A fat red-faced man in check breeches and gaiters, who looked like a publican, was stroking her nose and feeding her with sugar.
vi: A stout man with a red face, wearing checkered trousers and gaiters, who seemed to be the tavern owner, was petting her and feeding her a piece of sugar.
tr: A fat, rosy-cheeked man, who looked like a tavern keeper, wearing checkered pants and gaiters, was stroking Mollie's nose and feeding her sugar.
es: A fat man, with a red face, wearing checkered breeches and gaiters, who looked like a publican, was stroking her nose and feeding her sugar.

en: Her coat was newly clipped and she wore a scarlet ribbon round her forelock.
vi: Her mane had been carefully trimmed and groomed, with a bright red ribbon tied to the tuft on her forehead.
tr: A red ribbon was tied to the forelock of Mollie, whose coat had been freshly clipped.
es: Mollie's coat was freshly clipped, and she wore a scarlet ribbon in her mane.

en: She appeared to be enjoying herself, so the pigeons said.
vi: According to the pigeons, she looked satisfied.
tr: According to the pigeons, she seemed to be in good spirits.
es: “She appeared to be enjoying herself,” said the pigeons.

en: None of the animals ever mentioned Mollie again.
vi: From then on, no one mentioned her again.
tr: From that day on, the animals never mentioned Mollie's name again.
es: None of the animals ever mentioned Mollie again.

en: In January there came bitterly hard weather.
vi: As January arrived, the weather became extremely harsh.
tr: In January, the weather became extremely cold.
es: In January, the weather was very bad.

en: The earth was like iron, and nothing could be done in the fields.
vi: The ground was as hard as rock, making it impossible to do any work.
tr: The ground was so hard that it was impossible to work in the fields.
es: The ground seemed like iron and nothing could be done in the fields.

en: Many meetings were held in the big barn, and the pigs occupied themselves with planning out the work of the coming season.
vi: Meetings were moved to the large barn, and the pigs focused on planning for the next season.
tr: Meeting after meeting was being held in the large barn, and the pigs were trying to plan the work for the coming season.
es: Many meetings were held in the big barn; the pigs were busy drawing up plans for the coming season.

en: It had come to be accepted that the pigs, who were manifestly cleverer than the other animals, should decide all questions of farm policy, though their decisions had to be ratified by a majority vote.
vi: They agreed that since the pigs were the smartest, they would be responsible for the overall direction of the farm, but their decisions had to be approved by an absolute majority.
tr: The authority to make decisions on all matters related to farm politics was given to the pigs, who were clearly more intelligent than the other animals; although their decisions had to be approved by a majority vote.
es: It was accepted that the pigs, who were manifestly more intelligent than the other animals, would decide all questions of farm management, though their decisions had to be ratified by a majority vote.

en: This arrangement would have worked well enough if it had not been for the disputes between Snowball and Napoleon.
vi: Everything would have been perfect if Snowball and Napoleon didn't constantly oppose each other.
tr: If it weren't for the constant quarrels between Snowball and Napoleon, who clashed on almost every issue, this system would have worked quite well.
es: This arrangement would have worked well enough if it had not been for the disputes between Snowball and Napoleon.

en: These two disagreed at every point where disagreement was possible.
vi: The two disagreed on every issue whenever they had the chance.
tr: If it weren't for the constant quarrels between Snowball and Napoleon, who clashed on almost every issue, this system would have worked quite well.
es: The two disagreed at every point where disagreement was possible.

en: If one of them suggested sowing a bigger acreage with barley, the other was certain to demand a bigger acreage of oats, and if one of them said that such and such a field was just right for cabbages, the other would declare that it was useless for anything except roots.
vi: If one said more barley should be sown, the other would insist on sowing more oats; if one said a certain field was suitable for cabbages, the other would argue that only turnips could be grown there.
tr: If one proposed to expand the area planted with barley, the other would argue that the area planted with oats should be expanded; if one said a field was suitable for growing cabbages, the other would claim that nothing but root crops could be grown there.
es: If one of them suggested sowing a bigger acreage with barley, the other was certain to demand a larger acreage of oats; and if one said that such and such a field was just right for cabbages, the other would declare that it was good for turnips.

en: Each had his own following, and there were some violent debates.
vi: Each had a number of supporters, so the debates were often very intense.
tr: Both had their supporters; sometimes fierce arguments would break out.
es: Each had his own following, and there were violent debates at every meeting.

en: At the Meetings Snowball often won over the majority by his brilliant speeches, but Napoleon was better at canvassing support for himself in between times.
vi: Thanks to his eloquence, Snowball usually won the majority in the Meetings, while outside, the majority supported Napoleon.
tr: With his brilliant speeches, Snowball often managed to win the majority of votes at meetings; but Napoleon was no less skilled at garnering support through behind-the-scenes work.
es: In many ways, Snowball's brilliant speeches would win over the majority, but Napoleon was better at canvassing support for himself in between times.

en: He was especially successful with the sheep.
vi: The most loyal to Napoleon were the sheep.
tr: He was particularly good at influencing the sheep.
es: A peculiar incident was the behavior of the sheep, who had taken to bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad” at crucial moments in Snowball's speeches.

en: Of late the sheep had taken to bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad” both in and out of season, and they often interrupted the Meeting with this.
vi: Recently, the sheep often chanted "Four legs good, two legs bad" for any reason or no reason at all, frequently interrupting the Meetings.
tr: The sheep, who had recently developed the habit of bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at every opportunity, were frequently disrupting the meetings.
es: A peculiar incident was the behavior of the sheep, who had taken to bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad” at crucial moments in Snowball's speeches.

en: It was noticed that they were especially liable to break into “Four legs good, two legs bad” at crucial moments in Snowball’s speeches.
vi: Especially during the most important parts of Snowball's speeches, the sheep would invariably shout "Four legs good, two legs bad".
tr: It was particularly noticeable that they would start bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at the most crucial points of Snowball's speeches.
es: It was noticed that they did this especially at critical moments in Snowball's speeches.

en: Snowball had made a close study of some back numbers of the ‘Farmer and Stockbreeder’ which he had found in the farmhouse, and was full of plans for innovations and improvements.
vi: Snowball had studied the "Agriculture and Livestock" magazine found in the main house thoroughly, and his head was full of plans for reforming and modernizing production.
tr: Snowball had read and studied old issues of a magazine called Farmer and Stockbreeder, which he found in the farmhouse, and had come up with a lot of plans for the renovation and improvement of the farm.
es: He had made a close study of some back numbers of the “Farmer and Stockbreeder” which he had found in the farmhouse, and was full of plans for innovations and improvements.

en: He talked learnedly about field drains, silage, and basic slag, and had worked out a complicated scheme for all the animals to drop their dung directly in the fields, at a different spot every day, to save the labour of cartage.
vi: He talked about drainage systems for the fields, silage pits, and phosphate fertilizers for the entire farm; he even drafted a sanitation schedule so that each animal would "go" in a different place each time to save on transportation later.
tr: He gave speeches demonstrating how well he knew topics such as opening water channels in the fields, preserving fodder in silos, and how to make use of manure. He had developed a complex plan for all the animals to defecate directly in the fields, in a different spot each day; this way, they would also save the labor and time spent transporting manure to the fields by cart.
es: He talked learnedly about field drains, silage, and basic slag, and had worked out a complicated scheme for all the animals to drop their dung directly in the fields, at a different spot every day, to save the labor of cartage.

en: Napoleon produced no schemes of his own, but said quietly that Snowball’s would come to nothing, and seemed to be biding his time.
vi: Napoleon, on the other hand, didn't draft anything but whispered to the others that Snowball was just talking nonsense and seemed to be waiting for the right moment to act.
tr: Napoleon, on the other hand, did not come up with a single original idea, quietly spreading the notion that Snowball's plans were useless, as if he were waiting for the right moment.
es: Napoleon had no plans of his own to offer, but said quietly that Snowball's would come to nothing, and seemed to be biding his time.

en: But of all their controversies, none was so bitter as the one that took place over the windmill.
vi: But the fiercest dispute between the two was over the construction of the windmill.
tr: But the fiercest argument between them would break out over the windmill.
es: But of all their controversies, none was so bitter as the one that took place over the windmill.

en: In the long pasture, not far from the farm buildings, there was a small knoll which was the highest point on the farm.
vi: On the grass field, not far from the rows of houses of the farm, there was a small mound, which was also the highest point in the farm.
tr: There was a small hill in the meadow that stretched out just beyond the farm buildings. This was the highest point of the farm.
es: In the long prairie, near the buildings, there was a small hill that was the highest point of the farm.

en: After surveying the ground, Snowball declared that this was just the place for a windmill, which could be made to operate a dynamo and supply the farm with electrical power.
vi: After surveying, Snowball declared that this was the best area to build a windmill, and they would install a generator on it to supply electricity to the entire farm.
tr: After carefully examining the ground, Snowball declared that this was the most suitable place for a windmill. The windmill could operate a dynamo and provide electrical power to the entire farm.
es: After studying the terrain, Snowball declared that this was the ideal place for a windmill, which could be used to run a dynamo and supply electricity to the farm.

en: This would light the stalls and warm them in winter, and would also run a circular saw, a chaff-cutter, a mangel-slicer, and an electric milking machine.
vi: The barns would then have electric lights, and in winter, there would be heaters, not to mention using electricity to run the saw, the grass cutter, the red beet slicer, and the milking machine.
tr: Thus, the barns could be illuminated and heated in winter; tools such as a circular saw, hay and straw cutter, beet slicer, and electric milking machine could be used.
es: This would provide light for the animals' stalls and heat them in winter, and it would also run a circular saw, a thresher, a cutter, an electric milker, etc.

en: The animals had never heard of anything of this kind before (for the farm was an old-fashioned one and had only the most primitive machinery), and they listened in astonishment while Snowball conjured up pictures of fantastic machines which would do their work for them while they grazed at their ease in the fields or improved their minds with reading and conversation.
vi: The animals had never heard of such things before (this farm was quite backward, only having the simplest machines), and they listened in amazement as Snowball enthusiastically talked about the wonderful machines that would do the work for them while they could leisurely graze in the fields or sit reading books and debating to gradually improve their minds.
tr: The animals had never heard of such a thing before (Beilik Farm, being an ancient farm, only had the most primitive tools); they listened to Snowball in astonishment as he conjured up those fantastical devices before their eyes. According to Snowball's descriptions, these incredible devices would handle all the farm's work, and they would lounge in the fields, enjoying themselves, reading books, and engaging in conversations to improve themselves.
es: The animals had never heard of such things (because the farm was old-fashioned and had the most primitive machinery), and they listened in astonishment to Snowball as he described to them pictures of fantastic machinery that would work for them, while they grazed peacefully in the fields or improved their minds through reading and conversation.

en: Within a few weeks Snowball’s plans for the windmill were fully worked out.
vi: Just a few weeks later, Tuyet Tron had completed the technical documents for the windmill project.
tr: Snowball's plans for the windmill were finalized in a few weeks.
es: In a few weeks, Snowball's plans for the windmill were completed.

en: The mechanical details came mostly from three books which had belonged to mr Jones —‘One Thousand Useful Things to Do About the House’, ‘Every Man His Own Bricklayer’, and ‘Electricity for Beginners’.
vi: The detailed mechanical drawings were drafted based on three of Mr. Jones's books: "A Thousand Useful Household Items," "Do-It-Yourself Masonry," and "What a Beginner Electrician Needs to Know."Tuyet Tron used the shed, which was previously an incubation area, as an office because it had a flat wooden floor that was very suitable for technical drawing.
tr: A large portion of the mechanical details were obtained from Mr. Jones's three books: A Thousand and One Tips for Your Home, Do It Yourself Wall Building, and Electricity in Ten Lessons.
es: The technical details came mainly from three books that had belonged to Mr. Jones: "A Thousand Useful Things to Do Around the House," "Every Man His Own Bricklayer," and "Electricity for Beginners."

en: Snowball used as his study a shed which had once been used for incubators and had a smooth wooden floor, suitable for drawing on.
vi: The detailed mechanical drawings were drafted based on three of Mr. Jones's books: "A Thousand Useful Household Items," "Do-It-Yourself Masonry," and "What a Beginner Electrician Needs to Know."Tuyet Tron used the shed, which was previously an incubation area, as an office because it had a flat wooden floor that was very suitable for technical drawing.
tr: Snowball was using the shed, where the incubators once stood and which had a smooth wooden floor suitable for drawing, as his study room.
es: As a study, Snowball used a shed that had once been used for incubators and had a smooth wooden floor, suitable for drawing.

en: He was closeted there for hours at a time.
vi: Tuyet Tron sat in there for hours on end.
tr: Sometimes he would lock himself in the shed for hours.
es: He would lock himself in there for hours on end.

en: With his books held open by a stone, and with a piece of chalk gripped between the knuckles of his trotter, he would move rapidly to and fro, drawing in line after line and uttering little whimpers of excitement.
vi: It placed a stone on the necessary book page, held a piece of chalk with one foot; it hopped back and forth, drawing as it hopped, sometimes squealing softly in delight.
tr: He placed weights on the pages of the books he laid on the ground, held a piece of chalk between the hooves of his front foot, and as he quickly made the drawings, he would get so excited that he was out of breath, making short, gasping sounds from his throat.
es: He kept his books open with a stone and, wielding a piece of chalk, moved quickly from side to side, drawing line after line and uttering small squeals of enthusiasm.

en: Gradually the plans grew into a complicated mass of cranks and cog-wheels, covering more than half the floor, which the other animals found completely unintelligible but very impressive.
