vi: Gradually, the drawings, consisting of numerous interlocking shafts and gears, covered nearly half of the shed, and although the other animals didn't understand them, they were extremely impressed.
tr: Snowball's drawings gradually turned into a complex heap of levers and gears, covering more than half of the shed. The other animals did not understand any of this, but they found it very impressive.
es: Gradually, his plans transformed into a complicated mass of cranks and gears that covered more than half of the floor, which the other animals found completely indecipherable but very impressive.

en: All of them came to look at Snowball’s drawings at least once a day.
vi: Every day, the animals came to look at Tuyet Tron's drawings at least once.
tr: They came to look at Snowball's drawings at least once a day.
es: Everyone went to look at Snowball's plans at least once a day.

en: Even the hens and ducks came, and were at pains not to tread on the chalk marks.
vi: Even the chickens and ducks came, but they stood at a distance to avoid stepping on the chalk drawings.
tr: The chickens and ducks also came, struggling not to step on the chalk-drawn lines.
es: Even the hens and ducks did so and took great care not to step on the chalk marks.

en: Only Napoleon held aloof.
vi: Only Napoleon didn't care at all.
tr: Only Napoleon, who had declared his opposition to the windmill from the very beginning, stayed away from there.
es: Only Napoleon kept his distance.

en: He had declared himself against the windmill from the start.
vi: He opposed it from the beginning.
tr: Only Napoleon, who had declared his opposition to the windmill from the very beginning, stayed away from there.
es: He had declared himself against the windmill from the beginning.

en: One day, however, he arrived unexpectedly to examine the plans.
vi: Nevertheless, one day he came to inspect the project without informing any of the animals beforehand.
tr: But he couldn't resist; one day, out of the blue, he came to see the drawings.
es: One day, however, he unexpectedly came with the purpose of examining the plans.

en: He walked heavily round the shed, looked closely at every detail of the plans and snuffed at them once or twice, then stood for a little while contemplating them out of the corner of his eye; then suddenly he lifted his leg, urinated over the plans, and walked out without uttering a word.
vi: He walked around the shed, then went in to scrutinize the drawings, sniffing here and there, then lifted his leg and urinated on them, after which he calmly walked out without saying a word.
tr: He slowly wandered inside the shed, examined every detail of the drawings at length, sniffed and prodded them several times, stood there for a while watching out of the corner of his eye, then suddenly lifted his leg and urinated on the drawings, and left without saying a single word.
es: He walked heavily around, carefully observed every detail, and even sniffed once or twice; then he stood for a while, glancing at them sideways; then, suddenly, he lifted his leg, urinated on the plans, and walked away without saying a word.

en: The whole farm was deeply divided on the subject of the windmill.
vi: Due to the construction of the windmill, the farm was divided into two opposing factions.
tr: The windmill issue had led to a deep division on the farm.
es: The entire farm was very divided on the matter of the windmill.

en: Snowball did not deny that to build it would be a difficult business.
vi: Snowball did not hide the fact that building the windmill would require a great sacrifice.
tr: Snowball did not deny that building the windmill would be very difficult.
es: Snowball did not deny that the construction would mean difficult work.

en: Stone would have to be carried and built up into walls, then the sails would have to be made and after that there would be need for dynamos and cables.
vi: They would have to quarry and transport stone to the site, then build, and only after that install the blades, motor, and electrical wiring (how to obtain those things, Snowball did not say).
tr: Stones would have to be carried from the quarry, walls built, the windmill's blades made, and then dynamos and cables would need to be found.
es: They would have to extract stones from the quarry and with them build walls, then construct the blades, and after all that, they would need dynamos and cables (how they would obtain those things, Snowball did not say).

en: (How these were to be procured, Snowball did not say.)
vi: They would have to quarry and transport stone to the site, then build, and only after that install the blades, motor, and electrical wiring (how to obtain those things, Snowball did not say).
tr: (Snowball never mentioned how all these tasks would be accomplished)
es: They would have to extract stones from the quarry and with them build walls, then construct the blades, and after all that, they would need dynamos and cables (how they would obtain those things, Snowball did not say).

en: But he maintained that it could all be done in a year.
vi: But he still asserted that the project could be completed within a year.
tr: He merely claimed that all the work would be completed within a year.
es: But he maintained that everything could be done in a year.

en: And thereafter, he declared, so much labour would be saved that the animals would only need to work three days a week.
vi: After that, he declared, the workload would decrease significantly, and they would only have to work three days a week.
tr: According to him, once the windmill was completed, work would become so easy that the animals would only need to work three days a week.
es: And henceforth, he declared, so much work would be saved that the animals would only have three working days per week.

en: Napoleon, on the other hand, argued that the great need of the moment was to increase food production, and that if they wasted time on the windmill they would all starve to death.
vi: On the other hand, Napoleon argued that the most important task at present was food production, and if they wasted time on building the windmill, they would starve.
tr: In contrast, Napoleon argued that their greatest need was to increase food production and that if time was wasted on the windmill, everyone would die of starvation.
es: Napoleon, on the other hand, maintained that the great need of the moment was to increase food production, and that if they wasted time on the windmill, they would all starve to death.

en: The animals formed themselves into two factions under the slogan, “Vote for Snowball and the three-day week” and “Vote for Napoleon and the full manger.”
vi: The animals divided into two factions; one faction adopted the slogan: "Support Snowball and three days of work a week"; the other adopted the slogan: "Support Napoleon and a full belly."
tr: The animals had split into two factions under the slogans "Vote for Snowball and work three days a week!" and "Vote for Napoleon and never go hungry!"
es: The animals grouped into two factions under the slogans: "Vote for Snowball and the three-day week" and "Vote for Napoleon and the full manger."

en: Benjamin was the only animal who did not side with either faction.
vi: Only Benjamin did not join any faction.
tr: The only animal who remained outside the factions was Benjamin.
es: Benjamin was the only animal who did not enlist in either of the two sides.

en: He refused to believe either that food would become more plentiful or that the windmill would save work.
vi: He did not believe that food would become abundant, nor did he believe that the windmill would help reduce manual labor.
tr: He believed neither in the coming of abundance nor that the windmill would make things easier.
es: He refused to believe that there would be more abundance of food or that the windmill would save work.

en: Windmill or no windmill, he said, life would go on as it had always gone on — that is, badly.
vi: With or without the windmill, it would be the same; they had lived as they did and would continue to live that way, meaning they would still suffer.
tr: "Whether there is a windmill or not, nothing will change in our miserable lives," he said.
es: "With windmill or without windmill," he said, "life will go on as it always has, that is, a disaster."

en: Apart from the disputes over the windmill, there was the question of the defence of the farm.
vi: Besides the windmill, they also argued about defense.
tr: While the windmill debates continued, there was also the issue of defending the farm.
es: Apart from the discussions regarding the windmill, there was the issue of the farm's defense.

en: It was fully realised that though the human beings had been defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed they might make another and more determined attempt to recapture the farm and reinstate mr Jones.
vi: Everyone understood that although humans were defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed, they would certainly fight another battle, this one fiercer, to reclaim the farm for Mr. Jones.
tr: Despite having been defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed, it was now understood by all the animals that the humans might make a second, more determined attempt to recapture the farm and return it to Mr. Jones.
es: It was perfectly understood that although the humans had been defeated in the "Battle of the Cowshed," they might make another attempt, more determined than the previous one, to reclaim the farm and restore Mr. Jones.

en: They had all the more reason for doing so because the news of their defeat had spread across the countryside and made the animals on the neighbouring farms more restive than ever.
vi: People were bound to do so because rumors of the humans' great defeat had spread throughout the countryside, and the animals in other farms had now become more rebellious than ever.
tr: The news of their defeat had spread to all the villages, causing the animals on neighboring farms to become even more rebellious; thus, the likelihood of the humans launching another attack had increased.
es: They had even greater reasons to do so, as the news of the defeat spread around and had made the animals more discontented than ever.

en: As usual, Snowball and Napoleon were in disagreement.
vi: As always, Snowball and Napoleon could not find common ground.
tr: Snowball and Napoleon, as with everything else, could not agree on this matter either.
es: As usual, Snowball and Napoleon were in disagreement.

en: According to Napoleon, what the animals must do was to procure firearms and train themselves in the use of them.
vi: According to Napoleon, the first thing to do was to purchase and learn to use firearms.
tr: According to Napoleon, the animals needed to find firearms from somewhere and learn how to use them.
es: According to Napoleon, what the animals should do was procure firearms and train themselves in their use.

en: According to Snowball, they must send out more and more pigeons and stir up rebellion among the animals on the other farms.
vi: According to Snowball, the urgent task now was to send flocks of pigeons to other farms to incite rebellions there.
tr: Snowball, on the other hand, believed that they should send more pigeons to the other farms and incite the animals to rebel.
es: Snowball believed they should send more and more pigeons and incite rebellion among the animals on the other farms.

en: The one argued that if they could not defend themselves they were bound to be conquered, the other argued that if rebellions happened everywhere they would have no need to defend themselves.
vi: One believed that if they could not defend themselves, they would certainly be conquered by humans, while the other argued that if rebellions broke out everywhere, there would be no need for defense.
tr: One argued that if they couldn't defend themselves, they would inevitably be defeated in the end; the other said that if uprisings broke out everywhere, there would be no need to defend themselves.
es: One argued that if they couldn't defend themselves, they were destined to be conquered; the other argued that if there were rebellions everywhere, they wouldn't need to defend themselves.

en: The animals listened first to Napoleon, then to Snowball, and could not make up their minds which was right; indeed, they always found themselves in agreement with the one who was speaking at the moment.
vi: The animals listened to Napoleon and then to Snowball, but could not decide who was right; in fact, whoever was speaking at the moment seemed right to them, as they had no firm opinions of their own.
tr: The animals listened to Napoleon and Snowball in turn, but they couldn't decide who was right. More precisely, they agreed with whoever was speaking at the time.
es: The animals listened first to Napoleon, then to Snowball, and couldn't decide who was right; to be honest, they always agreed with whoever was speaking to them at the moment.

en: At last the day came when Snowball’s plans were completed.
vi: Finally, Snowball completed all the drawings for his project.
tr: In the end, Snowball's plans came true.
es: Finally, the day arrived when Snowball completed his plans.

en: At the Meeting on the following Sunday the question of whether or not to begin work on the windmill was to be put to the vote.
vi: In the meeting on Sunday, the issue of building the windmill was put to a vote.
tr: In the Meeting to be held next Sunday, the proposal to start the construction of the windmill would be put to a vote.
es: At the next Sunday Meeting, it would be put to a vote whether or not to start building the windmill.

en: When the animals had assembled in the big barn, Snowball stood up and, though occasionally interrupted by bleating from the sheep, set forth his reasons for advocating the building of the windmill.
vi: All the animals gathered in the large barn, Snowball spoke first and although he was occasionally interrupted by the sheep, he convincingly presented the benefits of the windmill.
tr: When the animals gathered in the big barn, Snowball stood up and, despite his speech being interrupted by the bleating of the sheep, he listed the reasons why the windmill should be built.
es: When the animals were gathered in the main barn, Snowball stood up and, although he was occasionally interrupted by the sheep's bleating, he laid out his reasons for defending the construction of the windmill.

en: Then Napoleon stood up to reply.
vi: Then it was Napoleon's turn.
tr: Then, Napoleon stood up to respond.
es: Then Napoleon stood up to respond.

en: He said very quietly that the windmill was nonsense and that he advised nobody to vote for it, and promptly sat down again; he had spoken for barely thirty seconds, and seemed almost indifferent as to the effect he produced.
vi: He calmly declared that the windmill was nonsense and advised everyone not to support the project; he spoke for only about thirty seconds and then sat down calmly, seemingly indifferent to the effect he had on the audience.
tr: In a very calm voice, he said that the windmill was nothing but nonsense, that he could not advise anyone to vote for the windmill, and immediately sat down. His speech had not even lasted half a minute; he seemed unaware of the impact of his words.
es: He calmly said that the windmill was nonsense and that he advised no one to vote for it. And he sat down immediately; he had spoken for barely thirty seconds, and he seemed indifferent to the effect he had produced.

en: At this Snowball sprang to his feet, and shouting down the sheep, who had begun bleating again, broke into a passionate appeal in favour of the windmill.
vi: Snowball stood up on his hind legs and immediately delivered a passionate speech to persuade the others to vote for the construction of the windmill, speaking so loudly that he drowned out the sheep.
tr: Upon this, Snowball jumped up, silencing the sheep who had started bleating again, and delivered a passionate speech about the benefits of the windmill.
es: Next, Snowball jumped to his feet, and shouting to be heard despite the sheep, who had started bleating again, he launched into a passionate argument in favor of the windmill.

en: Until now the animals had been about equally divided in their sympathies, but in a moment Snowball’s eloquence had carried them away.
vi: Previously, the farm was divided into two equal factions, but this time Snowball had convinced the majority to support him.
tr: Until that moment, the number of animals in favor of the windmill and those against it seemed roughly equal, but Snowball's eloquence quickly broke the tie.
es: Until then, the animals were more or less equally divided in their sympathies, but in an instant, Snowball's eloquence had convinced them.

en: In glowing sentences he painted a picture of Animal Farm as it might be when sordid labour was lifted from the animals’ backs.
vi: He spoke about the future of Animal Farm, a very bright future where manual labor would no longer weigh heavily on their backs.
tr: With brilliant words, Snowball painted a picture of an Animal Farm where the animals would be freed from working like slaves, and his imagination now extended far beyond chaff cutters and beet slicers.
es: With fiery phrases, he painted a picture of what "Animal Farm" could be like when the vile labor was lifted from the animals' backs.

en: His imagination had now run far beyond chaff-cutters and turnip-slicers.
vi: His imagination went beyond straw cutters and beet slicers.
tr: With brilliant words, Snowball painted a picture of an Animal Farm where the animals would be freed from working like slaves, and his imagination now extended far beyond chaff cutters and beet slicers.
es: His imagination had gone far beyond threshers and reapers.

en: Electricity, he said, could operate threshing machines, ploughs, harrows, rollers, and reapers and binders, besides supplying every stall with its own electric light, hot and cold water, and an electric heater.
vi: Electricity, he said, could power threshers, plows, harrows, rollers; it could also provide lighting, hot water, cold water, and heating for all the stalls.
tr: He said that threshing machines, plows, harrows, rollers, reapers, and binders would all be powered by electricity, and that every barn would have its own light, hot and cold water, and its own electric heater.
es: "Electricity," he said, "could power the threshers, plows, harrows, rollers, reapers, and binders, as well as provide each stall with its own electric light, cold and hot water, and an electric heater."

en: By the time he had finished speaking, there was no doubt as to which way the vote would go.
vi: The result of the vote was clear even before Snowball finished his speech.
tr: When he finished his speech, there was no doubt left about where the votes would go.
es: When he finished speaking, there was no doubt about the outcome of the vote.

en: But just at this moment Napoleon stood up and, casting a peculiar sidelong look at Snowball, uttered a high-pitched whimper of a kind no one had ever heard him utter before.
vi: But just at that moment, Napoleon stood up, glanced sharply at Snowball, and let out a high-pitched squeal like a whistle, a sound none of them had ever heard before.
tr: But just at that moment, Napoleon stood up, glanced sideways at Snowball, and let out a high-pitched scream that no one had ever heard before.
es: But immediately Napoleon stood up and, casting a strange sidelong glance at Snowball, let out a high-pitched, shrill squeal that had never been heard from him before.

en: At this there was a terrible baying sound outside, and nine enormous dogs wearing brass-studded collars came bounding into the barn.
vi: There was a loud barking outside, then a pack of nine extremely large dogs with brass collars charged into the barn.
tr: At that moment, terrifying barks were heard from outside, and soon nine large dogs with spiked collars burst in like a spear.
es: Immediately afterwards, terrible barking was heard coming from outside, and nine enormous dogs wearing collars studded with nails burst into the barn.

en: They dashed straight for Snowball, who only sprang from his place just in time to escape their snapping jaws.
vi: They rushed straight at Snowball, but luckily he dodged their snapping jaws.
tr: They lunged straight at Snowball. If Snowball hadn't leaped out of the way just in time, he would have been devoured by the ferociously attacking dogs.
es: And they went straight for Snowball, who jumped from his spot just in time to dodge their ferocious fangs.

en: In a moment he was out of the door and they were after him.
vi: Snowball hurriedly ran outside with the pack of dogs chasing after him.
tr: He immediately threw himself outside, with the dogs in pursuit.
es: In an instant, he was on the other side of the door with the dogs after him.

en: Too amazed and frightened to speak, all the animals crowded through the door to watch the chase.
vi: The remaining animals were extremely surprised and frightened, and they all rushed to the door to watch the chase.
tr: The animals, struck dumb with astonishment and fear, crowded at the door and began to watch the chase.
es: Too astonished and scared to say anything, all the animals crowded at the door to watch the chase.

en: Snowball was racing across the long pasture that led to the road.
vi: Snowball ran across the meadow towards the main road.
tr: Snowball was running as fast as a pig could run, trying to cross the meadow and reach the main road.
es: Snowball was running at full speed across the long meadow that led to the road.

en: He was running as only a pig can run, but the dogs were close on his heels.
vi: He ran for his life while the pack of dogs kept right on his heels.
tr: But the dogs were right on his heels.
es: He ran as only a pig can, but the dogs were hot on his heels.

en: Suddenly he slipped and it seemed certain that they had him.
vi: Suddenly, he slipped, and it seemed like the dogs would catch him any moment.
tr: Suddenly, he slipped and fell; just when everyone thought he was surely caught, he got back up and started running even faster.
es: Suddenly, he slipped and seemed to be easy prey for the dogs, but as soon as he regained his balance, he kept running faster than ever, though the hounds were gaining on him again.

en: Then he was up again, running faster than ever, then the dogs were gaining on him again.
vi: But he managed to get back up, this time running even faster with the dogs still in close pursuit.
tr: The dogs were like a storm, they were about to catch their prey.
es: Suddenly, he slipped and seemed to be easy prey for the dogs, but as soon as he regained his balance, he kept running faster than ever, though the hounds were gaining on him again.

en: One of them all but closed his jaws on Snowball’s tail, but Snowball whisked it free just in time.
vi: It seemed as if one of the dogs had caught Snowball's tail, but he managed to flick it to the side just in time.
tr: One of them was just about to grab his tail, but Snowball pulled it away just in time.
es: One of them was about to close its jaws on Snowball's tail, but he managed to dodge the bite just in time.

en: Then he put on an extra spurt and, with a few inches to spare, slipped through a hole in the hedge and was seen no more.
vi: He sped up again, this time gaining some distance from the dogs, and then he squeezed through a hole in the fence. None of the dogs could see Snowball anymore.
tr: With the dogs nearly an inch away from him, he made one last effort and dashed forward, escaping through one of the holes in the fence. Snowball was never seen again.
es: And with a supreme effort, he managed to slip through a hole in the hedge, thus putting himself out of danger.

en: Silent and terrified, the animals crept back into the barn.
vi: Extremely frightened, the animals silently turned back to the barn.
tr: The animals, silent and cowed, returned to the barn.
es: Silent and terrified, the animals stealthily returned to the barn.

en: In a moment the dogs came bounding back.
vi: The hunting dogs also returned shortly after.
tr: Soon after, the dogs came running.
es: The dogs also returned, leaping about.

en: At first no one had been able to imagine where these creatures came from, but the problem was soon solved: they were the puppies whom Napoleon had taken away from their mothers and reared privately.
vi: At first, each one wondered: where did those dogs come from? But then it was no longer a secret: these dogs had been taken by Napoleon when they were young and raised separately.
tr: At first, no one could understand where these monsters had come from, but the truth soon emerged. These were the pups that Napoleon had separated from their mothers and specially trained.
es: At first, no one could imagine where those beasts had come from, but the problem was quickly clarified; they were the puppies that Napoleon had taken from their mothers and raised in seclusion.

en: Though not yet full-grown, they were huge dogs, and as fierce-looking as wolves.
vi: Though not fully grown, they looked big and fierce like wolves.
tr: Although they were not fully grown, they were quite large; they looked as wild as wolves.
es: Although they were not yet fully grown, they were immense dogs, fierce as wolves.

en: They kept close to Napoleon.
vi: They stood right next to Napoleon.
tr: They never left Napoleon's side.
es: They never strayed far from Napoleon.

en: It was noticed that they wagged their tails to him in the same way as the other dogs had been used to do to mr Jones.
vi: They also wagged their tails at Napoleon just like the others used to do for Mr. Jones.
tr: Just as the other dogs had fawned over Mr. Jones, it did not escape anyone's notice that they wagged their tails at Napoleon.
es: And it was observed that they wagged their tails before him as the other dogs used to do with Mr. Jones.

en: Napoleon, with the dogs following him, now mounted on to the raised portion of the floor where Major had previously stood to deliver his speech.
vi: Napoleon, escorted by the dogs, stepped onto the platform where the Leader used to speak.
tr: Napoleon, with his dogs behind him, climbed to the elevation where once the Great Leader had given speeches and announced that the Sunday morning meetings would be discontinued:
es: Napoleon, with the dogs behind him, climbed onto the platform that Major had occupied when he delivered his historic speech.

en: He announced that from now on the Sunday-morning Meetings would come to an end.
vi: He declared that from now on, the weekly Sunday Meetings would be abolished.
tr: Napoleon, with his dogs behind him, climbed to the elevation where once the Great Leader had given speeches and announced that the Sunday morning meetings would be discontinued:
es: He announced that from that moment on, the Sunday morning meetings were over.

en: They were unnecessary, he said, and wasted time.
vi: He said that those Meetings were pointless and only a waste of time.
tr: These unnecessary meetings were nothing but a waste of time.
es: They were unnecessary, he said, and wasted time.

en: In future all questions relating to the working of the farm would be settled by a special committee of pigs, presided over by himself.
vi: From now on, matters related to the farm's work would be resolved by a committee of pigs with Napoleon as the chairman.
tr: Henceforth, all issues regarding the operation of the farm would be resolved by a special committee of pigs, presided over by himself.
es: In the future, all matters related to the governance of the farm would be resolved by a special committee of pigs, presided over by him.

en: These would meet in private and afterwards communicate their decisions to the others.
vi: These would be closed Meetings, and the resolutions would be announced to the entire farm afterward.
tr: The committee would discuss the issues in closed sessions and later communicate the decisions to the other animals.
es: They would meet in council and then communicate their decisions to the others.

en: The animals would still assemble on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing ‘Beasts of England’, and receive their orders for the week; but there would be no more debates.
vi: The animals would still gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing "Beasts of England," and receive their work assignments for the following week, but there would be no more discussions.
tr: The animals would still gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing the "Beasts of England" song, and receive weekly orders, but debates would no longer be permitted.
es: The animals would gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing "Beasts of England," and receive their orders for the week; but there would be no more debates.

en: In spite of the shock that Snowball’s expulsion had given them, the animals were dismayed by this announcement.
vi: Although shocked by Tuyet Tron’s expulsion, the decision to cancel the discussions left everyone completely disappointed.
tr: The animals, who had not yet recovered from the shock of Snowball's expulsion, fell into even deeper despair at this explanation.
es: If the expulsion of Snowball had made a great impression on them, this announcement dismayed the animals.

en: Several of them would have protested if they could have found the right arguments.
vi: Some of them would certainly protest if they could find a plausible argument.
tr: Some of them would have protested if they could find a proper reason.
es: Some of them would have protested if they had the appropriate arguments.

en: Even Boxer was vaguely troubled.
vi: Even Vo Si felt uneasy.
tr: Even Boxer was uneasy.
es: Even Boxer was a bit stunned.

en: He set his ears back, shook his forelock several times, and tried hard to marshal his thoughts; but in the end he could not think of anything to say.
vi: He pricked up his ears, shook his mane a few times, thoughts jumping around, and despite trying very hard, he still didn't know what to say.
tr: He laid his ears back, shook his mane, and tried to gather his thoughts; but he couldn't find anything to say.
es: He pricked his ears back, shook his mane several times, and tried hard to organize his thoughts; but in the end, he couldn't think of anything to say.

en: Some of the pigs themselves, however, were more articulate.
vi: But the pigs were more articulate.
tr: Some of the pigs, however, did not hesitate to express their thoughts openly.
es: Some pigs, however, were more expressive.

en: Four young porkers in the front row uttered shrill squeals of disapproval, and all four of them sprang to their feet and began speaking at once.
vi: The four porkers in the front row shouted in protest, then all four jumped up and spoke in unison.
tr: The four young pigs in the front row all stood up together and loudly declared that they did not approve of what was happening.
es: Four young pigs in the front row emitted sharp cries of disapproval, and they all stood up abruptly and began to speak at the same time.

en: But suddenly the dogs sitting round Napoleon let out deep, menacing growls, and the pigs fell silent and sat down again.
vi: But the dogs surrounding Napoleon barked loudly, and those pigs had to shut their mouths and quietly return to their places.
tr: But when the dogs lying at Napoleon's feet suddenly growled in a frightening manner, they had to fall silent and sit back down.
es: But suddenly, the dogs sitting around Napoleon let out deep, threatening growls, and the pigs fell silent, sitting back down.

en: Then the sheep broke out into a tremendous bleating of “Four legs good, two legs bad!” which went on for nearly a quarter of an hour and put an end to any chance of discussion.
vi: Then the sheep started their chant of "Four legs good, two legs bad," which lasted about fifteen minutes, ending all discussions.
tr: At that moment, the sheep also began to bleat, "Four legs good, two legs bad!" in a deafening chorus. The demonstration went on so long that there was no opportunity to discuss the matter.
es: Then the sheep burst out with a tremendous bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad!" which continued for almost a quarter of an hour and ended all attempts at discussion.

en: Afterwards Squealer was sent round the farm to explain the new arrangement to the others.
vi: Chỉ Điểm was sent to explain to the others.
tr: After a while, Squealer was given the task of touring the farm and explaining the new order to the other animals.
es: Then Squealer was sent all over the farm to explain the new decisions to the others.

en: “Comrades,” he said, “I trust that every animal here appreciates the sacrifice that Comrade Napoleon has made in taking this extra labour upon himself.
vi: "Comrades," said Chỉ Điểm, "I hope that all of you appreciate the sacrifice of Comrade Napoleon when he took on the responsibility of leading the farm.
tr: "Comrades," said Squealer, "I have no doubt that all the animals here understand very well the great sacrifice Comrade Napoleon has made by taking on such a duty.
es: —Comrades —he said—, I hope that all the animals present will realize and appreciate the sacrifice that Comrade Napoleon has made by taking on this additional work.

en: Do not imagine, comrades, that leadership is a pleasure!
vi: Do not think that leadership is an easy task!
tr: Comrades, do not think that leadership is about lying back and enjoying oneself.
es: Do not think, comrades, that being a leader is a pleasure!

en: On the contrary, it is a deep and heavy responsibility.
vi: On the contrary, it is an extremely heavy and difficult responsibility.
tr: On the contrary, leadership imposes a very heavy responsibility.
es: On the contrary, it is a deep and heavy responsibility.

en: No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon that all animals are equal.
vi: None of us believe as deeply as Comrade Napoleon that all animals are born equal.
tr: Among us, it is Comrade Napoleon who most believes that all animals are equal.
es: No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon in the principle that all animals are equal.

en: He would be only too happy to let you make your decisions for yourselves.
vi: He would be very happy if you could decide your own fate.
tr: He would be very happy to allow you to make decisions on your own.
es: He would be very happy to let you make your own decisions.

en: But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades, and then where should we be?
vi: But who can guarantee that sometimes you will not make the wrong decision, and what will happen to our farm then?
tr: But comrades, sometimes you might make wrong decisions, and then what would become of us?
es: But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades. And where would we be then?

en: Suppose you had decided to follow Snowball, with his moonshine of windmills — Snowball, who, as we now know, was no better than a criminal?”
vi: For example, what if you follow Snowball with his fanciful windmill, follow someone whose actions are no different from a criminal?"
tr: For example, if you had decided to follow Snowball, who advocated that windmill nonsense, what would we have done? Hasn't it now become clear that Snowball is nothing but a traitor?"
es: Suppose you had decided to follow Snowball, with his ridiculous windmills; Snowball, who, as we now know, was nothing more than a criminal…

en: “He fought bravely at the Battle of the Cowshed,” said somebody.
vi: "He fought bravely in the Cow Shed Campaign," someone spoke up.
tr: One of the animals said, "Snowball fought bravely in the Battle of the Cowshed."
es: —He fought valiantly in the "Battle of the Cow Shed" —someone said.

en: “Bravery is not enough,” said Squealer.
vi: "Courage alone is not enough," Chỉ Điểm said, "Loyalty and obedience are even more important.
tr: "Bravery is not enough," replied Squealer.
es: —Bravery is not enough —affirmed Squealer—.

en: “Loyalty and obedience are more important.
vi: "Courage alone is not enough," Chỉ Điểm said, "Loyalty and obedience are even more important.
tr: "Loyalty and obedience are more important.
es: Loyalty and obedience are more important.

en: And as to the Battle of the Cowshed, I believe the time will come when we shall find that Snowball’s part in it was much exaggerated.
vi: Speaking of the Cow Shed Campaign, I believe there will come a time when we see that Tuyết Tròn's role has been grossly exaggerated.
tr: As for the Battle of the Cowshed; I believe that one day you will understand that Snowball's role in this battle has been greatly exaggerated.
es: And as for the "Battle of the Cowshed," I believe that the day will come when we will prove that the role played by Snowball has been greatly exaggerated.

en: Discipline, comrades, iron discipline!
vi: Discipline, comrades, iron discipline!
tr: Discipline, comrades, iron discipline!
es: Discipline, comrades, iron discipline!

en: That is the watchword for today.
vi: That is our slogan in the current phase.
tr: Today, this should be our motto.
es: That is the watchword for today.

en: One false step, and our enemies would be upon us.
vi: Just one misstep and the enemy will attack immediately.
tr: If we take a single wrong step, our enemies will be upon us immediately.
es: One misstep, and our enemies would fall upon us.

en: Surely, comrades, you do not want Jones back?”
vi: Surely you don't want old Jones to come back, do you?"
tr: Comrades, surely you do not want Jones to come back!"
es: Surely, comrades, you do not want the return of Jones, do you?

en: Once again this argument was unanswerable.
vi: Its argument was indeed hard to refute.
tr: This question also remained unanswered.
es: Once again, this argument proved irrefutable.

en: Certainly the animals did not want Jones back; if the holding of debates on Sunday mornings was liable to bring him back, then the debates must stop.
vi: Surely, none of them wanted Mr. Jones to come back, and if the Sunday debates gave him an excuse to return, they would stop arguing.
tr: Of course, they did not want Jones to come back; if the meetings held on Sunday mornings had the potential to lead to Jones's return, the discussions undoubtedly had to be stopped.
es: It was clear that the animals did not want Jones to return; if holding debates on Sunday mornings could imply his return, then the debates had to be abolished.

en: Boxer, who had now had time to think things over, voiced the general feeling by saying: “If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right.”
vi: Boxer thought it over carefully and spoke on behalf of everyone: "Comrade Napoleon is always right. Comrade Napoleon is never wrong."
tr: Boxer, who was turning over the events in his mind, expressed everyone's thoughts: "If Comrade Napoleon says so, then it is so."
es: Boxer, who had had time to coordinate his thoughts, expressed the general opinion by saying: "If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right."

en: And from then on he adopted the maxim, “Napoleon is always right,” in addition to his private motto of “I will work harder.”
vi: From then on, besides "I will try harder", Chiến Sĩ also had a new slogan: "Comrade Napoleon is always right".
tr: From that day on, in addition to the motto he adopted for himself, "I will work harder," he also took up the saying, "Napoleon is always right."
es: And from that moment on, he adopted the slogan: "Napoleon is always right," in addition to his personal motto: "I will work harder."

en: By this time the weather had broken and the spring ploughing had begun.
vi: The weather has gradually warmed up, marking the start of a new plowing season.
tr: With the arrival of spring, the weather had warmed up, and the fields had begun to be plowed.
es: By then the weather had changed and the spring plowing had begun.

en: The shed where Snowball had drawn his plans of the windmill had been shut up and it was assumed that the plans had been rubbed off the floor.
vi: The warehouse, where Tuyet Tron designed the windmill, has been closed, and perhaps the drawings have also been erased.
tr: The shed where Snowball had made the windmill drawings was closed, and if the rumors were true, the drawings on the ground had also been erased.
es: The shed where Snowball had drawn the plans for the windmill was closed, and it was assumed that the plans had been erased from the floor.

en: Every Sunday morning at ten o’clock the animals assembled in the big barn to receive their orders for the week.
vi: Every Sunday at ten in the morning, the animals gather in the large barn to receive production tasks for the following week.
tr: The animals gathered in the big barn every Sunday morning at ten o'clock to receive the weekly orders.
es: Every Sunday at ten in the morning, the animals gathered in the main barn to receive their orders for the week.

en: The skull of old Major, now clean of flesh, had been disinterred from the orchard and set up on a stump at the foot of the flagstaff, beside the gun.
vi: The Leader's skull, now just bones, was dug up and placed on a tree stump, next to the gun, at the foot of the flagpole.
tr: The skull of Old Major, now completely dried out, had been dug up from where it was buried in the orchard and placed on a stump next to the flagpole, beside the gun.
es: The skull of Old Major, now devoid of flesh, had been unearthed from the orchard and placed on a post at the foot of the flagpole, next to the shotgun.

en: After the hoisting of the flag, the animals were required to file past the skull in a reverent manner before entering the barn.
vi: After attending the flag-raising ceremony, the animals must solemnly march past the Leader's skull before entering the barn.
tr: After the flag was hoisted, the animals had to pass respectfully in front of the skull before entering the barn.
es: After raising the flag, the animals had to parade reverently past the skull before entering the barn.

en: Nowadays they did not sit all together as they had done in the past.
vi: Now they no longer sit mixed together as they used to.
tr: In the barn, they no longer sat together as they used to.
es: They no longer sat all together as they used to.

en: Napoleon, with Squealer and another pig named Minimus, who had a remarkable gift for composing songs and poems, sat on the front of the raised platform, with the nine young dogs forming a semicircle round them, and the other pigs sitting behind.
vi: Napoleon, Chỉ Điểm, and Kế Tục, a pig with a talent for composing songs and poems, sat on the wooden platform, nine dogs forming a semicircle around them, with the other pigs sitting behind.
tr: Napoleon sat in front of the raised platform; a pig named Minimus, who had an extraordinary talent for writing poetry and composing songs, and Squealer sat on either side of him. Nine young dogs formed a semicircle around them, while the other pigs sat further back.
es: Napoleon, with Squealer and another pig named Minimus, who had an extraordinary gift for composing songs and poems, sat on the platform, with the nine dogs forming a semicircle around them, and the other pigs positioned behind them.

en: The rest of the animals sat facing them in the main body of the barn.
vi: The remaining animals sat on the floor.
tr: All the remaining animals lined up facing them, opposite the raised platform.
es: The other animals placed themselves in front, in the main body of the barn.

en: Napoleon read out the orders for the week in a gruff soldierly style, and after a single singing of ‘Beasts of England’, all the animals dispersed.
vi: Napoleon read out the work assignments for the following week, then they sang "Beasts of England" once and dispersed.
tr: Napoleon read the weekly orders in a stern, military-like voice, the song "Beasts of England" was sung once, and then everyone dispersed.
es: Napoleon read them the orders for the week in a harsh military style, and after singing "Beasts of England" once, all the animals dispersed.

en: On the third Sunday after Snowball’s expulsion, the animals were somewhat surprised to hear Napoleon announce that the windmill was to be built after all.
vi: On the third Sunday since Snowball's expulsion, the animals suddenly heard Napoleon declare that the windmill must be built.
tr: It had only been three Sundays since Snowball was expelled from the farm. When Napoleon suddenly announced that the windmill had to be built, all the animals were stunned.
es: On the third Sunday after Snowball's expulsion, the animals were somewhat surprised to hear Napoleon announce that, after all, the windmill would be built.

en: He did not give any reason for having changed his mind, but merely warned the animals that this extra task would mean very hard work, it might even be necessary to reduce their rations.
vi: He did not explain why he changed his decision, but said that this task would require everyone to make great efforts and sacrifices, including the possibility of reducing daily rations.
tr: Napoleon did not explain the reason for this sudden change of mind, he only warned everyone that this heavy task would require very hard work; even the reduction of rations might be in question.
es: He gave no explanation for this change of mind, but simply warned the animals that this extraordinary task would mean very hard work; it might be necessary to reduce their rations.

en: The plans, however, had all been prepared, down to the last detail.
vi: The project had been detailed to the last detail.
tr: But the plans were prepared down to the finest details.
es: The plans, however, had been prepared down to the smallest detail.

en: A special committee of pigs had been at work upon them for the past three weeks.
vi: A committee of pigs had been studying this project for the past three weeks.
tr: A special committee of pigs had been brainstorming for three weeks.
es: A special committee of pigs had been working on them for the past three weeks.

en: The building of the windmill, with various other improvements, was expected to take two years.
vi: The construction of the windmill and other auxiliary works could take up to two years.
tr: The construction of the windmill, with some modifications, could take two years.
es: The construction of the windmill, along with other planned improvements, would require two years of work.

en: That evening Squealer explained privately to the other animals that Napoleon had never in reality been opposed to the windmill.
vi: In the afternoon, Squealer came to explain to each animal that actually Napoleon was not opposed to the construction of the windmill.
tr: That evening, Squealer told the other animals that Napoleon had never actually opposed the windmill project.
es: That very night, Squealer privately explained to the other animals that in reality, Napoleon had never been against the windmill.

en: On the contrary, it was he who had advocated it in the beginning, and the plan which Snowball had drawn on the floor of the incubator shed had actually been stolen from among Napoleon’s papers.
vi: On the contrary, from the very beginning, he had supported the project, and the drawings they saw in the incubator were stolen by Snowball from Napoleon.
tr: On the contrary, Napoleon was the first to advocate for this project; in fact, the designs that Snowball had drawn on the barn floor were actually stolen from Napoleon's files.
es: On the contrary, it was he who advocated for its construction, and the plan that Snowball had drawn on the floor of the incubator shed was actually stolen from Napoleon's papers.

en: The windmill was, in fact, Napoleon’s own creation.
vi: The windmill was Napoleon's own initiative.
tr: The windmill had, in reality, originated from his idea.
es: The windmill was truly a creation of Napoleon himself.

en: Why, then, asked somebody, had he spoken so strongly against it?
vi: Then why - some animals asked - was Napoleon so adamantly against it before?
tr: One of the animals couldn't help but ask: "If it was born from his idea, why did Napoleon oppose the windmill so fiercely?"
es: “Why, then,” someone asked, “did he so firmly oppose the windmill?”

en: Here Squealer looked very sly.
vi: Squealer appeared very cunning.
tr: A devilish expression appeared on Squealer's face: "Comrade Napoleon acted cunningly," he said.
es: Here Squealer put on a cunning face.

en: That, he said, was Comrade Napoleon’s cunning.
vi: That - he explained - was the cleverness of Comrade Napoleon.
tr: A devilish expression appeared on Squealer's face: "Comrade Napoleon acted cunningly," he said.
es: “That,” he said, “was the sagacity of Comrade Napoleon.”

en: He had SEEMED to oppose the windmill, simply as a manoeuvre to get rid of Snowball, who was a dangerous character and a bad influence.
vi: He only pretended to be against it to get rid of Snowball, a dangerous enemy who could lead them astray at any moment.
tr: "Snowball was a dangerous one, setting a bad example for everyone. Comrade Napoleon appeared to be against the windmill to get rid of him."
es: He had pretended to oppose the windmill, but simply as a maneuver to get rid of Snowball, who was a dangerous and harmful influence.

en: Now that Snowball was out of the way, the plan could go forward without his interference.
vi: Now, with Snowball gone, they could proceed without fearing any more disturbances from him.
tr: According to Squealer, now that Snowball was out of the picture, the windmill project could be easily implemented.
es: Now that Snowball had been eliminated, the plan could proceed without his interference.

en: This, said Squealer, was something called tactics.
vi: That is called tactics, Squealer said.
tr: This was what they called tactics.
es: “This,” said Squealer, “is what is called tactics.”

en: He repeated a number of times, “Tactics, comrades, tactics!” skipping round and whisking his tail with a merry laugh.
vi: He repeated: "Tactics, comrades, it is all tactics," while smiling and jumping around, his tail wagging furiously.
tr: Squealer, hopping and skipping, laughing merrily and wagging his tail, repeated several times, "Tactics, comrades, tactics!"
es: He repeated several times, “Tactics, comrades, tactics!” jumping and wagging his tail with a cheerful laugh.

en: The animals were not certain what the word meant, but Squealer spoke so persuasively, and the three dogs who happened to be with him growled so threateningly, that they accepted his explanation without further questions.
vi: The animals did not understand anything, but Squealer spoke very eloquently, and the three dogs accompanying him suddenly barked loudly, so they accepted without further questions. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: The animals didn't really understand much from the word "tactics"; but Squealer spoke so convincingly, and the three dogs that happened to be beside him by coincidence were growling so menacingly, that they accepted Squealer's explanation without further objection.
es: The animals were not certain about the meaning of the word, but Squealer spoke so persuasively, and three of the dogs that were with him growled so threateningly, that they accepted his explanation without further questions.

en: Chapter 6
vi: Chapter 6
tr: Chapter Six
es: VI

en: All that year the animals worked like slaves.
vi: Throughout that year, the animals had to work tirelessly, no different from slaves.
tr: They worked like slaves for a whole year.
es: All that year, the animals worked like slaves.

en: But they were happy in their work; they grudged no effort or sacrifice, well aware that everything that they did was for the benefit of themselves and those of their kind who would come after them, and not for a pack of idle, thieving human beings.
vi: But working was a joy for them; they spared no effort and were ready to accept any sacrifice because they knew they were working for themselves and their offspring, not for a bunch of lazy, thieving humans anymore.
tr: But they were happy to work like this; because they were aware that whatever they were doing, they were doing it not for the benefit of a handful of idle and thieving people, but for their own benefit and for future generations, they were striving with all their might and silently enduring all kinds of sacrifices.
es: But they were happy in their task; they did not spare any effort or sacrifice, for they knew well that everything they did was for their own benefit and for those of their kind who would come after, and not for a few greedy and lazy human beings.

en: Throughout the spring and summer they worked a sixty-hour week, and in August Napoleon announced that there would be work on Sunday afternoons as well.
vi: Throughout the spring and summer, they worked sixty-four hours a week, but by August, Napoleon declared that they would work Sunday afternoons as well.
tr: They had worked sixty hours a week throughout the spring and summer. When August came, Napoleon announced that they would also work on Sunday afternoons.
es: Throughout the entire spring and summer, they worked sixty hours a week, and in August, Napoleon announced that they would also have to work on Sunday afternoons.

en: This work was strictly voluntary, but any animal who absented himself from it would have his rations reduced by half.
vi: This work was completely voluntary, but any animal absent would have their rations cut by half.
tr: This would be strictly voluntary work, but the ration of any animal who did not come to work would be cut in half.
es: This work was strictly voluntary, but any animal that did not show up would have their rations cut in half.

en: Even so, it was found necessary to leave certain tasks undone.
vi: Despite this, they still could not complete the planned tasks.
tr: Despite this, some tasks had to be abandoned.
es: Even so, it was necessary to leave several tasks undone.

en: The harvest was a little less successful than in the previous year, and two fields which should have been sown with roots in the early summer were not sown because the ploughing had not been completed early enough.
vi: This year’s harvest was worse than last year’s, and they did not manage to plant turnips on two fields because the plowing was too slow.
tr: The harvest was not as bountiful as the previous year; two fields had not been sown because they could not be plowed in time.
es: The harvest was somewhat less abundant than the previous year, and two plots that should have been planted with turnips at the beginning of the summer were not because they were not plowed in time.

en: It was possible to foresee that the coming winter would be a hard one.
vi: It could be foreseen that the coming winter would bring many difficulties.
tr: One did not need to be a prophet to foresee that the approaching winter would be harsh.
es: It was easy to foresee that the next winter would be harsh.

en: The windmill presented unexpected difficulties.
vi: The construction of the windmill encountered quite a few troubles.
tr: The windmill was causing unexpected difficulties.
es: The windmill presented unexpected difficulties.

en: There was a good quarry of limestone on the farm, and plenty of sand and cement had been found in one of the outhouses, so that all the materials for building were at hand.
vi: Right on the farm, there was a good limestone quarry, sand was also plentiful, and cement was readily available in the warehouse; all building materials were sufficient.
tr: There was a large limestone quarry on the farm; sand and cement were found in one of the small buildings; therefore, they had all kinds of construction materials at their disposal.
es: There was a good limestone quarry on the farm, and quite a bit of sand and cement was found in one of the outbuildings, so they had all the necessary materials for construction on hand.

en: But the problem the animals could not at first solve was how to break up the stone into pieces of suitable size.
vi: But there was one problem that the animals couldn't solve immediately, which was how to break the stones into pieces of the desired size.
tr: But the problem the animals couldn't solve at first was how to break the stones into suitable sizes.
es: But the problem, which the animals could not solve at first, was how to break the stone into appropriately sized pieces.

en: There seemed no way of doing this except with picks and crowbars, which no animal could use, because no animal could stand on his hind legs.
vi: It seemed that the only way was to use pickaxes and crowbars; but none of them knew how to use those tools because they couldn't stand on their hind legs.
tr: Chisels and sledgehammers were needed, but the animals couldn't use these tools because they couldn't stand on their hind legs.
es: Apparently, there was no way to do it except with picks and iron levers, which they could not use because no animal was able to stand on its hind legs.

en: Only after weeks of vain effort did the right idea occur to somebody-namely, to utilise the force of gravity.
vi: It took them several weeks of tinkering to figure out how to utilize the force of gravity.
tr: They pondered for weeks and were about to lose hope when someone found a solution: They would take advantage of gravity.
es: After several weeks of futile efforts, one of them came up with the right idea, namely: to use the force of gravity.

en: Huge boulders, far too big to be used as they were, were lying all over the bed of the quarry.
vi: The large rocks, which couldn't be used, lay at the bottom of the limestone quarry.
tr: The quarry was filled with pieces of rock too large to be used without breaking.
es: Immense stones, too large to use as they were, were found all over the bottom of the quarry.

en: The animals lashed ropes round these, and then all together, cows, horses, sheep, any animal that could lay hold of the rope — even the pigs sometimes joined in at critical moments — they dragged them with desperate slowness up the slope to the top of the quarry, where they were toppled over the edge, to shatter to pieces below.
vi: The animals wrapped ropes around the rocks, and then all of them, whether cows, horses, or sheep, any animal that could hold onto the rope was present, and in emergencies, even the pigs grabbed the rope and slowly pulled it up the slope, then they let the rock fall to the bottom to break into smaller pieces.
tr: They tied these pieces of rock with ropes; then the cows, horses, sheep, all the animals that could hold the rope – even the pigs in difficult situations – slowly pulled the rocks up to the top of the quarry. The rocks they released from there would shatter into pieces below.
es: The animals tied them with ropes, and then all together, cows, horses, sheep, anyone who could pull the rope —even the pigs sometimes helped in critical moments— dragged them with exasperating slowness up the slope to the top of the quarry, from where they let them fall over the edge to break into pieces upon hitting the bottom.

en: Transporting the stone when it was once broken was comparatively simple.
vi: Transporting the broken stones was not difficult.
tr: It was easier to transport the stones.
es: The work of transporting the stone once broken was relatively simple.

en: The horses carried it off in cart-loads, the sheep dragged single blocks, even Muriel and Benjamin yoked themselves into an old governess-cart and did their share.
vi: The horses transported them using small carts, the sheep carried them one by one, even Muriel and Benjamin harnessed themselves to a two-wheeled cart and participated in the transportation.
tr: The carts pulled by the horses were very useful; the sheep dragged the stones one by one; even Muriel and Benjamin contributed by harnessing themselves to an old cart.
es: The horses carried the pieces in carts, the sheep dragged them one by one, and even Muriel and Benjamin, pulling an old sulky, did their part.

en: By late summer a sufficient store of stone had accumulated, and then the building began, under the superintendence of the pigs.
vi: By the end of the summer, they had gathered enough stones, the construction work began, and the pigs took on the roles of supervisors and foremen.
tr: Once enough stones were piled up by the end of summer, construction began under the supervision of the pigs.
es: By the end of summer, they had accumulated a good supply of stone, and it was then that the construction of the windmill began, under the supervision of the pigs.

en: But it was a slow, laborious process.
vi: But the construction proceeded very slowly, consuming a lot of effort.
tr: However, they had given a challenging effort that took a lot of time.
es: It was a slow and laborious process.

en: Frequently it took a whole day of exhausting effort to drag a single boulder to the top of the quarry, and sometimes when it was pushed over the edge it failed to break.
vi: They often took an entire day just to pull a stone to the top, but when they dropped it, it wouldn't break.
tr: Lifting a single rock to the top of the quarry often took their entire day and required extraordinary effort. Sometimes, the rock rolling down did not break apart.
es: Frequently, it took them an entire day of exhausting effort to drag a single stone to the top of the quarry, and sometimes, when they threw it off the cliff, it wouldn't break.

en: Nothing could have been achieved without Boxer, whose strength seemed equal to that of all the rest of the animals put together.
vi: Without Warrior, nothing would get done properly; it alone did the work of all the others combined.
tr: If it weren't for Boxer, whose strength was nearly equal to that of all the other animals combined, they might not have been able to manage this task.
es: They wouldn't have been able to achieve anything without Boxer, whose strength seemed to equal that of all the other animals combined.

en: When the boulder began to slip and the animals cried out in despair at finding themselves dragged down the hill, it was always Boxer who strained himself against the rope and brought the boulder to a stop.
vi: If the stone was too heavy and the whole group was dragged down, Warrior would always strive to pull it up.
tr: When the animals saw themselves being dragged along with the rock sliding down the hill, they would start to shout desperately, and Boxer would immediately come to the rescue, pulling the rope with all his might to stop the rock.
es: When the stone started to slip and the animals cried out in desperation as they were dragged down the slope, it was always Boxer who, pulling on the rope like a convict, managed to stop the stone.

en: To see him toiling up the slope inch by inch, his breath coming fast, the tips of his hoofs clawing at the ground, and his great sides matted with sweat, filled everyone with admiration.
vi: Everyone had to admire it when they saw it, feet firmly planted on the ground, breathing heavily, sides drenched in sweat, striving to pull the stones up step by step.
tr: The animals watched in admiration as he struggled breathlessly to prevent the rock from sliding, gripping the ground with his hooves, and his broad flanks drenched in sweat.
es: Seeing him dragging it up the incline, inch by inch, panting, digging the tips of his hooves into the ground, and his enormous flanks sweaty, filled everyone with admiration.

en: Clover warned him sometimes to be careful not to overstrain himself, but Boxer would never listen to her.
vi: Fatty occasionally reminded it not to overwork, but it wouldn't listen.
tr: Sometimes Clover would warn him not to push himself too hard, but Boxer never listened to her.
es: Clover sometimes warned him to be careful and not to overexert himself, but Boxer never paid attention.

en: His two slogans, “I will work harder” and “Napoleon is always right,” seemed to him a sufficient answer to all problems.
vi: It seemed that for it, the two slogans: "I will try harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right" were the answers to every problem.
tr: "I will work harder" and "Napoleon is always right" were slogans that, in his eyes, were the cure for all problems.
es: His two mottos: "I will work harder" and "Napoleon is always right," seemed to him a satisfactory answer to all problems.

en: He had made arrangements with the cockerel to call him three-quarters of an hour earlier in the mornings instead of half an hour.
vi: It even asked the rooster to wake it up forty-five minutes earlier instead of half an hour as before.
tr: He had made an arrangement with the small rooster to wake him up not half an hour, but forty-five minutes early.
es: He had arranged with the rooster to wake him up three-quarters of an hour earlier in the morning, instead of half an hour.

en: And in his spare moments, of which there were not many nowadays, he would go alone to the quarry, collect a load of broken stone, and drag it down to the site of the windmill unassisted.
vi: In its spare time, which was now very limited, it would go alone to the quarry, arrange the broken stones, and pull them to the windmill construction site without any help.
tr: As if all this were not enough, in his now greatly diminished free time, he would go to the quarry alone, collect broken stones, and drag them to the site where the windmill was to be built without any help from anyone.
es: And in his free time, of which he had very little these days, he would go to the quarry, gather a pile of stone pieces, and drag it by himself to the site of the windmill.

en: The animals were not badly off throughout that summer, in spite of the hardness of their work.
vi: Although they had to work hard, the animals' lives in the summer were not too bad.
tr: Despite the heaviness of the work, the animals did not have such a bad time that summer.
es: The animals did not have such a hard time throughout that summer, despite the harshness of their work.

en: If they had no more food than they had had in Jones’s day, at least they did not have less.
vi: They did not eat more than they did during Mr. Jones's time, but they did not eat less either.
tr: Their rations were no more than they had been in Jones's time, but they were certainly no less.
es: If they did not have more food than they had during Jones's time, they did not have less either.

en: The advantage of only having to feed themselves, and not having to support five extravagant human beings as well, was so great that it would have taken a lot of failures to outweigh it.
vi: In return, they only had to work to feed themselves; they did not have to feed the five greedy humans anymore, and this alone was enough to motivate them to overcome all the piled-up difficulties.
tr: At the very least, they were no longer feeding five insatiable human beings; the pleasure of only having to feed themselves was so great that they willingly endured the hardships.
es: The advantage of feeding themselves and not having to also support five useless human beings was so great that it would have taken countless failures to lose it.

en: And in many ways the animal method of doing things was more efficient and saved labour.
vi: Moreover, the animals' methods were often efficient and quick.
tr: Moreover, the animals' method of working was more efficient in many ways and prevented waste of labor.
es: And in many situations, the animal method of doing things was more efficient than the human one and saved labor.

en: Such jobs as weeding, for instance, could be done with a thoroughness impossible to human beings.
vi: For example, they weeded faster and more neatly than humans.
tr: For instance, tasks like weeding were done with a proficiency that humans could never achieve.
es: Some tasks, such as weeding, could be done with an efficiency impossible for human beings.

en: And again, since no animal now stole, it was unnecessary to fence off pasture from arable land, which saved a lot of labour on the upkeep of hedges and gates.
vi: Now that no animal was stealing, there was no need to repair the fences and gates between the pasture and the cultivated area anymore.
tr: Since no animal now attempted to steal, there was no need to separate the pasture from the fields with fences; this saved the labor that would have been spent on maintaining and repairing the fences and barriers.
es: And besides, since no animal stole, it was not necessary to build fences to separate the pastures from the arable land, which saved a lot of work in maintaining the hedges and fences.

en: Nevertheless, as the summer wore on, various unforeseen shortages began to make them selves felt.
vi: But from that summer, shortages began to occur, now this thing, now that thing.
tr: However, as the summer progressed, some unforeseen shortages began to make themselves felt.
es: However, as the summer progressed, an unforeseen shortage of various things began to be felt.

en: There was need of paraffin oil, nails, string, dog biscuits, and iron for the horses’ shoes, none of which could be produced on the farm.
vi: They needed oil, nails, ropes, dog biscuits, iron for horseshoes, things that Animal Farm could not produce.
tr: There was a need for kerosene, nails, string, and dog biscuits; iron for horseshoes was also required; moreover, none of these could be produced on the farm.
es: There was a need for paraffin oil, nails, biscuits for the dogs, and iron for the horseshoes, none of which could be produced on the farm.

en: Later there would also be need for seeds and artificial manures, besides various tools and, finally, the machinery for the windmill.
vi: Then there were seeds, chemical fertilizers, tools like hoes and shovels, and even equipment for the windmill.
tr: Later on, there would be a need for seeds and artificial fertilizers, various tools, and some machinery parts for the windmill.
es: Later on, there would also be a need for seeds and artificial fertilizers, as well as various tools and, finally, the most important thing: the machinery for the windmill.

en: How these were to be procured, no one was able to imagine.
vi: No animal knew how to buy those things.
tr: No one knew how these would be obtained.
es: Nobody could imagine how all these items were going to be obtained.

en: One Sunday morning, when the animals assembled to receive their orders, Napoleon announced that he had decided upon a new policy.
vi: One Sunday morning, when the animals gathered to receive their tasks for the upcoming week, Napoleon suddenly announced that he had decided to implement a new policy.
tr: One Sunday morning, when they gathered to receive orders, Napoleon announced that he had determined a new policy.
es: One Sunday morning, when the animals gathered to receive orders, Napoleon announced that he had decided to adopt a new system.

en: From now onwards Animal Farm would engage in trade with the neighbouring farms: not, of course, for any commercial purpose, but simply in order to obtain certain materials which were urgently necessary.
vi: From now on, Animal Farm would trade with neighboring farms: of course, not for profit but only to purchase some truly necessary supplies.
tr: From now on, Animal Farm would engage in trade with neighboring farms. Undoubtedly, not for commercial purposes, but solely to acquire some urgently needed supplies.
es: Henceforth, "Animal Farm" would negotiate with the neighboring farms; and not, of course, for any commercial purpose, but simply to obtain certain materials that were urgently needed.

en: The needs of the windmill must override everything else, he said.
vi: The task of building the windmill is of utmost importance to us, he said.
tr: Napoleon said, "The needs of the windmill must be prioritized above everything else."
es: "The needs of the windmill are above everything else," he stated.

en: He was therefore making arrangements to sell a stack of hay and part of the current year’s wheat crop, and later on, if more money were needed, it would have to be made up by the sale of eggs, for which there was always a market in Willingdon.
vi: Therefore, he had negotiated the sale of hay and part of the last wheat crop, and later, if more money was needed, they might have to sell eggs, as the demand for eggs in Willingdon was very high.
tr: Therefore, he was making arrangements to sell a large stack of hay and a portion of that year's wheat crop; later, if more money was needed, eggs, which always had a market in Willingdon, could also be sold.
es: Consequently, he was taking the necessary measures to sell a portion of the hay and another part of that year's wheat harvest, and later on, if they needed more money, they would have to obtain it by selling eggs, for which there was always a market in Willingdon.

en: The hens, said Napoleon, should welcome this sacrifice as their own special contribution towards the building of the windmill.
vi: Comrades, the hens, Napoleon said, should be proud to have made special contributions to the construction of the windmill.
tr: According to Napoleon, the hens should see this as their special contribution to the construction of the windmill and should not hesitate to make such a sacrifice.
es: "The hens," said Napoleon, "should gladly accept this sacrifice as a special contribution to the construction of the windmill."

en: Once again the animals were conscious of a vague uneasiness.
vi: Once again, the animals felt anxious.
tr: The animals, once again, had become vaguely uneasy.
es: Once again the animals felt themselves gripped by a vague unease.

en: Never to have any dealings with human beings, never to engage in trade, never to make use of money — had not these been among the earliest resolutions passed at that first triumphant Meeting after Jones was expelled?
vi: No dealings with humans, no engaging in trade, no use of money - weren't these the resolutions passed at the first Meeting celebrating the victory after driving out Mr. Jones?
tr: Never do business with humans! Never engage in trade! Never use money! Weren't these the first decisions made at the Victory Meeting held after Jones was expelled from the farm?
es: “Never to have any dealings with humans, never to engage in trade, never to use money,” weren’t those the first resolutions adopted at that triumphant meeting, after Jones had been expelled?

en: All the animals remembered passing such resolutions: or at least they thought that they remembered it.
vi: All the animals remembered that they had passed those resolutions, or at least they thought they remembered.
tr: All the animals remembered these decisions being approved, or at least they thought they remembered.
es: All the animals remembered having approved such resolutions or, at least, they believed they remembered it.

en: The four young pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the Meetings raised their voices timidly, but they were promptly silenced by a tremendous growling from the dogs.
vi: The four pigs who had stood up to protest when Napoleon announced the cancellation of the weekend Meetings were about to speak again, but they quickly shut their mouths because the dogs had started barking loudly.
tr: The four little pigs who had protested against Napoleon abolishing the meetings timidly raised their voices, but suddenly fell silent in the face of the dogs' terrifying growls.
es: The four young pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the meetings timidly raised their voices, but were immediately silenced by the fierce growling of the dogs.

en: Then, as usual, the sheep broke into “Four legs good, two legs bad!” and the momentary awkwardness was smoothed over.
vi: As always, the sheep began chanting "Four legs good, two legs bad!" and everything settled down.
tr: Immediately after, as usual, the sheep began to bleat "Four legs good, two legs bad!" and the tense atmosphere was diffused.
es: Then, as usual, the sheep burst out with their “Four legs good, two legs bad!” and their chant prevailed.

en: Finally Napoleon raised his trotter for silence and announced that he had already made all the arrangements.
vi: Finally, Napoleon raised his hoof to call for order and declared that he had resolved everything satisfactorily.
tr: Soon after, Napoleon raised his foreleg to silence everyone and announced that he had already arranged everything.
es: Finally, Napoleon raised his paw to impose silence and announced that he had already decided all the agreements.

en: There would be no need for any of the animals to come in contact with human beings, which would clearly be most undesirable.
vi: No animal would have to deal with humans, as it was not a pleasant task.
tr: Knowing that it would be extremely problematic for the farm animals to interact with humans, he had decided to create conditions where this would not be necessary.
es: There would be no need for any of the animals to come into contact with human beings, which would be undesirable.

en: He intended to take the whole burden upon his own shoulders.
vi: He would take full responsibility for that heavy task.
tr: He would take all the responsibility himself.
es: He intended to take the full weight of the decisions upon his own shoulders.

en: A mr Whymper, a solicitor living in Willingdon, had agreed to act as intermediary between Animal Farm and the outside world, and would visit the farm every Monday morning to receive his instructions.
vi: A lawyer currently living in Willingdon named Whymper had agreed to act as an intermediary between Animal Farm and the neighboring farms; he would take up his duties on Monday mornings each week.
tr: A lawyer named Mr. Whymper, who lived in Willingdon, had agreed to mediate in the dealings between Animal Farm and the outside world; he would come to the farm every Monday morning to receive instructions from Napoleon.
es: A certain Mr. Whymper, a broker who lived in Willingdon, had agreed to act as an intermediary between “Animal Farm” and the outside world, and would visit the farm every Monday morning to receive instructions.

en: Napoleon ended his speech with his usual cry of “Long live Animal Farm!” and after the singing of ‘Beasts of England’ the animals were dismissed.
vi: As usual, Napoleon ended his speech by shouting the slogan "Long live Animal Farm" and after singing "Beasts of England," the animals dispersed.
tr: After Napoleon, as always, concluded his speech with the cry "Long live Animal Farm!" the animals sang the Beasts of England song and dispersed.
es: Napoleon ended his speech with his usual cry of “Long live Animal Farm!” and after singing “Beasts of England,” he dismissed the animals.

en: Afterwards Squealer made a round of the farm and set the animals’ minds at rest.
vi: After that, Chỉ Điểm went around the camp to conduct ideological work.
tr: Before long, Squealer set about touring the farm to dispel the doubts that had arisen in the animals' minds.
es: Then Squealer went around the farm and reassured them.

en: He assured them that the resolution against engaging in trade and using money had never been passed, or even suggested.
vi: He assured that the decision not to trade and not to use money had never been put to a vote, let alone passed.
tr: With a convincing tone, he explained that no decision had ever been made regarding not engaging in trade or using money, and furthermore, that such a proposal had never even been suggested.
es: He assured them that the resolution prohibiting trade and the use of money had never been passed, nor even suggested.

en: It was pure imagination, probably traceable in the beginning to lies circulated by Snowball.
vi: That was just a fabrication, and if traced back to the beginning, it might have been made up by Tuyết Tròn.
