tr: All of this was most likely a figment of the imagination, stemming from the lies Snowball had spread in the early days.
es: It was pure imagination, probably attributable to lies spread by Snowball.

en: A few animals still felt faintly doubtful, but Squealer asked them shrewdly, “Are you certain that this is not something that you have dreamed, comrades?
vi: But some still did not believe, so Chỉ Điểm asked: "Comrade, are you sure you didn't imagine it?
tr: Noticing that some still harbored doubts, Squealer cunningly asked, "Could this be something you dreamed, comrades?
es: Some animals still had certain doubts, but Squealer cunningly asked them: "Are you sure this isn't something you have dreamed, comrades?

en: Have you any record of such a resolution?
vi: Do you have any documents confirming that?
tr: Is there any document of such a decision?
es: Do you have any record of such a resolution?

en: Is it written down anywhere?”
vi: Where is that decision recorded?".
tr: Is it written down anywhere?"
es: Is it written down anywhere?"

en: And since it was certainly true that nothing of the kind existed in writing, the animals were satisfied that they had been mistaken.
vi: Surely those decisions were not recorded anywhere, so in the end, the animals believed they were mistaken.
tr: Indeed, since there was no such written document to be found, the animals were forced to admit they were mistaken.
es: And since it was true that none of this was written down, the animals were convinced that they were mistaken.

en: Every Monday mr Whymper visited the farm as had been arranged.
vi: Every Monday, Mr. Whymper came to the farm.
tr: Mr. Whymper, as previously arranged, visited the farm every Monday.
es: Every Monday, Mr. Whymper visited the farm, as had been agreed.

en: He was a sly-looking little man with side whiskers, a solicitor in a very small way of business, but sharp enough to have realised earlier than anyone else that Animal Farm would need a broker and that the commissions would be worth having.
vi: He was a small-statured lawyer with long sideburns, just starting out in business, but quite shrewd, immediately recognizing that Animal Farm would definitely need a broker and that the commission would naturally be "substantial."
tr: Mr. Whymper, a lawyer who dealt with trivial matters, was a small man with sideburns and a mischievous look. But he was shrewd enough to realize long before that Animal Farm would eventually need a broker, and that this broker's share would not be insignificant.
es: He was a short, cunning man with broad sideburns, a retail broker, but smart enough to realize, before anyone else, that "Animal Farm" was going to need an agent and that the commissions would be worth it.

en: The animals watched his coming and going with a kind of dread, and avoided him as much as possible.
vi: The animals were afraid of Whymper and tried to avoid him as much as possible.
tr: The animals watched his comings and goings with trepidation, avoiding encounters with him as much as possible.
es: The animals watched his comings and goings with some fear, and avoided him as much as possible.

en: Nevertheless, the sight of Napoleon, on all fours, delivering orders to Whymper, who stood on two legs, roused their pride and partly reconciled them to the new arrangement.
vi: Nevertheless, the fact that Napoleon, standing on four legs, gave orders to Whymper, who stood on two legs, instilled in them a legitimate sense of pride and somewhat mitigated their reaction to the new policy.
tr: Nevertheless, seeing the four-legged Napoleon giving orders to the two-legged Whymper stroked their pride and helped them somewhat accept this new situation.
es: However, the sight of Napoleon, on his four legs, giving orders to Whymper, who stood on his two feet, stirred their pride and partially reconciled them to the new situation.

en: Their relations with the human race were now not quite the same as they had been before.
vi: Their relationship with humans was no longer the same as before.
tr: Their relations with the human race were no longer quite the same.
es: Their relations with the human race were not as they had been before.

en: The human beings did not hate Animal Farm any less now that it was prospering; indeed, they hated it more than ever.
vi: The humans' hatred for Animal Farm not only did not decrease but actually increased as it became more prosperous.
tr: The humans' hatred for Animal Farm had not diminished; on the contrary, they hated it more than ever as they saw the farm prospering.
es: The humans, for their part, did not hate "Animal Farm" any less now that it was prospering; on the contrary, they hated it more than ever.

en: Every human being held it as an article of faith that the farm would go bankrupt sooner or later, and, above all, that the windmill would be a failure.
vi: Everyone believed that sooner or later the farm would go bankrupt, and the windmill was sure to fail.
tr: They all wholeheartedly believed that the farm would eventually go bankrupt and, more importantly, that the windmill project would end in complete failure.
es: Every human was certain that, sooner or later, the farm would go bankrupt, and above all, that the windmill would be a failure.

en: They would meet in the public-houses and prove to one another by means of diagrams that the windmill was bound to fall down, or that if it did stand up, then that it would never work.
vi: They often gathered in pubs and drew diagrams to prove that the windmill would definitely collapse, and even if it didn't, it would never work.
tr: They gathered in taverns, trying to prove to each other with drawings that the windmill could never be built, and even if it were, it would never work.
es: They gathered in taverns and demonstrated to each other, through diagrams, that the windmill was destined to fall or, if it stood, that it would never work.

en: And yet, against their will, they had developed a certain respect for the efficiency with which the animals were managing their own affairs.
vi: But despite their dislike, they had to respect the animals because they managed the farm quite efficiently.
tr: On the other hand, they reluctantly admired the animals' skillful management of their own affairs.
es: And yet, against their wishes, they came to have a certain respect for the efficiency with which the animals were managing their own affairs.

en: One symptom of this was that they had begun to call Animal Farm by its proper name and ceased to pretend that it was called the Manor Farm.
vi: The proof was that they had started calling it Animal Farm and had stopped pretending it was still named Manor Farm.
tr: The fact that they had stopped insisting that the farm's real name was Manor Farm and had started using the name Animal Farm was an indication of this.
es: One of the signs of this was that they began to call "Animal Farm" by its real name and stopped pretending it was called "Manor Farm."

en: They had also dropped their championship of Jones, who had given up hope of getting his farm back and gone to live in another part of the county.
vi: They also no longer supported Mr. Jones, who had lost all hope of reclaiming the farm and had gone to work elsewhere.
tr: They had also ceased defending Jones, who had lost hope of reclaiming his farm and had moved to another part of the country.
es: They also ceased to support Jones, who had lost hope of regaining his farm and went to live elsewhere in the country.

en: Except through Whymper, there was as yet no contact between Animal Farm and the outside world, but there were constant rumours that Napoleon was about to enter into a definite business agreement either with mr Pilkington of Foxwood or with mr Frederick of Pinchfield — but never, it was noticed, with both simultaneously.
vi: Although currently all relations between Animal Farm and the outside world were conducted through Whymper, there were rumors that Napoleon was about to sign a trade agreement either with Pilkington's Foxwood Farm or Frederick's Pinchfield Farm, but people also said that there would be no deal with both farms at the same time.
tr: There was no connection between Animal Farm and the outside world except for Whymper, but there were constant rumors that Napoleon was about to make a concrete business deal either with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood Farm or Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, though it was said he would never make a deal with both at the same time.
es: Except for Whymper, there was still no contact between "Animal Farm" and the outside world, but there were constant rumors that Napoleon was definitely going to make a trade agreement with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood, or with Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield; but never — it was noted — with both simultaneously.

en: It was about this time that the pigs suddenly moved into the farmhouse and took up their residence there.
vi: Around that time, the pigs suddenly moved into the main house.
tr: It was around that time that the pigs moved into the farmhouse and made it their residence.
es: It was around that time when the pigs suddenly moved into the farmhouse and established their residence there.

en: Again the animals seemed to remember that a resolution against this had been passed in the early days, and again Squealer was able to convince them that this was not the case.
vi: This time, the animals also believed that from the very beginning they had decided that no one was allowed to move into the main house. Squealer once again convinced them that they were mistaken.
tr: The animals vaguely remembered that there had been a resolution passed against such behavior, but Squealer once again managed to convince them that this was not the case at all.
es: Once again, the animals thought they remembered that in the early days a resolution had been passed against such a measure, and once again Squealer had to convince them that it was not so.

en: It was absolutely necessary, he said, that the pigs, who were the brains of the farm, should have a quiet place to work in.
vi: The pigs were the brains of the entire farm, he said, so they needed quiet places to work.
tr: He said that it was absolutely necessary for the pigs, the brains of the farm, to work in a quiet and peaceful place.
es: It was absolutely necessary, he said, that the pigs, who were the brains of the farm, had a quiet place to work.

en: It was also more suited to the dignity of the Leader (for of late he had taken to speaking of Napoleon under the title of “Leader”) to live in a house than in a mere sty.
vi: The Leader (recently he had started calling Napoleon the Leader) had to live in a worthy place and couldn't just keep living in a pigsty.
tr: Moreover, for the Leader's (recently, they had started referring to Napoleon as "the Leader") dignity, it was more appropriate for him to live in a house rather than a simple shed.
es: It was also more appropriate for the dignity of the Leader (because lately they had begun to refer to Napoleon with the title of "Leader") that he lived in a house instead of a simple pigsty.

en: Nevertheless, some of the animals were disturbed when they heard that the pigs not only took their meals in the kitchen and used the drawing-room as a recreation room, but also slept in the beds.
vi: However, some were worried when they heard that the pigs not only ate in the kitchen and rested in the living room but also slept in beds.
tr: Nevertheless, some animals were quite disturbed when they heard that the pigs not only ate their meals in the kitchen and used the living room as a recreation room, but also slept in beds.
es: However, some animals were upset to learn that the pigs not only ate in the kitchen and used the living room as a recreation area, but also slept in the beds.

en: Boxer passed it off as usual with “Napoleon is always right!”, but Clover, who thought she remembered a definite ruling against beds, went to the end of the barn and tried to puzzle out the Seven Commandments which were inscribed there.
vi: Boxer still said "Comrade Napoleon is always right," but Clover thought there surely was a rule against sleeping in beds, so she went to the end of the barn to check the Seven Commandments.
tr: Boxer, as usual, dismissed the situation by saying, "Napoleon is always right!" but Clover, who vaguely remembered a strict law against sleeping in beds, went to the wall of the big barn and tried to read the Seven Commandments written there.
es: Boxer overlooked it, as usual, repeating "Napoleon is always right!", but Clover, who believed she remembered a specific provision against beds, went to the end of the barn and tried to decipher the seven commandments that were written there.

en: Finding herself unable to read more than individual letters, she fetched Muriel.
vi: But she could only recognize the letters and couldn't read the words, so she had to find Muriel.
tr: Seeing that she couldn't make out anything other than individual letters, she called Muriel.
es: Seeing that she could only read the letters one by one, she brought Muriel.

en: “Muriel,” she said, “read me the Fourth Commandment.
vi: "Muriel," Fatty said, "read me the Fourth Commandment.
tr: "Muriel," he said, "read me the Fourth Commandment.
es: —Muriel —he said—, read me the fourth commandment.

en: Does it not say something about never sleeping in a bed?”
vi: Is it that we should never sleep in a bed?"
tr: Does it say anything about never sleeping in a bed?"
es: Doesn't it say something about never sleeping in a bed?

en: With some difficulty Muriel spelt it out.
vi: Muriel had to spell it out for a long time before finishing.
tr: Muriel, who could barely read the writing, said, "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."
es: With a bit of difficulty, Muriel spelled it out.

en: “It says, ‘No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets,”’ she announced finally.
vi: "This Commandment reads: No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets," Muriel said.
tr: Muriel, who could barely read the writing, said, "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."
es: —He says: "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."

en: Curiously enough, Clover had not remembered that the Fourth Commandment mentioned sheets; but as it was there on the wall, it must have done so.
vi: It's strange, Fat Lady remembered that the Fourth Commandment didn't mention bed sheets, but if it was clearly written on the wall like that, then it must be so.
tr: It was a bit strange; Clover did not remember any mention of sheets in the Fourth Commandment; but since it was written on the wall, there was nothing to be done.
es: The curious thing was that Clover did not remember the Fourth Commandment mentioning the sheets; but since it was written on the wall, it must have been so.

en: And Squealer, who happened to be passing at this moment, attended by two or three dogs, was able to put the whole matter in its proper perspective.
vi: At that moment, Chỉ Điểm, along with two or three dogs, accidentally walked by.
tr: At that moment, Squealer, who was passing by with two or three dogs, did not delay in clarifying the matter.
es: And Squealer, who was passing by at that moment, accompanied by two or three dogs, was able to clarify the matter and set it straight.

en: “You have heard then, comrades,” he said, “that we pigs now sleep in the beds of the farmhouse?
vi: "Comrades," it said, "I think you know that we pigs have been sleeping in beds already?
tr: "Comrades," he said. "It seems that you have heard that we pigs are sleeping in the beds of the farmhouse.
es: —You have heard, comrades —he said—, that we pigs now sleep in the beds of the house.

en: And why not?
vi: Why not?
tr: Why shouldn't we?
es: And why not?

en: You did not suppose, surely, that there was ever a ruling against beds?
vi: Do you really think there is a rule against sleeping in beds?
tr: I hope you don't think there is a commandment that forbids beds!
es: Surely, you would not suppose that there was ever a ruling against beds.

en: A bed merely means a place to sleep in.
vi: What is a bed, but a place to sleep?
tr: A bed is a place to lie down and sleep.
es: A bed simply means a place to sleep.

en: A pile of straw in a stall is a bed, properly regarded.
vi: In fact, a pile of straw in a barn is also a bed.
tr: In this sense, a pile of straw in the barn is also considered a bed.
es: For example: a pile of straw in a barn is a bed.

en: The rule was against sheets, which are a human invention.
vi: The rule is against sleeping with sheets, because those are a human invention.
tr: The commandment forbade sheets, which are a human invention.
es: The resolution was against the sheets, which are an invention of human beings.

en: We have removed the sheets from the farmhouse beds, and sleep between blankets.
vi: We have removed all the sheets, now we only use blankets.
tr: We removed the sheets from the beds in the farmhouse and are sleeping with blankets.
es: We have removed the sheets from the beds in the house and sleep between blankets.

en: And very comfortable beds they are too!
vi: Beds are actually very convenient!
tr: Moreover, the beds are very comfortable!
es: And indeed, they are very comfortable beds!

en: But not more comfortable than we need, I can tell you, comrades, with all the brainwork we have to do nowadays.
vi: But they are not too luxurious, I can tell you that they are exactly what we need for intellectual workers like us.
tr: But believe me, for those of us who have to think hard about a lot of issues these days, a bed should not be begrudged.
es: But they are no more than what we need, I can assure you, comrades, considering all the brainwork we have these days.

en: You would not rob us of our repose, would you, comrades?
vi: Don't you want us to rest?
tr: You wouldn't begrudge us this comfort, would you, comrades?
es: You wouldn't want to deprive us of our rest, would you, comrades?

en: You would not have us too tired to carry out our duties?
vi: Do you want us to be exhausted?
tr: Surely you don't want us to be too tired to fulfill our duties.
es: You wouldn't want us to be so tired that we can't fulfill our duties.

en: Surely none of you wishes to see Jones back?”
vi: Surely none of you want old Jones to come back, right?"
tr: I don't think any of you want Jones to come back!"
es: Surely, none of you would want Jones to come back.

en: The animals reassured him on this point immediately, and no more was said about the pigs sleeping in the farmhouse beds.
vi: The animals assured it that they did not think so, and from then on, no one mentioned the pigs sleeping in beds anymore.
tr: The animals immediately reassured Squealer on this matter and never brought up the issue of the pigs sleeping in the farmhouse beds again.
es: The animals immediately calmed him down and the matter of the pigs sleeping in the house beds was not discussed further.

en: And when, some days afterwards, it was announced that from now on the pigs would get up an hour later in the mornings than the other animals, no complaint was made about that either.
vi: A few days later, it was announced that from now on, the pigs would get up an hour later than the other animals; this time, no one complained at all.
tr: A few days later, when it was announced that the pigs would now get up an hour later than the other animals in the mornings, no one said a word.
es: And when, days later, it was announced that from then on the pigs would get up an hour later in the morning than the other animals, there was no complaint about it either.

en: By the autumn the animals were tired but happy.
vi: Autumn arrived, and although the animals were tired, they were happy.
tr: When autumn came, the animals were tired but happy.
es: When autumn arrived, the animals were tired but happy.

en: They had had a hard year, and after the sale of part of the hay and corn, the stores of food for the winter were none too plentiful, but the windmill compensated for everything.
vi: The past year had been a hard one; they had to sell some of the hay and grain, so the winter reserves were not very abundant, but the windmill compensated for all their efforts.
tr: They had left a difficult year behind. Although it couldn't be said that the stock of winter food was abundant after some of the hay and crops were sold, the windmill would make up for this shortfall.
es: They had had a difficult year and after selling some of the hay and corn, the food supplies were not as abundant, but the windmill made up for everything.

en: It was almost half built now.
vi: The windmill was nearly halfway built.
tr: Nearly half of the construction was completed.
es: It was almost built.

en: After the harvest there was a stretch of clear dry weather, and the animals toiled harder than ever, thinking it well worth while to plod to and fro all day with blocks of stone if by doing so they could raise the walls another foot.
vi: After the harvest, the weather was very favorable, and the animals worked harder than ever before, willing to move and carry things all day as long as the wall grew taller, even if just a little.
tr: After the harvest, the weather cleared up, and the animals were working harder than ever, thinking it was worth carrying stones from morning till night, as long as the walls of the windmill rose another inch.
es: After the harvest, they had a season of dry and clear weather, and the animals worked harder than ever, thinking it was well worth running back and forth all day with stone blocks if by doing so they could raise the walls another foot in height.

en: Boxer would even come out at nights and work for an hour or two on his own by the light of the harvest moon.
vi: At night, Boxer would even put in an extra hour or two under the moonlight.
tr: Boxer didn't even take nights off; he worked alone for an extra hour or two in the light of the full moon.
es: Boxer even sometimes went out at night and worked an hour or two on his own by moonlight.

en: In their spare moments the animals would walk round and round the half-finished mill, admiring the strength and perpendicularity of its walls and marvelling that they should ever have been able to build anything so imposing.
vi: In their free time, the animals often strolled around the construction site, admiring the straight and sturdy walls; they wondered if they had really built such a magnificent structure.
tr: In their free time, the animals wandered around the half-built windmill, admiring its solid, towering walls, and were amazed at how they had managed to create such a magnificent structure.
es: In their free time, the animals walked around and around the almost finished windmill, admiring the strength and verticality of its walls and marveling that they had ever been able to build something so imposing.

en: Only old Benjamin refused to grow enthusiastic about the windmill, though, as usual, he would utter nothing beyond the cryptic remark that donkeys live a long time.
vi: Only Benjamin remained unchanged; he said nothing except his usual remark that donkeys live a long time.
tr: The only animal who avoided getting enthusiastic about the windmill was old Benjamin; as always, he limited himself to saying cryptic things like, "Donkeys live a long time."
es: Only old Benjamin refused to get excited about the windmill, although, as usual, he insisted on his enigmatic statement that donkeys lived a long time.

en: November came, with raging south-west winds.
vi: November begins with southwest winds.
tr: November came with strong winds blowing from the southwest.
es: November arrived, with its furious southwest winds.

en: Building had to stop because it was now too wet to mix the cement.
vi: Construction work was halted because it was too damp to mix mortar.
tr: They had to stop the construction; it was impossible to mix cement because the weather was too rainy.
es: They had to stop the construction because there was too much humidity to mix the cement.

en: Finally there came a night when the gale was so violent that the farm buildings rocked on their foundations and several tiles were blown off the roof of the barn.
vi: One night, the wind was so strong that the roof tiles were blown off, and the walls seemed on the verge of collapsing.
tr: Finally, one night, a storm broke out so violently that the farm buildings shook from their foundations, and tiles flew off the roof of the barn.
es: And then came a night when the gale was so violent that the farm buildings trembled on their foundations and several tiles were torn off the barn roof.

en: The hens woke up squawking with terror because they had all dreamed simultaneously of hearing a gun go off in the distance.
vi: The chickens woke up and clucked loudly because they all dreamt of hearing gunshots somewhere.
tr: The chickens woke up clucking in fear; they had all heard a gunshot in the distance in the dream they saw at the same time.
es: The hens woke up clucking in terror because they all dreamed they had heard something like the boom of a cannon in the distance.

en: In the morning the animals came out of their stalls to find that the flagstaff had been blown down and an elm tree at the foot of the orchard had been plucked up like a radish.
vi: In the morning, when the animals came out of the barn, they saw that the flagpole had fallen, and the elm tree at the end of the garden had been uprooted as if someone had pulled up a radish.
tr: In the morning, they saw that the flagpole had fallen, and one of the elm trees in the orchard had been uprooted like a radish.
es: In the morning, the animals came out of their stalls and found the flagpole knocked down and an elm tree, which was at the foot of the orchard, uprooted.

en: They had just noticed this when a cry of despair broke from every animal’s throat.
vi: In the morning, when the animals came out of the barn, they saw that the flagpole had fallen, and the elm tree at the end of the garden had been uprooted as if someone had pulled up a radish.
tr: Before they could understand what was happening, all the animals started screaming in terror:
es: They had barely seen this when a cry of despair burst from their throats.

en: A terrible sight had met their eyes.
vi: But that was not all; in front of them was an even more terrifying sight.
tr: Before they could understand what was happening, all the animals started screaming in terror:
es: A terrible scene presented itself to their eyes.

en: The windmill was in ruins.
vi: The windmill had completely collapsed.
tr: The windmill had collapsed.
es: The windmill was in ruins.

en: With one accord they dashed down to the spot.
vi: They all cried out in unison in despair. They rushed towards the construction site.
tr: They all rushed together to the windmill.
es: All at once they rushed towards the place.

en: Napoleon, who seldom moved out of a walk, raced ahead of them all.
vi: Napoleon, who always considered running to be beneath him, was now at the head of the group, running as fast as he could.
tr: Napoleon, who had never been seen even walking briskly, was at the forefront, kicking up dust.
es: Napoleon, who rarely hurried when walking, was running at the head of all of them.

en: Yes, there it lay, the fruit of all their struggles, levelled to its foundations, the stones they had broken and carried so laboriously scattered all around.
vi: It was all over; everything had gone to waste. The stones they had painstakingly broken and transported were now scattered everywhere.
tr: The windmill, which they had worked so hard to build, was completely destroyed, and the stones they had painstakingly broken and carried were scattered all around.
es: Yes, there lay the fruit of all their efforts, demolished to its foundations; the stones, which they had so diligently broken and moved, were scattered everywhere.

en: Unable at first to speak, they stood gazing mournfully at the litter of fallen stone.
vi: Speechless, they stood silently, painfully gazing at the pile of fallen stones.
tr: They stood there as if struck dumb, staring at the stones scattered around.
es: Unable, at first, to utter a word, they could only look sadly at the fallen rubble in disarray.

en: Napoleon paced to and fro in silence, occasionally snuffing at the ground.
vi: Napoleon walked back and forth in silence, occasionally sniffing the ground.
tr: Napoleon was pacing silently, sniffing the ground every now and then, and judging by the rapid swishing of his erect tail, his mind was racing.
es: Napoleon walked back and forth in silence, occasionally sniffing the ground.

en: His tail had grown rigid and twitched sharply from side to side, a sign in him of intense mental activity.
vi: His tail was stretched out, wagging vigorously, indicating that he was deep in thought.
tr: Napoleon was pacing silently, sniffing the ground every now and then, and judging by the rapid swishing of his erect tail, his mind was racing.
es: His tail had gone stiff and was moving nervously from side to side, a sign of his intense mental activity.

en: Suddenly he halted as though his mind were made up.
vi: Suddenly, he stopped, which meant he had found a solution.
tr: Suddenly, as if he had made up his mind, he stopped.
es: Suddenly he stopped as if he had clearly seen the origin of that disaster.

en: “Comrades,” he said quietly, “do you know who is responsible for this?
vi: "Comrades," he calmly said, "do you know who is responsible for this?
tr: Without raising his voice, he said, "Comrades." "Do you know who did this?
es: —Comrades —he said in a calm voice—, do you know who is responsible for all this?

en: Do you know the enemy who has come in the night and overthrown our windmill?
vi: Who sabotaged, who destroyed our windmill last night?
tr: Do you know who the enemy is that came here at night and destroyed our windmill?"
es: Do you know who the enemy is that came during the night and knocked down our windmill?

en: SNOWBALL!” he suddenly roared in a voice of thunder.
vi: Snowball!" he suddenly shouted, "it was Snowball, no one else.
tr: Then he suddenly roared: "Snowball!
es: Snowball! —he suddenly roared with a thunderous voice—.

en: “Snowball has done this thing!
vi: Snowball!" he suddenly shouted, "it was Snowball, no one else.
tr: This is Snowball's doing!
es: Snowball did this!

en: In sheer malignity, thinking to set back our plans and avenge himself for his ignominious expulsion, this traitor has crept here under cover of night and destroyed our work of nearly a year.
vi: That treacherous traitor has heartlessly sought to ruin us and take revenge for his humiliating expulsion; he took advantage of the darkness to sneak in and destroy the entire year's worth of our labor.
tr: This traitor, just to cause harm, to ruin our plans and take revenge for his disgraceful expulsion, came here under the cover of darkness and destroyed a year's worth of work.
es: Out of pure malice, believing that he was going to ruin our plans and take revenge for his ignominious expulsion, that traitor crawled here under the cover of darkness and destroyed our work of nearly a year.

en: Comrades, here and now I pronounce the death sentence upon Snowball.
vi: Today, here, I declare a death sentence on Snowball.
tr: Comrades, I hereby sentence Snowball to death.
es: Comrades, at this moment and place, I sentence Snowball to death.

en: ‘Animal Hero, Second Class,’ and half a bushel of apples to any animal who brings him to justice.
vi: Whoever kills him will be awarded Animal Hero, Second Class, and half a barrel of apples.
tr: To the animal who gives him the punishment he deserves, the 'Second Class Animal Hero' medal and half a bucket of apples.
es: I will reward and name "Animal Hero, Second Class" and give half a bushel of apples to the animal that brings him dead.

en: A full bushel to anyone who captures him alive!”
vi: Whoever captures him alive will be rewarded with a full barrel of apples."
tr: To the one who brings him back alive, a full bucket of apples!"
es: A whole bushel to the one who captures him alive.

en: The animals were shocked beyond measure to learn that even Snowball could be guilty of such an action.
vi: Every animal was extremely furious upon hearing the news that Snowball had committed such a heinous crime.
tr: The animals, who had never even imagined that Snowball could commit such a crime until that day, were stunned.
es: The animals were horrified to learn that Snowball could be guilty of such an action.

en: There was a cry of indignation, and everyone began thinking out ways of catching Snowball if he should ever come back.
vi: Their anger erupted into screams, and each one thought of ways to capture Snowball alive if he was still lurking around.
tr: They were growling with anger, calculating how they would catch Snowball if he ever came back.
es: There was a cry of indignation and everyone began to devise a way to catch Snowball, if they ever found him.

en: Almost immediately the footprints of a pig were discovered in the grass at a little distance from the knoll.
vi: They also discovered pig tracks on the grass near the hill.
tr: Soon after, pig tracks were found among the grass a little further ahead of the small hill.
es: Almost immediately, the footprints of a pig were discovered in the grass, a short distance from the hill.

en: They could only be traced for a few yards, but appeared to lead to a hole in the hedge.
vi: The tracks extended for about ten meters, seemingly heading towards a hole in the fence.
tr: The tracks continued for a few meters, apparently leading to a hole in the fence.
es: The tracks could be followed for a few meters, but they seemed to lead to a hole in the hedge.

en: Napoleon snuffed deeply at them and pronounced them to be Snowball’s.
vi: Napoleon sniffed the tracks deeply and then declared that they were Snowball's tracks.
tr: After sniffing for a long time, Napoleon declared that the tracks belonged to Snowball.
es: Napoleon sniffed them well and declared that they were Snowball's.

en: He gave it as his opinion that Snowball had probably come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
vi: Napoleon said that Snowball might have come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
tr: He guessed that Snowball had come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
es: He opined that Snowball had probably come from "Foxwood Farm."

en: “No more delays, comrades!” cried Napoleon when the footprints had been examined.
vi: "Slow means death," Napoleon declared after examining the footprints, "we must continue the work, comrades!
tr: Napoleon, after examining the footprints, shouted, "Let's not waste time, comrades!"
es: —There is no time to lose, comrades! —shouted Napoleon once he had examined the footprints—.

en: “There is work to be done.
vi: "Slow means death," Napoleon declared after examining the footprints, "we must continue the work, comrades!
tr: "We have a lot of work to do.
es: There is much work to be done.

en: This very morning we begin rebuilding the windmill, and we will build all through the winter, rain or shine.
vi: We will start rebuilding the windmill from this very morning, we will work throughout this winter, regardless of wind, rain, or cold.
tr: Starting this morning, we will rebuild the windmill. We will work through the winter, regardless of snow and mud.
es: This very morning we will start rebuilding the windmill and we will reconstruct it throughout the winter, come rain or shine.

en: We will teach this miserable traitor that he cannot undo our work so easily.
vi: We will teach that treacherous scoundrel a lesson that he cannot stop us.
tr: We will show this lowly traitor that he cannot defeat us so easily.
es: We will show that miserable traitor that he cannot undo our work so easily.

en: Remember, comrades, there must be no alteration in our plans: they shall be carried out to the day.
vi: Please remember, comrades: our plan remains unchanged. We are determined to complete the construction of the windmill on time.
tr: Keep in mind, comrades, there should not be the slightest disruption in our plans; all plans must be executed day by day.
es: Remember, comrades; there must be no alteration in our plans, which will be carried out no matter what.

en: Forward, comrades!
vi: Comrades, forward!
tr: Come on, comrades!
es: Forward, comrades!

en: Long live the windmill!
vi: Long live the windmill!
tr: Long live the windmill!
es: Long live the windmill!

en: Long live Animal Farm!”
vi: Long live Animal Farm!". George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: Long live Animal Farm!"
es: Long live "Animal Farm"!

en: Chapter 7
vi: Chapter 7
tr: Chapter Seven
es: VII

en: It was a bitter winter.
vi: The winter that year was very harsh.
tr: The winter was very harsh.
es: A harsh winter set in.

en: The stormy weather was followed by sleet and snow, and then by a hard frost which did not break till well into February.
vi: Storms followed by rain, then snow and frost; by February, the ice had not yet melted.
tr: After the storms, first came sleet, then snow, and later everything was covered in ice until February.
es: The stormy weather was followed by hail and snow and then by a severe frost that lasted until mid-February.

en: The animals carried on as best they could with the rebuilding of the windmill, well knowing that the outside world was watching them and that the envious human beings would rejoice and triumph if the mill were not finished on time.
vi: Yet the animals diligently rebuilt the windmill, knowing that people were watching them and those wicked people would have a reason to rejoice if they did not complete the project on time.
tr: The animals were working with all their might, knowing that the entire outside world had its eyes on Animal Farm, and that if the windmill was not completed on time, the envious humans would rejoice.
es: The animals managed as best they could to rebuild the windmill, for they knew well that the outside world was watching them and that the envious humans would rejoice and triumph over them if they did not finish the work on time.

en: Out of spite, the human beings pretended not to believe that it was Snowball who had destroyer the windmill: they said that it had fallen down because the walls were too thin.
vi: To provoke them, people even pretended not to believe that Snowball had destroyed the windmill; they claimed it collapsed because the walls were too thin.
tr: It seems that people do not believe that Snowball destroyed the windmill out of sheer stubbornness; they were saying that the windmill collapsed because its walls were built too thin.
es: Resentful, the humans pretended not to believe that it was Snowball who had destroyed the windmill; they claimed it collapsed because the walls were too thin.

en: The animals knew that this was not the case.
vi: But the animals were convinced that wasn't the case.
tr: Although the animals were not unaware that this was not true, it was decided that the walls, which were previously forty-five centimeters thick, would be built ninety centimeters thick this time; this required carrying much more stone.
es: The animals knew that wasn't true.

en: Still, it had been decided to build the walls three feet thick this time instead of eighteen inches as before, which meant collecting much larger quantities of stone.
vi: In any case, they decided to build the walls one meter thick instead of forty centimeters as before, which meant they needed to quarry more stone than before.
tr: Although the animals were not unaware that this was not true, it was decided that the walls, which were previously forty-five centimeters thick, would be built ninety centimeters thick this time; this required carrying much more stone.
es: Despite this, they decided to build the walls one meter thick instead of half a meter as before, which meant gathering a much larger amount of stones.

en: For a long time the quarry was full of snowdrifts and nothing could be done.
vi: The quarry had been buried under snow for a long time, so they couldn't start.
tr: Since the quarry remained under snow for a long time, nothing could be done.
es: For a long time, the quarry was completely covered by a layer of snow and nothing could be done.

en: Some progress was made in the dry frosty weather that followed, but it was cruel work, and the animals could not feel so hopeful about it as they had felt before.
vi: After that, although the weather was cold, it was dry, but the work was truly dreadful, and the animals were no longer as enthusiastic as before.
tr: Later, when the weather turned cold and frosty, they started working again, but they were facing great difficulties and were not as hopeful as before.
es: Some progress was made during the dry and cold period that followed, but it was a cruel labor and the animals did not feel as optimistic as before.

en: They were always cold, and usually hungry as well.
vi: They were not only cold but also constantly hungry.
tr: They were freezing from the cold and often working on an empty stomach.
es: They were always cold and often hungry.

en: Only Boxer and Clover never lost heart.
vi: Only Boxer and Clover remained enthusiastic.
tr: Only Boxer and Clover had not lost their courage.
es: Only Boxer and Clover never lost heart.

en: Squealer made excellent speeches on the joy of service and the dignity of labour, but the other animals found more inspiration in Boxer’s strength and his never-failing cry of “I will work harder!”
vi: Squealer encouraged the movement with speeches, eloquently proving that labor was happiness and glory. But Squealer's speeches had no effect; it was Boxer's strength and his motto "I will work harder" that greatly motivated the others.
tr: Squealer was giving tremendous speeches about the happiness of serving the public and the honor of labor, and Boxer's strength and his constant cry of "I will work harder!" were inciting and motivating the animals.
es: Squealer gave magnificent speeches about the pride of service and the dignity of labor, but the other animals found more inspiration in Boxer's strength and his unfailing cry: "I will work harder!"

en: In January food fell short.
vi: Food supplies began to run out in January.
tr: In January, the food supplies began to run out.
es: In January, food was scarce.

en: The corn ration was drastically reduced, and it was announced that an extra potato ration would be issued to make up for it.
vi: Rations of grain were reduced, replaced by potatoes.
tr: Grain rations were significantly reduced, and it was announced that extra potatoes would be given to make up for the shortfall.
es: The corn ration was drastically reduced, and it was announced that, in compensation, a supplementary ration of potatoes would be given.

en: Then it was discovered that the greater part of the potato crop had been frosted in the clamps, which had not been covered thickly enough.
vi: It was then discovered that most of the piled-up potatoes had rotted due to improper covering, leaving very few edible ones.
tr: But soon it was discovered that the potatoes had frozen because they were not sufficiently covered.
es: But then it was discovered that most of the potato harvest had frozen due to insufficient protection.

en: The potatoes had become soft and discoloured, and only a few were edible.
vi: It was then discovered that most of the piled-up potatoes had rotted due to improper covering, leaving very few edible ones.
tr: Very few of the potatoes, which had softened and spoiled, were edible.
es: The tubers had softened and discolored, and very few were edible.

en: For days at a time the animals had nothing to eat but chaff and mangels.
vi: Many days, they only had grass and turnips to eat.
tr: For days, they ate nothing but peelings and beets.
es: For entire days, the animals had nothing to eat except straw and beets.

en: Starvation seemed to stare them in the face.
vi: Famine began to threaten.
tr: They were now on the brink of starvation.
es: The specter of hunger seemed to stare them in the face.

en: It was vitally necessary to conceal this fact from the outside world.
vi: This information must be kept strictly confidential, not to be disclosed to those around.
tr: This situation absolutely had to be kept hidden from the outside world.
es: It was absolutely necessary to hide that from the outside world.

en: Emboldened by the collapse of the windmill, the human beings were inventing fresh lies about Animal Farm.
vi: Excited by the collapse of the windmill, people spread even more false rumors about Animal Farm.
tr: Emboldened by the destruction of the windmill, people were inventing new lies about Animal Farm.
es: Encouraged by the collapse of the windmill, humans were inventing new lies about "Animal Farm."

en: Once again it was being put about that all the animals were dying of famine and disease, and that they were continually fighting among themselves and had resorted to cannibalism and infanticide.
vi: They gossiped that the animals were on the verge of dying from hunger and disease, that they fought all day, that they were eating each other, and even killing the young ones.
tr: Again, rumors spread that all the animals were being decimated by famine and disease, constantly fighting with each other, that cannibalism was rampant, and that newborns were being slaughtered.
es: Once again, it was being spread that all the animals were dying of hunger and disease, that they were constantly fighting among themselves, and had fallen into cannibalism and infanticide.

en: Napoleon was well aware of the bad results that might follow if the real facts of the food situation were known, and he decided to make use of mr Whymper to spread a contrary impression.
vi: Napoleon understood that there would be many troubles if outsiders knew the farm was facing food shortages, so he decided to use Whymper as a tool for counter-propaganda.
tr: Napoleon, very well aware of the bad consequences that could arise if the truth about the food situation were known, decided to use Mr. Whymper to create the opposite effect.
es: Napoleon was well aware of the disastrous consequences that would result from the discovery of the true food situation, and decided to use Mr. Whymper to spread a contrary impression.

en: Hitherto the animals had had little or no contact with Whymper on his weekly visits: now, however, a few selected animals, mostly sheep, were instructed to remark casually in his hearing that rations had been increased.
vi: Previously, the animals usually stood at a distance whenever Whymper visited the farm, but now some selected ones, mainly sheep, were allowed to come closer and, as if by chance, mention that rations had increased lately.
tr: Until that day, the animals either rarely encountered Whymper, who came to the farm every week, or did not encounter him at all. However, this time, a group of animals, mostly sheep, were instructed to loiter near Mr. Whymper and, pretending to talk among themselves but loud enough for him to hear, mention that the rations had been increased.
es: Until then, the animals had little or no contact with Whymper during his weekly visits; now, however, a few selected beasts, mostly sheep, were instructed to casually comment within his hearing range that the rations had been increased.

en: In addition, Napoleon ordered the almost empty bins in the store-shed to be filled nearly to the brim with sand, which was then covered up with what remained of the grain and meal.
vi: Additionally, Napoleon ordered sand to be poured almost to the brim of the bins in the storehouse and then covered it with grain and flour.
tr: Napoleon ordered that the nearly empty barrels in the barn be filled with sand and that the sand be covered with the remaining grain and feed.
es: Moreover, Napoleon ordered that the nearly empty bins in the sheds be filled to the top with sand and then covered with what little grain and forage remained.

en: On some suitable pretext Whymper was led through the store-shed and allowed to catch a glimpse of the bins.
vi: Whenever there was an opportunity, they would lead Whymper past the storehouse so he could see the food stored there.
tr: Whymper was taken to the barn under some pretext and made to see the barrels, seemingly full to the brim, even if only out of the corner of his eye.
es: Under an appropriate pretext, Whymper was led through those sheds and allowed to take a look at the bins.

en: He was deceived, and continued to report to the outside world that there was no food shortage on Animal Farm.
vi: Whymper was deceived and often told everyone that Animal Farm still had enough food.
tr: Falling for Napoleon's trick, Whymper began to spread the word everywhere he went that there was no food shortage at Animal Farm.
es: They managed to deceive him, and he continued to report to the outside world that there was no food shortage on "Animal Farm."

en: Nevertheless, towards the end of January it became obvious that it would be necessary to procure some more grain from somewhere.
vi: However, by the end of January, it became clear that they needed to find a way to buy more grain.
tr: By the end of January, it became inevitable to get some more grain from somewhere.
es: However, by the end of January, it was evident that there was a need to obtain more grain from somewhere.

en: In these days Napoleon rarely appeared in public, but spent all his time in the farmhouse, which was guarded at each door by fierce-looking dogs.
vi: These days, Napoleon rarely went outside; he stayed in the main house, with fierce dogs guarding all the entrances strictly.
tr: In those days, Napoleon was rarely seen, not stepping outside the farmhouse guarded by ferocious dogs.
es: During those days, Napoleon rarely appeared in public; he spent all his time inside the house, whose doors were guarded by fierce-looking dogs.

en: When he did emerge, it was in a ceremonial manner, with an escort of six dogs who closely surrounded him and growled if anyone came too near.
vi: If he did go outside, he was always escorted by six dogs, who would immediately bare their teeth and growl threateningly if any other animals came near.
tr: When he did come out, he wandered around with six dogs acting as his bodyguards, not acknowledging anyone, and if anyone got too close, the dogs would immediately growl.
es: When he did appear, it was in a ceremonious manner, with an escort of six dogs that closely surrounded him and growled if anyone came too close.

en: Frequently he did not even appear on Sunday mornings, but issued his orders through one of the other pigs, usually Squealer.
vi: He also no longer participated in the Sunday Meetings, delegating another pig, usually Squealer, to read the work assignments instead.
tr: Napoleon, who no longer attended the Sunday morning meetings, communicated his orders through one of the other pigs, usually Squealer.
es: He was no longer seen on Sunday mornings either, but gave his orders through another pig, who was usually Squealer.

en: One Sunday morning Squealer announced that the hens, who had just come in to lay again, must surrender their eggs.
vi: One time, on a Sunday, Chỉ Điểm declared that the hens, who had just started laying eggs, must hand over their eggs.
tr: One Sunday morning, Squealer announced that the hens, who were just about to lay eggs, had to give their eggs to the farm management.
es: One Sunday morning, Squealer announced that the hens, who were starting to lay eggs again, had to deliver their eggs.

en: Napoleon had accepted, through Whymper, a contract for four hundred eggs a week.
vi: Through Whymper, Napoleon had signed a contract to supply four hundred eggs each week.
tr: Napoleon had signed a contract mediated by Whymper; according to the contract, they had to deliver four hundred eggs per week.
es: Napoleon had signed, through Whymper, a contract to sell four hundred eggs weekly.

en: The price of these would pay for enough grain and meal to keep the farm going till summer came on and conditions were easier.
vi: The money from selling the eggs would be enough to buy food until summer, and by then everything would be easier.
tr: With the money from the eggs, they would buy grain and feed to sustain the farm until summer came and things improved.
es: The price of these would be enough to buy a sufficient amount of grain and food, and would allow the farm to subsist until summer arrived and conditions improved.

en: When the hens heard this, they raised a terrible outcry.
vi: The hens squawked loudly.
tr: As soon as the chickens heard the news, they caused a commotion.
es: When the hens heard this, they raised a great clamor.

en: They had been warned earlier that this sacrifice might be necessary, but had not believed that it would really happen.
vi: Previously, they had been reminded that they needed to sacrifice, but they did not expect things to be this bad.
tr: Although they had been warned before that such a sacrifice might be necessary, they honestly never believed it would actually happen one day.
es: They had been warned beforehand that this sacrifice would be necessary, but they did not believe that this reality would come to pass.

en: They were just getting their clutches ready for the spring sitting, and they protested that to take the eggs away now was murder.
vi: They had prepared nests for the spring hatching, declaring that taking the eggs now was akin to murder.
tr: What else could it be but murder to take the eggs just when they were preparing for the spring hatching?
es: They were preparing their nests to brood in the spring and protested, saying that taking their eggs was a crime.

en: For the first time since the expulsion of Jones, there was something resembling a rebellion.
vi: Since the expulsion of Mr. Jones, this was the first time there had been a gathering resembling a riot.
tr: For the first time since Jones was expelled from the farm, something resembling a rebellion occurred.
es: For the first time since Jones's expulsion, there was something resembling a rebellion.

en: Led by three young Black Minorca pullets, the hens made a determined effort to thwart Napoleon’s wishes.
vi: Three young Minorca hens led the uprising against Napoleon's plan.
tr: The chickens, led by three Black Minorca pullets, resolutely opposed Napoleon's command.
es: Led by three young Black Minorca hens, the hens made a determined attempt to thwart Napoleon's wishes.

en: Their method was to fly up to the rafters and there lay their eggs, which smashed to pieces on the floor.
vi: Their tactic was to fly up to the rafters and lay their eggs so they would break.
tr: They perched on the roof beams and laid their eggs there, which then fell and broke on the ground.
es: Their protest was to fly up to the rafters and lay their eggs there, which shattered upon hitting the ground.

en: Napoleon acted swiftly and ruthlessly.
vi: Napoleon acted swiftly and decisively.
tr: Napoleon, undoubtedly, did not delay in taking swift and ruthless measures.
es: Napoleon acted quickly and mercilessly.

en: He ordered the hens’ rations to be stopped, and decreed that any animal giving so much as a grain of corn to a hen should be punished by death.
vi: He ordered that the hens were not to be fed and declared that anyone giving them even a grain of corn would be executed immediately.
tr: He not only ordered the chickens' rations to be cut off, but also issued a decree that any animal attempting to give even a bit of food to the chickens would be sentenced to death.
es: He ordered that the hens' rations be suspended and decreed that any animal giving even a grain of corn to a hen would be punished with death.

en: The dogs saw to it that these orders were carried out.
vi: The dogs were assigned to monitor them.
tr: The dogs would ensure compliance with the orders.
es: The dogs ensured that the orders were carried out.

en: For five days the hens held out, then they capitulated and went back to their nesting boxes.
vi: The hens held out for five days, but eventually had to surrender and return to laying in their nests as before.
tr: Although the chickens resisted for about five days, they eventually surrendered and returned to their nests.
es: The hens held out for five days, then capitulated and returned to their nests.

en: Nine hens had died in the meantime.
vi: Nine hens died.
tr: Meanwhile, nine chickens that died were buried in the orchard, and it was said that they had died of bloody diarrhea.
es: Nine hens died in the meantime.

en: Their bodies were buried in the orchard, and it was given out that they had died of coccidiosis.
vi: They were considered to have died from coccidiosis and were buried in the garden.
tr: Meanwhile, nine chickens that died were buried in the orchard, and it was said that they had died of bloody diarrhea.
es: Their bodies were buried in the orchard and it was reported that they had died of coccidiosis.

en: Whymper heard nothing of this affair, and the eggs were duly delivered, a grocer’s van driving up to the farm once a week to take them away.
vi: Whymper knew nothing of this and a cart came weekly to collect the eggs.
tr: Whymper was not even aware of what had happened; the eggs were delivered on time, and a cart that came to the farm once a week took the eggs away.
es: Whymper did not find out about this matter and the eggs were duly delivered; the grocer's van came to the farm weekly to collect them.

en: All this while no more had been seen of Snowball.
vi: Snowball was nowhere to be seen.
tr: Meanwhile, Snowball had not been seen around; rumors had spread that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms, either at Foxwood or Pinchfield.
es: During all this time there were no signs of Snowball.

en: He was rumoured to be hiding on one of the neighbouring farms, either Foxwood or Pinchfield.
vi: There were rumors that he was hiding in Foxwood or Pinchfield.
tr: Meanwhile, Snowball had not been seen around; rumors had spread that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms, either at Foxwood or Pinchfield.
es: It was rumored that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms: Foxwood or Pinchfield.

en: Napoleon was by this time on slightly better terms with the other farmers than before.
vi: Relations between Napoleon and the surrounding farms had somewhat improved.
tr: Napoleon's relations with the other farmers had somewhat improved.
es: Napoleon maintained better relations than before with the other farmers.

en: It happened that there was in the yard a pile of timber which had been stacked there ten years earlier when a beech spinney was cleared.
vi: At that time, they suddenly discovered a pile of timber in the yard, which had been felled about ten years ago.
tr: In the yard, there was a large pile of timber that had dried out completely because it had been cut down when a grove of hornbeam trees was cleared about ten years ago.
es: And it happened that in the yard there was a pile of timber for construction, which had been there for ten years, since a beech forest was felled.

en: It was well seasoned, and Whymper had advised Napoleon to sell it; both mr Pilkington and mr Frederick were anxious to buy it.
vi: The timber was found at just the right time, and Whymper advised Napoleon to sell it; both Pilkington and Frederick wanted to buy it.
tr: Whymper had advised Napoleon to sell them; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy the timber, but Napoleon couldn't decide to whom he should sell it.
es: It was well maintained and Whymper advised Napoleon to sell it; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy it.

en: Napoleon was hesitating between the two, unable to make up his mind.
vi: Napoleon hesitated, not knowing whom to sell it to.
tr: Whymper had advised Napoleon to sell them; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy the timber, but Napoleon couldn't decide to whom he should sell it.
es: Napoleon was undecided between the two, unable to make a resolution.

en: It was noticed that whenever he seemed on the point of coming to an agreement with Frederick, Snowball was declared to be in hiding at Foxwood, while, when he inclined toward Pilkington, Snowball was said to be at Pinchfield.
vi: Whenever he decided to sell to Frederick, there would be news that Snowball was hiding in Foxwood, but when he leaned towards Pilkington, there would be news that Snowball was in Pinchfield.
tr: When he seemed to be making a deal with Frederick, news would come that Snowball was hiding at Foxwood Farm, and when he seemed to be leaning towards Pilkington, rumors would spread that Snowball was concealed at Pinchfield Farm.
es: It was noted that when he seemed about to reach an agreement with Frederick, it was said that Snowball was hiding in Foxwood, and when he leaned towards Pilkington, it was claimed that Snowball was in Pinchfield.

en: Suddenly, early in the spring, an alarming thing was discovered.
vi: At the beginning of January, the entire camp suddenly became agitated because of an unexpected piece of news, like a bolt from the blue.
tr: It was the early days of spring; suddenly, a piece of news caused a commotion: Snowball was secretly coming to the farm after dark!
es: Suddenly, at the beginning of spring, something alarming was discovered.

en: Snowball was secretly frequenting the farm by night!
vi: It turned out that Snowball had been secretly infiltrating the camp at night!
tr: It was the early days of spring; suddenly, a piece of news caused a commotion: Snowball was secretly coming to the farm after dark!
es: Snowball was secretly frequenting the farm at night!

en: The animals were so disturbed that they could hardly sleep in their stalls.
vi: The animals were so worried that they lost sleep.
tr: The animals were so anxious that they couldn't sleep at night.
es: The animals were so disturbed that they could barely sleep in their stables.

en: Every night, it was said, he came creeping in under cover of darkness and performed all kinds of mischief.
vi: It was rumored that every night Snowball would sneak in to cause havoc.
tr: According to the rumors, Snowball was sneaking into the farm every night under the cover of darkness, causing all sorts of mischief.
es: Every night, it was said, he would sneak in under the cover of darkness and cause all sorts of damage.

en: He stole the corn, he upset the milk-pails, he broke the eggs, he trampled the seedbeds, he gnawed the bark off the fruit trees.
vi: He stole food, knocked over milk pails, broke eggs, trampled the seedlings, and chewed the bark of the trees in the garden.
tr: He was stealing the grain, knocking over the milk pails, breaking the eggs, trampling and crushing the seedlings, and gnawing the bark off the fruit trees.
es: He would steal the corn, overturn the milk pails, break the eggs, trample the seedlings, gnaw the bark of the fruit trees.

en: Whenever anything went wrong it became usual to attribute it to Snowball.
vi: Any difficulty or failure was blamed on Snowball.
tr: From then on, whenever something went wrong on the farm, Snowball was immediately blamed.
es: Whenever something went wrong, it became customary to always attribute it to Snowball.

en: If a window was broken or a drain was blocked up, someone was certain to say that Snowball had come in the night and done it, and when the key of the store-shed was lost, the whole farm was convinced that Snowball had thrown it down the well.
vi: If a window was broken or a drain was clogged, someone would say it was Snowball's doing, and even when the warehouse key was lost, the whole camp believed Snowball had thrown it down the well.
tr: If a window broke or a gutter got clogged, it was said that Snowball had come to the farm again at night and done it. One day, when the key to the storehouse was lost, the entire farm believed the rumor that Snowball had thrown the key into the well.
es: If a window was broken or a drain was clogged, it was a sure thing that someone would say Snowball had done it during the night, and when the key to the food shed was lost, the entire farm was convinced that Snowball had thrown it down the well.

en: Curiously enough, they went on believing this even after the mislaid key was found under a sack of meal.
vi: The strange thing was that even after the key was found under a sack of flour, the whole camp still believed it was Snowball's fault.
tr: Strangely enough, even when the lost key was found under a sack of flour, the animals did not stop believing in this rumor.
es: Curiously enough, they continued to believe this even after the lost key was found under a sack of flour.

en: The cows declared unanimously that Snowball crept into their stalls and milked them in their sleep.
vi: The cows insisted that at night Snowball would sneak into the barn and steal milk while they slept.
tr: The cows even claimed that Snowball had secretly entered their barn and milked them in their sleep.
es: The cows unanimously declared that Snowball had slipped into their stalls and milked them while they slept.

en: The rats, which had been troublesome that winter, were also said to be in league with Snowball.
vi: It was rumored that the rats, which had caused a lot of trouble last winter, were also in league with Snowball.
tr: It was also said that the rats, which had caused a lot of damage to the farm that winter, were in collaboration with Snowball.
es: It was also said that the mice, which had been quite troublesome that winter, were in league with Snowball.

en: Napoleon decreed that there should be a full investigation into Snowball’s activities.
vi: Napoleon ordered a thorough investigation into the activities of Snowball.
tr: Deciding that a thorough investigation into Snowball's schemes was necessary, Napoleon took his dogs and began to tour the farm buildings, probing and examining every nook and cranny; the other animals followed him at a respectful distance.
es: Napoleon ordered a thorough investigation of Snowball's activities.

en: With his dogs in attendance he set out and made a careful tour of inspection of the farm buildings, the other animals following at a respectful distance.
vi: Napoleon, escorted by a few dogs, surveyed all the buildings in the farm, while others followed at a distance.
tr: Deciding that a thorough investigation into Snowball's schemes was necessary, Napoleon took his dogs and began to tour the farm buildings, probing and examining every nook and cranny; the other animals followed him at a respectful distance.
es: With his entourage of dogs, he went out to inspect the farm buildings, followed at a prudent distance by the other animals.

en: At every few steps Napoleon stopped and snuffed the ground for traces of Snowball’s footsteps, which, he said, he could detect by the smell.
vi: He claimed he could smell Snowball, so he would stop every few steps to sniff the ground for traces.
tr: Claiming that he could find Snowball's trail by scent, Napoleon would stop every few steps to sniff the ground.
es: Every few steps, Napoleon would stop and sniff the ground, searching for traces of Snowball's footprints, which he claimed he could recognize by scent.

en: He snuffed in every corner, in the barn, in the cow-shed, in the henhouses, in the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere.
vi: He sniffed every corner, including the warehouse, the cow shed, the chicken coop, the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball everywhere.
tr: He left no corner of the barn, the cow shed, the henhouses, or the vegetable garden unsniffed and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere.
es: He sniffed in every corner, in the barn, in the cow shed, in the henhouses, in the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere.

en: He would put his snout to the ground, give several deep sniffs, ad exclaim in a terrible voice, “Snowball!
vi: He pressed his nose to the ground several times, inhaled deeply, and then declared in a chilling voice: "Snowball!
tr: Pressing his long snout to the ground and sniffing rapidly, he would then shout in a terrifying voice, "Snowball!
es: Pressing his snout to the ground, he would sniff deeply several times and then exclaim in a terrible voice: "Snowball!

en: He has been here!
vi: He has been here! I have recognized his scent!"
tr: He's been here! This is his scent!"
es: He has been here!

en: I can smell him distinctly!” and at the word “Snowball” all the dogs let out blood-curdling growls and showed their side teeth.
vi: Every time the word "Snowball" was mentioned, the dogs would bare their teeth and bark in agreement.
tr: Every time Napoleon shouted "Snowball!", the dogs would bare their teeth and emit blood-curdling growls.
es: I can smell him perfectly!" and upon hearing the word "Snowball," all the dogs would let out horrible growls and bare their fangs.

en: The animals were thoroughly frightened.
vi: Everyone trembled with fear.
tr: The animals were like they were possessed by a demon.
es: The animals were completely terrified.

en: It seemed to them as though Snowball were some kind of invisible influence, pervading the air about them and menacing them with all kinds of dangers.
vi: It felt as if the mysterious and powerful Tuyet Tron was lurking somewhere nearby, ready to unleash disaster upon them.
tr: Snowball seemed to have become invisible, constantly lurking around them, and it was impossible to predict what mischief he might cause next.
es: It seemed to them that Snowball was a kind of invisible curse that infested the breathable air and threatened them with all kinds of dangers.

en: In the evening Squealer called them together, and with an alarmed expression on his face told them that he had some serious news to report.
vi: That night, Chi Diem called everyone together and with a serious face, said that there was some urgent news to announce.
tr: In the evening, Squealer gathered all the animals together and, with a worried tone, said that he had important news.
es: At dusk, Squealer gathered them all, and with a troubled face, announced that he had serious news to communicate to them.

en: “Comrades!” cried Squealer, making little nervous skips, “a most terrible thing has been discovered.
vi: "Comrades!", he shouted, "we have discovered an unforgivable crime.
tr: Jumping from place to place nervously, he shouted, "Comrades!" "We have received a terrifying piece of news.
es: —Comrades —shouted Squealer, making some nervous little jumps—, something terrible has been discovered!

en: Snowball has sold himself to Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, who is even now plotting to attack us and take our farm away from us!
vi: Snowball has sold himself to Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, who is planning to attack and seize our farm!
tr: Traitor Snowball has allied with Frederick, the owner of Pinchfield Farm! Frederick is planning to attack us and take over our farm!
es: Snowball has sold himself to Frederick, from "Pinchfield Farm," and at this very moment he must be conspiring to attack us and take our farm!

en: Snowball is to act as his guide when the attack begins.
vi: Once war breaks out, Snowball will act as a guide.
tr: When the attack begins, Snowball will guide them.
es: Snowball will act as a guide when the attack begins.

en: But there is worse than that.
vi: But he is even more unscrupulous than that.
tr: There's more.
es: But there is something even worse.

en: We had thought that Snowball’s rebellion was caused simply by his vanity and ambition.
vi: Previously, we thought that Snowball's disruptions were due to his vanity and lust for power.
tr: We thought Snowball rebelled because of his arrogance and greed.
es: We had believed that Snowball's rebellion was motivated simply by his vanity and ambition.

en: But we were wrong, comrades.
vi: But comrades, we were wrong.
tr: But we were wrong, comrades.
es: But we were wrong, comrades.

en: Do you know what the real reason was?
vi: Do you know where the real reason lies?
tr: Do you know what the real reason was?
es: Do you know what the real reason was?

en: Snowball was in league with Jones from the very start!
vi: From the very beginning, he has been in league with Jones!
tr: Snowball was Jones' man from the very beginning!
es: Snowball was in agreement with Jones from the very beginning!

en: He was Jones’s secret agent all the time.
vi: He is Jones's undercover spy.
tr: He was a secret agent of Jones all along.
es: He has always been Jones's secret agent.

en: It has all been proved by documents which he left behind him and which we have only just discovered.
vi: The evidence is in the documents he left behind, which we have only recently discovered.
tr: We just captured the documents he left behind, and everything has come to light.
es: This has been proven by documents he left behind and that we have now discovered.

en: To my mind this explains a great deal, comrades.
vi: Comrades, I believe that explains a lot.
tr: As far as I'm concerned, everything is as clear as day, comrades.
es: To me, this explains many things, comrades: haven't we seen ourselves how he tried, fortunately without success, to provoke our defeat and annihilation in the "Battle of the Cowshed"?

en: Did we not see for ourselves how he attempted — fortunately without success — to get us defeated and destroyed at the Battle of the Cowshed?”
vi: Haven't we realized that he tried, fortunately unsuccessfully, to make us lose and disband during the Battle of the Cowshed?"
tr: Hadn't we already seen with our own eyes the schemes he plotted to defeat us in the Battle of the Cowshed? Fortunately, he failed."
es: To me, this explains many things, comrades: haven't we seen ourselves how he tried, fortunately without success, to provoke our defeat and annihilation in the "Battle of the Cowshed"?

en: The animals were stupefied.
vi: Everyone was stunned.
tr: The animals were dumbfounded.
es: The animals were stunned.

en: This was a wickedness far outdoing Snowball’s destruction of the windmill.
vi: This crime was truly horrifying, far worse than the destruction of the windmill.
tr: This was a betrayal much greater than destroying the windmill.
es: That was an evil much greater than the destruction of the windmill.

en: But it was some minutes before they could fully take it in.
vi: It took them a while to fully grasp the severity of the situation.
tr: But as soon as their initial shock passed, they remembered, or seemed to remember, how Snowball had fought bravely at the forefront during the Battle of the Cowshed, how he had rallied and encouraged them when they were about to retreat, and how he had charged forward even when he was wounded by the pellets from Jones's gun.
es: But it took them several minutes to understand its meaning.

en: They all remembered, or thought they remembered, how they had seen Snowball charging ahead of them at the Battle of the Cowshed, how he had rallied and encouraged them at every turn, and how he had not paused for an instant even when the pellets from Jones’s gun had wounded his back.
vi: They all still remembered, or thought they remembered, the image of Snowball leading the charge in the Battle of the Cowshed, uniting and encouraging them, never giving up even after being wounded by Jones.
tr: But as soon as their initial shock passed, they remembered, or seemed to remember, how Snowball had fought bravely at the forefront during the Battle of the Cowshed, how he had rallied and encouraged them when they were about to retreat, and how he had charged forward even when he was wounded by the pellets from Jones's gun.
es: They all remembered, or thought they remembered, how they had seen Snowball leading the attack in the "Battle of the Cowshed," how he had rallied and encouraged them at every setback, and how he had not hesitated for a single moment, even though Jones's shotgun pellets had wounded him in the back.

en: At first it was a little difficult to see how this fitted in with his being on Jones’s side.
vi: It was hard to imagine how that could have happened if he had been Jones's spy.
tr: It was indeed a bit difficult to reconcile Snowball's heroism in the battle with the idea of him being Jones's secret agent.
es: At first, it was a bit difficult to understand how all this fit with the fact that he was on Jones's side.

en: Even Boxer, who seldom asked questions, was puzzled.
vi: Even Boxer, usually so taciturn, felt confused.
tr: Even Boxer, who rarely asked questions, was confused.
es: Even Boxer, who rarely asked questions, was perplexed.

en: He lay down, tucked his fore hoofs beneath him, shut his eyes, and with a hard effort managed to formulate his thoughts.
vi: Boxer lay down, tucked his forelegs under his belly, closed his eyes, tried to concentrate, and finally said:
tr: He lay down, tucked his forelegs under him; he closed his eyes, trying to clear his head.
es: He lay down, tucked his front legs under his chest, closed his eyes, and with great effort managed to piece together his thoughts.

en: “I do not believe that,” he said.
vi: "I don't believe it, during the Snowball Barn Campaign, he fought bravely.
tr: "I don't believe this," he said.
es: —I don't believe that —he said—, Snowball fought bravely in the "Battle of the Cowshed."

en: “Snowball fought bravely at the Battle of the Cowshed.
vi: "I don't believe it, during the Snowball Barn Campaign, he fought bravely.
tr: "Snowball fought like a lion in the Battle of the Cowshed.
es: —I don't believe that —he said—, Snowball fought bravely in the "Battle of the Cowshed."

en: I saw him myself.
vi: I saw it with my own eyes.
tr: I saw it with my own eyes.
es: I saw it myself.

en: Did we not give him ‘Animal Hero, first Class,’ immediately afterwards?”
vi: Didn't we just honor him as a First Class Animal Hero right after the campaign?"
tr: Didn't we award him the 'Animal Hero, First Class' medal immediately after the battle ended?"
es: Didn't we immediately award him the "Animal Hero, First Class" right after?

en: “That was our mistake, comrade.
vi: "Comrades, that is precisely our mistake."
tr: Squealer replied, "We were mistaken, comrade."
es: —That was our mistake, comrade.

en: For we know now — it is all written down in the secret documents that we have found — that in reality he was trying to lure us to our doom.”
vi: "Now we know that these matters are clearly documented in the secret files we have just found; it was intended to lure us into a trap for the others to eliminate us."
tr: "In fact, he was trying to lead us to ruin; the secret documents we obtained explain everything."
es: Because now we know —it is all written in the secret documents we have found— that in reality, he was dragging us towards our ruin.

en: “But he was wounded,” said Boxer.
vi: "But it was also injured," said the Warrior, "we all saw the blood flowing as it was running."
tr: "But she was injured," said Boxer.
es: —But he was wounded —argued Boxer—.

en: “We all saw him running with blood.”
vi: "But it was also injured," said the Warrior, "we all saw the blood flowing as it was running."
tr: "We all saw her running around covered in blood."
es: We all saw him bleeding.

en: “That was part of the arrangement!” cried Squealer.
vi: "It was all prearranged!", Squealer shouted, "Jones's shot only grazed him.
tr: "It was a staged fight!" shouted Squealer, jumping up and down.
es: —That was part of the agreement! —shouted Squealer—.

en: “Jones’s shot only grazed him.
vi: "It was all prearranged!", Squealer shouted, "Jones's shot only grazed him.
tr: "The bullets actually just grazed him.
es: Jones's shot only grazed him.

en: I could show you this in his own writing, if you were able to read it.
vi: If only you comrades could read, I could show you how Snowball wrote it all down in black and white.
