tr: If you could read, I would show you his own writing; then you would understand everything.
es: I could prove this to you, which is written in his own handwriting, if you could read it.

en: The plot was for Snowball, at the critical moment, to give the signal for flight and leave the field to the enemy.
vi: They had agreed that at the most critical moment, Snowball would order a retreat, leaving the battlefield to the enemy.
tr: All of Snowball's dirty laundry has come out: He was going to find an excuse to give the order to retreat and leave the field to the enemy, and we had no idea.
es: The plan was that Snowball, at the critical moment, would give the signal to retreat, leaving the field in the enemy's hands.

en: And he very nearly succeeded — I will even say, comrades, he WOULD have succeeded if it had not been for our heroic Leader, Comrade Napoleon.
vi: And he almost succeeded, I can say he certainly would have succeeded if it weren't for our heroic Leader, Comrade Napoleon.
tr: He almost succeeded too. In fact, comrades, I have no doubt that if it weren't for our brave leader Comrade Napoleon, he would have definitely done it.
es: And he almost succeeded: I will say more, comrades: he would have succeeded if it weren't for our heroic Leader, comrade Napoleon.

en: Do you not remember how, just at the moment when Jones and his men had got inside the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and fled, and many animals followed him?
vi: Do you remember when Jones and his men entered the yard? Snowball turned tail and many of the animals followed him.
tr: Have you forgotten that when Jones and his men stormed into the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and started to run away, and many animals followed him?
es: Do you remember how, at the precise moment when Jones and his men reached the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and fled, and many animals followed him?

en: And do you not remember, too, that it was just at that moment, when panic was spreading and all seemed lost, that Comrade Napoleon sprang forward with a cry of ‘Death to Humanity!’ and sank his teeth in Jones’s leg?
vi: Don't you remember that at that very moment, when chaos began to spread and it seemed the front was about to break, Comrade Napoleon charged forward and shouted "Kill!" and then dashed straight at Jones's legs?
tr: At that very moment, when we were all panicking and thought the battle was lost, don't you remember how Comrade Napoleon charged forward shouting 'Death to Humanity!' and sank his teeth into Jones' leg?
es: And do you also remember that just at that moment, when panic spread and it seemed that all was lost, comrade Napoleon leaped forward with the cry of "Death to Humanity!" and sank his teeth into Jones's leg?

en: Surely you remember THAT, comrades?” exclaimed Squealer, frisking from side to side.
vi: Comrades, surely you remember that detail!", Squealer said, hopping from side to side.
tr: You can't have forgotten that, comrades!"
es: Surely you have not forgotten this, comrades — exclaimed Squealer.

en: Now when Squealer described the scene so graphically, it seemed to the animals that they did remember it.
vi: Now, when Chỉ Điểm described it so vividly, the animals seemed to remember.
tr: When Squealer described the scene so vividly, the animals almost seemed to remember it.
es: As Squealer described the scene so graphically, it seemed to the animals that they remembered it.

en: At any rate, they remembered that at the critical moment of the battle Snowball had turned to flee.
vi: In any case, they clearly remembered that Tuyết Tròn had turned and run at the critical moment.
tr: At the very least, they remembered Snowball turning tail and running at the critical moment of the battle.
es: In any case, they knew that at the critical moment of the battle, Snowball had turned to flee.

en: But Boxer was still a little uneasy.
vi: But Chiến Sĩ still felt uneasy.
tr: But there was still a sense of unease in Boxer.
es: But Boxer was still somewhat undecided.

en: “I do not believe that Snowball was a traitor at the beginning,” he said finally.
vi: "I don't believe that Snowball betrayed us from the beginning," he said, "later on, it was a different story."
tr: He finally let the cat out of the bag: "I don't believe Snowball was a traitor from the beginning.
es: —I don't believe that Snowball was a traitor at the beginning —he finally said—.

en: “What he has done since is different.
vi: "I don't believe that Snowball betrayed us from the beginning," he said, "later on, it was a different story."
tr: I have nothing to say about what he did later.
es: What he may have done since then is different.

en: But I believe that at the Battle of the Cowshed he was a good comrade.”
vi: "I believe that during the Cowshed Campaign, Snowball was still a good comrade."
tr: But I believe that Snowball acted like a true comrade during the Battle of the Cowshed."
es: But I believe that in the "Battle of the Cowshed" he was a good comrade.

en: “Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon,” announced Squealer, speaking very slowly and firmly, “has stated categorically — categorically, comrade — that Snowball was Jones’s agent from the very beginning — yes, and from long before the Rebellion was ever thought of.”
vi: "Our leader, Comrade Napoleon," Squealer said slowly and firmly, "has categorically declared, I repeat, comrades, categorically declared that from the very beginning Snowball has been a spy for Mr. Jones, even before we thought about the Rebellion."
tr: Squealer, in a low but determined voice, said, "Look, comrade." "Our leader Comrade Napoleon has unequivocally, yes unequivocally, revealed that Snowball has been Jones's agent from the very beginning, even before there was any talk of the Rebellion."
es: —Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon —announced Squealer, speaking slowly and firmly—, has categorically, categorically, comrades, stated that Snowball was Jones's agent from the very beginning of everything and in any case, long before the Rebellion was even thought of.

en: “Ah, that is different!” said Boxer.
vi: "That's different!", Chiến
tr: Upon this, "Ah, then that's different!" said Boxer.
es: —Ah, that's different! —shouted Boxer—.

en: “If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right.”
vi: Sỹ said, "Comrade Napoleon has spoken, so it must be right."
tr: "If Comrade Napoleon says so, then it must be so."
es: If Comrade Napoleon says so, it must be true.

en: “That is the true spirit, comrade!” cried Squealer, but it was noticed he cast a very ugly look at Boxer with his little twinkling eyes.
vi: "That is a truly constructive attitude, comrades!", Chỉ Điểm exclaimed, but everyone could see its narrow, shifty, resentful eyes glaring straight at Chiến Sĩ.
tr: Squealer shouted, "Now, this is what I call the spirit of comradeship!" But it did not go unnoticed that he was glaring at Boxer with his tiny, constantly blinking eyes.
es: —That's the true spirit, comrade! —shouted Squealer, but it was noticeable that he cast a sullen glance at Boxer with his flashing little eyes.

en: He turned to go, then paused and added impressively: “I warn every animal on this farm to keep his eyes very wide open.
vi: It was about to leave, but added menacingly, "I must warn you all to be vigilant.
tr: Just as he was about to leave, he suddenly stopped and added in an impressive voice: "I warn all the animals on this farm, keep your eyes wide open.
es: He turned to leave, then stopped and added impressively—: I warn every animal on this farm to keep their eyes wide open, because we have reason to believe that some of Snowball's secret agents are among us and lurking at this very moment!

en: For we have reason to think that some of Snowball’s secret agents are lurking among us at this moment!”
vi: There is ample reason to believe that there are still agents of Tuyết Tròn in this camp!"
tr: It is obvious that Snowball's agents are already walking among us freely!"
es: He turned to leave, then stopped and added impressively—: I warn every animal on this farm to keep their eyes wide open, because we have reason to believe that some of Snowball's secret agents are among us and lurking at this very moment!

en: Four days later, in the late afternoon, Napoleon ordered all the animals to assemble in the yard.
vi: Four days later, in the afternoon, Napoleon ordered everyone to be present in the yard.
tr: Four days later, towards evening, Napoleon ordered all the animals to gather in the yard.
es: Four days later, at dusk, Napoleon ordered the animals to gather in the yard.

en: When they were all gathered together, Napoleon emerged from the farmhouse, wearing both his medals (for he had recently awarded himself “Animal Hero, First Class”, and “Animal Hero, Second Class”), with his nine huge dogs frisking round him and uttering growls that sent shivers down all the animals’ spines.
vi: When everyone had gathered, Napoleon appeared, wearing two medals on his chest (he had recently awarded himself the titles of Animal Hero First Class and Animal Hero Second Class) with nine large dogs, running around and barking so loudly that the animals were terrified to the point of getting goosebumps.
tr: When everyone had gathered, Napoleon appeared with his medals on his chest (some time ago, he had awarded himself both the "First Class Animal Hero" and the "Second Class Animal Hero" medals); nine large dogs were circling around him, growling every now and then, instilling fear in the hearts of all the animals.
es: When they were all assembled, Napoleon emerged from the house, wearing his two medals (because he had recently named himself "Animal Hero First Class" and "Animal Hero Second Class"), with his nine enormous dogs leaping around and emitting growls that sent chills down the other animals' spines.

en: They all cowered silently in their places, seeming to know in advance that some terrible thing was about to happen.
vi: They sat silently, huddled together, as if awaiting a fierce storm.
tr: As if sensing that something very bad was going to happen, everyone quietly crouched down on the ground.
es: They all quietly took their places, seeming to know in advance that terrible things were about to happen.

en: Napoleon stood sternly surveying his audience; then he uttered a high-pitched whimper.
vi: Napoleon sternly looked at the crowd, then hissed sharply like a whistle.
tr: Napoleon stood there, scanning the crowd with a stern gaze; then suddenly let out a high-pitched scream.
es: Napoleon stood observing his audience sternly; then he let out a sharp growl.

en: Immediately the dogs bounded forward, seized four of the pigs by the ear and dragged them, squealing with pain and terror, to Napoleon’s feet.
vi: Immediately, the dogs rushed in to bite the ears of four pigs, some of which fainted from pain and fear, then dragged themselves to Napoleon's feet.
tr: The dogs, as soon as they heard the scream, leapt forward and grabbed four of the pigs by their ears, dragging the squealing and terrified animals to Napoleon's feet.
es: Immediately, the dogs leaped forward, grabbed four of the pigs by their ears, and dragged them, terrified and squealing in pain, to Napoleon's feet.

en: The pigs’ ears were bleeding, the dogs had tasted blood, and for a few moments they appeared to go quite mad.
vi: Blood flowed from the pigs' ears, and the dogs went mad when they smelled the fresh blood.
tr: Blood was dripping from the pigs' ears, and the dogs, having tasted the blood, went wild.
es: The pigs' ears were bleeding; the dogs had tasted blood and for a few moments seemed crazed.

en: To the amazement of everybody, three of them flung themselves upon Boxer.
vi: Everyone was even more surprised when three dogs charged at Boxer.
tr: Suddenly, three of the dogs, to everyone's astonishment, leapt at Boxer.
es: To everyone's astonishment, three of them pounced on Boxer.

en: Boxer saw them coming and put out his great hoof, caught a dog in mid-air, and pinned him to the ground.
vi: Boxer quickly raised his leg to grab one and pinned it to the ground.
tr: As soon as Boxer saw them coming, he raised his huge foreleg, caught one of the dogs in mid-air, and slammed it to the ground.
es: He saw them coming and stretched out his enormous hoof, caught one in mid-air, and pinned it to the ground.

en: The dog shrieked for mercy and the other two fled with their tails between their legs.
vi: That dog immediately cried out for mercy, while the other two tucked their tails and ran away.
tr: The dog, pinned to the ground, screamed for mercy, while the other two tucked their tails between their legs and ran off.
es: The dog squealed for mercy and the others fled with their tails between their legs.

en: Boxer looked at Napoleon to know whether he should crush the dog to death or let it go.
vi: Boxer looked at Napoleon as if to ask whether to crush or release the captured dog.
tr: Boxer's eyes were on Napoleon; should he crush and kill the dog, or let it go?
es: Boxer looked at Napoleon to see if he should continue crushing the dog to death or if he should release it.

en: Napoleon appeared to change countenance, and sharply ordered Boxer to let the dog go, whereat Boxer lifted his hoof, and the dog slunk away, bruised and howling.
vi: Napoleon changed his expression and ordered Boxer to release it, so Boxer lifted his leg, and the pitiful dog, bruised all over, limped away while whimpering.
tr: Napoleon's face was contorted; he ordered Boxer in a harsh voice to release the dog. Upon this, Boxer lifted his foot off the dog, which then slunk away, whimpering in pain.
es: Napoleon seemed to change his expression and brusquely ordered him to release the dog, to which Boxer lifted his hoof and the dog fled, battered and whimpering.

en: Presently the tumult died down.
vi: Order was quickly restored.
tr: Soon after, the place had calmed down.
es: Soon the tumult ceased.

en: The four pigs waited, trembling, with guilt written on every line of their countenances.
vi: Four pigs lay awaiting their fate, trembling, guilt evident on every face.
tr: The four pigs, whose guilt was written all over their faces, were trembling and waiting.
es: The four pigs waited, trembling, with guilt written in every furrow of their faces.

en: Napoleon now called upon them to confess their crimes.
vi: Napoleon ordered them to confess their crimes.
tr: Napoleon turned to them and asked them to confess their crimes.
es: Napoleon demanded that they confess their crimes.

en: They were the same four pigs as had protested when Napoleon abolished the Sunday Meetings.
vi: These were the four pigs who had stood up to oppose Napoleon when he decided to abolish the Sunday Meetings.
tr: These were the pigs who had opposed Napoleon's decision to abolish the Sunday meetings.
es: They were the same four pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the Sunday meetings.

en: Without any further prompting they confessed that they had been secretly in touch with Snowball ever since his expulsion, that they had collaborated with him in destroying the windmill, and that they had entered into an agreement with him to hand over Animal Farm to mr Frederick.
vi: They immediately confessed to having secretly communicated with Snowball since his expulsion, helped him destroy the windmill, and conspired with him to sell Animal Farm to Frederick.
tr: Without much resistance, they confessed everything: They had secretly met with Snowball since the day he was expelled from the farm, collaborated in the destruction of the windmill, and had reached an agreement to transfer Animal Farm to Mr. Frederick.
es: Without further prompting, they confessed that they had been in clandestine contact with Snowball since his expulsion, collaborated with him in the destruction of the windmill, and agreed to hand over "Animal Farm" to Mr. Frederick.

en: They added that Snowball had privately admitted to them that he had been Jones’s secret agent for years past.
vi: They also added that Snowball had told them he had been Jones's spy for years.
tr: They also did not hesitate to say that Snowball had confessed to them that he had been Jones's secret agent for years.
es: They added that Snowball had admitted, confidentially, that he had been Mr. Jones's secret agent for many years.

en: When they had finished their confession, the dogs promptly tore their throats out, and in a terrible voice Napoleon demanded whether any other animal had anything to confess.
vi: As soon as they finished speaking, the dogs leapt up and tore out their throats, after which Napoleon, in a menacing voice that sent chills down their spines, asked if any other animal felt the need to confess.
tr: As soon as their confessions were complete, the dogs leapt upon them and tore their throats out. Then, Napoleon turned back to the assembly and said in a terrible voice, "If there are any other animals who wish to confess, let them come forward."
es: When they finished their confession, the dogs, without wasting time, tore their throats out, and meanwhile, Napoleon, in a terrible voice, asked if any other animal had anything to confess.

en: The three hens who had been the ringleaders in the attempted rebellion over the eggs now came forward and stated that Snowball had appeared to them in a dream and incited them to disobey Napoleon’s orders.
vi: The three chickens who led the rebellion over the eggs stepped forward and declared that they had dreamt of Snowball inciting them to disobey Napoleon's orders.
tr: The three hens who had tried to lead the egg rebellion stepped forward and declared that in their dreams, Snowball had urged them to disobey Napoleon's orders.
es: The three hens, who were the ringleaders of the attempted rebellion over the eggs, stepped forward and declared that Snowball had appeared to them in dreams, urging them to disobey Napoleon's orders.

en: They, too, were slaughtered.
vi: They were also executed.
tr: And at that moment, they were throttled by the dogs.
es: They too were slaughtered.

en: Then a goose came forward and confessed to having secreted six ears of corn during the last year’s harvest and eaten them in the night.
vi: Then a goose stepped forward and confessed to having stolen six ears of corn from the last harvest to eat at night.
tr: Then, a goose came forward and confessed that it had secretly eaten six ears of wheat that it had stolen and hidden during the last harvest.
es: Then a goose stepped forward and confessed that it had hidden six ears of corn during the previous year's harvest and had eaten them at night.

en: Then a sheep confessed to having urinated in the drinking pool — urged to do this, so she said, by Snowball — and two other sheep confessed to having murdered an old ram, an especially devoted follower of Napoleon, by chasing him round and round a bonfire when he was suffering from a cough.
vi: Next, a ewe confessed that Snowball had incited her to urinate in the drinking water, and then two more sheep confessed to having tortured an old ram to death, a ram particularly loyal to Napoleon, by chasing it around the bonfire when it was coughing.
tr: Next, one of the sheep declared that, at Snowball's request, it had urinated in the drinking water. Two other sheep confessed that they had chased and killed an old ram, known for his loyalty to Napoleon, around the fire while he was having a coughing fit.
es: Then a sheep admitted that it had urinated in the drinking pool, instigated to do so, it said, by Snowball, and two other sheep confessed that they had murdered an old ram, very loyal to Napoleon, by chasing him around a bonfire when he was coughing.

en: They were all slain on the spot.
vi: All of these animals were executed on the spot.
tr: They were all slaughtered on the spot.
es: All of them were executed on the spot.

en: And so the tale of confessions and executions went on, until there was a pile of corpses lying before Napoleon’s feet and the air was heavy with the smell of blood, which had been unknown there since the expulsion of Jones.
vi: Thus, execution immediately followed confession. Soon, at Napoleon's feet lay a pile of corpses, and the air was thick with the smell of fresh blood, a scene unprecedented since the expulsion of Mr. Jones.
tr: The confessions and executions continued in this manner. In the end, they found themselves surrounded by corpses at Napoleon's feet. The smell of blood filled the air. Such a smell had not been sensed on the farm since the day Jones was expelled.
es: And so the series of confessions and executions continued until a pile of corpses lay at Napoleon's feet and the air was heavy with the smell of blood, a smell that had been unknown since Jones's expulsion.

en: When it was all over, the remaining animals, except for the pigs and dogs, crept away in a body.
vi: The remaining animals after the execution, of course excluding the dogs and pigs, gathered into a group and quietly crawled out of the yard.
tr: After everything was over, all the animals except the pigs and dogs huddled together and moved away from there.
es: When this was over, the remaining animals, except for the pigs and the dogs, walked away together.

en: They were shaken and miserable.
vi: They looked so small and miserable.
tr: They had tucked their tails in and were trembling with fear.
es: They were shaken and dismayed.

en: They did not know which was more shocking — the treachery of the animals who had leagued themselves with Snowball, or the cruel retribution they had just witnessed.
vi: They couldn't understand whether the betrayal of those associated with Snowball or the brutal punishment they had just witnessed was more shocking.
tr: They couldn't decide which was more terrifying: the betrayal of the animals who had sided with Snowball, or the ruthless reprisals they had just witnessed?
es: They did not know what was more terrifying: the betrayal of the animals who conspired with Snowball or the cruel repression they had just witnessed.

en: In the old days there had often been scenes of bloodshed equally terrible, but it seemed to all of them that it was far worse now that it was happening among themselves.
vi: In the past, they had witnessed equally barbaric massacres, but this time it was clearly more terrifying because it was them killing each other.
tr: They had witnessed such bloody massacres before, but at least they weren't slaughtering each other.
es: In the past, there had been many equally terrible scenes of slaughter, but this one seemed much worse to everyone because it had happened among themselves.

en: Since Jones had left the farm, until today, no animal had killed another animal.
vi: Since old Jones left, no animal had been killed.
tr: Since Jones was expelled, it had never been seen that one animal killed another.
es: Since Jones had left the farm, no animal had killed another animal.

en: Not even a rat had been killed.
vi: Not even a rat had been killed.
tr: Not even a rat had been killed.
es: Not even a rat.

en: They had made their way on to the little knoll where the half-finished windmill stood, and with one accord they all lay down as though huddling together for warmth — Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, and a whole flock of geese and hens — everyone, indeed, except the cat, who had suddenly disappeared just before Napoleon ordered the animals to assemble.
vi: They went up the hill and lay close together for warmth next to the half-built windmill: Fatty lay next to Mona, Benjamin, then the cows, sheep, chickens, and geese, with only the cat missing, as it had slipped away just before Napoleon summoned them.
tr: When they reached the small hill where the half-completed windmill stood, they lay down close to each other as if trying to warm up. Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, the geese, the chickens, everyone was there. Only the cat, who had suddenly disappeared just before Napoleon ordered all the animals to gather, was not among them.
es: They reached the small hill where the half-built windmill stood and, by common agreement, they all lay down, as if huddling together for warmth: Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, and a whole flock of geese and hens: all, indeed, except for the cat, who had suddenly disappeared shortly before Napoleon ordered the animals to assemble.

en: For some time nobody spoke.
vi: They lay silently.
tr: For a while, no one spoke.
es: For some time, no one spoke.

en: Only Boxer remained on his feet.
vi: Only Boxer remained standing.
tr: Only Boxer was standing.
es: Only Boxer remained standing, flicking his long black tail against his sides and occasionally letting out a small neigh of bewilderment.

en: He fidgeted to and fro, swishing his long black tail against his sides and occasionally uttering a little whinny of surprise.
vi: He kept pacing back and forth, his tail continuously hitting his sides, occasionally neighing softly with anxiety.
tr: He couldn't stay still, kept swaying his long black tail from side to side, and was neighing softly in confusion.
es: Only Boxer remained standing, flicking his long black tail against his sides and occasionally letting out a small neigh of bewilderment.

en: Finally he said:
vi: Finally, he said:
tr: Finally, he said:
es: Finally, he said: "I don't understand.

en: “I do not understand it.
vi: "I don't understand anything at all.
tr: "I can't make sense of what's happening.
es: Finally, he said: "I don't understand.

en: I would not have believed that such things could happen on our farm.
vi: It's unbelievable that such a thing could happen in our camp.
tr: Even if I thought for forty years, I wouldn't have imagined such things happening on our farm.
es: I would never have believed that such things could happen on our farm.

en: It must be due to some fault in ourselves.
vi: Maybe we are also at fault.
tr: We must have made a mistake.
es: It must be due to some fault of ours.

en: The solution, as I see it, is to work harder.
vi: There is only one way out, and that is to work more.
tr: If you ask me, the only way out is to work harder.
es: The solution, as I see it, is to work harder.

en: From now onwards I shall get up a full hour earlier in the mornings.”
vi: From now on, I will wake up an hour earlier."
tr: As for me, from now on, I will get up an hour earlier in the mornings."
es: From now on, I will get up an hour earlier every morning."

en: And he moved off at his lumbering trot and made for the quarry.
vi: Then he sadly walked back to the quarry.
tr: With all his laziness, he started trotting and headed towards the quarry.
es: And he walked away with his heavy trot towards the quarry.

en: Having got there, he collected two successive loads of stone and dragged them down to the windmill before retiring for the night.
vi: The little guy filled up two carts and dragged them to the construction site before going to sleep.
tr: When he arrived there, he hauled two loads of stones to the windmill with the cart, and then went to bed.
es: Once there, he gathered two cartloads of stones and pulled them to the mill before going to bed.

en: The animals huddled about Clover, not speaking.
vi: The group of animals huddled around Mrs. Fat but none of them spoke up.
tr: The animals had gathered around Clover, and no one could utter a word.
es: The animals huddled around Clover, without speaking.

en: The knoll where they were lying gave them a wide prospect across the countryside.
vi: From the top of the hill, they could see the entire area.
tr: From the hill they were on, they could see the fields stretching out all around.
es: The hill where they were lying offered them a wide view across the countryside.

en: Most of Animal Farm was within their view — the long pasture stretching down to the main road, the hayfield, the spinney, the drinking pool, the ploughed fields where the young wheat was thick and green, and the red roofs of the farm buildings with the smoke curling from the chimneys.
vi: They could see almost the entire Animal Farm - the grazing fields stretching to the main road, the grass fields, the forest, the water basin, the cultivated fields with green wheat growing, and the tiled roofs of the farmhouses with winding trails of smoke.
tr: A large part of Animal Farm was within their view: the pasture extending to the main road, the mown and dried hay, the grove, the trough, the lush, green crops beginning to sprout in the plowed fields, the red roofs of the farm buildings, and the smoking chimneys...
es: Most of "Animal Farm" was in sight: the long meadow, stretching to the road, the hayfield, the drinking pool, the plowed fields where the new wheat was growing, thick and green, and the red roofs of the farm buildings, with smoke spiraling up from their chimneys.

en: It was a clear spring evening.
vi: It was a spring afternoon, the sky clear and cloudless.
tr: It was a bright spring evening.
es: It was a clear spring evening.

en: The grass and the bursting hedges were gilded by the level rays of the sun.
vi: The twilight cast a golden hue on the grass and the distant hedges.
tr: The grass and the leaf-budding hedges illuminated by the sun's rays were sparkling.
es: The grass and the blooming hedges were golden in the rays of the setting sun.

en: Never had the farm — and with a kind of surprise they remembered that it was their own farm, every inch of it their own property — appeared to the animals so desirable a place.
vi: They were surprised to remember that this farm was theirs, every inch of land here was their property, every inch was so precious.
tr: The farm had never looked so beautiful to their eyes. Suddenly, they remembered that this was their own farm; every inch of this land was theirs.
es: The farm had never seemed to them—and with some surprise, they remembered that it was their own farm, and that every inch of it was their property—a place so desirable.

en: As Clover looked down the hillside her eyes filled with tears.
vi: Mrs. Fat looked into the distance, her eyes filled with tears.
tr: As Clover looked down from the hill, her eyes filled with tears.
es: As Clover looked down the hillside, her eyes filled with tears.

en: If she could have spoken her thoughts, it would have been to say that this was not what they had aimed at when they had set themselves years ago to work for the overthrow of the human race.
vi: If she could express all her thoughts, she would surely say that this was not what they intended when they decided to overthrow human rule.
tr: If she could express her thoughts, she would say that when they set out years ago to overthrow the human race, this was never their goal.
es: If she could express her thoughts, it would have been to say that this was not what they had aspired to when they set out, years ago, to overthrow the human race.

en: These scenes of terror and slaughter were not what they had looked forward to on that night when old Major first stirred them to rebellion.
vi: On the night the old Leader called for their uprising, they could not have imagined the terror and mass killings of today.
tr: Could the violence and slaughter they now witnessed be what they had envisioned on the night Old Major first called for the Rebellion?
es: Those scenes of terror and slaughter were not what they had dreamed of that night when Old Major first stirred them to rebellion.

en: If she herself had had any picture of the future, it had been of a society of animals set free from hunger and the whip, all equal, each working according to his capacity, the strong protecting the weak, as she had protected the lost brood of ducklings with her foreleg on the night of Major’s speech.
vi: If she had thought about the future then, it would have been a society where animals were no longer hungry, no longer beaten, all were equal, all worked according to their ability, the strong protected the weak, just as she had protected the orphaned ducklings on the night the old Leader spoke.
tr: In the future she had imagined, there was a society where animals were free from hunger and the whip, where everyone was equal, everyone worked according to their ability, and the strong protected the weak just as Old Major had embraced the lost ducklings on the night he spoke.
es: If she herself had conceived a picture of the future, it would have been of a society of animals freed from hunger and the whip, all equal, each working according to their capacity, the strong protecting the weak, as she had protected those lost ducklings with her foreleg the night of Major's speech.

en: Instead — she did not know why — they had come to a time when no one dared speak his mind, when fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and when you had to watch your comrades torn to pieces after confessing to shocking crimes.
vi: Yet, she could not understand why now no one dared to speak their true thoughts anymore, the fierce hunting dogs roamed everywhere, and all had to witness the killing of comrades after they confessed to heinous crimes.
tr: However, for some unknown reason, a society had emerged where no one dared to express their thoughts, wild, savage dogs roamed everywhere growling, and they were forced to watch their comrades being torn apart after confessing to horrific crimes.
es: Instead—she did not know why—they had come to a state where no one dared to say what they thought, where fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and where one had to watch their comrades being torn to pieces after confessing to horrible crimes.

en: There was no thought of rebellion or disobedience in her mind.
vi: But in her mind, there was no thought of disobedience or rebellion.
tr: But thoughts of rebelling or rising up did not cross her mind.
es: There was no thought of rebellion or disobedience in her mind.

en: She knew that, even as things were, they were far better off than they had been in the days of Jones, and that before all else it was needful to prevent the return of the human beings.
vi: After all, they were still better off than under old Jones, and the main thing was to prevent humans from returning.
tr: She knew that even their current situation was much better than it had been in Jones's time and that above all, it was necessary to prevent the humans from returning to the farm.
es: She knew that, even as things were, they were much better off than in the days of Jones and that, above all, it was necessary to prevent the return of human beings.

en: Whatever happened she would remain faithful, work hard, carry out the orders that were given to her, and accept the leadership of Napoleon.
vi: No matter what, she remained loyal to the cause, continued to work tirelessly, completed all tasks, and followed the path that Napoleon had chosen.
tr: No matter what, she would remain loyal to the administration, follow the orders given to her to the letter, and accept Napoleon's leadership.
es: Whatever happened, she would remain loyal, work hard, follow the orders given to her, and accept Napoleon's directives.

en: But still, it was not for this that she and all the other animals had hoped and toiled.
vi: But was this really what they had longed for, what they had worked so hard to create?
tr: But still, this should not have been the result of so much hope and effort.
es: But even so, this was not what she and the other animals had yearned for and worked so hard for.

en: It was not for this that they had built the windmill and faced the bullets of Jones’s gun.
vi: No, they built the windmill for a completely different purpose, the life-and-death struggle with old Jones was also to create a society completely different from what they had received today.
tr: Should this be the reward for building the windmill with such difficulty and braving the pellets from Jones's gun?
es: It was not for this that they had built the windmill and faced Jones's bullets.

en: Such were her thoughts, though she lacked the words to express them.
vi: These were the thoughts that flashed through Mrs. Fat's mind, but she could not put them into words.
tr: She thought this way, but she could not put her thoughts into words and express them.
es: Such were her thoughts, though she lacked the words to express them.

en: At last, feeling this to be in some way a substitute for the words she was unable to find, she began to sing ‘Beasts of England’.
vi: Unable to find words to say, Mrs. Fat had to sing the song "Beasts of England," which was also a way to express the emotions surging in her heart.
tr: In the end, thinking it would take the place of the words she couldn't express, Clover began to sing the song of the Beasts of England.
es: In the end, sensing that perhaps it would be a substitute for the words she could not find, she began to sing "Beasts of England."

en: The other animals sitting round her took it up, and they sang it three times over — very tunefully, but slowly and mournfully, in a way they had never sung it before.
vi: The other animals immediately sang along. They sang three times, their voices melodious, slow, and sad; they had never sung like that before.
tr: The other animals sitting around her also joined in the song. They sang the song three times in total, and very beautifully; but it had never been sung so slowly and sadly before.
es: The other animals around her imitated her and sang it three times, melodiously, though slowly and mournfully as they had never done before.

en: They had just finished singing it for the third time when Squealer, attended by two dogs, approached them with the air of having something important to say.
vi: When they had just finished singing for the third time, Chỉ Điểm, accompanied by two dogs, approached. Just by looking at them, it was clear that there was important news that needed to be urgently announced.
tr: They had just finished when Squealer appeared with two dogs; it was clear he had something important to say.
es: They had just finished repeating it for the third time when Squealer approached, accompanied by two dogs, with the air of someone who has something important to say.

en: He announced that, by a special decree of Comrade Napoleon, ‘Beasts of England’ had been abolished.
vi: He declared that the song "Beasts of England" had been abolished by a special decree from Comrade Napoleon.
tr: When he came near them, he announced that by a special decree of Comrade Napoleon, the song "Beasts of England" had been abolished.
es: He announced that by a special decree of Comrade Napoleon, the singing of "Beasts of England" had been abolished.

en: From now onwards it was forbidden to sing it.
vi: From now on, no animal was allowed to sing that song anymore.
tr: It was now forbidden to sing "Beasts of England."
es: From that moment on, it was forbidden to sing that song.

en: The animals were taken aback.
vi: The animals were all dumbfounded.
tr: The animals were surprised.
es: The animals were astonished.

en: “Why?” cried Muriel.
vi: "Why?", Muriel asked.
tr: Muriel shouted, "Why?"
es: —Why? —shouted Muriel.

en: “It’s no longer needed, comrade,” said Squealer stiffly.
vi: "Comrades, this song is outdated," Chỉ Điểm said coldly, "The song 'Beasts of England' is a call for insurrection.
tr: Squealer, fawningly, said, "There is no longer any need, comrade."
es: —There is no longer any need, comrade —said Squealer dryly—.

en: “‘Beasts of England’ was the song of the Rebellion.
vi: "Comrades, this song is outdated," Chỉ Điểm said coldly, "The song 'Beasts of England' is a call for insurrection.
tr: 'Beasts of England' was the song of the Rebellion.
es: “Beasts of England” was the song of the Rebellion.

en: But the Rebellion is now completed.
vi: The insurrection has been completely victorious.
tr: The Rebellion is now complete.
es: But the Rebellion is now over.

en: The execution of the traitors this afternoon was the final act.
vi: This afternoon's execution was the final battle.
tr: This afternoon's execution of the traitors was the final act.
es: The execution of the traitors this afternoon was the final act.

en: The enemy both external and internal has been defeated.
vi: The enemy, both internal and external, has been defeated.
tr: Both the internal and external enemies have been defeated.
es: The enemy, both external and internal, has been defeated.

en: In ‘Beasts of England’ we expressed our longing for a better society in days to come.
vi: The song 'Beasts of England' expresses our dream of a better society in the future.
tr: In the song 'Beasts of England,' we expressed our longing for a better society to be established in the future.
es: In “Beasts of England” we expressed our longing for a better society in the future.

en: But that society has now been established.
vi: That society has been built.
tr: Now that society has been established, this song no longer has any meaning."
es: But that society has now been established.

en: Clearly this song has no longer any purpose.”
vi: This song is clearly no longer necessary."
tr: Now that society has been established, this song no longer has any meaning."
es: Truly, this song no longer has a purpose.

en: Frightened though they were, some of the animals might possibly have protested, but at this moment the sheep set up their usual bleating of “Four legs good, two legs bad,” which went on for several minutes and put an end to the discussion.
vi: Even though they were very frightened, there would definitely have been some who stood up to protest if the sheep had not immediately chanted as usual: "Four legs good, two legs bad." They chanted for several minutes, so no one could voice any opinions anymore.
tr: Despite being very frightened, some of the animals were preparing to resist, but as usual, the sheep's bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad!" ended the discussion before it could start.
es: Although they were scared, some of the animals would have protested, but at that moment the sheep began their usual bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad," which lasted several minutes and ended the discussion.

en: So ‘Beasts of England’ was heard no more.
vi: No animal sang "Beasts of England" anymore.
tr: From that day on, the song of England's Animals was never heard again.
es: And in this way, "Beasts of England" was heard no more.

en: In its place Minimus, the poet, had composed another song which began:
vi: Instead, Continuity, a newly emerged poet, had written another song, which began as follows:
tr: Instead, the poet Minimus had composed another song. The song began like this:
es: In its place, Minimus, the poet, had composed another song that began like this:

en: Animal Farm, Animal Farm,
vi: This Animal Farm, This Animal Farm
tr: Animal Farm, Animal Farm, believe,
es: Animal Farm, Animal Farm,

en: Never through me shalt thou come to harm!
vi: The enemy will be shattered.
tr: No harm will ever come to you from me!
es: You will never have any harm because of me!

en: and this was sung every Sunday morning after the hoisting of the flag.
vi: From then on, they always sang this song after the flag-raising ceremony on Sunday mornings.
tr: The new song was sung every Sunday after the flag was hoisted.
es: And this was sung every Sunday morning after raising the flag.

en: But somehow neither the words nor the tune ever seemed to the animals to come up to ‘Beasts of England’.
vi: But the animals thought that both the melody and the lyrics of the new song were not as good as the previous "Beasts of England". George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: But for some reason, the animals could not love its melody or lyrics as much as they loved "Beasts of England."
es: But, for some reason, the animals felt that neither the lyrics nor the music were up to the level of "Beasts of England."

en: Chapter 8
vi: Chapter 8
tr: Chapter Eight
es: VIII

en: A few days later, when the terror caused by the executions had died down, some of the animals remembered — or thought they remembered — that the Sixth Commandment decreed “No animal shall kill any other animal.”
vi: A few days later, when the fear caused by the massacre had subsided, some of them remembered, or thought they remembered, that the Sixth Commandment said: "Animals shall not kill each other."
tr: A few days later, when the terror caused by the executions had subsided, some animals remembered or seemed to remember the Sixth Commandment: "No animal shall kill any other animal."
es: DAYS later, when the terror produced by the executions had already disappeared, some animals remembered—or believed they remembered—that the sixth commandment decreed: "No animal shall kill another animal."

en: And though no one cared to mention it in the hearing of the pigs or the dogs, it was felt that the killings which had taken place did not square with this.
vi: Although they did not dare to speak up when near the dogs and pigs, they all believed that the recent killings were not in accordance with the Sixth Commandment.
tr: Although no one dared to speak up in the presence of the pigs or the dogs, everyone was aware that the murders did not comply with this commandment.
es: And although no one wanted to mention it in the hearing of the pigs or the dogs, there was a sense that the killings that had taken place did not agree with that.

en: Clover asked Benjamin to read her the Sixth Commandment, and when Benjamin, as usual, said that he refused to meddle in such matters, she fetched Muriel.
vi: Mrs. Fat asked Benjamin to read the Sixth Commandment, but as always, Benjamin said he did not get involved in such matters.
tr: Clover asked Benjamin to read the Sixth Commandment to her, but Benjamin, as always, said he did not want to get involved in such matters.
es: Clover asked Benjamin to read the sixth commandment to her, and when Benjamin, as usual, said he refused to meddle in such matters, she went in search of Muriel.

en: Muriel read the Commandment for her.
vi: Mrs. Fat had to find Muriel to ask her to read it.
tr: So Clover found Muriel.
es: Muriel read the Commandment to her.

en: It ran: “No animal shall kill any other animal WITHOUT CAUSE.”
vi: It was written as follows: "Animals shall not kill each other without reason."
tr: Muriel read the Sixth Commandment as follows: "No animal shall kill any other animal without cause."
es: It said: "No animal shall kill another animal without cause."

en: Somehow or other, the last two words had slipped out of the animals’ memory.
vi: It turned out they had forgotten the last few words.
tr: Apparently, the words without cause had somehow been erased from the animals' memories.
es: For one reason or another, the last two words had slipped from the animals' memory.

en: But they saw now that the Commandment had not been violated; for clearly there was good reason for killing the traitors who had leagued themselves with Snowball.
vi: But this meant that the Commandment was still respected, and the traitors associated with Snowball deserved to be killed.
tr: Thus, the Sixth Commandment had not been violated; because the traitors who had conspired with Snowball had not been killed without cause.
es: But they confirmed that the Commandment had not been violated; because, evidently, there was ample reason to kill the traitors who had conspired with Snowball.

en: Throughout the year the animals worked even harder than they had worked in the previous year.
vi: This year they worked much harder than the previous year.
tr: That year, the animals worked much harder than the previous year.
es: During this year, the animals worked even harder than the previous year.

en: To rebuild the windmill, with walls twice as thick as before, and to finish it by the appointed date, together with the regular work of the farm, was a tremendous labour.
vi: Besides the usual farm tasks, they also had to rebuild the windmill with walls twice as thick, and they had to complete it on schedule.
tr: On one hand, the reconstruction of the windmill with walls twice as thick and its completion by the predetermined date, and on the other hand, the daily operations of the farm required an extraordinary effort.
es: Rebuilding the windmill, with walls twice as thick as before, and completing it by a set date, in addition to the daily farm work, was a tremendous task.

en: There were times when it seemed to the animals that they worked longer hours and fed no better than they had done in Jones’s day.
vi: There were times when they felt they had to work more but were fed no better than during Mr. Jones's time.
tr: From time to time, the animals began to notice that despite working more than they did during Jones's era, they were not better fed.
es: Sometimes it seemed to them that they worked more and did not eat better than in Jones's time.

en: On Sunday mornings Squealer, holding down a long strip of paper with his trotter, would read out to them lists of figures proving that the production of every class of foodstuff had increased by two hundred per cent, three hundred per cent, or five hundred per cent, as the case might be.
vi: Every Sunday morning, Squealer would hold a long piece of paper and read out figures proving that the production of various foodstuffs had increased, sometimes by two hundred, sometimes by three hundred, sometimes by five hundred percent.
tr: On Sunday mornings, Squealer would read out some figures from a long piece of paper he held with his foot, explaining that the production of various foodstuffs had increased by two hundred percent, three hundred percent, five hundred percent.
es: On Sunday mornings, Squealer, holding a long paper with one paw, would read them long lists of figures, showing that the production of all kinds of foodstuffs had increased by 200 percent, 300 percent, or 500 percent, as the case might be.

en: The animals saw no reason to disbelieve him, especially as they could no longer remember very clearly what conditions had been like before the Rebellion.
vi: They saw no reason to doubt it, especially since they had forgotten and no longer remembered anything from before the Rebellion.
tr: Since the animals no longer remembered the conditions before the Rebellion accurately, they saw no reason not to believe him.
es: The animals saw no reason not to believe him, especially since they could not clearly remember how things were before the Rebellion.

en: All the same, there were days when they felt that they would sooner have had less figures and more food.
vi: However, sometimes they felt it would be better if the figures were lower but the food was more.
tr: But still, there were days when they couldn't help but wonder when they would see the days where they listened to fewer numbers and ate more food.
es: Even so, they sometimes preferred to have fewer figures and more food.

en: All orders were now issued through Squealer or one of the other pigs.
vi: All orders now were issued by Squealer or another pig.
tr: From now on, all orders were conveyed by Squealer or one of the other pigs.
es: All orders were issued through Squealer or any of the other pigs.

en: Napoleon himself was not seen in public as often as once in a fortnight.
vi: Napoleon appeared only once every fortnight.
tr: Napoleon only appeared in public once every fortnight, and when he did, he was accompanied not only by his entourage of dogs but also by a black rooster.
es: Napoleon was not seen in public, at most, once every fortnight.

en: When he did appear, he was attended not only by his retinue of dogs but by a black cockerel who marched in front of him and acted as a kind of trumpeter, letting out a loud “cock-a-doodle-doo” before Napoleon spoke.
vi: Each time he appeared, he was escorted by a pack of dogs and preceded by a black rooster, like a bugler in a cavalry regiment, which always crowed "Cock-a-doodle-doo" loudly before Napoleon cleared his throat to begin his speech.
tr: The rooster walked ahead and, like a bugler, crowed as loudly as he could, "Cock-a-doodle-doo!" whenever Napoleon was about to speak.
es: When he did appear, he was accompanied not only by his entourage of dogs but also by a black rooster that marched ahead and acted as a sort of herald, letting out a loud crow before Napoleon spoke.

en: Even in the farmhouse, it was said, Napoleon inhabited separate apartments from the others.
vi: It was rumored that even in the main house, Napoleon had a separate room, distinct from the other pigs.
tr: It was said that Napoleon even stayed in separate rooms from the others in the farmhouse.
es: Even in the house, it was said, Napoleon occupied quarters separate from the others.

en: He took his meals alone, with two dogs to wait upon him, and always ate from the Crown Derby dinner service which had been in the glass cupboard in the drawing-room.
vi: He ate alone, always attended by two dogs, and used porcelain dishes that had previously been kept in the drawing-room cupboard and only brought out on special occasions during Mr. Jones's time.
tr: While eating his meals alone, two dogs would stand guard beside him; he used the Crown Derby dinner service that once stood in the glass cabinet in the sitting room.
es: He ate alone, with two dogs to serve him, and always used the tableware that had been in the glass cabinet in the living room.

en: It was also announced that the gun would be fired every year on Napoleon’s birthday, as well as on the other two anniversaries.
vi: There was also a new decree that from now on, the gun would be fired three times: once on Napoleon's birthday and twice on other major holidays of the farm.
tr: Meanwhile, it was announced that, in addition to the other two anniversaries, Napoleon's birthday would also be celebrated with a ceremonial gunshot.
es: It was also announced that the shotgun would be fired every year on Napoleon's birthday, just like on the other two anniversaries.

en: Napoleon was now never spoken of simply as “Napoleon.”
vi: Now they no longer address Napoleon as simply as before.
tr: No one could simply refer to Napoleon as "Napoleon" anymore; it was required to formally address him as "Our Leader Comrade Napoleon."
es: Napoleon was no longer simply mentioned as "Napoleon."

en: He was always referred to in formal style as “our Leader, Comrade Napoleon,” and this pigs liked to invent for him such titles as Father of All Animals, Terror of Mankind, Protector of the Sheep-fold, Ducklings’ Friend, and the like.
vi: His name always comes with titles like "Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon," and the pigs even try to invent new titles such as: Father of All Animals, Terror of Mankind, Protector of the Sheep, Friend of the Ducks, etc.
tr: The pigs were competing with each other to come up with titles for him such as Father of All Animals, Terror of Humans, Protector Angel of the Sheep, and Dear Friend of the Ducklings.
es: He was always referred to ceremoniously as "our Leader, comrade Napoleon," and the pigs liked to invent titles for him such as "Father of all animals," "Terror of mankind," "Protector of the sheep flock," "Friend of the ducklings," and others of the sort.

en: In his speeches, Squealer would talk with the tears rolling down his cheeks of Napoleon’s wisdom the goodness of his heart, and the deep love he bore to all animals everywhere, even and especially the unhappy animals who still lived in ignorance and slavery on other farms.
vi: Whenever they speak of Napoleon's wisdom, kindness, and love as deep as the ocean for the animals, especially those still living in the dark bondage of other farms, Snowball's tears would wet his cheeks.
tr: Squealer, with tears streaming from his eyes during his speeches, spoke of how wise and kind-hearted an animal Napoleon was, and how deeply he loved all the animals on earth, especially the unhappy animals still living like slaves in the darkness of ignorance on other farms.
es: In his speeches, Squealer spoke with tears in his eyes about Napoleon's wisdom, the kindness of his heart, and the deep love he felt for all animals everywhere, and especially for the unfortunate beasts that still lived in ignorance and slavery on other farms.

en: It had become usual to give Napoleon the credit for every successful achievement and every stroke of good fortune.
vi: All achievements were attributed to Napoleon.
tr: It had become a habit to attribute every success and every joyous event to Napoleon.
es: It had become customary to attribute every successful feat and stroke of luck to Napoleon.

en: You would often hear one hen remark to another, “Under the guidance of our Leader, Comrade Napoleon, I have laid five eggs in six days”; or two cows, enjoying a drink at the pool, would exclaim, “Thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, how excellent this water tastes!”
vi: You could hear two hens confiding: "Under the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, our Leader, I have laid five eggs in the past six days"; or two cows drinking water saying: "Thanks to Comrade Napoleon's wise leadership, the water tastes so sweet these days!"
tr: It was even heard that a hen said to another hen, "If it weren't for Our Leader Comrade Napoleon, I wouldn't have been able to lay five eggs in six days," and that two cows drinking water from the lake shouted, "Would the lake's water be this sweet without Comrade Napoleon's leadership?"
es: It was often heard that one hen would say to another: "Under the leadership of our Leader, comrade Napoleon, I have laid five eggs in six days," or two cows, while savoring the water from the trough, would exclaim: "Thanks to our Leader, comrade Napoleon, how delicious this water tastes!"

en: The general feeling on the farm was well expressed in a poem entitled Comrade Napoleon, which was composed by Minimus and which ran as follows:
vi: The general sentiment of the farm was expressed in a poem titled: "Comrade Napoleon" composed by Minimus: Comrade Napoleon!
tr: The feelings and thoughts of the animals on the farm about this were echoed in a poem titled "Comrade Napoleon," written by Minimus:
es: The general sentiment of the farm was well expressed in a poem titled "Comrade Napoleon," written by Minimus, which went like this:

en: Friend of fatherless!
vi: You are the father of the orphans,
tr: The one and only father of orphans!
es: Friend of the disinherited!

en: Fountain of happiness!
vi: It is the eternal source of happiness,
tr: The fountain of our happiness!
es: Source of well-being!

en: Lord of the swill-bucket!
vi: It is the sun shining in the sky.
tr: The sultan of the feed buckets!
es: Lord of the feast, who ignites my soul when I gaze upon fortunate

en: Oh, how my soul is on
vi: Your gaze forever warms my heart.
tr: You resemble the sun in the sky,
es: Lord of the feast, who ignites my soul when I gaze upon fortunate

en: Fire when I gaze at thy
vi: Your gaze forever warms my heart.
tr: With your cold and commanding gaze
es: Lord of the feast, who ignites my soul when I gaze upon fortunate

en: Calm and commanding eye,
vi: Your gaze forever warms my heart.
tr: With your cold and commanding gaze
es: your firm and confident gaze,

en: Like the sun in the sky,
vi: Comrade Napoleon!
tr: You stir excitement in my heart,
es: like the sun that dazzles the sky.

en: Comrade Napoleon!
vi: Comrade Napoleon!
tr: Comrade Napoleon!
es: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Thou are the giver of
vi: The person who gave me a meal when I was hungry.
tr: Everything that His servants love
es: Singular giver

en: All that thy creatures love,
vi: The person who gave me a warm straw mattress in the winter.
tr: You are the one who grants to them,
es: of all that your creatures love

en: Full belly twice a day, clean straw to roll upon;
vi: The person who gave me a warm straw mattress in the winter.
tr: Two meals, a perfectly clean straw mattress;
es: —their bellies full and clean straw to lie on—.

en: Every beast great or small
vi: The person sitting guard,
tr: Every animal, big or small
es: All the beasts, big or small,

en: Sleeps at peace in his stall,
vi: Give the children a peaceful sleep. My child!
tr: Sleeps comfortably every evening,
es: to sleep in peace in their stables they long for under your protective gaze.

en: Thou watchest over all,
vi: Eternal happiness,
tr: You are the one who protects and looks after them,
es: to sleep in peace in their stables they long for under your protective gaze.

en: Comrade Napoleon!
vi: It's thanks to Comrade Napoleon.
tr: Comrade Napoleon!
es: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Had I a sucking-pig,
vi: Father's name, mother's name, husband's name,
tr: If one day I have a child,
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Ere he had grown as big
vi: You may forget.
tr: When still a tiny baby
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Even as a pint bottle or as a rolling-pin,
vi: But the name of the person,
tr: His height is less than six spans
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: He should have learned to be
vi: The sun shines eternally
tr: One must learn to appreciate your worth,
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Faithful and true to thee,
vi: The sun shines eternally
tr: As soon as they open their eyes to the world
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: Yes, his first squeak should be
vi: You must remember forever:
tr: The scream that should be pressed with a shriek:
es: The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!

en: “Comrade Napoleon!”
vi: Napoleon, Napoleon, oh dear! 1
tr: "Comrade Napoleon!"
es: Napoleon approved this poem and had it inscribed on the wall of the main barn, at the opposite end of the Seven Commandments.

en: Napoleon approved of this poem and caused it to be inscribed on the wall of the big barn, at the opposite end from the Seven Commandments.
vi: Napoleon accepted the poem and ordered it to be written on the wall of the large barn, next to the Seven Commandments.
tr: Napoleon approved and endorsed the poem, and had it written on the wall of the big barn, next to the Seven Commandments.
es: Napoleon approved this poem and had it inscribed on the wall of the main barn, at the opposite end of the Seven Commandments.

en: It was surmounted by a portrait of Napoleon, in profile, executed by Squealer in white paint.
vi: Above the poem was a portrait of Napoleon in profile, painted in white by Squealer.
tr: A profile portrait of Napoleon, done by Squealer in white paint, was also hung above the poem.
es: Above it, there was a portrait of Napoleon, in profile, painted by Squealer with white paint.

en: Meanwhile, through the agency of Whymper, Napoleon was engaged in complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington.
vi: Meanwhile, Napoleon, through the intermediary Whymper, was conducting complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington.
tr: Meanwhile, Napoleon had entered into complicated relations with Frederick and Pilkington through Whymper.
es: Meanwhile, through Whymper, Napoleon was engaged in complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington.

en: The pile of timber was still unsold.
vi: The pile of wood still hadn't been sold.
tr: The timber was still waiting to be sold.
es: The pile of timber was still unsold.

en: Of the two, Frederick was the more anxious to get hold of it, but he would not offer a reasonable price.
vi: Frederick was very eager to buy it, but he offered too low a price.
tr: Although Frederick seemed more eager to buy, he was unwilling to offer a fair price.
es: Of the two, Frederick was the one most eager to obtain it, but he did not want to offer a reasonable price.

en: At the same time there were renewed rumours that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack Animal Farm and to destroy the windmill, the building of which had aroused furious jealousy in him.
vi: At the same time, there were rumors that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack Animal Farm to destroy the windmill because he hated this place bitterly.
tr: Moreover, according to rumors that had begun to circulate again, Frederick was planning to attack Animal Farm with his men and destroy the windmill he was very envious of.
es: At the same time, persistent rumors were circulating that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack "Animal Farm" and destroy the windmill, whose construction had provoked furious envy in him.

en: Snowball was known to be still skulking on Pinchfield Farm.
vi: It was said that Snowball was still hiding at Pinchfield Farm.
tr: It was also known that Snowball was still hiding at Pinchfield Farm.
es: It was known that Snowball was still lurking on Pinchfield Farm.

en: In the middle of the summer the animals were alarmed to hear that three hens had come forward and confessed that, inspired by Snowball, they had entered into a plot to murder Napoleon.
vi: By mid-summer, the animals were once again thrown into a panic when they heard rumors that three hens had confessed to being incited by Snowball to plot Napoleon's assassination.
tr: In the middle of summer, the animals were struck with great fear upon hearing that three hens had confessed to participating in a plot to assassinate Napoleon.
es: In the middle of the summer, the animals were alarmed to hear that three hens had confessed to plotting, inspired by Snowball, a conspiracy to assassinate Napoleon.

en: They were executed immediately, and fresh precautions for Napoleon’s safety were taken.
vi: They were executed immediately, and stricter security measures for Napoleon were implemented.
tr: The hens were immediately executed, and new measures were taken for Napoleon's safety.
es: They were executed immediately, and new precautions were taken for the Leader's safety.

en: Four dogs guarded his bed at night, one at each corner, and a young pig named Pinkeye was given the task of tasting all his food before he ate it, lest it should be poisoned.
vi: From now on, at night, four dogs would guard each corner of Napoleon's bed, and to avoid being poisoned, a dog named Pinkeye was assigned to taste all his food before Napoleon ate it.
tr: At night, dogs stood guard around his bed, and every meal he ate was first tasted by a young pig named Pinkeye to check if it was poisoned.
es: Four dogs guarded his bed at night, one in each corner, and a young pig named Pinkeye was appointed to taste all his food before the Leader ate it, for fear it might be poisoned.

en: At about the same time it was given out that Napoleon had arranged to sell the pile of timber to mr Pilkington; he was also going to enter into a regular agreement for the exchange of certain products between Animal Farm and Foxwood.
vi: Around that time, there was news that Napoleon had decided to sell timber to Pilkington; moreover, it was planned to establish regular product exchanges between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm.
tr: In the same days, it was announced that Napoleon had decided to sell the timber to Mr. Pilkington; furthermore, a suitable agreement was to be made regarding the exchange of some products between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm.
es: More or less around that time, it was disclosed that Napoleon had agreed to sell the pile of wood to Mr. Pilkington; a formal agreement was also to be celebrated for the exchange of certain products between "Animal Farm" and Foxwood.

en: The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, though they were only conducted through Whymper, were now almost friendly.
vi: The relationship between Napoleon and Pilkington, even though it was only through the intermediary Whymper, had become quite friendly.
tr: The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, although conducted only through Whymper, had now taken on an almost friendly nature.
es: The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, although conducted solely through Whymper, were almost friendly.

en: The animals distrusted Pilkington, as a human being, but greatly preferred him to Frederick, whom they both feared and hated.
vi: Pilkington, like everyone else, was never trusted by the animals, but they still preferred him over Frederick, whom they both hated and feared.
tr: Although the animals did not trust Pilkington as a human being even a little, they still preferred him over Frederick, whom they both feared and hated.
es: The animals distrusted Pilkington, as a human being, but they much preferred him over Frederick, whom they feared and hated at the same time.

en: As the summer wore on, and the windmill neared completion, the rumours of an impending treacherous attack grew stronger and stronger.
vi: As the end of summer approached, when the windmill was nearly completed, rumors of a treacherous attack increased.
tr: As summer progressed and the construction of the windmill neared completion, rumors of an imminent and relentless attack on the farm increased.
es: When the summer was ending and the construction of the windmill was nearing completion, rumors of an imminent treacherous attack were increasing.

en: Frederick, it was said, intended to bring against them twenty men all armed with guns, and he had already bribed the magistrates and police, so that if he could once get hold of the title-deeds of Animal Farm they would ask no questions.
vi: Some said that Frederick planned to attack with an army of twenty men fully armed and had bribed the government as well as the police to act freely.
tr: According to what was said, Frederick had gathered twenty armed men and had already bribed judges and police so that they would not question him when he seized the deeds of Animal Farm.
es: Frederick, it was said, intended to bring against them twenty men, all armed with shotguns, and had already bribed the magistrates and the police so that, in the event he could obtain the property titles of "Animal Farm," they would not investigate.

en: Moreover, terrible stories were leaking out from Pinchfield about the cruelties that Frederick practised upon his animals.
vi: Additionally, news of his cruel deeds towards the animals at Pinchfield Farm was revealed.
tr: Moreover, from Pinchfield Farm, chilling information about how cruelly Frederick treated his animals was leaking out.
es: Moreover, some terrible stories were leaking from Pinchfield regarding the cruelties Frederick inflicted on the animals.

en: He had flogged an old horse to death, he starved his cows, he had killed a dog by throwing it into the furnace, he amused himself in the evenings by making cocks fight with splinters of razor-blade tied to their spurs.
vi: He beat an old horse to death, starved the cows, threw a dog into the furnace, and every evening he incited the roosters to fight each other, not just any fight, but he also tied razor blades to their spurs for extra thrill.
tr: If true, he had whipped an old horse to death, starved the cows for days, thrown one of the dogs into the furnace; in the evenings, he took pleasure in making roosters fight with sharp razors attached to their spurs.
es: He had whipped a horse to death; starved his cows, killed a dog by throwing it into an oven, and entertained himself at night with cockfights, tying pieces of razor blades to the spurs.

en: The animals’ blood boiled with rage when they heard of these things beingdone to their comrades, and sometimes they clamoured to be allowed to go out in a body and attack Pinchfield Farm, drive out the humans, and set the animals free.
vi: When they heard that their comrades were being treated so barbarically, every animal's blood boiled with anger, and sometimes they shouted for an attack on Pinchfield Farm to drive out the humans and reclaim freedom for the animals there.
tr: As the animals heard about what was done to their comrades, they were furious with rage, and from time to time, they asked for permission to attack Pinchfield Farm together and drive out the humans to set the animals free.
es: The animals' blood boiled with rage when they learned of the things being done to their comrades, and sometimes they clamored to be allowed to go out and attack "Pinchfield Farm" en masse, drive out the humans, and liberate the animals.

en: But Squealer counselled them to avoid rash actions and trust in Comrade Napoleon’s strategy.
vi: But Squealer advised them to avoid hasty actions and to trust in Comrade Napoleon's strategic plan.
tr: Squealer, however, said that if they acted in anger, they would suffer losses, and advised them to trust in Comrade Napoleon's knowledge and experience.
es: But Squealer advised them to avoid rash actions and to trust in Napoleon's strategy.

en: Nevertheless, feeling against Frederick continued to run high.
vi: The hatred towards Frederick increased day by day.
tr: However, the hatred for Frederick was growing day by day.
es: However, the resentment against Frederick continued to grow.

en: One Sunday morning Napoleon appeared in the barn and explained that he had never at any time contemplated selling the pile of timber to Frederick; he considered it beneath his dignity, he said, to have dealings with scoundrels of that description.
vi: One day, on a Sunday, Napoleon appeared in the warehouse to explain to the animals that he had never thought of selling the wood to Frederick, saying that such types were not worthy of his dealings.
tr: One Sunday morning, Napoleon came to the barn and declared that he had never even considered selling the timber to Frederick, as he could not bear the dishonor of dealing with such a vile creature.
es: One Sunday morning, Napoleon appeared in the barn and explained that at no time had he intended to sell the pile of wood to Frederick; he considered it incompatible with his dignity to have dealings with scoundrels of that sort.

en: The pigeons who were still sent out to spread tidings of the Rebellion were forbidden to set foot anywhere on Foxwood, and were also ordered to drop their former slogan of “Death to Humanity” in favour of “Death to Frederick.”
vi: The pigeons, which were still being sent to call on animals in other farms to rise up in rebellion, were forbidden from approaching Foxwood Farm, and the slogan "Death to Humanity!" was replaced with "Death to Frederick!".
tr: The pigeons, which were still being sent to neighboring farms to spread the idea of rebellion, were instructed not to set foot on Foxwood Farm, and they were ordered to abandon the slogan "Death to Humanity" and instead use the slogan "Death to Frederick."
es: The pigeons, who were still being sent to spread news about the Rebellion, were forbidden to set foot in Foxwood and were also forced to abandon their previous slogan of "Death to Humanity," replacing it with "Death to Frederick."

en: In the late summer yet another of Snowball’s machinations was laid bare.
vi: By the end of summer, another crime of Snowball was discovered.
tr: Towards the end of summer, another one of Snowball's schemes was uncovered.
es: At the end of summer, a new plot by Snowball was uncovered.

en: The wheat crop was full of weeds, and it was discovered that on one of his nocturnal visits Snowball had mixed weed seeds with the seed corn.
vi: This time it was the wheat field full of weeds - after investigation, it was discovered that Snowball had sneaked into the farm at night and mixed weed seeds with the wheat seeds.
tr: No one could solve the mystery of the weeds that had been plaguing the crops for some time; finally, it was discovered that Snowball had secretly entered the farm one night and mixed weed seeds with the wheat seeds.
es: The wheat fields were full of weeds, and it was discovered that, during one of his nocturnal visits, Snowball had mixed thistle seeds with the wheat seeds.

en: A gander who had been privy to the plot had confessed his guilt to Squealer and immediately committed suicide by swallowing deadly nightshade berries.
vi: A male goose, an accomplice in this affair, confessed his guilt to Squealer and then immediately swallowed a poisonous nightshade berry to commit suicide.
tr: A male goose, who had been an accomplice to Snowball, confessed his crime to Squealer and then committed suicide by swallowing poisonous yew berries.
es: A goose, an accomplice in the plot, had confessed its guilt to Squealer and immediately committed suicide by ingesting some toxic herbs.

en: The animals now also learned that Snowball had never — as many of them had believed hitherto — received the order of “Animal Hero, First Class.”
vi: The animals were also informed that, contrary to what many believed, Snowball had never been awarded the title of Animal Hero, First Class.
tr: Meanwhile, the animals learned that, contrary to what many had known until that day, Snowball had never received the "Animal Hero, First Class" medal.
es: The animals also learned that Snowball had never—as many of them had believed until then—received the order of "Animal Hero, First Class."

en: This was merely a legend which had been spread some time after the Battle of the Cowshed by Snowball himself.
vi: That story was fabricated by Snowball himself right after the Battle of the Cowshed.
tr: Snowball had fabricated this story himself some time after the Battle of the Cowshed.
es: It was simply a legend spread shortly after the "Battle of the Cowshed" by Snowball himself.

en: So far from being decorated, he had been censured for showing cowardice in the battle.
vi: Not only was he not rewarded, but he was also heavily criticized for showing cowardice during the battle.
tr: Far from being rewarded with a medal, he had been condemned for showing cowardice in the battle.
es: Far from being decorated, he was censured for showing cowardice in the battle.

en: Once again some of the animals heard this with a certain bewilderment, but Squealer was soon able to convince them that their memories had been at fault.
vi: As always, this news confused some of the animals, but Squealer quickly convinced them that it was simply due to their poor memory.
tr: When the animals heard all this, they reacted with great astonishment once again. But Squealer was quick to calm them down, saying that memory was deceptive.
es: Once again, some animals listened to this with some perplexity, but Squealer managed to convince them that their memories were mistaken.

en: In the autumn, by a tremendous, exhausting effort — for the harvest had to be gathered at almost the same time — the windmill was finished.
vi: The windmill was completed in the fall, right at the time of the harvest, and they had to work until they were exhausted.
tr: The windmill was completed in the autumn; but since the harvest also needed to be gathered around the same time, they were exhausted from fatigue.
es: In the autumn, through a tremendous and exhausting effort—because the harvest had to be done almost simultaneously—the windmill was completed.

en: The machinery had still to be installed, and Whymper was negotiating the purchase of it, but the structure was completed.
