vi: Although the equipment still needed to be installed, which Whymper was negotiating to purchase, the main thing was that the workshop was already built.
tr: The machines had not yet been installed, Whymper was conducting the purchase negotiations; but the construction work was finished.
es: The machinery still needed to be installed and Whymper was still negotiating its purchase, but the construction was finished.

en: In the teeth of every difficulty, in spite of inexperience, of primitive implements, of bad luck and of Snowball’s treachery, the work had been finished punctually to the very day!
vi: Despite numerous difficulties, lack of technology and experience, and even sabotage by Snowball, they still managed to complete the construction on the scheduled date!
tr: Despite inexperience, the primitiveness of the tools used, misfortunes, Snowball's betrayal, in short, despite all kinds of difficulties and obstacles, they managed to finish the work on the exact day specified!
es: Despite all the difficulties, despite the inexperience, the primitive tools, the bad luck, and the betrayal of Snowball, the work had been completed punctually on the set day!

en: Tired out but proud, the animals walked round and round their masterpiece, which appeared even more beautiful in their eyes than when it had been built the first time.
vi: Even though they were very tired, the animals still tried to walk around the windmill many times, full of pride, and at this moment, it looked even more beautiful than the first time it was built.
tr: The animals, their bodies tired but their hearts full of pride, were circling around the masterpiece they had created, losing themselves as they watched the windmill, which they found much more beautiful than the first one built.
es: Very tired but proud, the animals circled around their masterpiece, which in their opinion appeared even more beautiful than when it was first erected.

en: Moreover, the walls were twice as thick as before.
vi: Not to mention, the walls this time were twice as thick as before.
tr: Moreover, this time the walls of the windmill were twice as thick as before.
es: Moreover, the thickness of the walls was double what it had been before.

en: Nothing short of explosives would lay them low this time!
vi: Now, it would be impossible to destroy it without explosives!
tr: Nothing but dynamite could destroy these walls!
es: Only with explosives would it be possible to bring it down this time!

en: And when they thought of how they had laboured, what discouragements they had overcome, and the enormous difference that would be made in their lives when the sails were turning and the dynamos running — when they thought of all this, their tiredness forsook them and they gambolled round and round the windmill, uttering cries of triumph.
vi: And when they thought about the amount of work done, the difficulties overcome, the changes that would come when the windmill blades started to turn, when the generator started running; when they thought about those things, all their fatigue disappeared, and they ran around the windmill together, shouting loudly.
tr: When they thought about how much effort they had put in, how many disappointments they had overcome, and how different their lives would be once the gears turned and the dynamos worked, their fatigue melted away; they began to hop and skip around the windmill, shouting victory cries.
es: And when they remembered how they had worked, the discouragement they had overcome, and the change it would bring to their lives when the sails were turning and the dynamos were functioning, when they thought of all this, their fatigue disappeared and they jumped around the windmill, shouting triumphantly.

en: Napoleon himself, attended by his dogs and his cockerel, came down to inspect the completed work; he personally congratulated the animals on their achievement, and announced that the mill would be named Napoleon Mill.
vi: Even Napoleon, escorted by a few dogs and a rooster, came to see it, congratulated everyone on the completion of the project, and declared that the project would be named the Napoleon Mill.
tr: Shortly after, Napoleon arrived with his dogs and rooster, inspected the windmill, congratulated the animals on their success, and announced that the windmill would henceforth be known as Napoleon Mill.
es: Napoleon himself, accompanied by his dogs and his rooster, came to inspect the finished work; he personally congratulated the animals on their feat and announced that the windmill would be called "Napoleon Mill."

en: Two days later the animals were called together for a special meeting in the barn.
vi: Two days later, the animals were invited to attend a special meeting in the barn.
tr: Two days later, the animals were called to a special meeting to be held in the barn.
es: Two days later, the animals were summoned for a special meeting in the barn.

en: They were struck dumb with surprise when Napoleon announced that he had sold the pile of timber to Frederick.
vi: They could not believe it when they heard Napoleon say that he had sold the timber to Frederick.
tr: At the meeting, they were stunned when Napoleon announced that he had sold all the timber to Frederick.
es: They were stunned when Napoleon announced that he had sold the pile of wood to Frederick.

en: Tomorrow Frederick’s wagons would arrive and begin carting it away.
vi: Tomorrow, Frederick's truck would come to collect it.
tr: The next day, Frederick's carts would come to the farm and start transporting the timber.
es: Frederick's carts would start taking it away.

en: Throughout the whole period of his seeming friendship with Pilkington, Napoleon had really been in secret agreement with Frederick.
vi: It turned out that all this time Napoleon had pretended to be friendly with Pilkington but was secretly negotiating with Frederick.
tr: Apparently, while Napoleon appeared to be friendly with Pilkington, he had actually already secretly made a deal with Frederick.
es: Throughout the entire period of his apparent friendship with Pilkington, Napoleon had actually been secretly in agreement with Frederick.

en: All relations with Foxwood had been broken off; insulting messages had been sent to Pilkington.
vi: All relations with Foxwood Farm were cut off, and a note filled with insulting words was sent to Pilkington.
tr: All relations with Foxwood Farm had been cut off, and denunciatory messages were sent to Pilkington.
es: All relations with Foxwood were cut off while insulting messages were sent to Pilkington.

en: The pigeons had been told to avoid Pinchfield Farm and to alter their slogan from “Death to Frederick” to “Death to Pilkington.”
vi: The pigeons were ordered to avoid Pinchfield Farm and change the slogan "Death to Frederick" to "Death to Pilkington".
tr: The pigeons were instructed not to visit Pinchfield Farm and to replace the slogan "Death to Frederick" with "Death to Pilkington."
es: The pigeons were instructed to avoid "Pinchfield Farm" and to change their slogan from "Death to Frederick" to "Death to Pilkington."

en: At the same time Napoleon assured the animals that the stories of an impending attack on Animal Farm were completely untrue, and that the tales about Frederick’s cruelty to his own animals had been greatly exaggerated.
vi: At the same time, Napoleon assured the animals that the rumors about the attack on Animal Farm were completely unfounded, and that the reports of Frederick's mistreatment of livestock had been greatly exaggerated.
tr: Meanwhile, Napoleon told the animals that the rumors about an imminent attack on Animal Farm were completely fabricated and that the stories about Frederick mistreating his animals were greatly exaggerated.
es: At the same time, Napoleon assured the animals that the rumors of an attack on "Animal Farm" were completely false and that the news regarding Frederick's cruelties to his animals had been greatly exaggerated.

en: All these rumours had probably originated with Snowball and his agents.
vi: It was likely that Snowball and his agents had spread these rumors.
tr: All these rumors were most likely spread by Snowball and his agents.
es: All those rumors had probably been spread by Snowball and his agents.

en: It now appeared that Snowball was not, after all, hiding on Pinchfield Farm, and in fact had never been there in his life: he was living — in considerable luxury, so it was said — at Foxwood, and had in reality been a pensioner of Pilkington for years past.
vi: It turned out that Snowball not only was not hiding in Pinchfield Farm but had never been there at all; in fact, he was living quite comfortably, according to reports, in Foxwood Farm: he had sold himself to Pilkington long ago.
tr: Now everything was clear: Snowball was not hiding at Pinchfield Farm, he had never been there; according to reports, he was living in great luxury at Foxwood Farm and had been serving Pilkington for years.
es: It was now discovered that Snowball was not hiding at "Pinchfield Farm" and that, in fact, he had never been there in his life; he was residing in Foxwood —in extraordinary luxury, it was said— and apparently, he had been a protégé of Pilkington for many years.

en: The pigs were in ecstasies over Napoleon’s cunning.
vi: The pigs took the opportunity to elevate Napoleon to cloud nine.
tr: The pigs tipped their hats to Napoleon's cunning, who, by appearing to advance his friendship with Pilkington, had managed to get Frederick to pay twelve pounds more for the timber.
es: The pigs were astonished by Napoleon's cunning.

en: By seeming to be friendly with Pilkington he had forced Frederick to raise his price by twelve pounds.
vi: Pretending to be friendly with Pilkington, he forced Frederick to pay an extra twenty pounds.
tr: The pigs tipped their hats to Napoleon's cunning, who, by appearing to advance his friendship with Pilkington, had managed to get Frederick to pay twelve pounds more for the timber.
es: Through his apparent friendship with Pilkington, he forced Frederick to increase his price by twelve pounds.

en: But the superior quality of Napoleon’s mind, said Squealer, was shown in the fact that he trusted nobody, not even Frederick.
vi: Squealer even said that Napoleon was an extraordinary pig because he never trusted anyone, not any animal, not even Frederick.
tr: But according to Squealer, the real proof of Napoleon's superior intelligence was that he trusted no one, not even Frederick.
es: But the superiority of Napoleon's mind, said Squealer, was demonstrated by the fact that he trusted no one, not even Frederick.

en: Frederick had wanted to pay for the timber with something called a cheque, which, it seemed, was a piece of paper with a promise to pay written upon it.
vi: Frederick wanted to pay by check, meaning a piece of paper specifying the amount that could be received when needed.
tr: Frederick had tried to pay for the timber with a check that was nothing more than a piece of paper promising payment; but Napoleon had outsmarted him, insisting that the payment be made in five-pound banknotes before the timber was moved.
es: Frederick had wanted to pay for the timber with something called a check, which, it seems, was a piece of paper with the promise to pay the amount written on it.

en: But Napoleon was too clever for him.
vi: But Napoleon proved to be much smarter than him.
tr: Frederick had tried to pay for the timber with a check that was nothing more than a piece of paper promising payment; but Napoleon had outsmarted him, insisting that the payment be made in five-pound banknotes before the timber was moved.
es: But Napoleon was too smart for him.

en: He had demanded payment in real five-pound notes, which were to be handed over before the timber was removed.
vi: He demanded payment in cash, in five-pound notes, and insisted that the full amount be paid before the wood could be taken away.
tr: Frederick had tried to pay for the timber with a check that was nothing more than a piece of paper promising payment; but Napoleon had outsmarted him, insisting that the payment be made in five-pound banknotes before the timber was moved.
es: He had demanded payment in genuine five-pound notes, which had to be paid before the timber was removed.

en: Already Frederick had paid up; and the sum he had paid was just enough to buy the machinery for the windmill.
vi: Frederick had already paid in full, and this amount was enough to buy all the equipment for the windmill.
tr: In the end, Frederick had indeed paid the money as demanded; the amount he paid was just enough to purchase the machinery needed for the windmill.
es: Frederick paid, and the amount paid was just enough to buy the machinery needed for the windmill.

en: Meanwhile the timber was being carted away at high speed.
vi: The wood was transported quite quickly.
tr: Meanwhile, the timbers were being transported at great speed.
es: Meanwhile, the timber was being hurriedly transported.

en: When it was all gone, another special meeting was held in the barn for the animals to inspect Frederick’s bank-notes.
vi: When the wood in the yard had all been taken away, the animals were invited to a special meeting to inspect the money delivered by Frederick.
tr: After all of them were transported, another special meeting was held in the big barn so that the animals could see the banknotes given by Frederick with their own eyes.
es: When it had been completely removed, another special meeting was held in the barn so that the animals could gaze upon Frederick's banknotes.

en: Smiling beatifically, and wearing both his decorations, Napoleon reposed on a bed of straw on the platform, with the money at his side, neatly piled on a china dish from the farmhouse kitchen.
vi: Napoleon, wearing two medals on his chest and smiling broadly, reclined on a straw mattress, next to a porcelain dish filled with crisp new bills.
tr: Napoleon, who was wearing both of his medals, was grinning carelessly; he was lying on the straw mattress on the elevation; the money, carefully placed in a porcelain bowl brought from the farmhouse kitchen, was right beside him.
es: Smiling beatifically and displaying his two decorations, Napoleon lay on his straw bed on the platform, with the money beside him, carefully stacked on a porcelain kitchen plate.

en: The animals filed slowly past, and each gazed his fill.
vi: The animals walked by one by one, freely admiring the sight.
tr: The animals slowly passed by and closely examined the money.
es: The animals slowly paraded past him and gazed at him to their heart's content.

en: And Boxer put out his nose to sniff at the bank-notes, and the flimsy white things stirred and rustled in his breath.
vi: Boxer even sniffed at them, causing the new bills to rustle softly.
tr: When Boxer tried to sniff by extending his nose, the thin banknotes rustled and moved.
es: Boxer stretched out his nose to sniff the bills, and the thin papers moved and rustled under his breath.

en: Three days later there was a terrible hullabaloo.
vi: Three days later, a commotion occurred.
tr: It had not even been three days when the farm was thrown into chaos.
es: Three days later, a terrible commotion was recorded.

en: Whymper, his face deadly pale, came racing up the path on his bicycle, flung it down in the yard and rushed straight into the farmhouse.
vi: That day, Whymper, his face as pale as someone about to die, rode his bicycle madly into the campyard, and as soon as he arrived, he threw his bike to the ground and hurriedly rushed into the main building.
tr: Suddenly, Whymper appeared on his bicycle from down the road; his face was as white as chalk; when he entered the yard, he threw his bicycle aside and rushed into the farmhouse.
es: Whymper, extremely pale, arrived at full speed on his bicycle, threw it to the ground upon reaching the yard, and ran inside.

en: The next moment a choking roar of rage sounded from Napoleon’s apartments.
vi: Almost immediately, a horrifying scream was heard from Napoleon's room.
tr: Soon, angry roars were heard from the room where Napoleon was staying.
es: Soon, a dull roar of rage was heard from Napoleon's room.

en: The news of what had happened sped round the farm like wildfire.
vi: The news spread throughout the camp like wildfire.
tr: The news spread throughout the farm like an uncontrollable wildfire.
es: The news of what had happened spread through the farm like wildfire.

en: The banknotes were forgeries!
vi: The money Frederick paid was all fake!
tr: The banknotes had turned out to be fake!
es: The banknotes were fake!

en: Frederick had got the timber for nothing!
vi: He had taken the wood for free!
tr: Frederick had swindled the timber!
es: Frederick had gotten the wood for free!

en: Napoleon called the animals together immediately and in a terrible voice pronounced the death sentence upon Frederick.
vi: Napoleon immediately ordered a gathering and declared a death sentence for Frederick.
tr: Napoleon immediately gathered the animals; in a terrifying voice, he announced that he had sentenced Frederick to death and would have him thrown into a cauldron alive as soon as he was caught.
es: Napoleon immediately gathered all the animals and with a terrible voice decreed a death sentence for Frederick.

en: When captured, he said, Frederick should be boiled alive.
vi: That guy deserves to be burned alive - he said so.
tr: Napoleon immediately gathered the animals; in a terrifying voice, he announced that he had sentenced Frederick to death and would have him thrown into a cauldron alive as soon as he was caught.
es: When captured, he said, Frederick was to be boiled alive.

en: At the same time he warned them that after this treacherous deed the worst was to be expected.
vi: At the same time, he also stated that everyone must be prepared to deal with the worst situations.
tr: On the other hand, he also warned the animals to be prepared for the worst situations after Frederick's treachery.
es: At the same time, he warned them that after this treacherous act, the worst should be expected.

en: Frederick and his men might make their long-expected attack at any moment.
vi: Frederick and his men could attack at any moment.
tr: Frederick and his men could launch their long-awaited attack at any moment.
es: Frederick and his people could launch their long-awaited attack at any moment.

en: Sentinels were placed at all the approaches to the farm.
vi: Guards must be stationed on every road leading into the camp.
tr: Guards were placed at every possible entry point to the farm.
es: Sentinels were posted at all access routes to the farm.

en: In addition, four pigeons were sent to Foxwood with a conciliatory message, which it was hoped might re-establish good relations with Pilkington.
vi: Additionally, he sent four pigeons carrying messages of goodwill to Foxwood Farm in hopes of normalizing relations.
tr: Four pigeons were also sent to Foxwood Farm with a letter of reconciliation, hoping to re-establish friendly relations with Pilkington.
es: Additionally, four pigeons were sent to Foxwood with a conciliatory message, hoping to restore good relations with Pilkington.

en: The very next morning the attack came.
vi: Early the next morning, Frederick organized an attack.
tr: The attack began the next morning.
es: The attack occurred the next morning.

en: The animals were at breakfast when the look-outs came racing in with the news that Frederick and his followers had already come through the five-barred gate.
vi: The animals were preparing to have breakfast when the guard ran in to report that Frederick and his men had crossed the main gate of the farm.
tr: The animals were just sitting down to breakfast when the scouts came rushing in, raising dust, and reported that Frederick and his men had entered through the main gate.
es: The animals were having breakfast when the lookouts came running in with the announcement that Frederick and his forces had already passed through the access gate.

en: Boldly enough the animals sallied forth to meet them, but this time they did not have the easy victory that they had had in the Battle of the Cowshed.
vi: Without hesitation, the animals immediately charged, but this time they had to fight much harder than in the Battle of the Cowshed.
tr: The animals bravely rushed forward to meet the attackers; but this time, achieving victory did not seem as easy as it had in the Battle of the Cowshed.
es: The animals boldly went out to fight, but this time they did not achieve the easy victory they had obtained in the "Battle of the Cowshed."

en: There were fifteen men, with half a dozen guns between them, and they opened fire as soon as they got within fifty yards.
vi: There were fifteen men with about half a dozen guns, and they started shooting from more than a hundred meters away.
tr: There were fifteen of them, six of whom had rifles; they opened fire when they were about fifty meters away.
es: There were fifteen men, with half a dozen shotguns, and they opened fire as soon as they got within fifty meters of the animals.

en: The animals could not face the terrible explosions and the stinging pellets, and in spite of the efforts of Napoleon and Boxer to rally them, they were soon driven back.
vi: The gunfire was deafening, and the bullets sprayed like chaff; the animals did not expect the battle to be so fierce, so despite Napoleon and Boxer’s efforts to motivate them, they gradually retreated.
tr: The animals, unable to withstand the terrible explosions and the pellets that burned their flesh, soon had to retreat. Napoleon and Boxer tried hard to rally them, but it was to no avail.
es: The animals could not withstand the terrible explosions with their scalding pellets, and despite the efforts of Napoleon and Boxer to regroup them, they were soon driven back.

en: A number of them were already wounded.
vi: Some of the animals were injured.
tr: There were wounded.
es: A few of them were wounded.

en: They took refuge in the farm buildings and peeped cautiously out from chinks and knot-holes.
vi: They ran into the buildings and peered through the holes in the walls.
tr: They had taken refuge in the farm buildings, watching the outside through cracks and knot holes.
es: They took refuge in the farm buildings and cautiously peered through the cracks and knot holes in the wood.

en: The whole of the big pasture, including the windmill, was in the hands of the enemy.
vi: The entire large pasture, including the windmill, had fallen into the hands of the enemy.
tr: The large pasture and the windmill had fallen into enemy hands.
es: The entire large meadow, including the windmill, was in the hands of the enemy.

en: For the moment even Napoleon seemed at a loss.
vi: Even Napoleon appeared confused.
tr: Even Napoleon was stunned, unsure of what to do.
es: For the moment, even Napoleon was at a loss for what to do.

en: He paced up and down without a word, his tail rigid and twitching.
vi: He paced silently, his twisted tail flicking from side to side.
tr: He was silent, pacing the room rapidly with his tail held high.
es: He paced back and forth without saying a word, his tail stiff and twitching nervously.

en: Wistful glances were sent in the direction of Foxwood.
vi: Occasionally, he looked towards Foxwood Farm.
tr: All eyes were on the road to Foxwood Farm.
es: They cast eager glances in the direction of Foxwood.

en: If Pilkington and his men would help them, the day might yet be won.
vi: If Pilkington brought reinforcements, they might be able to drive the enemy away.
tr: If Pilkington and his men came to help, they might be saved.
es: If Pilkington and his people helped them, they might still come out well.

en: But at this moment the four pigeons, who had been sent out on the day before, returned, one of them bearing a scrap of paper from Pilkington.
vi: But at that moment, the four pigeons sent out the day before returned.
tr: But just at that moment, the pigeons they had sent out the day before returned. One of them had a note from Pilkington in its beak.
es: But at that moment the four pigeons that had been sent the day before returned, one of them carrying a piece of paper from Pilkington.

en: On it was pencilled the words: “Serves you right.”
vi: One of them held a piece of paper with the words "Serves you right."
tr: The note, written in pencil, read: "Serves you right!"
es: On it were written the following words in pencil: "Serves you right."

en: Meanwhile Frederick and his men had halted about the windmill.
vi: Meanwhile, Frederick and his men had approached the windmill.
tr: In the meantime, Frederick and his men had gathered around the windmill.
es: Meanwhile, Frederick and his men stopped by the mill.

en: The animals watched them, and a murmur of dismay went round.
vi: The animals watched intently, and anxious whispers began to rise.
tr: The animals, too, were watching them with helpless grumbles.
es: The animals watched them, and a murmur of anguish escaped their lips.

en: Two of the men had produced a crowbar and a sledge hammer.
vi: Two men were carrying hammers and crowbars.
tr: They saw two men take out a crowbar and a sledgehammer.
es: Two of the men wielded an iron crowbar and a hammer.

en: They were going to knock the windmill down.
vi: They were probably planning to destroy the windmill.
tr: They were preparing to demolish the windmill.
es: They were going to tear down the windmill.

en: “Impossible!” cried Napoleon.
vi: "It's not going to work!", Napoleon shouted, "The windmill walls are very thick, they can't do anything.
tr: "They can't do anything!" shouted Napoleon.
es: —Impossible! —shouted Napoleon—.

en: “We have built the walls far too thick for that.
vi: "It's not going to work!", Napoleon shouted, "The windmill walls are very thick, they can't do anything.
tr: "Their sledgehammers won't penetrate our thick walls.
es: We have built the walls too thick for that.

en: They could not knock it down in a week.
vi: It will take at least a week.
tr: Even if they work for a week, they still won't be able to bring them down.
es: They won't be able to bring them down even in a week.

en: Courage, comrades!”
vi: Stay calm, comrades!"
tr: Don't be afraid, comrades!"
es: Take heart, comrades!

en: But Benjamin was watching the movements of the men intently.
vi: But Benjamin did not take his eyes off all the movements.
tr: But Benjamin kept his eyes wide open, trying to understand what the men were doing.
es: But Benjamin was intently observing the movements of the men.

en: The two with the hammer and the crowbar were drilling a hole near the base of the windmill.
vi: The two men were using hammers and crowbars to dig a hole right at the foot of the windmill wall.
tr: Then he saw that the two men were digging a hole near the base of the windmill with a crowbar and a sledgehammer.
es: Those handling the hammer and the iron lever were opening a hole near the base of the mill.

en: Slowly, and with an air almost of amusement, Benjamin nodded his long muzzle.
vi: Benjamin nodded his long snout, seemingly finding it interesting.
tr: He slowly shook his long nose from side to side and smiled knowingly.
es: Slowly, and with an almost amused air, Benjamin shook his long snout.

en: “I thought so,” he said.
vi: "I still think so, it said, do you know what they are doing?
tr: "I knew it," he said.
es: —I thought so —he said—.

en: “Do you not see what they are doing?
vi: "I still think so, it said, do you know what they are doing?
tr: "Can't you see?
es: Don't you see what you're doing?

en: In another moment they are going to pack blasting powder into that hole.”
vi: They are going to put explosives in the hole."
tr: Soon they will fill that hole with gunpowder."
es: They're going to fill that hole with gunpowder right away.

en: Terrified, the animals waited.
vi: The animals waited in fear.
tr: The animals were waiting in fear.
es: The animals waited terrified.

en: It was impossible now to venture out of the shelter of the buildings.
vi: None of them dared to risk rushing out.
tr: It was now impossible for them to attempt to leave the buildings they had taken refuge in.
es: It was impossible to venture outside the shelter of the buildings.

en: After a few minutes the men were seen to be running in all directions.
vi: Then they saw the humans scattering in all directions.
tr: A few minutes later, they saw the men fleeing from the mill.
es: After several minutes, the men were seen running in all directions.

en: Then there was a deafening roar.
vi: A deafening explosion rang out.
tr: Immediately after, a deafening roar erupted.
es: Then a deafening roar was heard.

en: The pigeons swirled into the air, and all the animals, except Napoleon, flung themselves flat on their bellies and hid their faces.
vi: The pigeons shot up into the air, while the other animals, except Napoleon, quickly lay flat on the ground, faces pressed to the earth.
tr: The pigeons flew into the air, and all the animals except Napoleon threw themselves face down on the ground and covered their faces.
es: The pigeons swirled in the air and all the animals, except for Napoleon, threw themselves to the ground face down and hid their faces.

en: When they got up again, a huge cloud of black smoke was hanging where the windmill had been.
vi: When they lifted their heads, they saw a cloud of black smoke still covering the area of the windmill.
tr: When they stood up, the place where the windmill had been was engulfed in thick black smoke.
es: When they got up again, a huge cloud of black smoke was floating where the windmill had been.

en: Slowly the breeze drifted it away.
vi: The smoke gradually cleared.
tr: When the smoke dispersed with the wind, they saw that there was nothing left of the windmill!
es: Slowly the breeze carried it away.

en: The windmill had ceased to exist!
vi: The windmill had been completely destroyed!
tr: When the smoke dispersed with the wind, they saw that there was nothing left of the windmill!
es: The windmill had ceased to exist!

en: At this sight the animals’ courage returned to them.
vi: The scene immediately awakened the animals.
tr: The animals, seeing all their labor blown away, suddenly gained courage.
es: Upon seeing this scene, the animals regained their courage.

en: The fear and despair they had felt a moment earlier were drowned in their rage against this vile, contemptible act.
vi: The cruel and wicked actions made them extremely angry.
tr: The anger they felt in the face of this treachery made them forget their earlier fear and despair.
es: The fear and despair they felt moments before were drowned by their anger against such a vile and abominable act.

en: A mighty cry for vengeance went up, and without waiting for further orders they charged forth in a body and made straight for the enemy.
vi: Without any orders, they simultaneously charged forward, rushing straight at the enemy, roaring with cries of hatred demanding revenge.
tr: A terrifying cry for revenge rose. Without waiting for anyone's orders, they all attacked the enemy together.
es: They let out a powerful cry for vengeance, and without waiting for another order, they attacked en masse and pounced on the enemy.

en: This time they did not heed the cruel pellets that swept over them like hail.
vi: Even the buckshot raining down on their backs did not make them falter.
tr: They no longer cared about the bullets raining down like hail.
es: This time they paid no attention to the cruel pellets that passed over their heads like hail.

en: It was a savage, bitter battle.
vi: They were ready to sacrifice everything.
tr: A wild, relentless battle ensued.
es: It was a fierce and savage battle.

en: The men fired again and again, and, when the animals got to close quarters, lashed out with their sticks and their heavy boots.
vi: Frederick and his men fired continuously, and when the animals got close, they used sticks to hit and kicked them.
tr: The men first fired repeatedly, and when the animals got very close, they started hitting them with sticks and thick boots.
es: The men fired again and again, and when the animals reached hand-to-hand combat, they beat them with their sticks and heavy boots.

en: A cow, three sheep, and two geese were killed, and nearly everyone was wounded.
vi: One cow, three sheep, and two geese were killed, almost all of them were injured.
tr: A cow, three sheep, and two geese died right there. Almost everyone was injured.
es: A cow, three sheep, and two geese died, and almost all were wounded.

en: Even Napoleon, who was directing operations from the rear, had the tip of his tail chipped by a pellet.
vi: Napoleon, commanding from behind, was also shot in the tail.
tr: Even Napoleon, who was directing the operation from behind, had the tip of his tail grazed by a bullet that reached him.
es: Even Napoleon, who was directing operations from the rear, was wounded on the tip of his tail by a pellet.

en: But the men did not go unscathed either.
vi: But some of Frederick's men were also bruised and battered.
tr: But the men had also suffered significant losses.
es: But the men did not come out unscathed either.

en: Three of them had their heads broken by blows from Boxer’s hoofs; another was gored in the belly by a cow’s horn; another had his trousers nearly torn off by Jessie and Bluebell.
vi: Three men had their heads smashed by Boxer, one was gored in the belly by a cow, and another had his pants torn by a dog bite.
tr: Boxer had smashed the heads of three men with his kicks, a cow had gored one in the stomach with its horns, and Jessie and Bluebell had torn another's pants to shreds with their teeth.
es: Three of them had their heads broken by Boxer's kicks; another was gored in the belly by a cow; one almost had his pants torn off by Jessie and Bluebell.

en: And when the nine dogs of Napoleon’s own bodyguard, whom he had instructed to make a detour under cover of the hedge, suddenly appeared on the men’s flank, baying ferociously, panic overtook them.
vi: When the nine dogs of Napoleon's guard were ordered to flank and attack while barking, the humans panicked.
tr: The nine dogs who were Napoleon's bodyguards, following their orders, circled around from behind the fence and attacked from the flank with terrifying barks, causing the men to panic.
es: And when Napoleon's nine guard dogs, whom he had ordered to circle around behind the fence, suddenly appeared on the flank barking fiercely, panic seized the men who saw the danger of being surrounded.

en: They saw that they were in danger of being surrounded.
vi: They realized they were about to be surrounded.
tr: They realized they were about to be surrounded.
es: And when Napoleon's nine guard dogs, whom he had ordered to circle around behind the fence, suddenly appeared on the flank barking fiercely, panic seized the men who saw the danger of being surrounded.

en: Frederick shouted to his men to get out while the going was good, and the next moment the cowardly enemy was running for dear life.
vi: Frederick ordered a retreat, and the enemy fled in panic.
tr: Frederick ordered his men to leave the farm before things got worse. Soon, the cowardly enemies were fleeing without looking back.
es: Frederick shouted to his men to escape while they still could, and immediately the enemy fled cowardly and at full speed.

en: The animals chased them right down to the bottom of the field, and got in some last kicks at them as they forced their way through the thorn hedge.
vi: The animals chased them all the way to the border and continued to butt them in the rear as they crawled through the fence separating the two farms.
tr: The animals chased the men down to the lower fields; they didn't miss the chance to land a few more kicks as the men tried to get through the barbed wire fence.
es: The animals chased them to the end of the field and managed to give them the last kicks as they crossed the barbed wire fence at full speed.

en: They had won, but they were weary and bleeding.
vi: They had won, but they were also exhausted from fatigue and injuries.
tr: They had won the war, but they were exhausted, covered in blood from head to toe.
es: They had won, but they were battered and bleeding.

en: Slowly they began to limp back towards the farm.
vi: They slowly returned to the farm.
tr: Limping, they headed back towards the farm.
es: Slowly and limping, they returned to the farm.

en: The sight of their dead comrades stretched upon the grass moved some of them to tears.
vi: The sight of their comrades' sacrifice moved them to tears.
tr: Some of them burst into tears upon seeing their fallen comrades lying on the grass.
es: The sight of the dead comrades lying on the grass made some of them cry.

en: And for a little while they halted in sorrowful silence at the place where the windmill had once stood.
vi: They stood silently beside the rubble of the windmill.
tr: They stood in respectful silence for a moment where the windmill once stood.
es: And for a while, they stopped, disconsolate and silent, at the place where the windmill had once stood.

en: Yes, it was gone; almost the last trace of their labour was gone!
vi: The windmill was gone, all their efforts erased!
tr: Yes, all their efforts had been in vain, not even a trace of the windmill remained!
es: Yes, it was gone; every last trace of their labor had vanished!

en: Even the foundations were partially destroyed.
vi: Even the foundation was almost completely destroyed.
tr: Even the foundation of the structure was partially destroyed.
es: Even the foundations were partially destroyed.

en: And in rebuilding it they could not this time, as before, make use of the fallen stones.
vi: Last time, when rebuilding, they could still use the old stones.
tr: Even if they tried to rebuild, they couldn't gather the stones from the demolished walls.
es: And to rebuild it, they could not, this time, use the fallen stones as they had before.

en: This time the stones had vanished too.
vi: Now, even the stones were gone.
tr: Even if they tried to rebuild, they couldn't gather the stones from the demolished walls.
es: Even those had disappeared.

en: The force of the explosion had flung them to distances of hundreds of yards.
vi: The explosion had scattered the stones everywhere, as far as a hundred meters away.
tr: The explosion had scattered them hundreds of meters away.
es: The force of the explosion had hurled them hundreds of meters away.

en: It was as though the windmill had never been.
vi: When they were nearing the farm, Chỉ Điểm, whom none of them had seen during the battle, suddenly appeared from somewhere, wagging its tail vigorously, looking very pleased.
tr: As they approached the farm, they saw Squealer, who had mysteriously disappeared during the war, hopping and skipping towards them.
es: It was as if the windmill had never existed.

en: As they approached the farm Squealer, who had unaccountably been absent during the fighting, came skipping towards them, whisking his tail and beaming with satisfaction.
vi: When they were nearing the farm, Chỉ Điểm, whom none of them had seen during the battle, suddenly appeared from somewhere, wagging its tail vigorously, looking very pleased.
tr: He was wagging his tail happily, his face shining with joy.
es: When they approached the farm, Squealer, who had been inexplicably absent during the fight, came skipping towards them, wagging his tail and brimming with joy.

en: And the animals heard, from the direction of the farm buildings, the solemn booming of a gun.
vi: The animals heard the sound of gunfire.
tr: At that moment, a gunshot rang out from the direction of the farm buildings.
es: And the animals heard, coming from the farm buildings, the solemn boom of a shotgun.

en: “What is that gun firing for?” said Boxer.
vi: "Why are they shooting?", Chiến Sĩ asked
tr: Boxer asked, "What is this?"
es: —What was that shot for? —asked Boxer.

en: “To celebrate our victory!” cried Squealer.
vi: "To celebrate the victory," Chỉ Điểm shouted.
tr: "They are celebrating our victory!" shouted Squealer.
es: —To celebrate our victory! —shouted Squealer.

en: “What victory?” said Boxer.
vi: "Which victory?" the Warrior said again.
tr: "What victory?" said Boxer.
es: —What victory? —exclaimed Boxer.

en: His knees were bleeding, he had lost a shoe and split his hoof, and a dozen pellets had lodged themselves in his hind leg.
vi: Its knees were all torn, the iron claws were loose, its feet were injured, and its hind legs were still embedded with dozens of shrapnel pieces.
tr: His knees were bleeding, he had lost one of his shoes, his hoof was split, and a lot of buckshot had lodged in his hind leg.
es: His knees were bleeding, he had lost a horseshoe, one hoof was cracked, and a dozen pellets were embedded in a hind leg.

en: “What victory, comrade?
vi: "What victory, comrades?
tr: "What do you mean, what victory, comrade?
es: —What victory, comrade?

en: Have we not driven the enemy off our soil — the sacred soil of Animal Farm?”
vi: Did we not just liberate the land, the sacred land of our Animal Farm?"
tr: Didn't we drive the enemy out of our lands, the sacred lands of Animal Farm?"
es: Haven't we driven the enemy off our soil, the sacred soil of "Animal Farm"?

en: “But they have destroyed the windmill.
vi: "But they have knocked down the windmill, two years of construction is not a small thing!"
tr: "But they blew up the windmill.
es: —But they have destroyed the mill.

en: And we had worked on it for two years!”
vi: "But they have knocked down the windmill, two years of construction is not a small thing!"
tr: We had spent exactly two years building that windmill!"
es: And we have worked for two years to build it!

en: “What matter?
vi: "So what?
tr: "Never mind, don't worry!
es: —What does it matter?

en: We will build another windmill.
vi: We will build another one.
tr: We'll make a new one.
es: We will build another windmill.

en: We will build six windmills if we feel like it.
vi: If we want, we can build six at once.
tr: If we feel like it, we'll build six more windmills.
es: We will build six windmills if we want.

en: You do not appreciate, comrade, the mighty thing that we have done.
vi: Perhaps you have not fully appreciated the great victory we just achieved.
tr: You don't seem to realize what a great achievement we've accomplished, comrade!
es: You do not appreciate, comrades, the importance of what we have done.

en: The enemy was in occupation of this very ground that we stand upon.
vi: The enemy had taken the very land we are standing on now.
tr: The land we're standing on was in enemy hands just a moment ago.
es: The enemy was occupying this ground we stand on.

en: And now — thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon — we have won every inch of it back again!”
vi: Now, thanks to Comrade Napoleon's leadership, we have reclaimed every inch of our land."
tr: But now we've taken back every inch of it; thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, of course!"
es: And now, thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, we have recaptured every inch of it!

en: “Then we have won back what we had before,” said Boxer.
vi: "We are reclaiming our own land," the Warrior said.
tr: "So, we have taken back what was already ours," said Boxer.
es: —So, have we regained what we had before? —asked Boxer.

en: “That is our victory,” said Squealer.
vi: "That's exactly the victory, isn't it?" Chỉ Điểm said.
tr: Squealer said, "This victory is ours."
es: —That is our victory —added Squealer.

en: They limped into the yard.
vi: Finally, they managed to drag themselves back to the campyard.
tr: They limped into the courtyard.
es: They limped into the yard.

en: The pellets under the skin of Boxer’s leg smarted painfully.
vi: The shrapnel still embedded in Chiến Sĩ's leg throbbed unbearably.
tr: The pellets in his leg were causing Boxer pain.
es: The pellets, embedded in Boxer's leg, burned him painfully.

en: He saw ahead of him the heavy labour of rebuilding the windmill from the foundations, and already in imagination he braced himself for the task.
vi: He had already envisioned the hardships and toil of rebuilding the windmill from scratch and was mentally prepared to dive into the work.
tr: As he thought about how arduous the task of rebuilding the windmill would be and how much responsibility would fall on him, he felt old for perhaps the first time; he realized that his massive muscles were no longer as strong as they used to be.
es: He saw before him the heavy task of rebuilding the windmill from the foundations and, in his imagination, he prepared for the task.

en: But for the first time it occurred to him that he was eleven years old and that perhaps his great muscles were not quite what they had once been.
vi: But this was also the first time he realized that he was already eleven years old, and his strength was not what it used to be.
tr: As he thought about how arduous the task of rebuilding the windmill would be and how much responsibility would fall on him, he felt old for perhaps the first time; he realized that his massive muscles were no longer as strong as they used to be.
es: But for the first time, it occurred to him that he was eleven years old and that perhaps his great muscles were no longer what they had been before.

en: But when the animals saw the green flag flying, and heard the gun firing again — seven times it was fired in all — and heard the speech that Napoleon made, congratulating them on their conduct, it did seem to them after all that they had won a great victory.
vi: But when they saw the green flag flying, heard the salvo of gunfire—seven volleys that day—and especially after hearing Napoleon's thanks for their brave fighting, they truly felt they had achieved a great victory.
tr: The other animals, after seeing the green flag waving, hearing the gun fired exactly seven times, and listening to Napoleon's speech congratulating them for their bravery in the battle, felt that they had indeed achieved a great victory.
es: But when the animals saw the green flag waving and heard the gun being fired again —seven times in total— and listened to the speech Napoleon gave, congratulating them on their conduct, it seemed to them that, after all, they had achieved a great victory.

en: The animals slain in the battle were given a solemn funeral.
vi: The fallen were buried with care.
tr: Those who died in the battle were buried with a solemn ceremony.
es: The dead in the battle received a solemn burial.

en: Boxer and Clover pulled the wagon which served as a hearse, and Napoleon himself walked at the head of the procession.
vi: The funeral procession was led by Napoleon himself, followed by a two-horse carriage used as a hearse, pulled by Warrior and Fatty.
tr: The cart used as a hearse was pulled by Boxer and Clover, and Napoleon walked at the front of the funeral procession.
es: Boxer and Clover pulled the cart that served as a hearse and Napoleon himself led the procession.

en: Two whole days were given over to celebrations.
vi: They took two days off to celebrate the victory.
tr: The celebrations lasted for a full two days.
es: For two whole days, celebrations took place.

en: There were songs, speeches, and more firing of the gun, and a special gift of an apple was bestowed on every animal, with two ounces of corn for each bird and three biscuits for each dog.
vi: They organized singing, gave speeches, and fired guns; each livestock animal received an apple, each poultry animal received sixty grams of grain, and each dog received three biscuits.
tr: Songs were sung, speeches were made, guns were fired; as a reward, each animal was given an apple, each bird fifty grams of millet, and each dog three biscuits.
es: There were songs, speeches, and more gunfire, and a special gift of an apple was given to each animal, with two ounces of corn for each bird and three biscuits for each dog.

en: It was announced that the battle would be called the Battle of the Windmill, and that Napoleon had created a new decoration, the Order of the Green Banner, which he had conferred upon himself.
vi: It was then announced that this battle would be called the Windmill Campaign, and Napoleon decided to establish a new title called the "Green Flag Medal," which he awarded to himself.
tr: It was then announced that this last battle would henceforth be known as the "Battle of the Windmill," that Napoleon had decided to establish a new decoration called the "Green Flag," and that he had awarded the first decoration to himself.
es: It was announced that the battle would be called the Battle of the Windmill and that Napoleon had created a new decoration, the "Order of the Green Banner," which he awarded to himself.

en: In the general rejoicings the unfortunate affair of the banknotes was forgotten.
vi: In that overwhelming collective joy, none of them thought about the counterfeit money incident anymore.
tr: The euphoria of victory had made them forget the counterfeit banknotes.
es: In the general rejoicing, the unfortunate incident of the banknotes was forgotten.

en: It was a few days later than this that the pigs came upon a case of whisky in the cellars of the farmhouse.
vi: A few days later, the pigs discovered a barrel of whisky in the basement of the main house.
tr: A few days later, the pigs found a case of whiskey in the cellar of the farmhouse.
es: A few days later, the pigs found a case of whiskey in the basement of the house.

en: It had been overlooked at the time when the house was first occupied.
vi: That afternoon, the other animals suddenly heard singing coming from the main house, and what surprised them even more was that there were parts of the song "Beasts of England".
tr: Apparently, they hadn't noticed it when they first entered the house.
es: It had been overlooked when the building was occupied.

en: That night there came from the farmhouse the sound of loud singing, in which, to everyone’s surprise, the strains of ‘Beasts of England’ were mixed up.
vi: That afternoon, the other animals suddenly heard singing coming from the main house, and what surprised them even more was that there were parts of the song "Beasts of England".
tr: That night, songs rose from the farmhouse; moreover, everyone was very surprised that tunes from "Beasts of England" occasionally mixed in.
es: That night, loud songs were heard from the house, where, to everyone's surprise, the chords of "Beasts of England" were intermingled.

en: At about half past nine Napoleon, wearing an old bowler hat of mr Jones’s, was distinctly seen to emerge from the back door, gallop rapidly round the yard, and disappear indoors again.
vi: Then, at around half-past nine, while it was still light, they saw Napoleon emerge from the back door, wearing Mr. Jones's old bowler hat, trotting around the yard once before going back inside.
tr: Around half-past nine, Napoleon came out the back door wearing Mr. Jones's bowler hat, circled around the yard, and went back inside.
es: Around half-past nine, Napoleon, wearing one of Mr. Jones's old bowler hats, was seen exiting through the back door, galloping around the yard, and re-entering.

en: But in the morning a deep silence hung over the farmhouse.
vi: The next morning, a silence enveloped the entire main house.
tr: By morning, a deep silence reigned in the farmhouse.
es: But, in the morning, a profound silence reigned in the house.

en: Not a pig appeared to be stirring.
vi: Not a single pig or any movement was seen around the house.
tr: Apparently, all the pigs were still sleeping.
es: Not a single pig was moving.

en: It was nearly nine o’clock when Squealer made his appearance, walking slowly and dejectedly, his eyes dull, his tail hanging limply behind him, and with every appearance of being seriously ill.
vi: It wasn't until around nine o'clock that Squealer appeared, his eyes looking glazed, tail drooping, and legs moving sluggishly, clearly very tired.
tr: Around nine, Squealer appeared at the door; he moved slowly; he looked exhausted, his gaze was blank, his tail hung down; he seemed as if he had caught an incurable disease.
es: It was almost nine when Squealer made his appearance, walking slowly and clumsily, his eyes dull, his tail hanging limply, and looking seriously ill.

en: He called the animals together and told them that he had a terrible piece of news to impart.
vi: He called everyone together and said there was an important announcement to make.
tr: He immediately gathered the animals.
es: He gathered the animals and told them he had bad news to share.

en: Comrade Napoleon was dying!
vi: Comrade Napoleon is dying!
tr: The news was bad: Comrade Napoleon was on his deathbed!
es: Comrade Napoleon was dying!

en: A cry of lamentation went up.
vi: The cries and wails rose up.
tr: A cry arose from the animals.
es: Expressions of pain rose in a unified cry.

en: Straw was laid down outside the doors of the farmhouse, and the animals walked on tiptoe.
vi: They hurriedly brought straw to spread in front of the main house's door, none of them dared to step heavily.
tr: Straw was spread in front of the doors of the farmhouse; everyone was walking on tiptoe.
es: Straw was placed at all the entrances of the house and the animals walked on tiptoe.

en: With tears in their eyes they asked one another what they should do if their Leader were taken away from them.
vi: Tears welling up, they whispered to each other about what they would do if the leader were to meet any misfortune.
tr: They were lamenting, saying, "What will become of us if we lose our leader?"
es: With tears in their eyes, they asked each other what they would do if they lost their Leader.

en: A rumour went round that Snowball had after all contrived to introduce poison into Napoleon’s food.
vi: There were rumors that Snowball had poisoned Napoleon.
tr: There was a rumor going around that Snowball had finally managed to poison Napoleon's food.
es: The rumor spread that Snowball, despite everything, had managed to introduce poison into Napoleon's food.

en: At eleven o’clock Squealer came out to make another announcement.
vi: At eleven o'clock, Squealer appeared again.
tr: At eleven o'clock, Squealer came out in front of the door to make another announcement.
es: At eleven, Squealer came out to make another announcement.

en: As his last act upon earth, Comrade Napoleon had pronounced a solemn decree: the drinking of alcohol was to be punished by death.
vi: Squealer said that before departing from this world, comrade Napoleon had signed a decree that from now on, any animal that drinks alcohol would be sentenced to death.
tr: Comrade Napoleon, on his deathbed, had issued one last decree: Those who drank alcohol would be sentenced to death.
es: As his last act on earth, comrade Napoleon issued a solemn decree: the act of drinking alcohol would be punished by death.

en: By the evening, however, Napoleon appeared to be somewhat better, and the following morning Squealer was able to tell them that he was well on the way to recovery.
vi: By the afternoon, there was news that Napoleon had improved, and the next morning, Chỉ Điểm announced that the leader was recovering.
tr: However, Squealer, who reported that Napoleon seemed a bit better towards the evening, announced the next morning that the Leader's health had rapidly improved.
es: At dusk, however, Napoleon seemed to be somewhat better and the next morning Squealer was able to tell them that he was on the way to a full recovery.

en: By the evening of that day Napoleon was back at work, and on the next day it was learned that he had instructed Whymper to purchase in Willingdon some booklets on brewing and distilling.
vi: That afternoon, Napoleon had gotten up to work, and the next morning, there was news that he had ordered Whymper to buy some books on brewing beer and wine in Willingdon.
tr: It was learned that Napoleon, who returned to his duties that evening, sent Whymper to Willingdon Farm the next day to purchase some booklets on fermentation and distillation methods.
es: That same night Napoleon was up and the next day it was known that he had ordered Whymper to buy some pamphlets on fermentation and distillation of beverages in Willingdon.

en: A week later Napoleon gave orders that the small paddock beyond the orchard, which it had previously been intended to set aside as a grazing-ground for animals who were past work, was to be ploughed up.
vi: A week later, Napoleon ordered the plowing of the land that had previously been intended as a pasture for the retired animals.
tr: About a week later, Napoleon ordered the plowing of the small meadow at the back of the orchard, which was intended to be set aside as pasture for animals that could no longer work.
es: A week later Napoleon ordered that the field behind the orchard be plowed, intended as a recreational area for animals retired from work.

en: It was given out that the pasture was exhausted and needed re-seeding; but it soon became known that Napoleon intended to sow it with barley.
vi: The animals were told that the land was too barren and needed to be cultivated for a while to regain its fertility, but it later became clear that Napoleon intended to plant barley there.
tr: Although it was said that the meadow had deteriorated and needed to be reseeded with grass, it soon became clear that Napoleon intended to plant barley there.
es: It was said that the field was exhausted and needed to be cultivated again, but it soon became known that Napoleon intended to sow it with barley.

en: About this time there occurred a strange incident which hardly anyone was able to understand.
vi: Around this time, an event occurred that almost none of the animals understood.
tr: It was precisely during those days that something strange, which no one could understand, happened.
es: More or less around that time, a strange incident occurred that almost no one was able to understand.

en: One night at about twelve o’clock there was a loud crash in the yard, and the animals rushed out of their stalls.
vi: That night, it was nearly midnight when a loud noise echoed from the yard, causing everyone to rush out of their pens.
tr: One night, around midnight, all the animals rushed outside upon hearing a crackling noise coming from the courtyard.
es: One night, around twelve, a loud crash was heard in the yard, and the animals came running out.

en: It was a moonlit night.
vi: That night, it was nearly midnight when a loud noise echoed from the yard, causing everyone to rush out of their pens.
tr: It was a moonlit night.
es: It was a clear, moonlit night.

en: At the foot of the end wall of the big barn, where the Seven Commandments were written, there lay a ladder broken in two pieces.
vi: The moon was very bright that night, and they all saw near the gable end of the large barn, where the "Seven Commandments" were inscribed, a ladder broken in two.
tr: At the foot of the long wall of the large barn where the Seven Commandments were written, a ladder split into two pieces was lying.
es: At the foot of the main barn wall, where the seven commandments were inscribed, there was a ladder broken into two pieces.

en: Squealer, temporarily stunned, was sprawling beside it, and near at hand there lay a lantern, a paint-brush, and an overturned pot of white paint.
vi: Nearby was Squealer, who was unconscious at the time, with a hurricane lamp and a can of white paint lying beside him.
tr: Squealer was also lying on the ground beside the ladder; he looked dazed. A little further away, a lantern, a paintbrush, and a knocked-over can of white paint were noticeable.
es: Squealer, momentarily stunned, was lying on the ground, and very close by were a lantern, a brush, and a spilled can of white paint.

en: The dogs immediately made a ring round Squealer, and escorted him back to the farmhouse as soon as he was able to walk.
vi: The dogs immediately formed a circle around Squealer and helped him back to the main house as he struggled to get up.
tr: The dogs immediately surrounded Squealer, and as soon as he was able to walk a little, they took him to the farmhouse.
es: The dogs immediately formed a circle around Squealer and escorted him back to the house as soon as he could walk.

en: None of the animals could form any idea as to what this meant, except old Benjamin, who nodded his muzzle with a knowing air, and seemed to understand, but would say nothing.
vi: It seemed that apart from Benjamin, none of the animals understood what had happened, but he just shook his head and said nothing.
tr: No one could make sense of this incident. Only old Benjamin, who was nodding his head wisely, seemed to understand everything, but he said nothing.
es: None of the animals could understand what it meant, except old Benjamin, who moved his snout knowingly, pretending to understand, but said nothing.

en: But a few days later Muriel, reading over the Seven Commandments to herself, noticed that there was yet another of them which the animals had remembered wrong.
vi: A few days later, Muriel, while rereading the Seven Commandments, discovered that they had misremembered another one.
tr: But a few days later, while Muriel was reading the Seven Commandments once again on her own, she noticed that the animals had misremembered another of the commandments.
es: After a few days, when Muriel was reading the seven commandments, she noticed that there was another one that the animals remembered incorrectly.

en: They had thought the Fifth Commandment was “No animal shall drink alcohol,” but there were two words that they had forgotten.
vi: They thought that the Fifth Commandment was "No animal shall drink alcohol," but they had forgotten three words.
tr: They knew the Fifth Commandment as "No animal shall drink alcohol!" which meant they had forgotten a word.
es: They believed that the fifth commandment said: "No animal shall drink alcohol," but they overlooked two words.

en: Actually the Commandment read: “No animal shall drink alcohol TO EXCESS.”
vi: In fact, the Commandment was: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess." George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: The correct version was: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess."
es: Now the commandment indicated: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess."

en: Chapter 9
vi: Chapter 9
tr: Ninth Chapter
es: IX

en: Boxer’s split hoof was a long time in healing.
vi: The injured hoof of Warrior took a long time to heal.
tr: It took a long time for Boxer's split hoof to heal.
es: Boxer's split hoof took a long time to heal.

en: They had started the rebuilding of the windmill the day after the victory celebrations were ended.
vi: Meanwhile, the animals proceeded to restore the windmill right after the victory celebration.
tr: They had started rebuilding the windmill the day after the victory celebrations ended.
es: They had begun the reconstruction of the windmill the day after the victory celebrations ended.

en: Boxer refused to take even a day off work, and made it a point of honour not to let it be seen that he was in pain.
vi: Warrior did not take a single day off, and it was very proud that it did not let the others see it was in pain.
tr: Boxer had not agreed to take a single day off; he saw it as a matter of honor not to show anyone that he was in pain, and he only confessed to Clover in the evenings that his hoof hurt a lot.
es: Boxer refused to take even a single day off and made it a point of honor not to show that he was in pain.

en: In the evenings he would admit privately to Clover that the hoof troubled him a great deal.
vi: Only in the evening did it tell Fatty that the wound was tormenting it.
tr: Boxer had not agreed to take a single day off; he saw it as a matter of honor not to show anyone that he was in pain, and he only confessed to Clover in the evenings that his hoof hurt a lot.
es: At night, he would privately admit to Clover that his hoof bothered him a lot.

en: Clover treated the hoof with poultices of herbs which she prepared by chewing them, and both she and Benjamin urged Boxer to work less hard.
vi: Fatty had to chew leaves and apply them to Warrior's wound. She, along with Benjamin, persuaded Warrior to take care of itself.
tr: Clover was trying to heal Boxer's wound with poultices she prepared by chewing various herbs. Clover and Benjamin were begging Boxer not to overexert himself.
es: Clover treated it with herbal poultices that she prepared by chewing them, and both she and Benjamin asked Boxer to work less.

en: “A horse’s lungs do not last for ever,” she said to him.
vi: "A horse's lungs are not very strong," it said.
tr: Clover would say, "Horses get tired too," but Boxer wouldn't listen:
es: "A horse's lungs are not eternal," she would tell him.

en: But Boxer would not listen.
vi: But Chiến Sĩ did not listen.
tr: Clover would say, "Horses get tired too," but Boxer wouldn't listen:
es: But Boxer paid no attention to her.

en: He had, he said, only one real ambition left — to see the windmill well under way before he reached the age for retirement.
vi: He said that he had only one wish, which was to see the windmill completed before he retired.
tr: He now had only one goal left, and that was to see the windmill working before he retired.
es: He said he had only one true ambition left: to see the windmill well advanced before reaching retirement age.

en: At the beginning, when the laws of Animal Farm were first formulated, the retiring age had been fixed for horses and pigs at twelve, for cows at fourteen, for dogs at nine, for sheep at seven, and for hens and geese at five.
vi: Right from the establishment of the Animal Farm's rules, it was stipulated that the retirement age for horses and pigs is twelve, for cows is fourteen, for dogs is nine, for sheep is seven, and for chickens is five.
tr: In the beginning, when the laws of Animal Farm were first being drafted, the retirement age was set at twelve for horses and pigs, fourteen for cows, nine for dogs, seven for sheep, and five for chickens and geese.
es: In the beginning, when the laws of "Animal Farm" were formulated, the following retirement ages were set: horses and pigs at twelve years, cows at fourteen, dogs at nine, sheep at seven, and chickens and geese at five.

en: Liberal old-age pensions had been agreed upon.
vi: They also agreed that those who retire would not lack anything.
tr: It was decided that the retirement pensions would be kept high.
es: Generous pensions were established for old age.

en: As yet no animal had actually retired on pension, but of late the subject had been discussed more and more.
vi: In fact, until now, no animal has retired yet, but recently this issue has been frequently discussed.
tr: Although no animal had yet retired, this topic had recently become more and more discussed.
es: Until then, no animal had retired, but lately, the discussion of the matter was increasing.

en: Now that the small field beyond the orchard had been set aside for barley, it was rumoured that a corner of the large pasture was to be fenced off and turned into a grazing-ground for superannuated animals.
vi: Now, with the plot of land next to the garden being used to grow barley, there is news that a corner of the long pasture will be fenced off for the elderly animals.
tr: After the small meadow at the back of the orchard was allocated for barley cultivation, there was a rumor that a corner of the large meadow would be fenced off and used as pasture for animals that were due to retire; it was said that retired horses should be given two and a half kilos of grain per day, seven and a half kilos of hay in winter, and on holidays, a carrot or, if possible, an apple.
es: Now that the small field behind the orchard had been designated for barley, there was a rumor that a corner of the long pasture would be fenced off, turning it into a field where retired animals would graze.

en: For a horse, it was said, the pension would be five pounds of corn a day and, in winter, fifteen pounds of hay, with a carrot or possibly an apple on public holidays.
vi: There is also news that retired horses will receive two pounds of grain per day in the summer, and seven pounds of hay in the winter, with an additional carrot or apple on holidays.
tr: After the small meadow at the back of the orchard was allocated for barley cultivation, there was a rumor that a corner of the large meadow would be fenced off and used as pasture for animals that were due to retire; it was said that retired horses should be given two and a half kilos of grain per day, seven and a half kilos of hay in winter, and on holidays, a carrot or, if possible, an apple.
es: For horses, it was said, the pension would be five pounds of maize per day and in winter fifteen pounds of hay, with a carrot or possibly an apple on holidays.

en: Boxer’s twelfth birthday was due in the late summer of the following year.
vi: Next year, Boxer will turn twelve years old.
tr: Boxer would turn twelve towards the end of next summer.
es: Boxer was going to turn twelve at the end of the summer of the following year.

en: Meanwhile life was hard.
vi: Currently, their lives must be said to be quite difficult.
tr: The hardships of life seemed never-ending.
es: Meanwhile, life continued to be hard.

en: The winter was as cold as the last one had been, and food was even shorter.
vi: This winter is as cold as last year, but food is even scarcer.
tr: This winter was as cold as the previous one, and food supplies had dwindled even further.
es: The winter was as cold as the previous one, and food even more scarce.

en: Once again all rations were reduced, except those of the pigs and the dogs.
vi: Rations, except for dogs and pigs, have all been reduced.
tr: Except for the rations of the pigs and dogs, all other rations had been cut once.
es: Once again, all rations were reduced, except for those of the pigs and the dogs.

en: A too rigid equality in rations, Squealer explained, would have been contrary to the principles of Animalism.
vi: Absolute equality, Squealer explained, is contrary to the principles of Animalism.
tr: According to Squealer's explanation, very strict equality in rations was against the principles of Animalism; it might seem like there was a food shortage, but the reality was far from it.
es: “A too rigid equality in rations,” explained Squealer, “would be contrary to the principles of Animalism.”

en: In any case he had no difficulty in proving to the other animals that they were NOT in reality short of food, whatever the appearances might be.
vi: He easily proved to the others that they actually had enough food, and that the food shortage was merely an illusion.
tr: Squealer was very good at soothing hearts.
es: In any case, he had no difficulty in demonstrating to the others that, in reality, they were not short of food, whatever the appearances might be.

en: For the time being, certainly, it had been found necessary to make a readjustment of rations (Squealer always spoke of it as a “readjustment,” never as a “reduction”), but in comparison with the days of Jones, the improvement was enormous.
vi: Of course, certain adjustments were necessary at this time (Squealer said "adjustments" rather than "reductions"), but compared to the days of old Jones, the improvement was clear.
tr: Undoubtedly, for now, they had to readjust the rations (Squealer never used the word "cut," preferring to say "readjustment"), but compared to Jones's era, there was still a significant improvement.
es: Certainly, it was necessary to make an adjustment of the rations (Squealer always referred to this as an “adjustment,” never as a “reduction”), but compared to Jones's times, the improvement was enormous.

en: Reading out the figures in a shrill, rapid voice, he proved to them in detail that they had more oats, more hay, more turnips than they had had in Jones’s day, that they worked shorter hours, that their drinking water was of better quality, that they lived longer, that a larger proportion of their young ones survived infancy, and that they had more straw in their stalls and suffered less from fleas.
vi: In a rapid, shrill voice, he presented very specific figures, proving that they harvested more oats, more hay, more turnips than in Jones's time, the work was lighter, the water quality was better, they lived longer, the infant survival rate was higher, they had more straw for bedding, and fewer lice.
tr: Reading the numbers in a high-pitched voice and quickly, he demonstrated that compared to Jones's era, they ate more oats, more hay, and more turnips, worked fewer hours, had better quality drinking water, lived longer, saw a significant reduction in the number of dead offspring, had more straw in the barns, and were less infested with fleas.
es: Reading them the figures in a shrill and rapid voice, he demonstrated in detail that they had more oats, more hay, and more turnips than they had in Jones's times; that they worked fewer hours, that the water they drank was of better quality, that they lived longer, that a greater proportion of creatures survived infancy, and that they had more straw in their stalls and fewer fleas.

en: The animals believed every word of it.
vi: All the animals believed this.
tr: The animals believed whatever he said.
es: The animals believed everything he said.

en: Truth to tell, Jones and all he stood for had almost faded out of their memories.
vi: In fact, they had almost forgotten all about the days of Mr. Jones.
tr: To be honest, what happened during Jones's time had almost entirely faded from their memories.
es: In truth, Jones, and what he represented, had almost faded from their memories.

en: They knew that life nowadays was harsh and bare, that they were often hungry and often cold, and that they were usually working when they were not asleep.
vi: They only knew that life now was very hard, arduous, they were often hungry, cold, and as soon as they opened their eyes, they had to work.
tr: They knew that nowadays they lived a poor and harsh life, often going hungry and freezing from the cold, spending every minute working except for sleeping.
es: They knew that life was hard and harsh, that many times they were hungry and cold, and generally they were working when they were not sleeping.

en: But doubtless it had been worse in the old days.
vi: It must have been even harder before.
tr: But they believed that the old days were even worse and took solace in that.
es: But, without a doubt, it had been worse in the old days.

en: They were glad to believe so.
vi: They were happy to believe this.
tr: But they believed that the old days were even worse and took solace in that.
es: They felt happy to believe it so.

en: Besides, in those days they had been slaves and now they were free, and that made all the difference, as Squealer did not fail to point out.
vi: Moreover, more importantly, they were slaves before, but now they were free, Squealer always emphasized this.
tr: Moreover, as Squealer constantly emphasized, although they were slaves in the past, they were now free; and that was the main difference.
es: Besides, in those days they were slaves and now they were free, and that made a big difference, as Squealer never forgot to point out to them.

en: There were many more mouths to feed now.
vi: The population is increasing day by day.
tr: The number of mouths to feed had also increased.
es: There were many more mouths to feed.

en: In the autumn the four sows had all littered about simultaneously, producing thirty-one young pigs between them.
vi: Last autumn, four sows farrowed at the same time, giving birth to a total of thirty-one piglets.
tr: In the fall, four sows had given birth to a total of thirty-one piglets around the same time.
es: In the autumn, the four sows gave birth simultaneously, nursing a total of thirty-one piglets.

en: The young pigs were piebald, and as Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was possible to guess at their parentage.
vi: All of them were spotted pigs, and since Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was easy to guess whose offspring they were.
tr: Since the only male pig on the farm was Napoleon, it was not hard to guess who the father of the spotted piglets was.
es: The young pigs were spotted, and since Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was not difficult to guess their paternal origin.

en: It was announced that later, when bricks and timber had been purchased, a schoolroom would be built in the farmhouse garden.
vi: The entire farm was informed that bricks and wood were being purchased, and once acquired, a schoolhouse would be built.
tr: It was announced that a classroom would be built in the garden of the farmhouse when bricks and timber were obtained in the future.
es: It was announced that later on, when bricks and wood were purchased, a school would be built in the garden.

en: For the time being, the young pigs were given their instruction by Napoleon himself in the farmhouse kitchen.
vi: In the meantime, the piglets would be taught by Napoleon in the kitchen area.
tr: But for now, Napoleon himself was teaching the young pigs in the kitchen of the farmhouse.
es: Meanwhile, the piglets were educated by Napoleon himself in the house's kitchen.

en: They took their exercise in the garden, and were discouraged from playing with the other young animals.
vi: The piglets were allowed to play in the garden but were forbidden to interact with other species' young.
tr: They would go out to the garden for physical education and walks, but they were not allowed to play with the other animals' offspring.
es: They did their exercises in the garden, and were discouraged from playing with the other young animals.

en: About this time, too, it was laid down as a rule that when a pig and any other animal met on the path, the other animal must stand aside: and also that all pigs, of whatever degree, were to have the privilege of wearing green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.
vi: A new rule was also introduced around this time, stating that everyone must step aside to give way to pigs, and additionally, pigs, regardless of rank, were to wear a green ribbon on their tails on Sundays.
tr: Around that time, new rules were introduced: When a pig and another animal met on the road, the other animal would step aside to let the pig pass, and all pigs would have the privilege of wearing green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.
es: At that time, the rule was also established that when a pig and any other animal met on the path, the latter had to step aside; and likewise, that pigs of any category would have the privilege of adorning themselves with green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.

en: The farm had had a fairly successful year, but was still short of money.
vi: This year has been quite successful, but money is still lacking.
tr: That year, although things were going well on the farm, they were still experiencing financial difficulties.
es: The farm had a fairly prosperous year, but they were still short of money.

en: There were the bricks, sand, and lime for the schoolroom to be purchased, and it would also be necessary to begin saving up again for the machinery for the windmill.
vi: We still have to buy bricks, lime, and sand to build the school; and we also have to save up to buy machinery for the windmill.
tr: They had to buy bricks, sand, and lime for the classroom and save money for the windmill's machinery.
es: They still needed to acquire the bricks, sand, and cement necessary for the school, and it was going to be necessary to save again for the mill machinery.
