en: Then there were lamp oil and candles for the house, sugar for Napoleon’s own table (he forbade this to the other pigs, on the ground that it made them fat), and all the usual replacements such as tools, nails, string, coal, wire, scrap-iron, and dog biscuits.
vi: Then we need to buy oil for lamps, candles, and sugar for Napoleon alone (he forbids the other pigs from eating sugar for fear they will gain weight) and many other things like tools, nails, ropes, coal, wire, roofing sheets, and biscuits for the dogs.
tr: Additionally, they needed to buy kerosene and candles for the house, and sugar for Napoleon's table (he had banned sugar for the other pigs to prevent them from getting fat); tools, nails, string, coal, wire, scrap iron, and dog biscuits were also necessary.
es: Additionally, oil was required for the lamps, candles for the house, sugar for Napoleon's table (he prohibited this for the other pigs, claiming it made them fat), and all the usual supplies like tools, nails, threads, coal, wire, iron, and biscuits for the dogs.

en: A stump of hay and part of the potato crop were sold off, and the contract for eggs was increased to six hundred a week, so that that year the hens barely hatched enough chicks to keep their numbers at the same level.
vi: We have to sell some hay and potatoes, the contract to sell eggs has increased to six hundred eggs per week, so the number of chickens has almost not increased, if not decreased, because the number of eggs they leave for hatching is too few.
tr: Some of the hay and potatoes had been sold; since the number of eggs in the contract had been increased to six hundred per week, the hens had not been able to hatch enough chicks that year.
es: A stack of hay and part of the potato harvest were sold, and the egg sale contract was increased to six hundred per week, so that year the hens barely hatched enough chicks to keep the numbers at the same level.

en: Rations, reduced in December, were reduced again in February, and lanterns in the stalls were forbidden to save oil.
vi: In December, the rations were reduced once, in February they were reduced again, and to save money, from now on, no lights are allowed to be lit in the barns at night.
tr: In February, the rations, which had been reduced in December, were restricted again, and lanterns were banned in the barns to save kerosene.
es: Rations, reduced in December, were decreased again in February, and lanterns in the stalls were banned to save oil.

en: But the pigs seemed comfortable enough, and in fact were putting on weight if anything.
vi: But the pigs seem to be living well, at least each one has gained weight.
tr: But the pigs were comfortable; in fact, it could even be said that they were getting fatter.
es: But the pigs seemed quite comfortable and, in fact, were gaining weight.

en: One afternoon in late February a warm, rich, appetising scent, such as the animals had never smelt before, wafted itself across the yard from the little brew-house, which had been disused in Jones’s time, and which stood beyond the kitchen.
vi: Once, on a February afternoon, a strong fragrance suddenly filled the farmyard, a smell the animals had never encountered before. It turned out the smell came from the house behind the kitchen, which in Jones's time was used for brewing beer, but had been abandoned for a long time.
tr: Towards the end of February, one evening, a warm, delicious, appetizing smell that the animals had never smelled before spread into the yard from the small brewery behind the kitchen, which had never been used during Jones's time.
es: One afternoon, at the end of February, a warm and appetizing aroma, like the animals had never smelled before, reached the yard, carried by the breeze and coming from the little house where beer was brewed in Jones's time, a house that was located beyond the kitchen.

en: Someone said it was the smell of cooking barley.
vi: Someone said it was the smell of brewing barley.
tr: One of the animals said that it was the smell of barley being cooked.
es: Someone said it was the smell of boiling barley.

en: The animals sniffed the air hungrily and wondered whether a warm mash was being prepared for their supper.
vi: The animals sniffed the strong, spicy aroma and tried to guess if they would get to eat the "mash" that night.
tr: The hungry animals, inhaling the smell, couldn't help but wonder if a hot mash was being prepared for dinner.
es: The animals sniffed hungrily and wondered if a hot mash was being prepared for their dinner.

en: But no warm mash appeared, and on the following Sunday it was announced that from now onwards all barley would be reserved for the pigs.
vi: But that night there was no "mash", and on Sunday they were informed that from now on the barley would be reserved exclusively for the pigs.
tr: But far from a hot mash, it was announced the next Sunday that all the barley would be reserved for the pigs.
es: But no hot mash appeared, and the following Sunday it was announced that from that moment all the barley would be reserved for the pigs.

en: The field beyond the orchard had already been sown with barley.
vi: The plot of land next to the garden had already been sown with barley.
tr: Barley had already been planted in the field behind the orchard.
es: The field behind the orchard had already been sown with barley.

en: And the news soon leaked out that every pig was now receiving a ration of a pint of beer daily, with half a gallon for Napoleon himself, which was always served to him in the Crown Derby soup tureen.
vi: Then there was news that from now on each pig would get half a liter of beer a day, while Napoleon would get two liters, and he had to drink it from a crystal goblet.
tr: Soon, a rumor spread: Each pig was now being given half a liter of beer a day, and Napoleon was receiving four liters, drinking his beer from the soup bowl of the Crown Derby set.
es: And soon it was known that all the pigs received a ration of one pint of beer per day, and half a gallon for Napoleon himself, which was always served to him in the soup tureen from the set kept in the glass cabinet.

en: But if there were hardships to be borne, they were partly offset by the fact that life nowadays had a greater dignity than it had had before.
vi: Although there are still many difficulties, life is much more worth living than before.
tr: Although the difficulties never ceased, the animals consoled themselves to some extent by thinking that they now lived much more honorably than before.
es: But although there were no shortages of hardships to endure, they were partly compensated by the fact that life had greater dignity than before.

en: There were more songs, more speeches, more processions.
vi: Never before have they been able to sing, listen to talks, attend rallies, and protest as much as they do now.
tr: More songs were sung, more speeches were made, and more ceremonies were held.
es: There were more songs, more speeches, more parades.

en: Napoleon had commanded that once a week there should be held something called a Spontaneous Demonstration, the object of which was to celebrate the struggles and triumphs of Animal Farm.
vi: Napoleon ordered that there must be a Parade every week, which he called Spontaneous, with the purpose of praising the struggle and achievements of Animal Farm.
tr: Napoleon had ordered Spontaneous Demonstrations to be held once a week to celebrate the struggles and victories achieved on Animal Farm.
es: Napoleon ordered that once a week something called a Spontaneous Demonstration be held, the purpose of which was to celebrate the struggles and triumphs of "Animal Farm."

en: At the appointed time the animals would leave their work and march round the precincts of the farm in military formation, with the pigs leading, then the horses, then the cows, then the sheep, and then the poultry.
vi: At the designated time, everyone would immediately leave their work, form ranks, starting with the pigs, followed by the horses, cows, sheep, and finally the chickens and ducks, and march around the farm.
tr: At the designated time, the animals would stop working and march around the farm in military formation: pigs at the front, followed by horses, then cows, sheep, and finally poultry at the back...
es: At the appointed time, the animals would abandon their tasks and march around the farm's boundaries in military formation, with the pigs at the head, followed by the horses, cows, sheep, and then the birds.

en: The dogs flanked the procession and at the head of all marched Napoleon’s black cockerel.
vi: Napoleon's black rooster always led the way, while the dogs flanked the parade.
tr: The dogs would walk on either side of the parade, and Napoleon's black rooster would lead the way.
es: The dogs marched on the sides and at the very front, Napoleon's black rooster.

en: Boxer and Clover always carried between them a green banner marked with the hoof and the horn and the caption, “Long live Comrade Napoleon!”
vi: Warrior and Fat Lady carried the green flag with the horn and hoof emblem and the slogan "Long live Comrade Napoleon."
tr: Boxer and Clover always carried a flag bearing the image of a hoof and horn, with the words "Long live Comrade Napoleon!"
es: Boxer and Clover always carried a green flag marked with the hoof and horn and the slogan: "Long live Comrade Napoleon!"

en: Afterwards there were recitations of poems composed in Napoleon’s honour, and a speech by Squealer giving particulars of the latest increases in the production of foodstuffs, and on occasion a shot was fired from the gun.
vi: The rallies always ended with the recitation of a poem praising Napoleon and a report from the Pointer on the achievements in production increases over the past period; celebrations often included gun salutes as well.
tr: Afterwards, poems written in honor of Napoleon were read, followed by Squealer giving a speech detailing the latest increases in food production, and occasionally a gun would be fired.
es: Then came recitals of poems composed in honor of Napoleon and a speech by Squealer giving details of the latest increases in food production, and on some occasions, a shotgun would be fired.

en: The sheep were the greatest devotees of the Spontaneous Demonstration, and if anyone complained (as a few animals sometimes did, when no pigs or dogs were near) that they wasted time and meant a lot of standing about in the cold, the sheep were sure to silence him with a tremendous bleating of “Four legs good, two legs bad!”
vi: The sheep particularly enjoyed the parades, and if any of them complained (especially when the dogs and pigs were absent) that the parades were just cold and a waste of time, they would immediately chant their eternal prayer: "Four legs good, two legs bad," so loudly that it drowned out all (even any) complaints and grumbles.
tr: The greatest enthusiasts of the Spontaneous Demonstrations were the sheep; if any animal tried to complain that they were wasting time and doing nothing but standing in the cold (some animals did indeed complain when the pigs and dogs were not around), the sheep would immediately silence them by bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at the top of their lungs.
es: The sheep were the most enthusiastic about the Spontaneous Demonstrations, and if anyone complained (as some animals did sometimes when there were no pigs or dogs around) saying that it was a waste of time and involved standing around in the open for a long time, the sheep would invariably silence them with a loud: "Four legs good, two legs bad!"

en: But by and large the animals enjoyed these celebrations.
vi: But generally, the majority liked such ceremonies.
tr: But generally, the animals enjoyed these ceremonies.
es: But, in the end, the animals liked these celebrations.

en: They found it comforting to be reminded that, after all, they were truly their own masters and that the work they did was for their own benefit.
vi: They felt somewhat comforted because such gatherings reminded them that they were truly the owners of the farm and everything they did was for themselves alone.
tr: After all, the reminder that they were their own masters and worked only for their own benefit was heartening.
es: It was satisfying to remember that, after all, they were really their own masters and that all the work they did was for the common benefit.

en: So that, what with the songs, the processions, Squealer’s lists of figures, the thunder of the gun, the crowing of the cockerel, and the fluttering of the flag, they were able to forget that their bellies were empty, at least part of the time.
vi: The songs, the parades, the Pointer's statistics, the gun salutes, the rooster's crowing, and the flag fluttering in the wind helped them forget, even if just for a moment, the gnawing hunger that tormented them.
tr: Thus, with the songs, parades, Squealer's statistics, the gun's roar, the rooster's crowing, and the flag's fluttering, they could occasionally forget their hunger.
es: And so, with the songs, the parades, Squealer's lists of figures, the thunder of the shotgun, the rooster's crowing, and the waving of the flag, they could forget for a while that their bellies were almost empty.

en: In April, Animal Farm was proclaimed a Republic, and it became necessary to elect a President.
vi: In April, Animal Farm declared itself a Republic, necessitating the election of a President.
tr: In April, a Republic was declared at Animal Farm. It was necessary to elect a president.
es: In April, "Animal Farm" was proclaimed a Republic, and it became necessary to elect a President.

en: There was only one candidate, Napoleon, who was elected unanimously.
vi: There was only one candidate. Napoleon was elected with one hundred percent of the vote.
tr: Napoleon, the only candidate, was unanimously elected president.
es: There was only one candidate: Napoleon, who was unanimously elected.

en: On the same day it was given out that fresh documents had been discovered which revealed further details about Snowball’s complicity with Jones.
vi: That very day, news came that new documents had been found proving that Snowball had been collaborating with Mr. Jones from the beginning.
tr: On the same day, it was announced that new documents had been found revealing detailed information about Snowball being an accomplice of Jones.
es: The same day it was revealed that new documents had been discovered giving more details regarding Snowball's complicity with Jones.

en: It now appeared that Snowball had not, as the animals had previously imagined, merely attempted to lose the Battle of the Cowshed by means of a stratagem, but had been openly fighting on Jones’s side.
vi: It turned out that Snowball not only used clever tactics to sabotage the Battle of the Cowshed, as previously thought, but had also fully sided with Mr. Jones.
tr: The documents showed that Snowball not only resorted to war tricks to lose the Battle of the Cowshed, as the animals initially thought, but also openly It revealed that he fought on Jones's side.
es: According to them, it seemed that Snowball not only tried to lose the "Battle of the Cowshed" through a stratagem, as the animals had supposed, but he was openly fighting in favor of Jones.

en: In fact, it was he who had actually been the leader of the human forces, and had charged into battle with the words “Long live Humanity!” on his lips.
vi: Snowball had led the human invasion, shouting loudly: "Long live humanity!".
tr: Moreover, he had taken command of the Human forces and launched an attack, shouting "Long live Humanity!"
es: In fact, it was he who led the human forces and charged into battle with the words "Long live Humanity!".

en: The wounds on Snowball’s back, which a few of the animals still remembered to have seen, had been inflicted by Napoleon’s teeth.
vi: As for the wounds on his back, some animals still alive had seen those wounds and remembered clearly that they were indeed Napoleon's bite marks.
tr: Those who remembered seeing the wounds on Snowball's back with their own eyes were learning something entirely new: It turned out that Napoleon had inflicted those wounds with his teeth.
es: The wounds on Snowball's back, which several animals still remembered seeing, were inflicted by Napoleon's teeth.

en: In the middle of the summer Moses the raven suddenly reappeared on the farm, after an absence of several years.
vi: After many years of absence, Moses suddenly reappeared in the middle of last summer.
tr: The raven Moses, who had not been seen for years, suddenly returned to the farm in the middle of summer.
es: In the middle of summer, Moses, the raven, suddenly reappeared on the farm after an absence of several years.

en: He was quite unchanged, still did no work, and talked in the same strain as ever about Sugarcandy Mountain.
vi: He had hardly changed, still refusing to do anything and spending all day telling fanciful stories about Sugarcandy Mountain.
tr: He had hardly changed; he did not lift a finger, and as before, he kept telling tales of the Sugarcandy Mountain.
es: He hadn't changed at all; he still did no work and spoke the same as always about Sugar Mountain.

en: He would perch on a stump, flap his black wings, and talk by the hour to anyone who would listen.
vi: He often perched on a tree branch, flapping his black wings and talking for hours on end, as long as there was someone willing to listen.
tr: He perched on a stump, flapped his black wings, and if he found someone to listen, he would talk for hours.
es: He would often perch on a post, flap his black wings, and talk for hours to anyone who would listen.

en: “Up there, comrades,” he would say solemnly, pointing to the sky with his large beak —“up there, just on the other side of that dark cloud that you can see — there it lies, Sugarcandy Mountain, that happy country where we poor animals shall rest for ever from our labours!”
vi: "Up there, comrades," It said while pointing its beak towards the sky, "above those black clouds is Mount Rice, where we, the wretched animals, will rest forever."
tr: Pointing to the sky with his big beak, he would say in a very serious voice, "It's there, comrades." "Sugarcandy Mountain, the land where we poor animals shall be free from all our troubles and live in peace forever, is there, just behind that black cloud you see!"
es: “Up there, comrades,” he would say, solemnly pointing to the sky with his long beak, “up there, just behind that dark cloud you can see, lies Sugar Mountain, that happy land where we poor animals will rest forever from our labors.”

en: He even claimed to have been there on one of his higher flights, and to have seen the everlasting fields of clover and the linseed cake and lump sugar growing on the hedges.
vi: It also said that it had once flown there, had seen clover fields lush all year round, and had seen gardens full of flaxseed cakes and sugar cubes.
tr: Moreover, he claimed that one day, while flying very high, he had passed by it and seen with his own eyes the clover fields stretching as far as the eye could see, and the hedges covered with linseed cakes and lumps of sugar.
es: He even claimed to have been there on one of his high flights and to have seen the perennial fields of clover and the linseed cake and sugar lumps growing in the hedges.

en: Many of the animals believed him.
vi: Yet there were many hostages.
tr: Many of the animals believed him.
es: Many of the animals believed him.

en: Their lives now, they reasoned, were hungry and laborious; was it not right and just that a better world should exist somewhere else?
vi: They thought they were starving, suffering, and struggling; so the idea of a more peaceful world somewhere else seemed only fair.
tr: They lived in hunger and deprivation in this world; what could be more true or understandable than the existence of a better world elsewhere?
es: Nowadays, they reasoned, their lives were nothing but hunger and work; wasn't it right and just, then, that a better world should exist somewhere?

en: A thing that was difficult to determine was the attitude of the pigs towards Moses.
vi: But what they couldn't understand was the pigs' attitude towards Moses.
tr: The real puzzle was the pigs' attitude towards Moses.
es: One difficult thing to determine was the pigs' attitude towards Moses.

en: They all declared contemptuously that his stories about Sugarcandy Mountain were lies, and yet they allowed him to remain on the farm, not working, with an allowance of a gill of beer a day.
vi: The pigs scorned the idea that Sugar Mountain was just a fabrication, but Moses was not only not driven away but was also given a pint of beer each day.
tr: They both ridiculed him, saying that his tales of Sugarcandy Mountain were lies, and yet they allowed him to stay on the farm without working, even letting him drink beer every day.
es: They all disdainfully declared that his tales about Sugar Mountain were lies, yet they allowed him to stay on the farm without working, with a small ration of beer per day.

en: After his hoof had healed up, Boxer worked harder than ever.
vi: Finally, Warrior's hoof healed, and it threw itself into work more enthusiastically than ever.
tr: After Boxer’s leg healed, he began to work harder than ever.
es: After his hoof was healed, Boxer worked harder than ever.

en: Indeed, all the animals worked like slaves that year.
vi: The other animals also had to work no differently than hard labor prisoners.
tr: In fact, that year, all the animals were working like slaves.
es: Indeed, all the animals worked like slaves that year.

en: Apart from the regular work of the farm, and the rebuilding of the windmill, there was the schoolhouse for the young pigs, which was started in March.
vi: Besides the regular farm tasks and restoring the windmill, there was also the job of building a school for the piglets. The school construction began in March.
tr: Besides the daily farm work and the rebuilding of the windmill, a classroom for the young pigs had also begun to be built in March.
es: Apart from the usual farm chores and the rebuilding of the windmill, there was the school for the piglets, which began in March.

en: Sometimes the long hours on insufficient food were hard to bear, but Boxer never faltered.
vi: Sometimes it seemed impossible to endure the time and intensity of the labor with an empty stomach, but Warrior never lost heart.
tr: Eating less and working more was unbearable, but Boxer never gave up.
es: Sometimes, the long hours of work with insufficient food were hard to endure, but Boxer never wavered.

en: In nothing that he said or did was there any sign that his strength was not what it had been.
vi: There was no sign, either in words or actions, that its strength was not what it used to be.
tr: It was impossible to tell from his speech or his work that he was no longer as strong as he used to be.
es: In nothing he said or did was there any sign that his strength was no longer what it used to be.

en: It was only his appearance that was a little altered; his hide was less shiny than it had used to be, and his great haunches seemed to have shrunken.
vi: However, its appearance had changed a bit; its skin was no longer as glossy, and its hips looked smaller.
tr: Only his appearance had changed a bit; his coat was no longer as shiny, and his massive haunches had sunken in.
es: Only his appearance had changed a little. His coat was less shiny and his haunches seemed to have shrunken.

en: The others said, “Boxer will pick up when the spring grass comes on”; but the spring came and Boxer grew no fatter.
vi: Everyone said, "With fresh grass, Warrior will recover immediately," but spring had come, the grass was green, and Warrior hadn't gained any weight.
tr: Everyone was saying, "Once the spring grass grows, Boxer will recover." The spring grass grew, but Boxer did not recover.
es: The others said that Boxer would recover when the spring grass appeared; but spring came and Boxer did not gain weight.

en: Sometimes on the slope leading to the top of the quarry, when he braced his muscles against the weight of some vast boulder, it seemed that nothing kept him on his feet except the will to continue.
vi: When watching it strain to pull stones up the slope, it seemed as if its strength was exhausted, and only a steely will kept it standing.
tr: Sometimes, on the slope leading to the quarry, when his muscles trembled under a large piece of rock, the only thing keeping him standing was his determination.
es: Sometimes, on the slope leading to the top of the quarry, when he strained his tense muscles under the weight of some huge stone, it seemed that nothing kept him standing except his will to continue.

en: At such times his lips were seen to form the words, “I will work harder”; he had no voice left.
vi: Looking at its lips, a keen observer could see it was trying to say, "I will try harder," but it couldn't utter the words.
tr: In such situations, despite having completely lost his voice, the words "I will work harder" could be read from his lips.
es: At these moments, one could guess that his lips were forming the words: "I will work harder" because he had no voice left.

en: Once again Clover and Benjamin warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer paid no attention.
vi: Mrs. Fat and Benjamin reminded it to take care of its health, but it ignored them.
tr: Clover and Benjamin constantly warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer did not listen.
es: Again Clover and Benjamin warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer paid no attention.

en: His twelfth birthday was approaching.
vi: Its twelfth birthday was approaching.
tr: His twelfth birthday was approaching.
es: His twelfth birthday was approaching.

en: He did not care what happened so long as a good store of stone was accumulated before he went on pension.
vi: It only cared about one thing: gathering as many stones as possible before retiring, and whatever happened after that didn't matter.
tr: He did not care about his health; his only wish was to gather enough stones for the windmill before he retired.
es: He did not care what happened, as long as a good amount of stone had been accumulated before he retired.

en: Late one evening in the summer, a sudden rumour ran round the farm that something had happened to Boxer.
vi: One night, when it was already quite late, there was suddenly news that Chiến Sĩ had met with an accident.
tr: One summer evening, a rumor suddenly spread on the farm: Something had happened to Boxer.
es: One summer day, at dusk, the rumor quickly spread across the farm that something had happened to Boxer.

en: He had gone out alone to drag a load of stone down to the windmill.
vi: It turned out that he had gone to pull the stone cart alone.
tr: He had tried to carry a load of stones for the windmill all by himself.
es: He had gone alone to drag a pile of stones to the mill.

en: And sure enough, the rumour was true.
vi: It was no longer a rumor, it was the truth; a few minutes later, two pigeons flew back.
tr: The rumor was undoubtedly true.
es: And, indeed, the rumor was true.

en: A few minutes later two pigeons came racing in with the news; “Boxer has fallen!
vi: "The Warrior has fallen!
tr: Soon after, two pigeons hurriedly brought the news: "Boxer has collapsed!
es: A few minutes later, two pigeons came flying in with the news: "Boxer has fallen!

en: He is lying on his side and can’t get up!”
vi: It fell and is lying on its side, it can't get up anymore!", the two pigeons reported.
tr: He can't get up!"
es: He is lying on his side and cannot get up!"

en: About half the animals on the farm rushed out to the knoll where the windmill stood.
vi: Almost half of the animals on the farm rushed towards the mound.
tr: Almost half of the animals on the farm ran to the small hill where the windmill was located.
es: Approximately half of the farm animals ran towards the hill where the windmill was.

en: There lay Boxer, between the shafts of the cart, his neck stretched out, unable even to raise his head.
vi: Warrior lay there, between the two cart shafts, his neck stretched out, but too weak to lift his head.
tr: Boxer was there, lying between the shafts of the cart, stretching his neck, unable to even lift his head.
es: There lay Boxer, between the shafts of the cart, his neck stretched out, unable to lift his head.

en: His eyes were glazed, his sides matted with sweat.
vi: His back was drenched in sweat, and his eyes looked wild.
tr: His eyes were glassy, and his body was drenched in sweat from head to toe.
es: His eyes were glassy, and his flanks were covered in sweat.

en: A thin stream of blood had trickled out of his mouth.
vi: A small stream of blood was oozing from his mouth.
tr: A thin stream of blood was oozing from his mouth.
es: A trickle of blood was coming out of his mouth.

en: Clover dropped to her knees at his side.
vi: Fat Lady knelt down beside him.
tr: Clover knelt down beside him.
es: Clover fell to her knees beside him.

en: “Boxer!” she cried, “how are you?”
vi: "Warrior!", it asked, "What happened to you?"
tr: "Boxer!" he shouted. "What happened to you?"
es: —Boxer! —he shouted—, how are you?

en: “It is my lung,” said Boxer in a weak voice.
vi: "I can't breathe anymore," Soldier whispered, "But it's okay.
tr: Boxer, in a barely audible voice, said, "My lungs gave out."
es: —It's my lung —said Boxer weakly—.

en: “It does not matter.
vi: "I can't breathe anymore," Soldier whispered, "But it's okay.
tr: "No matter.
es: It doesn't matter.

en: I think you will be able to finish the windmill without me.
vi: I think you all will be able to rebuild the windmill.
tr: You can finish the windmill without me."
es: I believe they can finish the windmill without me.

en: There is a pretty good store of stone accumulated.
vi: There are plenty of stones already.
tr: A lot of stones have been collected.
es: There is a good amount of stone accumulated.

en: I had only another month to go in any case.
vi: Anyway, it's only one more month until I retire.
tr: And I only had a month left.
es: Anyway, I only had one more month left.

en: To tell you the truth, I had been looking forward to my retirement.
vi: To be honest, I'm really looking forward to retirement.
tr: Honestly, I was eagerly looking forward to my retirement.
es: To tell the truth, I was looking forward to retirement.

en: And perhaps, as Benjamin is growing old too, they will let him retire at the same time and be a companion to me.”
vi: Benjamin is old too, if he could retire at the same time as me to keep me company, that would be wonderful."
tr: Benjamin has aged too; maybe they'll retire him as well, and he can keep me company."
es: And since Benjamin is also getting old, maybe they'll let him retire at the same time, and he could keep me company.

en: “We must get help at once,” said Clover.
vi: "Go inform Chỉ Điểm immediately," Mrs. Mập said.
tr: Clover said, "We must ask for help immediately." "Run, inform Squealer.""
es: —We must get help immediately —demanded Clover—.

en: “Run, somebody, and tell Squealer what has happened.”
vi: "Go inform Chỉ Điểm immediately," Mrs. Mập said.
tr: The animals all ran together to the farmhouse to tell Squealer what had happened.
es: Someone should run to inform Squealer about what has happened.

en: All the other animals immediately raced back to the farmhouse to give Squealer the news.
vi: Everyone immediately ran to the main house to find Chỉ Điểm.
tr: The animals all ran together to the farmhouse to tell Squealer what had happened.
es: All the animals immediately ran towards the house to give the news to Squealer.

en: Only Clover remained, and Benjamin who lay down at Boxer’s side, and, without speaking, kept the flies off him with his long tail.
vi: Only Bà Mập and Benjamin stayed behind. Benjamin quietly lay down next to Chiến Sĩ and used his tail to swat flies away from him.
tr: Only Clover and Benjamin stayed behind; Benjamin lay down beside Boxer, swatting flies away with his long tail.
es: Only Clover and Benjamin stayed, who lay down next to Boxer and, without saying a word, shooed away the flies with his long tail.

en: After about a quarter of an hour Squealer appeared, full of sympathy and concern.
vi: About fifteen minutes later, Chỉ Điểm arrived, his face showing full of sympathy and eagerness.
tr: About fifteen minutes later, Squealer appeared; he looked sad and worried.
es: A quarter of an hour later, Squealer appeared, alarmed and full of interest.

en: He said that Comrade Napoleon had learned with the very deepest distress of this misfortune to one of the most loyal workers on the farm, and was already making arrangements to send Boxer to be treated in the hospital at Willingdon.
vi: He said that comrade Napoleon was very sad to hear that an accident had happened to one of the farm's most loyal workers and was arranging to take Chiến Sĩ to be treated at the hospital in Willingdon.
tr: He said that Comrade Napoleon had learned with great sorrow what had happened to one of the farm's most loyal workers and was trying to arrange for Boxer to be sent to the hospital in Willingdon for treatment.
es: He said that comrade Napoleon, greatly distressed by the misfortune that had befallen one of the farm's most loyal workers, was making arrangements to send Boxer to a hospital in Willingdon for treatment.

en: The animals felt a little uneasy at this.
vi: But the animals felt uneasy because, until now, apart from Mollie and Tuyết Tròn, no one had ever left the farm, and they also didn't like the idea of handing over a sick comrade to humans.
tr: The animals felt a bit uneasy.
es: The animals felt a bit uneasy upon hearing this.

en: Except for Mollie and Snowball, no other animal had ever left the farm, and they did not like to think of their sick comrade in the hands of human beings.
vi: But the animals felt uneasy because, until now, apart from Mollie and Tuyết Tròn, no one had ever left the farm, and they also didn't like the idea of handing over a sick comrade to humans.
tr: Until that day, no animal except Mollie and Snowball had ever left the farm; they did not like the idea of their sick comrade being handed over to humans.
es: Except for Mollie and Snowball, no other animal had ever left the farm, and they did not like the idea of leaving their sick comrade in the hands of human beings.

en: However, Squealer easily convinced them that the veterinary surgeon in Willingdon could treat Boxer’s case more satisfactorily than could be done on the farm.
vi: However, Chỉ Điểm easily convinced them that the veterinarians in Willingdon would treat Chiến Sĩ better than just letting him lie in the farm.
tr: But Squealer did not delay in calming them down: the veterinarian in Willingdon could treat Boxer much better.
es: However, Squealer easily convinced them that the veterinarian in Willingdon could treat Boxer's case more satisfactorily than on the farm.

en: And about half an hour later, when Boxer had somewhat recovered, he was with difficulty got on to his feet, and managed to limp back to his stall, where Clover and Benjamin had prepared a good bed of straw for him.
vi: About half an hour later, Chiến Sĩ managed to stand up and slowly made his way back to the barn. Bà Mập and Benjamin spread straw to make him a rather thick bed.
tr: About half an hour later, Boxer recovered a bit and got up with difficulty; he hobbled to his stall and lay down on the straw bed that Clover and Benjamin had prepared.
es: And half an hour later, when Boxer recovered a little, they laboriously lifted him, and thus he managed to limp back to his stable where Clover and Benjamin had quickly prepared a very large and comfortable straw bed for him.

en: For the next two days Boxer remained in his stall.
vi: The Warrior lay in the pen for two consecutive days.
tr: Boxer stayed in his stable for two days.
es: During the following two days, Boxer remained in his stable.

en: The pigs had sent out a large bottle of pink medicine which they had found in the medicine chest in the bathroom, and Clover administered it to Boxer twice a day after meals.
vi: The pigs found a rather large bottle of pink medicine in the medicine cabinet in the bathroom and brought it to him. Mrs. Fat made him take it twice a day, right after meals.
tr: The pigs had sent a large medicine bottle they found in the bathroom medicine cabinet. Clover was giving Boxer the pink medicine from the bottle twice a day after meals.
es: The pigs had sent a large bottle of the pink medicine they found in the bathroom cabinet, and Clover administered it to Boxer twice a day after meals.

en: In the evenings she lay in his stall and talked to him, while Benjamin kept the flies off him.
vi: In the evening, Mrs. Fat went into the Warrior's pen to chat, while Benjamin shooed away the flies for him.
tr: In the evenings, Clover stayed in Boxer's stable and talked with him, while Benjamin shooed away the flies.
es: In the afternoons, she stayed in the stable talking with him, while Benjamin shooed away the flies.

en: Boxer professed not to be sorry for what had happened.
vi: The Warrior said he had nothing to complain about.
tr: Boxer said he was not upset about what had happened to him.
es: Boxer stated that he did not regret what had happened.

en: If he made a good recovery, he might expect to live another three years, and he looked forward to the peaceful days that he would spend in the corner of the big pasture.
vi: If he recovered this time, he could live for another three years, and he hoped to spend his remaining peaceful days in the corner of the large meadow reserved for retirees.
tr: If he could recover, he could live at least three more years and spend peaceful days in a corner of the large pasture.
es: If he recovered, he could live for about three more years, and he thought about the peaceful days he would spend in the corner of the large meadow.

en: It would be the first time that he had had leisure to study and improve his mind.
vi: He would devote all his free time to studying and improving his skills.
tr: Perhaps for the first time in his life, he would be able to take time to read and learn something.
es: It would be the first time he would have free time to study and improve himself.

en: He intended, he said, to devote the rest of his life to learning the remaining twenty-two letters of the alphabet.
vi: He said he would spend the rest of his life learning to master the twenty-two letters of the alphabet.
tr: He was thinking of dedicating his final years to learning the entire alphabet.
es: He intended, he said, to dedicate the rest of his life to learning the remaining twenty-two letters of the alphabet.

en: However, Benjamin and Clover could only be with Boxer after working hours, and it was in the middle of the day when the van came to take him away.
vi: Benjamin and Mrs. Fat could only take care of Warrior after working hours, yet the vehicle to take him away appeared around noon.
tr: However, Benjamin and Clover could only look after Boxer after working hours. When a covered cart came to take Boxer away, it was noon.
es: However, Benjamin and Clover could only be with Boxer after working hours, and at noon a van arrived to take him away.

en: The animals were all at work weeding turnips under the supervision of a pig, when they were astonished to see Benjamin come galloping from the direction of the farm buildings, braying at the top of his voice.
vi: The pigs were commanding the group to sow mustard seeds in the field when suddenly they saw Benjamin galloping from the farm, shouting until his voice was hoarse.
tr: The animals, who were weeding the turnip field under the supervision of a pig, were very surprised to see Benjamin galloping from the direction of the farm buildings, braying at the top of his lungs.
es: The animals were working under the supervision of a pig, weeding the turnips, when they were surprised to see Benjamin coming at a gallop from the house, braying with all his might.

en: It was the first time that they had ever seen Benjamin excited — indeed, it was the first time that anyone had ever seen him gallop.
vi: This was the first time they had seen Benjamin so emotional, and also the first time they had seen him gallop.
tr: They were seeing Benjamin agitated for the first time in their lives; in fact, no one had ever seen him gallop until that day.
es: They had never seen Benjamin so excited; indeed, it was the first time anyone had seen him gallop.

en: “Quick, quick!” he shouted.
vi: "Hurry up!
tr: "Quick! Quick!" shouted Benjamin.
es: “Quick, quick! —he shouted—.

en: “Come at once!
vi: Hurry up!", he screamed, "Come here quickly!
tr: "Come at once!
es: Come at once!

en: They’re taking Boxer away!”
vi: They have taken the Warrior away!"
tr: They're taking Boxer away!"
es: They're taking Boxer away!”

en: Without waiting for orders from the pig, the animals broke off work and raced back to the farm buildings.
vi: The whole group immediately dropped what they were doing and ran towards the main house, not waiting for the pigs' permission.
tr: The animals, disregarding the pig, left their work and ran towards the farm buildings.
es: Without waiting for orders from the pig, the animals abandoned their work and ran towards the farm buildings.

en: Sure enough, there in the yard was a large closed van, drawn by two horses, with lettering on its side and a sly-looking man in a low-crowned bowler hat sitting on the driver’s seat.
vi: Indeed, in the yard, there was a closed two-horse carriage, with large letters written on its side, and the coachman wore a fedora that made him look quite cunning.
tr: Indeed, in the yard, there was a large covered cart with two horses. On the side of the cart, there was a writing, and on the driver's seat sat a man with a bowler hat and a devilish look.
es: Indeed, in the yard there was a large closed van, with signs on the sides, pulled by two horses, and a sly-looking man wearing a crushed bowler hat on the driver's seat.

en: And Boxer’s stall was empty.
vi: Warrior was no longer in the pen.
tr: Boxer's stall was empty.
es: Boxer's stall was empty.

en: The animals crowded round the van.
vi: The animals gathered around the vehicle.
tr: The animals had surrounded the car and were all shouting together, "Goodbye, Boxer!" "Safe travels!"
es: The animals crowded around the cart.

en: “Good-bye, Boxer!” they chorused, “good-bye!”
vi: "Travel safely, Warrior!", They shouted in unison, "Goodbye!"
tr: The animals had surrounded the car and were all shouting together, "Goodbye, Boxer!" "Safe travels!"
es: —Goodbye, Boxer! —they shouted in unison—, goodbye! —Idiots!

en: “Fools! Fools!” shouted Benjamin, prancing round them and stamping the earth with his small hoofs.
vi: "Stupid, so stupid," Benjamin screamed while running around, his feet thudding on the ground, "Stupid, can't you see any letters?"
tr: But Benjamin was leaping around them and stamping the earth with his small hoofs.
es: Idiots! —exclaimed Benjamin, jumping around them and kicking the ground with his small hooves—.

en: “Fools!
vi: "Stupid, so stupid," Benjamin screamed while running around, his feet thudding on the ground, "Stupid, can't you see any letters?"
tr: "Fools! Fools!" he shouted.
es: Idiots!

en: Do you not see what is written on the side of that van?”
vi: "Stupid, so stupid," Benjamin screamed while running around, his feet thudding on the ground, "Stupid, can't you see any letters?"
tr: "Do you not see what is written on the side of that van? Do you not see what they are doing?"
es: Don't you see what is written on the signs of that van?

en: That gave the animals pause, and there was a hush.
vi: The whole group seemed to awaken, silently looking at each other.
tr: The animals who heard Benjamin paused; a silence enveloped the surroundings.
es: That pacified the animals, and silence fell.

en: Muriel began to spell out the words.
vi: The donkey Muriel began to spell out, but Benjamin pushed her aside and read:
tr: Muriel was trying to decipher the writing.
es: Muriel began to spell out the words.

en: But Benjamin pushed her aside and in the midst of a deadly silence he read:
vi: The donkey Muriel began to spell out, but Benjamin pushed her aside and read:
tr: Benjamin pushed her aside and read the writing in the midst of the deathly silence:
es: But Benjamin pushed her aside and, in the midst of a sepulchral silence, read:

en: “‘Alfred Simmonds, Horse Slaughterer and Glue Boiler, Willingdon.
vi: "Alfred Simmond's slaughterhouse, Willingdon.
tr: "Alfred Simmonds, Horse Slaughterer and Glue Boiler, Willingdon.
es: —"Alfredo Simmonds, horse slaughterer and glue manufacturer, Willingdon.

en: Dealer in Hides and Bone-Meal.
vi: Buying and selling meat, bones, horse hides.
tr: Dealer in Hides and Bone-Meal.
es: Dealer in hides and bone meal.

en: Kennels Supplied.’
vi: Providing dog kennels.
tr: Dog Kennels Supplied.
es: Supplies kennels."

en: Do you not understand what that means?
vi: Do you understand?
tr: Do you understand now?
es: Don't you understand what that means?

en: They are taking Boxer to the knacker’s!”
vi: They are taking Warrior to be slaughtered!"
tr: They're taking Boxer to the horse slaughterer, they're going to make dog food out of him!"
es: They're taking him to the knacker!

en: A cry of horror burst from all the animals.
vi: A terrifying scream erupted from every chest.
tr: The animals screamed in terror.
es: The animals let out a cry of horror.

en: At this moment the man on the box whipped up his horses and the van moved out of the yard at a smart trot.
vi: At that moment, the coachman cracked his whip, and the two horses began to trot. The carriage slowly moved out of the yard.
tr: At that moment, the man sitting in the driver's seat whipped the horses, and the carriage, pulled by the trotting horses, exited the courtyard.
es: At that moment, the driver whipped the horses and the van left the yard at a light trot.

en: All the animals followed, crying out at the tops of their voices.
vi: The whole group ran after it, crying like a storm.
tr: All the animals, making a tremendous noise, followed behind the carriage.
es: All the animals followed it, shouting.

en: Clover forced her way to the front.
vi: Fat Lady rushed forward.
tr: Clover was leading the way with all her might.
es: Clover moved forward.

en: The van began to gather speed.
vi: The carriage also sped up.
tr: The carriage began to speed up.
es: The van began to pick up speed.

en: Clover tried to stir her stout limbs to a gallop, and achieved a canter.
vi: Fat Lady tried to leap forward, but she was exhausted and couldn't keep up with the other two.
tr: Although Clover tried to break into a gallop with her strong legs, she could only manage a canter.
es: Clover tried to gallop, but her heavy hooves only managed a half-gallop.

en: “Boxer!” she cried.
vi: "Warrior!", he screamed, "Warrior! Warrior!
tr: "Boxer!" she was shouting.
es: —Boxer! —she shouted—.

en: “Boxer! Boxer! Boxer!”
vi: Warrior!"
tr: "Boxer! Boxer! Boxer!"
es: Boxer! Boxer!

en: And just at this moment, as though he had heard the uproar outside, Boxer’s face, with the white stripe down his nose, appeared at the small window at the back of the van.
vi: It is unknown whether Chiến Sĩ heard the call from outside or not, but its snout with a white streak running along its nose was peeking inside the small window at the back of the vehicle.
tr: Just then, as if he had heard the commotion outside, Boxer's face appeared in the small window at the back of the carriage.
es: At that moment, as if he had heard the commotion, Boxer's face, with the white stripe on his muzzle, appeared in the rear window of the cart.

en: “Boxer!” cried Clover in a terrible voice.
vi: "Warrior!", Mrs. Fat shouted until her voice was hoarse, "Run! Run!
tr: Clover cried out, "Boxer!" in a heart-wrenching voice.
es: —Boxer! —shouted Clover in a terrible voice—.

en: “Boxer!
vi: "Warrior!", Mrs. Fat shouted until her voice was hoarse, "Run! Run!
tr: "Boxer!
es: Boxer!

en: Get out!
vi: Run quickly!
tr: Get out of there!
es: Get out of there!

en: Get out quickly!
vi: Run quickly!
tr: Get out quickly!
es: Get out quickly!

en: They’re taking you to your death!”
vi: They will kill you!"
tr: They're taking you to be slaughtered!"
es: They are taking you to your death!

en: All the animals took up the cry of “Get out, Boxer, get out!”
vi: Everyone shouted in unison: "Run, Warrior, Run!"
tr: The animals were also shouting, "Get out of there, Boxer! Throw yourself out!"
es: All the animals began to shout:

en: But the van was already gathering speed and drawing away from them.
vi: But the two horses had increased their speed, and the cart was getting farther away.
tr: But the cart had picked up speed and was getting farther away.
es: “Get out of there, Boxer, get out of there!” but the van had already picked up speed and was moving away from them.

en: It was uncertain whether Boxer had understood what Clover had said.
vi: It was unclear whether Chiến Sĩ had heard what Bà Mập said or not, but his muzzle was no longer visible inside the window, and at the same time, one could hear his paws hitting the side of the cart rhythmically and loudly, much like the sound of a drum.
tr: It was unclear whether Boxer understood what Clover was saying.
es: It was not known if Boxer understood what Clover said.

en: But a moment later his face disappeared from the window and there was the sound of a tremendous drumming of hoofs inside the van.
vi: It was unclear whether Chiến Sĩ had heard what Bà Mập said or not, but his muzzle was no longer visible inside the window, and at the same time, one could hear his paws hitting the side of the cart rhythmically and loudly, much like the sound of a drum.
tr: But soon his face disappeared from the window, and terrible thumping sounds were heard from inside the cart.
es: But a moment later, his face disappeared from the window and the sound of hooves kicking was heard inside the van.

en: He was trying to kick his way out.
vi: That was Chiến Sĩ kicking the side of the cart to find a way out.
tr: He was trying to kick open the door.
es: He was trying to kick his way out.

en: The time had been when a few kicks from Boxer’s hoofs would have smashed the van to matchwood.
vi: In the past, just a few kicks like that would have been enough to turn this cart into firewood.
tr: In the past, he would have shattered the cart door with a few kicks.
es: In earlier times, a few kicks from Boxer’s hooves would have shattered the van.

en: But alas!
vi: But oh my God!
tr: But not anymore!
es: But, unfortunately, his strength had left him; and soon the sound of hooves grew weaker and died away.

en: his strength had left him; and in a few moments the sound of drumming hoofs grew fainter and died away.
vi: His strength was gone now, and the sound of his kicks grew fainter and fainter until it stopped completely.
tr: The strength he once had was long gone. After a while, the thumping gradually weakened and finally stopped altogether.
es: But, unfortunately, his strength had left him; and soon the sound of hooves grew weaker and died away.

en: In desperation the animals began appealing to the two horses which drew the van to stop.
vi: Not knowing what else to do, the animals turned to the two pulling horses for help, begging them to stop running.
tr: Desperate, the animals this time called out to the horses pulling the cart: "Comrades!
es: In their desperation, the animals began to appeal to the two horses pulling the van to stop.

en: “Comrades, comrades!” they shouted.
vi: "Comrades! Comrades!",
tr: Comrades!
es: “Comrades, comrades!” they shouted.

en: “Don’t take your own brother to his death!
vi: They shouted in unison again, "Do you know where you are taking your brother?"
tr: Don't take your brother to his death!"
es: “Don’t take your own brother to his death!”

en: “But the stupid brutes, too ignorant to realise what was happening, merely set back their ears and quickened their pace.
vi: But the two dim-witted animals did not understand; they only perked up their ears slightly and ran even faster.
tr: But the stupid horses, not understanding what was happening, laid their ears back and sped up a little more.
es: But the stupid beasts, too ignorant to realize what was happening, laid back their ears and quickened their trot.

en: Boxer’s face did not reappear at the window.
vi: Warrior was no longer visible through the small window.
tr: Boxer's face did not appear at the window again.
es: Boxer’s face did not appear at the window again.

en: Too late, someone thought of racing ahead and shutting the five-barred gate; but in another moment the van was through it and rapidly disappearing down the road.
vi: Some thought about running out to close the large gate, but it was too late; the vehicle had already reached the main road and was getting farther away.
tr: One of them thought of running ahead to close the farm gate, but it was too late; the cart passed through the gate and quickly disappeared from sight.
es: It was too late when someone thought to run ahead to close the gate; in an instant, the van was gone and disappeared down the road.

en: Boxer was never seen again.
vi: From then on, no one saw Warrior again.
tr: They never saw Boxer again.
es: Boxer was never seen again.

en: Three days later it was announced that he had died in the hospital at Willingdon, in spite of receiving every attention a horse could have.
vi: Three days later, there was an announcement that Warrior had passed away at the hospital in Willingdon, despite receiving very attentive care.
tr: The news came three days later that Boxer had died in the hospital at Willingdon despite all the care shown.
es: Three days later, it was announced that he had died in the hospital at Willingdon, despite receiving all the care that could be given to a horse.

en: Squealer came to announce the news to the others.
vi: It was Squealer who made the announcement.
tr: Squealer, who announced the news, said he was with Boxer in his final moments.
es: Squealer announced the news to the others.

en: He had, he said, been present during Boxer’s last hours.
vi: He also said that he had been by Warrior's side during his final moments.
tr: Squealer, who announced the news, said he was with Boxer in his final moments.
es: He had been present, he said, during Boxer’s last hours.

en: “It was the most affecting sight I have ever seen!” said Squealer, lifting his trotter and wiping away a tear.
vi: "It was incredibly moving," Chỉ Điểm said while wiping away tears, "I sat beside Chiến Sĩ as he took his last breath.
tr: Squealer, lifting his foreleg to wipe away his tears, said, "I have never seen such a touching scene!"
es: —It was the most moving scene I have ever witnessed! —expressed Squealer, raising his paw to wipe away a tear—.

en: “I was at his bedside at the very last.
vi: "It was incredibly moving," Chỉ Điểm said while wiping away tears, "I sat beside Chiến Sĩ as he took his last breath.
tr: "I was by his side until the very end.
es: I was by his bedside until the very last moment, and in the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered to me that his only regret was dying before the windmill was finished.

en: And at the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered in my ear that his sole sorrow was to have passed on before the windmill was finished.
vi: Before he died, he was very weak, unable to speak, but he still tried to whisper that he regretted not being able to attend the windmill's inauguration.
tr: He no longer had the strength to speak. With his last breath, he whispered in my ear that his only regret was not being able to see the windmill completed.
es: I was by his bedside until the very last moment, and in the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered to me that his only regret was dying before the windmill was finished.

en: ‘Forward, comrades!’ he whispered.
vi: "Forward, comrades - he said - For the cause of the Rebellion, march forward!
tr: 'Forward, comrades!' he said with difficulty.
es: «Onward, comrades —he murmured—.

en: ‘Forward in the name of the Rebellion.
vi: "Forward, comrades - he said - For the cause of the Rebellion, march forward!
tr: 'Forward in the name of the Rebellion!
es: Onward in the name of the Rebellion.

en: Long live Animal Farm!
vi: Long live Animal Farm!
tr: Long live Animal Farm!
es: Long live "Animal Farm"!

en: Long live Comrade Napoleon!
vi: Long live Comrade Napoleon!
tr: Long live Comrade Napoleon!
es: Long live Comrade Napoleon!

en: Napoleon is always right.’
vi: Comrade Napoleon is always right!" - Those were his last words."
tr: Napoleon is always right!'
es: Napoleon is always right!»

en: Those were his very last words, comrades.”
vi: Comrade Napoleon is always right!" - Those were his last words."
tr: These were his last words, comrades."
es: Those were his last words, comrades.

en: Here Squealer’s demeanour suddenly changed.
vi: At that moment, Chỉ Điểm's attitude suddenly changed.
tr: Then, Squealer's demeanor suddenly changed.
es: Here Squealer's demeanor changed suddenly.

en: He fell silent for a moment, and his little eyes darted suspicious glances from side to side before he proceeded.
vi: He sat still for a while, then looked around before continuing the story.
tr: He paused for a moment, cast suspicious glances around with his tiny eyes, and then began to speak.
es: He remained silent for a moment, and his little eyes darted suspicious glances from side to side before continuing.

en: It had come to his knowledge, he said, that a foolish and wicked rumour had been circulated at the time of Boxer’s removal.
vi: It said that since Chiến Sỹ was taken away, unfounded rumors had been spreading in the camp.
tr: After Boxer was taken away, he had heard that a ridiculous and vile rumor had spread on the farm.
es: It had come to his attention —he said— that a ridiculous and malicious rumor circulated when Boxer was taken away.

en: Some of the animals had noticed that the van which took Boxer away was marked “Horse Slaughterer,” and had actually jumped to the conclusion that Boxer was being sent to the knacker’s.
vi: Some animals, upon seeing the words "Slaughterhouse" on the side of the truck, hastily concluded that Chiến Sỹ was taken away to be slaughtered.
tr: According to the rumor, some animals had seen "Horse Slaughterer" written on the cart that took Boxer away and immediately concluded that Boxer was being sent to be slaughtered.
es: Some animals noticed that the van that transported Boxer had the inscription: "Horse Slaughterer," and hastily concluded that this was indeed Boxer's fate.

en: It was almost unbelievable, said Squealer, that any animal could be so stupid.
vi: Chỉ Điểm said that it couldn't believe that the animals in the camp were that foolish.
tr: It was unbelievable that an animal could be so stupid.
es: It was almost unbelievable, said Squealer, that an animal could be so stupid.

en: Surely, he cried indignantly, whisking his tail and skipping from side to side, surely they knew their beloved Leader, Comrade Napoleon, better than that?
vi: Unbelievable, Chỉ Điểm said while wagging its tail and jumping around, that the animals in the camp could think of their beloved leader, think of comrade Napoleon in such a way!
tr: He was pacing back and forth, shouting angrily. Did they not know their beloved Leader Comrade Napoleon at all? Would Comrade Napoleon ever allow such a thing?
es: Surely, he cried indignantly, wagging his tail and jumping from side to side, surely they knew their beloved Leader, comrade Napoleon, better than anyone.

en: But the explanation was really very simple.
vi: Things were much simpler.
tr: Yet the truth was very simple.
es: But the explanation, in truth, was very simple.

en: The van had previously been the property of the knacker, and had been bought by the veterinary surgeon, who had not yet painted the old name out.
vi: The fact was that the veterinarian had bought the truck from the slaughterhouse, but he hadn't had the chance to remove the old owner's name yet.
tr: The cart, which had once been used by a horse slaughterer, had been bought by the veterinarian a short while ago, but the veterinarian had not had time to erase the writing on the cart.
es: The van had previously been owned by the knacker and had been bought by the veterinarian, who had not yet erased the previous name.

en: That was how the mistake had arisen.
vi: That was the only reason.
tr: This was where the problem stemmed from.
es: That was how the mistake was born.

en: The animals were enormously relieved to hear this.
vi: Hearing that, everyone felt reassured.
tr: The animals, once they learned the truth, felt a bit relieved from the distress in their hearts.
es: The animals were greatly relieved to hear this.

en: And when Squealer went on to give further graphic details of Boxer’s death-bed, the admirable care he had received, and the expensive medicines for which Napoleon had paid without a thought as to the cost, their last doubts disappeared and the sorrow that they felt for their comrade’s death was tempered by the thought that at least he had died happy.
vi: And when Chỉ Điểm vividly described the care, as well as the expensive medicines that Napoleon ordered to treat Chiến Sĩ in his final days, all the long-standing doubts were completely dispelled, and the sorrow of losing a friend was greatly alleviated: after all, Chiến Sĩ had received a proper burial.
tr: Especially when Squealer detailed how much care was given to Boxer on his deathbed, how Napoleon had immediately ordered those expensive medicines without the slightest hesitation, their last doubts were dispelled; the thought that Boxer had at least died happily alleviated the pain that had settled in their hearts with the death of their comrade.
es: And when Squealer continued giving them more graphic details of Boxer's deathbed, the admirable care he received, and the expensive medicines that Napoleon paid for without regard to the cost, their last doubts disappeared, and the sorrow they felt for the death of their comrade was mitigated by the idea that, at least, he had died happy.

en: Napoleon himself appeared at the meeting on the following Sunday morning and pronounced a short oration in Boxer’s honour.
vi: Napoleon himself attended the meeting on Sunday morning and delivered a speech commemorating the Warrior.
tr: On the next Sunday, Napoleon attended the meeting held in the morning and delivered a short speech extolling Boxer.
es: Napoleon himself appeared at the meeting the following Sunday and delivered a brief funeral oration in Boxer's memory.

en: It had not been possible, he said, to bring back their lamented comrade’s remains for interment on the farm, but he had ordered a large wreath to be made from the laurels in the farmhouse garden and sent down to be placed on Boxer’s grave.
vi: We are not in a position, he said, to bring the remains of the fallen comrade back to the farm, but he had ordered a large wreath to be made, with flowers taken directly from the farm's garden, and sent to Willingdon to be placed on the Warrior's grave.
tr: It had not been possible to bring the body of their comrade, whose loss they felt deeply, to the farm for burial. But he had sent a large wreath made of laurel branches for Boxer's funeral, which was to be held in the garden of the farmhouse.
es: It was not possible to bring back the remains of their mourned comrade to be buried at the Farm, but he had ordered that a large wreath made of laurel from the house garden be placed on Boxer's grave.

en: And in a few days’ time the pigs intended to hold a memorial banquet in Boxer’s honour.
vi: The pigs will organize a grand forty-nine-day ceremony [1] for the Warrior, he promised.
tr: The pigs were going to organize a memorial feast for Boxer in a few days.
es: And after a few days, the pigs planned to hold a commemorative banquet in his honor.

en: Napoleon ended his speech with a reminder of Boxer’s two favourite maxims, “I will work harder” and “Comrade Napoleon is always right”— maxims, he said, which every animal would do well to adopt as his own.
vi: Napoleon concluded his speech by reiterating the Warrior's two slogans: "I will work harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right." Napoleon also said that all the animals on the farm should emulate the Warrior, adopting his slogans as their own guiding principles.
tr: Napoleon ended his speech with Boxer's two favorite maxims: "I will work harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right." Every animal should engrave these maxims in their minds.
es: Napoleon concluded his speech by reminding them of Boxer's two favorite mottos: "I will work harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right," mottos, he said, that every animal would do well to adopt for themselves.

en: On the day appointed for the banquet, a grocer’s van drove up from Willingdon and delivered a large wooden crate at the farmhouse.
vi: On the exact day of the forty-nine-day ceremony for Chiến Sỹ, a truck carrying a large wooden crate arrived at the main building.
tr: On the day of the feast, a grocer's cart from Willingdon left a huge crate at the farmhouse.
es: On the appointed day for the banquet, a storekeeper's cart came from Willingdon and unloaded a large wooden crate.

en: That night there was the sound of uproarious singing, which was followed by what sounded like a violent quarrel and ended at about eleven o’clock with a tremendous crash of glass.
vi: That evening, sounds of singing and loud arguments emanated from the building, and at eleven o'clock, the sound of glass breaking was heard, followed by complete silence.
tr: That night, loud singing was heard, followed by sounds of scuffling and fighting, and finally, around eleven, a crash.
es: That night, the sound of boisterous singing was heard, followed by what seemed to be a violent quarrel that ended around eleven with a tremendous crash of breaking glass.

en: No one stirred in the farmhouse before noon on the following day, and the word went round that from somewhere or other the pigs had acquired the money to buy themselves another case of whisky.
vi: The main building remained tightly shut until noon the next day, during which time rumors spread that the pigs had made money and bought an entire crate of whiskey. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: Until noon the next day, there was no sound from any of those who had stayed in the farmhouse. A rumor was circulating on the farm: The pigs, having somehow found the money, had bought another case of whiskey.
es: No one moved in the house before noon the next day, and word spread that the pigs had managed to get money to buy another crate of whiskey.

en: Chapter 10
vi: Chapter 10
tr: Tenth Chapter
es: X

en: Years passed.
vi: Many years have passed.
tr: Years passed, seasons changed, and the short lives of the animals came to an end one by one.
es: The years passed.

en: The seasons came and went, the short animal lives fled by.
vi: Spring goes, winter comes, the life of animals is like a fleeting shadow through the window.
tr: Years passed, seasons changed, and the short lives of the animals came to an end one by one.
es: The seasons came and went; the short lives of the animals flew by.

en: A time came when there was no one who remembered the old days before the Rebellion, except Clover, Benjamin, Moses the raven, and a number of the pigs.
vi: Only Benjamin, Mrs. Fat, the raven Moses, and a few pigs still remember the "old days," before the Rebellion.
tr: Now, apart from Clover, Benjamin, the raven Moses, and a few pigs, no one remembered the days before the Rebellion.
es: There came a time when no one remembered the old days before the Rebellion, except for Clover, Benjamin, Moses the raven, and a few pigs.

en: Muriel was dead; Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher were dead.
vi: Muriel is dead. Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher are also gone.
tr: Muriel had died, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher had died.
es: Muriel had died; Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher had died.

en: Jones too was dead — he had died in an inebriates’ home in another part of the country.
vi: Mr. Jones is also dead, having died in an inebriates' home.
tr: Jones was no longer alive either; he had passed away in a distant home for the elderly.
es: Jones also died; he passed away in a home for drunks in another part of the country.

en: Snowball was forgotten.
vi: No one mentions Snowball anymore.
tr: Snowball had been forgotten.
es: Snowball was forgotten.

en: Boxer was forgotten, except by the few who had known him.
vi: Only a few animals remember Boxer.
tr: Except for a few animals who had known him, Boxer had also been forgotten.
es: Boxer had been forgotten as well, except by the few who had known him.

en: Clover was an old stout mare now, stiff in the joints and with a tendency to rheumy eyes.
vi: Clover has become a fat, old horse, slow of foot and dim of eye.
tr: Clover had aged and grown fat; her joints had stiffened, and her eyes had begun to water.
es: Clover was now an old and fat mare, with stiff joints and bleary eyes.

en: She was two years past the retiring age, but in fact no animal had ever actually retired.
vi: She has been past retirement age for two years, but in reality, no animal has ever retired.
tr: She had been due for retirement for two years, but no animal had ever been seen to retire up to that day.
es: She had reached retirement age two years ago, but in reality, no animal had retired.

en: The talk of setting aside a corner of the pasture for superannuated animals had long since been dropped.
vi: No one talks about setting aside a piece of land for the old animals anymore.
tr: The plan to set aside a corner of the pasture for the aging animals had long since ceased to be mentioned.
es: It had been a long time since anyone talked about reserving a corner of the pasture for retired animals.

en: Napoleon was now a mature boar of twenty-four stone.
vi: Napoleon has become a huge boar, weighing at least a ton and a half.
tr: Napoleon had become an almost three hundred-pound boar.
es: Napoleon was now a mature pig of about one hundred and fifty kilos.

en: Squealer was so fat that he could with difficulty see out of his eyes.
vi: Squealer is also very fat, his eyes nearly closed, almost unable to see.
tr: Squealer had turned into a ball of fat; his eyes were so squinty that he could barely see.
es: Squealer was so fat that he had difficulty seeing beyond his nose.

en: Only old Benjamin was much the same as ever, except for being a little greyer about the muzzle, and, since Boxer’s death, more morose and taciturn than ever.
vi: Only Benjamin is still the same, though his muzzle is white, and since Boxer's death, he has become more morose and taciturn.
tr: Only old Benjamin had hardly changed; only a bit of gray had appeared in his mane; and after Boxer's death, he had become even more morose and taciturn.
es: Only old Benjamin was more or less the same as always, except that his muzzle was grayer and, since Boxer's death, he was more bad-tempered and taciturn than ever.

en: There were many more creatures on the farm now, though the increase was not so great as had been expected in earlier years.
vi: Animal Farm had many new members, though not as many as they initially thought.
tr: Although the population increase was not as high as initially expected, the number of animals on the farm had still grown.
es: There were many more animals than before on the farm, although the increase was not as great as had been expected in the early years.

en: Many animals had been born to whom the Rebellion was only a dim tradition, passed on by word of mouth, and others had been bought who had never heard mention of such a thing before their arrival.
vi: Some were born right there, for whom the Rebellion was just a vague tradition, passed down orally. Some were bought from elsewhere, and these had never heard anyone talk about it before arriving here.
tr: For many animals born in recent years, the Rebellion was nothing more than a tale passed down by word of mouth; the animals purchased from outside had not even heard of the Rebellion until they arrived at the farm.
es: Many animals were born for whom the Rebellion was an almost forgotten tradition, passed down verbally; and others, who had been acquired, had never heard of such a thing before their arrival.

en: The farm possessed three horses now besides Clover.
vi: Besides the Fat Lady, the farm also had three more horses.
tr: Besides Clover, there were three more horses on the farm.
es: The farm now had three horses, in addition to Clover.

en: They were fine upstanding beasts, willing workers and good comrades, but very stupid.
vi: They were large, strong, hardworking, kind-hearted but very stupid.
tr: They were animals with pure hearts, honest, and hardworking; their companionship was impeccable, but they were very stupid.
es: They were impressive beasts, willing workers, and excellent comrades, but very stupid.

en: None of them proved able to learn the alphabet beyond the letter B.
vi: None of them knew more than the letter B.
tr: They could not get past the letter B of the alphabet.
es: None of them managed to learn the alphabet beyond the letter B.

en: They accepted everything that they were told about the Rebellion and the principles of Animalism, especially from Clover, for whom they had an almost filial respect; but it was doubtful whether they understood very much of it.
vi: They had absolute faith in the Animalism and the stories about the Rebellion, especially those told by the Fat Lady, whom they regarded as a mother; but it seemed they didn't understand anything at all.
tr: They accepted everything they were told about the Rebellion and the basic principles of animalism without question; especially if it came from the mouth of Clover, whom they deeply respected... But it could not be said that they understood much of what was being told.
es: They accepted everything they were told about the Rebellion and the principles of Animalism, especially from Clover, whom they had an almost filial respect for; but it was doubtful that they had understood much of what was said to them.

en: The farm was more prosperous now, and better organised: it had even been enlarged by two fields which had been bought from mr Pilkington.
vi: The farm was well-organized and increasingly prosperous; they even expanded by purchasing two more plots of land from Pilkington.
tr: The farm had now become richer and better organized; it had grown even larger with the addition of two fields purchased from Mr. Pilkington.
es: The farm was more prosperous and better organized; it had even been expanded with two strips of land purchased from Mr. Pilkington.

en: The windmill had been successfully completed at last, and the farm possessed a threshing machine and a hay elevator of its own, and various new buildings had been added to it.
vi: The windmill was completed, they bought a threshing machine, a hoist, and built many more buildings.
tr: The windmill had finally been successfully completed, the farm had acquired a threshing machine, a hay and straw barn, and new buildings had been constructed.
es: The windmill was finally completed, and the farm owned a threshing machine and a hay elevator, with several buildings also added.

en: Whymper had bought himself a dogcart.
vi: Whymper also bought himself a small cart.
tr: Whymper had bought himself a small one-horse carriage.
es: Whymper had bought himself a car.

en: The windmill, however, had not after all been used for generating electrical power.
vi: They did not install a generator on the windmill but used it for milling, which earned them a lot of money.
tr: But the windmill had never been used for generating electricity.
es: The windmill, however, was not used to generate electricity.

en: It was used for milling corn, and brought in a handsome money profit.
vi: They did not install a generator on the windmill but used it for milling, which earned them a lot of money.
tr: The mill, used for grinding flour, was bringing in quite a good amount of money.
es: It was used to grind corn and produced a healthy cash profit.

en: The animals were hard at work building yet another windmill; when that one was finished, so it was said, the dynamos would be installed.
vi: They were building another windmill, where they said they would install a generator.
tr: Now the animals were working with all their might to build another windmill. According to what was being said, once this new windmill was completed, dynamos would be installed.
es: The animals were working hard on the construction of another windmill; when this one was finished, it was said, dynamos would be installed.

en: But the luxuries of which Snowball had once taught the animals to dream, the stalls with electric light and hot and cold water, and the three-day week, were no longer talked about.
vi: But luxuries like electric lights, hot water, and a three-day work week, which they once dreamed of during Snowball's time, were no longer mentioned.
tr: However, the dreams that Snowball once vividly described to the animals, such as barns illuminated by electric light, with hot and cold water, and working only three days a week, had now faded from memory.
es: But the luxuries that Snowball had made the animals dream of, the stalls with electric light and hot and cold water, and the three-day week, were no longer mentioned.

en: Napoleon had denounced such ideas as contrary to the spirit of Animalism.
vi: Napoleon had declared that such ideas were completely contrary to the spirit of Animalism.
tr: Napoleon had declared that such ideas were incompatible with the spirit of Animalism.
es: Napoleon had censured these ideas, considering them contrary to the spirit of Animalism.

en: The truest happiness, he said, lay in working hard and living frugally.
vi: True happiness, he said, was hard work and living frugally and thriftily.
tr: According to the Leader, true happiness lay in working hard and living simply.
es: True happiness, he said, consisted of working hard and living frugally.

en: Somehow it seemed as though the farm had grown richer without making the animals themselves any richer-except, of course, for the pigs and the dogs.
vi: The farm became wealthier, but except for the pigs and dogs, the lives of the other animals remained the same as before.
tr: In the meantime, the farm had become richer, but for some reason, the living conditions of the animals had not changed; except for the pigs and dogs, of course.
es: Somehow it seemed as though the farm had grown richer without making the animals themselves richer; except, of course, for the pigs and the dogs.

en: Perhaps this was partly because there were so many pigs and so many dogs.
vi: It might also be partly because there were too many pigs and dogs.
tr: This was perhaps partly due to their being numerous.
es: Perhaps this was partly due to the fact that there were so many pigs and so many dogs.

en: It was not that these creatures did not work, after their fashion.
vi: They did work, of course, in their own way.
tr: Indeed, they were working in their own way.
es: It was not that these animals did not work in their own way.

en: There was, as Squealer was never tired of explaining, endless work in the supervision and organisation of the farm.
vi: Squealer tirelessly explained that organizing and supervising the farm's work were tasks that had to be done regularly and continuously.
