tr: According to what Squealer tirelessly explained, the supervision and management of the farm required them to work incessantly.
es: There was, as Squealer never tired of explaining to them, an endless amount of work in the supervision and organization of the Farm.

en: Much of this work was of a kind that the other animals were too ignorant to understand.
vi: And other species couldn't handle it; this job required a lot of intelligence.
tr: Most of these tasks were beyond the knowledge and skills of the other animals.
es: Much of this work had characteristics such that the other animals were too ignorant to understand it.

en: For example, Squealer told them that the pigs had to expend enormous labours every day upon mysterious things called “files,” “reports,” “minutes,” and “memoranda”.
vi: For example, Squealer said that the pigs spent a lot of effort drafting what they called "documents," "data," "reports," "minutes," and "memos."
tr: For instance, the pigs had to rack their brains every day from morning till night over things like "vouchers," "reports," "minutes," and "files," which no one could make heads or tails of.
es: For example, Squealer told them that the pigs had to make an enormous effort every day with some mysterious things called "files," "reports," "minutes," and "memoranda."

en: These were large sheets of paper which had to be closely covered with writing, and as soon as they were so covered, they were burnt in the furnace.
vi: These were large sheets of paper filled with writing, and after they were written, they were taken to the furnace to be burned.
tr: These were sheets of paper filled with dense writing, which, once filled, were thrown into the fire and burned.
es: These were long sheets of paper that had to be completely filled with writing, and then were burned in the furnace.

en: This was of the highest importance for the welfare of the farm, Squealer said.
vi: Thanks to this, the farm became as prosperous as it is today, Squealer often said.
tr: Squealer said that this was of great importance for the peace and order of the farm.
es: This was of utmost importance for the welfare of the Farm, Squealer pointed out.

en: But still, neither pigs nor dogs produced any food by their own labour; and there were very many of them, and their appetites were always good.
vi: Anyway, those things couldn't fill the pigs' and dogs' bellies, and they were very gluttonous.
tr: But still, neither the pigs nor the dogs produced food with their own labor; moreover, they were both very numerous and always had a good appetite.
es: But in any case, neither the pigs nor the dogs produced anything edible through their own labor; they were many and always had a good appetite.

en: As for the others, their life, so far as they knew, was as it had always been.
vi: The lives of the other animals remained the same as before.
tr: As for the other animals; as far as they could see, not much had changed in their lives.
es: As for the others, their life, as far as they knew, was what it had always been.

en: They were generally hungry, they slept on straw, they drank from the pool, they laboured in the fields; in winter they were troubled by the cold, and in summer by the flies.
vi: During the day, they were often hungry, at night they slept on straw beds, drank water directly from the pond, worked in the open fields, suffered from sleeplessness due to the cold in winter, and were tormented by flies in the summer.
tr: Most of the time they were hungry, sleeping on the straw, drinking their water from the puddle, working in the fields; freezing in the winter, and being attacked by flies in the summer.
es: They were generally hungry, slept on straw, drank from the pond, worked in the fields; in winter they suffered from the cold and in summer from the flies.

en: Sometimes the older ones among them racked their dim memories and tried to determine whether in the early days of the Rebellion, when Jones’s expulsion was still recent, things had been better or worse than now.
vi: Occasionally, the older animals tried to recall whether their lives were better now compared to just after the Rebellion, when they had just driven Mr. Jones away.
tr: The older ones, straining their memories, were trying to figure out whether the situation in the early days of the Rebellion, when Jones had just been expelled from the farm, was better or worse than now; but they couldn't remember much.
es: Sometimes, the oldest among them searched their murky memories and tried to determine if in the early days of the Rebellion, when Jones's expulsion was still recent, things were better or worse than now.

en: They could not remember.
vi: But they could not remember.
tr: The older ones, straining their memories, were trying to figure out whether the situation in the early days of the Rebellion, when Jones had just been expelled from the farm, was better or worse than now; but they couldn't remember much.
es: They could not remember.

en: There was nothing with which they could compare their present lives: they had nothing to go upon except Squealer’s lists of figures, which invariably demonstrated that everything was getting better and better.
vi: They had nothing to compare with: their minds were filled only with Squealer's statistics, numbers that always proved that everything was improving, getting better step by step every day.
tr: They had nothing left to compare their current lives with; all they had were Squealer's lists filled with figures showing that the situation was improving day by day.
es: There was nothing to compare their present life with, they had nothing to go on except Squealer's lists of figures which invariably demonstrated that everything was getting better and better.

en: The animals found the problem insoluble; in any case, they had little time for speculating on such things now.
vi: So they accepted it and besides, they didn't have much time to think about such things.
tr: They couldn't make sense of it; besides, they no longer had the time to ponder such things at length.
es: The animals found no solution to the problem; in any case, they now had little time to ponder these things.

en: Only old Benjamin professed to remember every detail of his long life and to know that things never had been, nor ever could be much better or much worse — hunger, hardship, and disappointment being, so he said, the unalterable law of life.
vi: Only old Benjamin asserted that he remembered everything, down to the smallest detail of what had happened, and knew clearly that they had never been worse off nor better off, it was always hunger, working tirelessly, and being deceived; such was the law of life, he often said.
tr: The only animal who claimed to remember all the details of his long life was old Benjamin; he said that the situation had never been better or worse and that it would continue like this. According to Benjamin, hunger, hardship, and disappointment were the unchanging laws of life.
es: Only old Benjamin claimed to remember every detail of his long life and knew that things had never been, nor could ever be, much better or much worse; hunger, oppression, and disappointment were, he said, the unalterable law of life.

en: And yet the animals never gave up hope.
vi: Anyway, they still kept hoping.
tr: However, the animals never lost their hope.
es: And yet, the animals never abandoned their hopes.

en: More, they never lost, even for an instant, their sense of honour and privilege in being members of Animal Farm.
vi: Moreover, they were always proud to be citizens of Animal Farm.
tr: More importantly, they never forgot for a moment how honorable and respectable it was to be a member of Animal Farm.
es: Moreover, they never lost, not even for an instant, their sense of honor and the privilege of being members of "Animal Farm."

en: They were still the only farm in the whole county — in all England!
vi: In this country, which is indeed England, this is the only farm run by animals and managed by animals!
tr: Animal Farm was still the only farm in the whole country – in all of England!
es: It was still the only farm in the whole county —in all of England!— owned and governed by animals.

en: — owned and operated by animals.
vi: In this country, which is indeed England, this is the only farm run by animals and managed by animals!
tr: – that was owned by animals and managed by animals.
es: It was still the only farm in the whole county —in all of England!— owned and governed by animals.

en: Not one of them, not even the youngest, not even the newcomers who had been brought from farms ten or twenty miles away, ever ceased to marvel at that.
vi: All the animals, from the smallest ones to those newly bought from tens of kilometers away, were proud of this.
tr: Even the youngest, and those who had been brought from farms twenty or thirty kilometers away, saw this as a miracle.
es: None, neither the youngest nor even the newcomers brought from farms ten or twenty miles away, ceased to marvel at it.

en: And when they heard the gun booming and saw the green flag fluttering at the masthead, their hearts swelled with imperishable pride, and the talk turned always towards the old heroic days, the expulsion of Jones, the writing of the Seven Commandments, the great battles in which the human invaders had been defeated.
vi: Especially when they heard the sound of gunfire, when they saw the green flag flying, their hearts would beat excitedly, and at that moment, no matter what they were talking about, they would return to the topic of those glorious years, about overthrowing Mr. Jones, about establishing the Seven Commandments, and about the heroic battles against the invading humans.
tr: When they heard the sound of the rifle, when they saw the green flag waving on the pole, their chests swelled with pride; the conversation inevitably turned to the old heroic days, the expulsion of Jones from the farm, the drafting of the Seven Commandments, and the defeat of the humans who tried to take over the farm.
es: And when they heard the gun thunder and saw the green flag waving at the top of the mast, their hearts swelled with inextinguishable pride, and the conversation always revolved around the heroic days of yore, the expulsion of Jones, the inscription of the seven commandments, the great battles in which the human invaders were defeated.

en: None of the old dreams had been abandoned.
vi: They also did not forget to remind each other of the initial expectations.
tr: They had not given up on any of the old dreams.
es: None of the old dreams had been abandoned.

en: The Republic of the Animals which Major had foretold, when the green fields of England should be untrodden by human feet, was still believed in.
vi: They believed that the prophecy of the old Leader about the day of establishing the Animal Republic across the entire territory of England, the day when humans would be expelled from this land, would definitely come.
tr: They had not lost their belief in the Animal Republic foretold by Old Major, where not a single human foot would tread on the green fields of England.
es: The Republic of the animals that Major had predicted, when the green fields of England would not be trodden by human feet, was still their aspiration.

en: Some day it was coming: it might not be soon, it might not be with in the lifetime of any animal now living, but still it was coming.
vi: Their dreams would come true, that day would definitely come, even if it was far away, even if all the animals currently living would not witness it, but that day would definitely come.
tr: One day it would definitely come true; maybe it wouldn't happen immediately, maybe those who were alive now wouldn't see those days, but their dreams would definitely come true one day.
es: Someday it would come; perhaps not soon, maybe not during the lifetime of the current generation of animals, but it would come.

en: Even the tune of ‘Beasts of England’ was perhaps hummed secretly here and there: at any rate, it was a fact that every animal on the farm knew it, though no one would have dared to sing it aloud.
vi: They also did not forget the song "Beasts of England," every animal knew how to sing this song, but they only dared to sing it quietly to each other.
tr: Even the tune of the song "Beasts of England" was being hummed secretly here and there; although none of them dared to sing it out loud, it was certain that every animal on the farm knew the song by heart.
es: Even the melody of "Beasts of England" was surely hummed in secret here or there; in any case, it was a fact that all the animals on the farm knew it, though none had dared to sing it out loud.

en: It might be that their lives were hard and that not all of their hopes had been fulfilled; but they were conscious that they were not as other animals.
vi: Even though life was still difficult, even though not all of their dreams were realized, deep down they knew that they were special animals.
tr: They might have been living a hard life, their hopes might not have all come true, but they were aware that they were different from other animals.
es: It might be that their lives were arduous and that not all their hopes were fulfilled; but they were aware that they were not like other animals.

en: If they went hungry, it was not from feeding tyrannical human beings; if they worked hard, at least they worked for themselves.
vi: Even though they were not yet full, they did not have to work to feed the cruel humans; even though they still had to labor hard, it was for themselves.
tr: If they were hungry, it wasn't because they were feeding tyrannical humans; if they were working hard, at least they were working for themselves.
es: If they went hungry, it was not to feed tyrants like human beings; if they worked hard, at least they did it for themselves.

en: No creature among them went upon two legs.
vi: No animal walked on two legs, there was no master-servant relationship.
tr: No animal walked on two legs.
es: None walked on two legs.

en: No creature called any other creature “Master.”
vi: No animal walked on two legs, there was no master-servant relationship.
tr: No animal was the "master" of any other animal.
es: None called another "master."

en: All animals were equal.
vi: All were equal.
tr: All animals were equal.
es: All animals were equal.

en: One day in early summer Squealer ordered the sheep to follow him, and led them out to a piece of waste ground at the other end of the farm, which had become overgrown with birch saplings.
vi: One day, at the beginning of summer, Chỉ Điểm suddenly ordered the flock of sheep to follow it to the abandoned field outside the farm, where there was a whole forest of young birch trees.
tr: It was the beginning of summer. One day, Squealer ordered the sheep to follow him and took them to a place at the other end of the farm, covered with young birch trees.
es: One day, at the beginning of summer, Squealer ordered the sheep to follow him, and he led them to a plot of uncultivated land at the other end of the farm, covered with birch saplings.

en: The sheep spent the whole day there browsing at the leaves under Squealer’s supervision.
vi: The flock of sheep stayed there all day, freely chewing on the leaves, of course under the direction of Chỉ Điểm.
tr: Under Squealer's supervision, the sheep ate the leaves of the trees until evening.
es: The sheep spent the whole day there eating leaves under Squealer's supervision.

en: In the evening he returned to the farmhouse himself, but, as it was warm weather, told the sheep to stay where they were.
vi: That evening, Chỉ Điểm returned to the farm alone, as the weather was good that day, it told the flock of sheep to sleep right outside in the field to stay cool.
tr: Before returning to the farmhouse in the evening, Squealer instructed the sheep to stay there; after all, the weather was warm.
es: At dusk, he returned to the house, but since it was hot, he told the sheep to stay where they were.

en: It ended by their remaining there for a whole week, during which time the other animals saw nothing of them.
vi: They stayed there for an entire week.
tr: The sheep stayed there for an entire week; during this time, the other animals did not encounter the sheep at all.
es: And there they remained all week, unseen by the other animals during that time.

en: Squealer was with them for the greater part of every day.
vi: Every day, Chỉ Điểm went out to the flock of sheep.
tr: Squealer went there every day, spending most of the day with the sheep.
es: Squealer was with them for most of the day.

en: He was, he said, teaching them to sing a new song, for which privacy was needed.
vi: According to what it said, it was teaching the flock of sheep a new song, and it was easier to learn in the quiet.
tr: He told them that he was teaching them a new song and that they needed to be away from prying eyes to work comfortably.
es: He said he was teaching them a new song, for which isolation was necessary.

en: It was just after the sheep had returned, on a pleasant evening when the animals had finished work and were making their way back to the farm buildings, that the terrified neighing of a horse sounded from the yard.
vi: One afternoon, the sheep had finished their lessons and returned, while the whole group was heading back after a day of labor when they suddenly heard a horse's frantic neigh coming from the direction of the farm.
tr: On a beautiful evening when the sheep had just returned to the farm, the animals had finished their work and were heading towards the farm buildings. Suddenly, a terrifying neigh was heard from the yard.
es: A quiet afternoon, shortly after the sheep had returned from their retreat —the animals had already finished working and were heading back towards the farm buildings—, a terrified neigh of a horse was heard from the yard.

en: Startled, the animals stopped in their tracks.
vi: Terrified, they all immediately stood as if rooted to the spot.
tr: The animals froze in their tracks, startled.
es: Alarmed, the animals stopped abruptly.

en: It was Clover’s voice.
vi: It was the cry of Fat Lady.
tr: It was Clover's voice.
es: It was Clover's voice.

en: She neighed again, and all the animals broke into a gallop and rushed into the yard.
vi: She cried out again, and they all immediately dashed into the farmyard to see what was happening.
tr: When she neighed once more, all the animals galloped into the yard.
es: She neighed again and everyone galloped, rushing into the yard.

en: Then they saw what Clover had seen.
vi: And they saw exactly what had caused Fat Lady's panic.
tr: And they saw what Clover had seen:
es: Then they saw what Clover had seen.

en: It was a pig walking on his hind legs.
vi: That is a pig walking on its two hind legs.
tr: A pig walking on its hind legs.
es: It was a pig, walking on its hind legs.

en: Yes, it was Squealer.
vi: Yes, it was Chỉ Điểm who was walking.
tr: This was Squealer.
es: Yes, it was Squealer.

en: A little awkwardly, as though not quite used to supporting his considerable bulk in that position, but with perfect balance, he was strolling across the yard.
vi: It seemed clumsy, of course, partly because it was not used to it, and partly because it was too heavy, but it still maintained its balance and walked from one side of the yard to the other.
tr: He was struggling to move forward as he was not used to carrying his large body on his hind legs, but he could still walk around the yard without losing his balance.
es: A bit clumsily, as if he were not entirely accustomed to holding his great bulk in that position, but with perfect balance, he was strolling around the yard.

en: And a moment later, out from the door of the farmhouse came a long file of pigs, all walking on their hind legs.
vi: A moment later, the whole herd of pigs came out from the main door of the house, all of them, without exception, were walking on their hind legs.
tr: Soon, a bunch of pigs came out of the farmhouse door; they were all walking on their hind legs.
es: And shortly after, through the door of the house appeared a long line of pigs, all walking on their hind legs.

en: Some did it better than others, one or two were even a trifle unsteady and looked as though they would have liked the support of a stick, but every one of them made his way right round the yard successfully.
vi: Some walked confidently, some staggered, and if they had canes, they would be more stable, but all of them made a round around the yard without any falling.
tr: Some were more skillful, while others had difficulty maintaining their balance; but they were all wandering around the yard without falling.
es: Some did it better than others, although one or two walked a bit unsteadily, giving the impression that they would have appreciated the support of a cane, but all of them successfully completed a full turn around the yard.

en: And finally there was a tremendous baying of dogs and a shrill crowing from the black cockerel, and out came Napoleon himself, majestically upright, casting haughty glances from side to side, and with his dogs gambolling round him.
vi: Finally, there was the sound of dogs barking fiercely, roosters crowing loudly, and Napoleon stepped out, his back straight, looking majestic, surveying the scene, surrounded by a flock of sheep.
tr: Finally, the dogs barked with terrifying sounds, the black rooster crowed loudly, and Napoleon appeared at the door: He was walking upright with all his grandeur, casting haughty glances to his right and left; his dogs were jumping around him.
es: Finally, there was a tremendous barking from the dogs and a sharp crowing from the black rooster, and Napoleon himself appeared, standing majestically, casting arrogant glances from side to side with the dogs jumping around.

en: He carried a whip in his trotter.
vi: Its front leg held a big whip.
tr: There was a whip on one of its front legs!
es: He was carrying a whip in his hand.

en: There was a deadly silence.
vi: It was as silent as a sheet around.
tr: A deathly silence had enveloped the surroundings.
es: A deathly silence fell.

en: Amazed, terrified, huddling together, the animals watched the long line of pigs march slowly round the yard.
vi: Surprised mixed with fear, the animals gathered in a corner to watch the pigs walk around the yard in a line.
tr: The animals, huddled together in bewilderment and fear, watched the pigs walking slowly around the yard.
es: Astonished, terrified, huddled together, the animals watched the long line of pigs slowly marching around the yard.

en: It was as though the world had turned upside-down.
vi: Has the world gone completely mad?
tr: It was as if the world had turned upside down.
es: It was as if the world had turned upside down.

en: Then there came a moment when the first shock had worn off and when, in spite of everything-in spite of their terror of the dogs, and of the habit, developed through long years, of never complaining, never criticising, no matter what happened — they might have uttered some word of protest.
vi: The initial panic eventually passed, and despite fearing the dogs, despite years of being accustomed to not daring to complain, not daring to protest, this time they would surely speak out in protest.
tr: As soon as their initial shock passed, despite their fear of the dogs and their long-standing habit of never complaining or criticizing anything, they were about to raise their voices against the pigs when the sheep, as if on cue, began to bleat in unison:
es: There came a moment when the first impression passed and, despite everything —despite their terror of the dogs and the habit, acquired over many years, of never complaining, never criticizing—, some word of protest was about to burst out.

en: But just at that moment, as though at a signal, all the sheep burst out into a tremendous bleating of —
vi: But at that moment, as if on cue, the sheep simultaneously cried out:
tr: As soon as their initial shock passed, despite their fear of the dogs and their long-standing habit of never complaining or criticizing anything, they were about to raise their voices against the pigs when the sheep, as if on cue, began to bleat in unison:
es: But at that precise moment, as if obeying a signal, all the sheep burst into a tremendous bleating: "Four legs good, two legs better!

en: “Four legs good, two legs BETTER!
vi: "Four legs good, two legs better!
tr: "Four legs good, two legs better!
es: Four legs good, two legs better!

en: Four legs good, two legs BETTER!
vi: Four legs good, two legs better!
tr: Four legs good, two legs better!
es: Four legs good, two legs better!

en: Four legs good, two legs BETTER!”
vi: Four legs good, two legs better!"
tr: Four legs good, two legs better!"
es: Four legs good, two legs better!"

en: It went on for five minutes without stopping.
vi: They chanted like that for five minutes straight, without stopping.
tr: The bleating lasted for five minutes without interruption.
es: The chant continued for five minutes without stopping.

en: And by the time the sheep had quieted down, the chance to utter any protest had passed, for the pigs had marched back into the farmhouse.
vi: When the sheep fell silent, the pigs had already entered the house; even if there were objections, no one would hear them.
tr: By the time the sheep fell silent, the pigs had already returned to the farmhouse; the opportunity to protest had been missed.
es: And when the sheep fell silent, the opportunity to protest had passed, for the pigs had re-entered the house.

en: Benjamin felt a nose nuzzling at his shoulder.
vi: Benjamin felt as if something was rubbing its nose against his shoulder.
tr: Benjamin turned around when he noticed someone touching his shoulder with their nose.
es: Benjamin felt a snout brush against his shoulder.

en: He looked round.
vi: He turned his head around.
tr: Benjamin turned around when he noticed someone touching his shoulder with their nose.
es: He turned around.

en: It was Clover.
vi: It turned out to be Mrs. Fat.
tr: It was Clover.
es: It was Clover.

en: Her old eyes looked dimmer than ever.
vi: Her already dim eyes looked sadder than ever.
tr: Her old eyes were duller than ever.
es: Her old eyes seemed dimmer than ever.

en: Without saying anything, she tugged gently at his mane and led him round to the end of the big barn, where the Seven Commandments were written.
vi: She gently nibbled at Benjamin's mane and pulled him towards the gable end of the large barn.
tr: Without saying anything, she gently pulled Benjamin by his mane and led him to the wall of the big barn where the Seven Commandments were written.
es: Without saying anything, she gently tugged at his mane and led him to the end of the main barn, where the seven commandments were inscribed.

en: For a minute or two they stood gazing at the tatted wall with its white lettering.
vi: They stood there, silently gazing at the white letters on the tarred wall.
tr: They stood there for a while, looking at the white letters on the tar-covered wall.
es: For a minute or two, they stood looking at the tarred wall with its white letters.

en: “My sight is failing,” she said finally.
vi: "I can't see anything anymore - Finally, the Fat Lady spoke up - Even when I was young, I couldn't read a single word.
tr: In the end, Clover said, "My eyes aren't seeing well anymore."
es: —My eyesight is failing me —she finally said—.

en: “Even when I was young I could not have read what was written there.
vi: "I can't see anything anymore - Finally, the Fat Lady spoke up - Even when I was young, I couldn't read a single word.
tr: "Though, I couldn't read properly even when I was young.
es: Not even when I was young could I read what was written there.

en: But it appears to me that that wall looks different.
vi: But it seems to me that the wall looks very different.
tr: But it seems to me that there is a change in the writings.
es: But it seems to me that this wall has changed.

en: Are the Seven Commandments the same as they used to be, Benjamin?”
vi: The Seven Commandments are still the same, aren't they, Benjamin?"
tr: Do the Seven Commandments still stand as they used to, Benjamin?"
es: Are the seven commandments the same as before, Benjamin?

en: For once Benjamin consented to break his rule, and he read out to her what was written on the wall.
vi: This is the first time Benjamin has given up its habitual practice and gently read aloud to Mrs. Fat.
tr: Benjamin broke his principle for the first time and read the writing on the wall to Clover.
es: For the first time, Benjamin agreed to break the custom and read what was written on the wall.

en: There was nothing there now except a single Commandment.
vi: On the wall, there was only one Commandment left, which read as follows:
tr: There was only one commandment written on the wall:
es: There was nothing there except a single Commandment.

en: It ran:
vi: On the wall, there was only one Commandment left, which read as follows:
tr: There was only one commandment written on the wall:
es: It said:

en: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL
vi: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL, BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS.
tr: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL
es: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL, BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS.

en: BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS
vi: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL, BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS.
tr: BUT SOME ANIMALS MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS
es: ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL, BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS.

en: After that it did not seem strange when next day the pigs who were supervising the work of the farm all carried whips in their trotters.
vi: After that, even the sight of the overseer pigs carrying whips to the fields no longer surprised them.
tr: The next day, it did not seem strange to anyone that all the pigs overseeing the farm work had whips.
es: After that, it did not seem strange to them that the next day the pigs who were supervising the farm work were all carrying a whip in their hands.

en: It did not seem strange to learn that the pigs had bought themselves a wireless set, were arranging to install a telephone, and had taken out subscriptions to ‘John Bull’, ‘Tit-Bits’, and the ‘Daily Mirror’.
vi: They were also not surprised to see the pigs buying radios, discussing contracts to install telephones, and subscribing to newspapers like John Bull, Tits-Bit, and the Daily Mirror.
tr: No one was surprised when it was heard that the pigs had gotten themselves a radio, were preparing to get a telephone line, and had subscribed to the John Bull and Tit-Bits magazines and the Daily Mirror newspaper.
es: It did not seem odd to them to learn that the pigs had bought a radio, were arranging for the installation of a telephone, and had subscribed to John Bull, Tit-Bits, and the Daily Mirror.

en: It did not seem strange when Napoleon was seen strolling in the farmhouse garden with a pipe in his mouth — no, not even when the pigs took mr Jones’s clothes out of the wardrobes and put them on, Napoleon himself appearing in a black coat, ratcatcher breeches, and leather leggings, while his favourite sow appeared in the watered silk dress which ms Jones had been used to wearing on Sundays.
vi: They were not surprised either when they saw Napoleon walking in the garden with a pipe in his mouth, or when they saw the pigs dressing up in Mr. Jones's clothes. Napoleon chose for himself a black coat, breeches, and leather boots; while the sow he favored most wore the silk dress that Mrs. Jones used to wear to church on Sundays.
tr: It did not seem odd to anyone that Napoleon was walking around the garden of the farmhouse with a pipe in his mouth. Even the fact that the pigs took Mrs. Jones's clothes from the wardrobe and wore them, that Napoleon walked around in a black coat, breeches, and leather leggings, and that his favorite sow wore the shimmering silk dress that Mrs. Jones once wore on Sundays did not surprise anyone.
es: It did not seem strange to them when they saw Napoleon walking through the garden of the house with a pipe in his mouth; no, not even when the pigs took Mr. Jones's clothes out of the wardrobes and put them on; Napoleon appeared in a black jacket, breeches, and leather leggings, while his favorite wore the silk dress that Mrs. Jones used to wear on Sundays.

en: A week later, in the afternoon, a number of dog-carts drove up to the farm.
vi: One week later, in the afternoon, many vehicles entered the farm.
tr: About a week later, one afternoon, small horse-drawn carriages arrived at the farm.
es: A week later, one afternoon, a number of cars arrived at the farm.

en: A deputation of neighbouring farmers had been invited to make a tour of inspection.
vi: These were representatives from neighboring farms invited to visit Animal Farm.
tr: A delegation from neighboring farms had been called for an inspection tour.
es: A delegation of neighboring farmers had been invited to make a visit.

en: They were shown all over the farm, and expressed great admiration for everything they saw, especially the windmill.
vi: The guests were very surprised when they saw the fields, the farm's production tools, and especially the windmill.
tr: The farmers who toured the entire farm expressed their admiration for everything they saw, especially the windmill.
es: They toured the farm and expressed great admiration for everything they saw, especially the windmill.

en: The animals were weeding the turnip field.
vi: At that time, the animals were weeding the turnip field.
tr: The animals were weeding the turnip field.
es: The animals were weeding the turnip field.

en: They worked diligently hardly raising their faces from the ground, and not knowing whether to be more frightened of the pigs or of the human visitors.
vi: They worked diligently, rarely lifting their heads. They also did not know which of the two groups, the guests or the pigs, were more frightening.
tr: They were completely absorbed in their work; they didn't even lift their heads as they couldn't decide whether to be more afraid of the pigs or the human guests visiting the farm.
es: They worked almost without lifting their faces from the ground and without knowing whom they should fear more: the pigs or the human visitors.

en: That evening loud laughter and bursts of singing came from the farmhouse.
vi: That evening, there were loud singing and laughter coming from the main house.
tr: In the evening, laughter and songs rose from the farmhouse.
es: That night, loud laughter and songs were heard from the house.

en: And suddenly, at the sound of the mingled voices, the animals were stricken with curiosity.
vi: The animals suddenly felt curious, wanting to know what was being discussed in that house because it was the first time humans and animals met as equal partners.
tr: The animals, hearing the mingling sounds, suddenly pricked up their ears.
es: The sound of the mingled voices suddenly aroused the curiosity of the animals.

en: What could be happening in there, now that for the first time animals and human beings were meeting on terms of equality?
vi: The animals suddenly felt curious, wanting to know what was being discussed in that house because it was the first time humans and animals met as equal partners.
tr: What were the animals and humans, meeting under equal conditions for the first time, doing there?
es: What could be happening there, now that, for the first time, animals and humans were gathered on equal terms?

en: With one accord they began to creep as quietly as possible into the farmhouse garden.
vi: Then, without any prompting, they all lay down and quietly crawled towards the main building.
tr: All together, trying to make no noise, they approached the farmhouse garden.
es: By mutual agreement, they crawled in utmost silence to the garden of the house.

en: At the gate they paused, half frightened to go on but Clover led the way in.
vi: They hesitated slightly when crawling to the gate, but Fat Lady had already moved to the front.
tr: When they arrived in front of the garden gate, they hesitated in fear, but with Clover leading the way, they tiptoed inside and headed towards the house.
es: Upon reaching the entrance, they stopped, half scared, but Clover advanced resolutely and the others followed her.

en: They tiptoed up to the house, and such animals as were tall enough peered in at the dining-room window.
vi: As they approached the building, they tiptoed and stood up, those tall enough could see through the window.
tr: The animals tall enough peeked inside through the dining room window.
es: They tiptoed to the house, and the taller animals peered through the dining room window.

en: There, round the long table, sat half a dozen farmers and half a dozen of the more eminent pigs, Napoleon himself occupying the seat of honour at the head of the table.
vi: Inside, six landowners and the six most outstanding pigs were sitting around a long table. Napoleon sat right at the head of the table, the most prestigious spot.
tr: Around the long table, six farmers and six leading pigs were seated. Napoleon had taken the head of the table, seated in the place of honor.
es: There, around a long table, sat half a dozen farmers and half a dozen of the most eminent pigs, with Napoleon occupying the place of honor at the head.

en: The pigs appeared completely at ease in their chairs.
vi: It seemed that the pigs had long been accustomed to sitting on chairs.
tr: The pigs did not appear uncomfortable in their chairs at all.
es: The pigs seemed to be completely at ease in the chairs.

en: The company had been enjoying a game of cards but had broken off for the moment, evidently in order to drink a toast.
vi: They had been playing cards, but at that moment had stopped, probably to raise their glasses and toast each other.
tr: They had paused their card game and were raising their glasses in a toast.
es: The group was playing a card game, but they had paused for a moment, undoubtedly to make a toast.

en: A large jug was circulating, and the mugs were being refilled with beer.
vi: A rather large pitcher was being passed around, and all the glasses were filled with beer.
tr: A large pitcher was being passed around, filling glasses with beer.
es: A large jug was passing from hand to hand and the glasses were being filled with beer over and over again.

en: No one noticed the wondering faces of the animals that gazed in at the window.
vi: No one paid attention to the animals curiously peeking through the window.
tr: None of them had noticed the astonished faces of the animals peeking in through the window.
es: A large jug was passing from hand to hand and the glasses were being filled with beer over and over again.

en: mr Pilkington, of Foxwood, had stood up, his mug in his hand.
vi: Mr. Pilkington, from Foxwood Farm, stood up with a beer glass in his hand.
tr: Mr. Pilkington, the owner of Foxwood Farm, stood up with his glass in hand.
es: Mr. Pilkington, of Foxwood, stood up with a glass in his hand.

en: In a moment, he said, he would ask the present company to drink a toast.
vi: He said that he would propose a toast shortly.
tr: He said that he would soon invite everyone to raise their glasses in a toast, but first, he felt it was his duty to say a few words.
es: In a moment, he explained, he was going to request a toast from those present.

en: But before doing so, there were a few words that he felt it incumbent upon him to say.
vi: But he asked to say a few words first.
tr: He said that he would soon invite everyone to raise their glasses in a toast, but first, he felt it was his duty to say a few words.
es: But first, he felt obliged to say a few words.

en: It was a source of great satisfaction to him, he said — and, he was sure, to all others present — to feel that a long period of mistrust and misunderstanding had now come to an end.
vi: "It is truly exhilarating," he said, "for him, as well as for everyone present here today, because the period of suspicion and misunderstanding has ended."
tr: The fact that a long period of distrust and disagreement had finally come to an end was a great source of happiness for him and undoubtedly for everyone present there.
es: “It was a source of great satisfaction for him,” he said, “and he was sure that for all the attendees, to see that a long period of distrust and disagreements was coming to an end.

en: There had been a time — not that he, or any of the present company, had shared such sentiments — but there had been a time when the respected proprietors of Animal Farm had been regarded, he would not say with hostility, but perhaps with a certain measure of misgiving, by their human neighbours.
vi: There was a time, of course, when he, like those present here today, did not want it to be so, but it is clear that there were times when those around looked at the esteemed owners of Animal Farm with an attitude that, while not hostile, was certainly lacking in goodwill.
tr: People from neighboring farms had approached the respectable owners of Animal Farm with suspicion, if not hostility, for a while; but he and those present had not even shared this suspicious approach of the people.
es: There was a time, not that he, or any of those present, shared such feelings, but there was a time when the respectable owners of 'Animal Farm' were considered, he wouldn’t say with hostility, but with a certain degree of suspicion by their human neighbors.

en: Unfortunate incidents had occurred, mistaken ideas had been current.
vi: Unfortunately, there were a few clashes, and some misconceptions were circulated.
tr: Unfortunate events had occurred, and some had fallen into wrong thoughts.
es: Unfortunate incidents occurred and misunderstandings were easy.

en: It had been felt that the existence of a farm owned and operated by pigs was somehow abnormal and was liable to have an unsettling effect in the neighbourhood.
vi: There was an opinion that a farm run by pigs and managed by pigs was an abnormal thing, and there was no doubt that this farm would have an undesirable influence on the surrounding farms.
tr: It was thought that a farm owned and managed by pigs was not at all ordinary, and it was feared that it might cause unease in the surrounding farms.
es: It was believed that the existence of a farm owned and governed by pigs was in some way abnormal and that it could have a disturbing effect on the neighborhood.

en: Too many farmers had assumed, without due enquiry, that on such a farm a spirit of licence and indiscipline would prevail.
vi: Many landowners, quite a few, without any investigation, hastily concluded that there would be many excessive and undisciplined behaviors here.
tr: Many farmers, without conducting the slightest investigation, had assumed that such a farm would be rife with lawlessness and disorder.
es: Too many farmers assumed, without proper information, that a spirit of debauchery and indiscipline prevailed on that farm.

en: They had been nervous about the effects upon their own animals, or even upon their human employees.
vi: They were worried about the influence of this farm not only on the animals but also on their hired workers.
tr: They had been uneasy, thinking that what was happening at Animal Farm could affect not only their own animals but also the people working on their farms.
es: They had been worried about the consequences this would bring to their own animals or even to their human employees.

en: But all such doubts were now dispelled.
vi: But all those doubts have ended.
tr: But all such doubts had now dissipated.
es: But all these doubts were now dispelled.

en: Today he and his friends had visited Animal Farm and inspected every inch of it with their own eyes, and what did they find?
vi: Today, he and his colleagues have been invited to visit the farm, they have examined it very carefully, and what did they find?
tr: Today, he and his friends had come there, toured around Animal Farm, and encountered not only the latest methods but also a discipline and order that should set an example for all farmers.
es: He and his friends had just visited 'Animal Farm' and inspected every inch with their own eyes. And what had they found?

en: Not only the most up-to-date methods, but a discipline and an orderliness which should be an example to all farmers everywhere.
vi: Not only the most modern technology but also the discipline and order of the farm are worthy of emulation by farms everywhere.
tr: Today, he and his friends had come there, toured around Animal Farm, and encountered not only the latest methods but also a discipline and order that should set an example for all farmers.
es: Not only the most modern methods, but a discipline and order that should serve as an example for farmers everywhere.

en: He believed that he was right in saying that the lower animals on Animal Farm did more work and received less food than any animals in the county.
vi: He believes it is not wrong to say that the lower animals here work more but receive smaller rations compared to other farms in the region.
tr: It would probably not be wrong to say that the lower animals at Animal Farm worked more and ate less than all the animals in the country.
es: He believed he was right in saying that the lower animals of 'Animal Farm' did more work and received less food than any animal in the county.

en: Indeed, he and his fellow-visitors today had observed many features which they intended to introduce on their own farms immediately.
vi: In short, he and his colleagues have seen many things here that should be immediately applied.
tr: Today, indeed, he and his friends had seen such things at Animal Farm that they were thinking of immediately implementing them on their own farms.
es: Indeed, he and his visiting colleagues observed many details that they planned to implement on their farms immediately.

en: He would end his remarks, he said, by emphasising once again the friendly feelings that subsisted, and ought to subsist, between Animal Farm and its neighbours.
vi: He said he wished for the friendship between Animal Farm and other farms to last forever.
tr: He wanted to end his words by once again emphasizing the feelings of friendship that existed and should continue between Animal Farm and its neighbors.
es: “I would like to conclude my speech,” he said, “by once again emphasizing the friendly sentiment that existed, and should exist, between 'Animal Farm' and its neighbors."

en: Between pigs and human beings there was not, and there need not be, any clash of interests whatever.
vi: The interests of pigs and humans do not and should not conflict with each other.
tr: There was not the slightest conflict of interest between the pigs and the humans, and he saw no reason for there to be.
es: There was, and should be, no clash of interests of any kind between the pigs and the human beings.

en: Their struggles and their difficulties were one.
vi: Both share common goals and common difficulties.
tr: Their efforts and the difficulties they encountered were the same.
es: Their efforts and their difficulties were identical.

en: Was not the labour problem the same everywhere?
vi: The issue of labor is the same everywhere, isn't it?
tr: Wasn't the labor problem the same everywhere?
es: Wasn't the labor problem the same everywhere?”

en: Here it became apparent that mr Pilkington was about to spring some carefully prepared witticism on the company, but for a moment he was too overcome by amusement to be able to utter it.
vi: At this point, it was clear that Pilkington intended to say a humorous remark he had prepared for a long time, but it was so funny that he couldn't utter it. After a moment of trying to suppress his emotions, Pilkington said the following sentence:
tr: Mr. Pilkington was about to make a clever joke that seemed to have been prepared in advance, but he had to stop his speech when he couldn't contain his laughter.
es: Here it seemed that Mr. Pilkington was about to tell some pre-prepared joke, but for a moment laughter overcame him, and he couldn't utter a word.

en: After much choking, during which his various chins turned purple, he managed to get it out: “If you have your lower animals to contend with,” he said, “we have our lower classes!”
vi: "If you have to deal with lower animals, then we, we also have to deal with lower classes."
tr: After laughing until his chubby cheeks turned purple, he delivered the joke: "If you have to deal with your lower-class animals," he said, "we have to deal with our lower-class humans!"
es: After a moment of choking during which his various chins turned red, he managed to explain: "While you have to deal with your lower animals," he said, "we have our lower classes!"

en: This BON MOT set the table in a roar; and mr Pilkington once again congratulated the pigs on the low rations, the long working hours, and the general absence of pampering which he had observed on Animal Farm.
vi: In response to that meaningful remark, there was laughter that seemed to shake the house, and Pilkington again congratulated the pigs on eating little, working hard, and the discipline and order of the farm.
tr: The joke drowned the table in laughter. Mr. Pilkington couldn't help but congratulate the pigs once again for keeping rations low at Animal Farm, ensuring work hours were longer than anywhere else, and not spoiling the animals by overwhelming them with abundance.
es: This occurrence made them burst into laughter; and Mr. Pilkington once again congratulated the pigs on the meager rations, the long working hours, and the lack of mollycoddling he observed at "Animal Farm."

en: And now, he said finally, he would ask the company to rise to their feet and make certain that their glasses were full.
vi: And now, Pilkington suggested everyone stand up and fill their glasses with beer.
tr: Finally, Mr. Pilkington, who invited everyone to stand up and fill their glasses, said, "Come on, gentlemen!"
es: "And now," he finally said, "I was going to ask those present to stand up and make sure their glasses were full."

en: “Gentlemen,” concluded mr Pilkington, “gentlemen, I give you a toast: To the prosperity of Animal Farm!”
vi: "Gentlemen!", Pilkington concluded his speech, "Gentlemen, please raise your glasses to toast the continued prosperity of Animal Farm."
tr: "Cheers! To the honor of Animal Farm!"
es: "Gentlemen," concluded Mr. Pilkington, "gentlemen, I propose a toast: To the prosperity of 'Animal Farm!'"

en: There was enthusiastic cheering and stamping of feet.
vi: The sound of applause, the sound of stomping feet thunderously.
tr: Everyone was shouting and stamping their feet with excitement.
es: There were enthusiastic cheers and a clattering of feet and hooves.

en: Napoleon was so gratified that he left his place and came round the table to clink his mug against mr Pilkington’s before emptying it.
vi: Napoleon enjoyed the speech so much that he clinked glasses with Pilkington before drinking.
tr: Napoleon was so delighted that he got up from his seat, walked around the table, clinked glasses with Mr. Pilkington, and then downed his beer in one gulp.
es: Napoleon was so pleased that he left his place and went around the table to clink his glass with Mr. Pilkington's before emptying it.

en: When the cheering had died down, Napoleon, who had remained on his feet, intimated that he too had a few words to say.
vi: When the applause had subsided, Napoleon, still standing, declared that he would also like to say a few words.
tr: When the shouting subsided, Napoleon, who was still standing, indicated that he had a few words to say.
es: When the cheering ended, Napoleon, who remained standing, hinted that he too had a few words to say.

en: Like all of Napoleon’s speeches, it was short and to the point.
vi: Napoleon always spoke briefly and got straight to the heart of the matter.
tr: As always, he spoke briefly and concisely.
es: As in all his speeches, Napoleon was brief and to the point.

en: He too, he said, was happy that the period of misunderstanding was at an end.
vi: Napoleon said that he was also very pleased to have cleared up all misunderstandings.
tr: He was also very happy because the period of disagreement had ended.
es: “He too,” he said, “was glad that the period of disagreements had come to an end.

en: For a long time there had been rumours — circulated, he had reason to think, by some malignant enemy — that there was something subversive and even revolutionary in the outlook of himself and his colleagues.
vi: Previously, there had been rumors, certainly propagated by hostile forces, suggesting that he and his associates were pursuing subversive ideas, if not revolutionary ones.
tr: For a long time, there had been rumors that his and his friends' attitudes and behaviors were destructive, moreover revolutionary. These rumors must have been spread by one of his ill-hearted enemies.
es: For a long time, there had been rumors spread —he had good reasons to believe by some malicious enemy— that there was something subversive and even revolutionary in his and his colleagues' views.

en: They had been credited with attempting to stir up rebellion among the animals on neighbouring farms.
vi: They were accused of intending to incite animals in other farms to revolt.
tr: It was said that they incited the animals on neighboring farms to revolt.
es: They were attributed the intention of fomenting rebellion among the animals of neighboring farms.

en: Nothing could be further from the truth!
vi: Slander, fabricated from start to finish!
tr: Such a lie had never been seen before, indeed!
es: Nothing could be further from the truth!

en: Their sole wish, now and in the past, was to live at peace and in normal business relations with their neighbours.
vi: Their sole desire, now as in the past, was to live in peace and have normal business relations with their neighbors.
tr: However, their only desire had always been to live in peace with their neighbors and to maintain business relations properly.
es: Their only desire, now and in the past, was to live in peace and maintain normal relations with their neighbors.

en: This farm which he had the honour to control, he added, was a co-operative enterprise.
vi: The farm that he had the honor of leading, Napoleon added, was a kind of cooperative.
tr: The farm he was proud to manage was a cooperative venture.
es: This farm that he had the honor to control,” he added, “was a cooperative enterprise.

en: The title-deeds, which were in his own possession, were owned by the pigs jointly.
vi: Everything under his management was the common property of all the pigs on the farm.
tr: The co-owners of the title deeds in his hand were the pigs.
es: The property titles, which were in his possession, belonged to all the pigs collectively.

en: He did not believe, he said, that any of the old suspicions still lingered, but certain changes had been made recently in the routine of the farm which should have the effect of promoting confidence still further.
vi: Napoleon said that he believed all doubts had been cleared and the recent changes had further increased mutual trust.
tr: Although he never believed that the old suspicions still persisted, he nevertheless saw the benefit in noting that some changes had recently been made to further increase the trust placed in the farm's operations.
es: "He did not believe," he said, "that there were still traces of the old suspicions, but certain changes had just been introduced into the farm's routine that would have the effect of fostering, even more, mutual trust."

en: Hitherto the animals on the farm had had a rather foolish custom of addressing one another as “Comrade.”
vi: Until now, the animals on the farm had an unpleasant habit of calling each other "Comrade".
tr: Until today, among the animals on the farm, there was a silly habit of calling each other "Comrade."
es: Until then, the animals on the farm had the somewhat silly habit of addressing each other as "comrade."

en: This was to be suppressed.
vi: This habit will be abolished.
tr: This habit would be put to an end.
es: That was going to be abolished.

en: There had also been a very strange custom, whose origin was unknown, of marching every Sunday morning past a boar’s skull which was nailed to a post in the garden.
vi: Another habit, whose origin is unknown, is the practice of marching in formation every morning around a pig's skull mounted on a post.
tr: Another strange habit, the origin of which they did not know, was their ceremonial march past the pig's head mounted on a stump in the garden every Sunday morning.
es: There was also another very strange custom, whose origin was unknown: parading every Sunday morning before the skull of a pig nailed to a post in the garden.

en: This, too, would be suppressed, and the skull had already been buried.
vi: This habit will also be abolished and the pig's head has already been buried.
tr: This habit would also be put to an end. They had already buried the pig's head in the ground.
es: That was also going to be abolished, and the skull had already been buried.

en: His visitors might have observed, too, the green flag which flew from the masthead.
vi: The guests must have had the opportunity to see the green flag flying.
tr: If the guests had looked carefully at the green flag waving on the pole, they must have noticed that the white hoof and horn had been removed from the flag.
es: Their visitors had also observed the green flag that waved at the top of the mast.

en: If so, they would perhaps have noted that the white hoof and horn with which it had previously been marked had now been removed.
vi: If indeed they have seen it, they must have noticed that the symbol of the white hoof and horn has also been removed.
tr: If the guests had looked carefully at the green flag waving on the pole, they must have noticed that the white hoof and horn had been removed from the flag.
es: In that case, they surely noticed that the hoof and the white horn that were previously marked on it had been removed.

en: It would be a plain green flag from now onwards.
vi: From now on, the flag will be pure green only.
tr: From now on, the flag would be plain green.
es: Henceforth, it would simply be a green flag.

en: He had only one criticism, he said, to make of mr Pilkington’s excellent and neighbourly speech.
vi: He said that he would like to make a few minor adjustments to Mr. Pilkington's extremely concise and well-intentioned speech.
tr: However, he wanted to make a small correction to Mr. Pilkington's extraordinary speech filled with feelings of friendship.
es: »I had to make only one criticism of Mr. Pilkington's magnificent and friendly speech.

en: mr Pilkington had referred throughout to “Animal Farm.”
vi: Throughout the speech, Mr. Pilkington referred to this farm as Animal Farm.
tr: Throughout his speech, Mr. Pilkington had referred to their farm as "Animal Farm."
es: Mr. Pilkington referred throughout to "Animal Farm".

en: He could not of course know — for he, Napoleon, was only now for the first time announcing it — that the name “Animal Farm” had been abolished.
vi: Mr. Pilkington, of course, could not have known, because today, for the first time, Napoleon announced the abolition of the name Animal Farm.
tr: There was no doubt that it was impossible for him to know that the name "Animal Farm" had been abolished, because he was announcing it there for the first time now.
es: He could not know, of course —because he, Napoleon, was going to announce it for the first time— that the name "Animal Farm" had been abolished.

en: Henceforward the farm was to be known as “The Manor Farm”— which, he believed, was its correct and original name.
vi: From now on, the farm will be known as Manor Farm, as it should be called since that was its original name.
tr: From now on, the farm would once again be known by its original name, "Manor Farm."
es: From that moment on, the farm was going to be known as "Manor Farm", which was its true and original name.

en: “Gentlemen,” concluded Napoleon, “I will give you the same toast as before, but in a different form.
vi: "Gentlemen!", Napoleon concluded, "I propose a toast, but with a slight modification.
tr: Napoleon, while finishing his words, said, "Gentlemen." "We will raise our glasses once more, but this time not in honor of Animal Farm!
es: "Gentlemen," concluded Napoleon, "I am going to propose the same toast as before, but in a different way."

en: Fill your glasses to the brim.
vi: Please fill your glasses first.
tr: Fill your glasses to the brim.
es: Fill your glasses to the brim.

en: Gentlemen, here is my toast: To the prosperity of The Manor Farm!”
vi: Let us toast to the continued prosperity of the Farm!"
tr: Come on, gentlemen: To the honor of Manor Farm!"
es: Gentlemen, here is my toast: To the prosperity of "Manor Farm!"

en: There was the same hearty cheering as before, and the mugs were emptied to the dregs.
vi: Applause rang out, and everyone raised their glasses.
tr: With a heartfelt enthusiasm, they shouted, "Cheers!"; the beers were finished in one gulp.
es: The same cordial cheering as before was repeated and the glasses were emptied in one gulp.

en: But as the animals outside gazed at the scene, it seemed to them that some strange thing was happening.
vi: But the animals standing outside felt like something strange was happening.
tr: However, while the animals outside were watching this scene, they sensed something strange.
es: But to the animals, who were observing the scene from outside, it seemed that something strange was happening.

en: What was it that had altered in the faces of the pigs?
vi: Why did the faces of the pigs look like that?
tr: There was something different about the faces of the pigs, but what was it?
es: What was it that had changed in the faces of the pigs?

en: Clover’s old dim eyes flitted from one face to another.
vi: Mrs. Fat's cloudy eyes looked from one to another.
tr: Clover's old dull eyes were wandering over the faces one by one.
es: The old and dim eyes of Clover quickly and alternately passed from one face to another.

en: Some of them had five chins, some had four, some had three.
vi: Some had five chins, some had four, and some had three.
tr: The jaws of some of the pigs had become fivefold, some fourfold, and some threefold.
es: Some had five chins, others had four, those had three.

en: But what was it that seemed to be melting and changing?
vi: Why did everything become so blurry and change so quickly?
tr: But what was the thing that was melting and changing?
es: But what was it that seemed to be fading and transforming?

en: Then, the applause having come to an end, the company took up their cards and continued the game that had been interrupted, and the animals crept silently away.
vi: The applause ended, the banquet returned to the unfinished card game, and the animals watching outside slowly crawled away.
tr: A little later, the shouting ceased, those at the table picked up their papers and resumed their interrupted game; the animals quietly moved away from there.
es: Then, after the applause ended, the attendees picked up the cards again and continued the interrupted game, while the animals walked away in silence.

en: But they had not gone twenty yards when they stopped short.
vi: But they had just crawled about twenty meters when all of them stopped.
tr: They had only moved about twenty or thirty meters away when they stopped in their tracks.
es: But they had not taken twenty steps when they stopped abruptly.

en: An uproar of voices was coming from the farmhouse.
vi: There was a loud shouting coming from the building.
tr: A commotion had erupted in the farmhouse.
es: A huge uproar of voices was coming from the house.

en: They rushed back and looked through the window again.
vi: They immediately turned back and continued looking through the window.
tr: They turned back and ran quickly to the house, peeking inside through the window.
es: They ran back and looked again through the window.

en: Yes, a violent quarrel was in progress.
vi: The argument was at its peak.
tr: A terrible fight had broken out in the house: shouting, banging on the table, suspicious stern looks, cursing and chaos...
es: Yes, a violent argument was unfolding: shouts, blows on the table, piercing and distrustful looks, furious denials.

en: There were shoutings, bangings on the table, sharp suspicious glances, furious denials.
vi: There were shouts, table banging, arguments, and suspicious glances.
tr: A terrible fight had broken out in the house: shouting, banging on the table, suspicious stern looks, cursing and chaos...
es: Yes, a violent argument was unfolding: shouts, blows on the table, piercing and distrustful looks, furious denials.

en: The source of the trouble appeared to be that Napoleon and mr Pilkington had each played an ace of spades simultaneously.
vi: The cause of the argument was probably because Napoleon and Pilkington both played the queen of spades at the same time.
tr: Apparently, the cause of the fight was that both Napoleon and Mr. Pilkington had drawn the ace of spades.
es: The origin of the conflict seemed to be that both Napoleon and Mr. Pilkington had simultaneously discovered an ace of spades each.

en: Twelve voices were shouting in anger, and they were all alike.
vi: Twelve angry mouths spoke at once, and only heaven could distinguish who was who.
tr: Inside, all twelve were shouting angrily, and all twelve looked alike.
es: Twelve voices were shouting in anger, and they were all alike.

en: No question, now, what had happened to the faces of the pigs.
vi: The animals no longer paid attention to the faces of the pigs inside.
tr: It was now clear what had happened to the faces of the pigs.
es: There was no doubt about the transformation that had taken place in the pigs' faces.

en: The creatures outside looked from pig to man, and from man to pig, and from pig to man again; but already it was impossible to say which was which.
vi: They looked at the pigs and then at the humans, looked at the humans and then at the pigs, and after a while, they gave up, unable to tell which was which.
tr: The animals outside looked from pig to man, and from man to pig, but it was impossible to say which was which.
es: The bewildered animals looked from pig to man, and from man to pig; and again from pig to man; but it was already impossible to say which was which.

en: November 1943-February 1944
vi: November 1943 - February 1944.
tr: November 1943 - February 1944
